OXFORD, Printed at the THEATER, M. DCC. XXIV.

DIV1.HEAD: Adjeci. ROBERT of GLOUCESTER's CHRONICLE.″

LG.L: ENGELOND Vide Camdeni Remaines concerning Brittaine, pag. 7. Ed. Lond. 1629. ys a wel god lond, ich wene of eche lond best,
Y set in þe ende of þe world, as al in þe West.
þe see goþ hym al a boute, he stont as an yle.
Here fon heo durre þe lasse doute, but hit be þorw gẏle
Of I. e. folc. fol of þe selue lond, as me haþ y seye wyle.
From Souþ to Norþ he ys long eiȝte hondred mẏle:
And Two Ar. foure hondred mẏle brod from Est to West to wende,
A mẏdde þo lond as yt be, and noȝt as by þe on ende.
Plente me may in Engelond of alle gode y se,
Bute folc yt for gulte oþer ȝeres þe worse be.
For Engelond ys ful ẏnow of fruyt and of tren,
Of wodes and of parkes, þat ioye yt ys to sen.
Of foules and of bestes of wylde and tame al so.
Of salt fysch and eche fresch, and fayre ryueres þer to.
Of welles swete and colde ynow, of lesen and of mede.
Of seluer or and of gold, of tyn and of lede.
Of stel, of yrn and of bras, of god corn gret won.
Of whyte and of wolle god, betere ne may be non.
Wateres he haþ eke gode y now, ac Deest in Ar. at″ be fore alle oþer þre
Out of the lond in to þe see, armes as þei be.
Ware by þe schippes mowe come fro þe se and wende,
And brynge on lond god y now, a boute in eche ende.
Seuerne and Temese, And Hum∣ber is the þrydde Ar. Homber ẏt is þe þridde.
And þenne is as wo seiþ þe pure lond a midde.
Homber bryngeþ by Norþ muche god and wyde,
Seuerne by West Deest Ar. Souþ,″ Temese by þe Est syde.
So þat of god y now, þat in oþer londes ys,
þer by comeþ to Engelond, þat no defaute nẏs.
Yles þer beþ monẏ on a boute Engelonde.
Ac þer beþ to fore alle oþere þre ich vnderstonde:
The yle of Man þat me clepuþ, by twene vs and Yrlonde:
þe grete yle of Orcades Ar. Orkeneye bi ȝonde Scotlonde.
þe þridde ys, toward Normandye, þe yle of Wyȝt bẏ Souþe.
þre þe beste ẏles þese beþ and Most of name couþe Ar. mest couþe.
þe firste lordes and maystres, þat in Engelond were,
þese chef townes heo lette in Engolonde rere.
London and Euerwik, Lyncolne and Leycestre;
Colchestre and Canterburẏ, Bristow and Wircestre.
Chichestre and Grauntebrigge, and þanne Cirencestre;
Dorchestre and Wyncestre, and seþþe Gloucestre.
And oþer grete tounes, þat þo were in Walis.
þis was þo in Engolond þat Bru∣tones Ar. Brytones were y wys.
Engolond haþ i be y nome and Y wonne pro i worred in Ar. i worred y lome.
First þoru grete lordes þe emperoures of Rome,
þat foȝte and wonne Engelond, and þat lond nome.
Seþþe þoru Pictes Ar. Picardes and Scottes, þat to Engelond come,
þat worrede and destruiode, ac al clene ne wonne it noȝt.
Seþþe þoru Englische and Saxones, þat hider were y brouȝt
þoru Brutones forto helpe hem, and seþþe hem ouercome
þe Brytones, þat hem hyder brouȝte, & þat lond hem bi nome.
Seþþe haþ Engelond y be Y wer∣red and y nome Ar. y werred y lome
Of þe folc of Denemark, þat were nought welcome Ar. þat beþ noȝt ȝet wel y some,
þat ofte wonne Engelond, and hulde yt bẏ maystrie.
þe fyfte tyme won Engelond þo folc of Normandie,
þat a mong vs woneþ ȝet, and schulleþ euer mo:
We schul here aftur in þis boke telle of al this wo.
Brytones were þe firste folc þat to Engelond come.
Foure kynges heo maden þo in þis kyndome.
þe kyng of West sex, & of Kent, & of Norþomber þe þridde,
And þe kyng of þe March, þat was here amidde.
þe Saxones and þe Englische þo heo hadden al an honde,
Fyue and þritti schiren heo maden in Engelonde.
Souþsex and Soþerei, Kent and Estsex,
Barkschire and Hamptschire, and þenne Myddelsex,
Dorsete and Wiltschire, and Somersete al so.
Deneschire and Cornewayle, and Gloucestre þer to.
Schropschire, and of Wircestre, and of Herford.
Chestre schire and Sic. Warwil, Derbẏ and Stafford.
Lyncolne ant Hontyndone, and of Bedeford.
Bockyngham and Norþamptoun; and of L. Oxenford. Oxenfoþ.
Norþfolc and Soþfolc, and Grauntebrigge al so.
Hertfort & Leycestre, and Nothyngam þer to.
Euerwik and Cardoel, and Norþomburlonde.
þese schires wiþ oute Walis beþ alle in Engolonde.
Seuentene bischopriches in Engelond beþ also.
Cardoil, and Duram, and Euerwik þer to.
Of Elẏ and of Cauntarbury, of Norþwiche, of Rouchestre,
Of London, of Salusbury, of Chichestre, of Wynchestre,
Of Lyncolne, and of Chestre, and of Wircestre,
Of Herford, and of Baþe, and al so of Excestre.
þenne þer beþ in Walis þre wiþ oute more,
Seynt Dauid, and Landaþ, and seþþe Bangore.
Of Euerwik and Canterbury beþ erchbischopes two.
Duram beþ and Cardoil vnder Euerwik y do.
And alle þe oþer of Engolond, and al so of Walis,
Under þe erchbischop beþ of Canterbury y wis.
þe Saxones in heore power þo heo were so riue,
Sene kynges heo maden in Engelonde, and seþen bute fyue.
þe kyng of Norþomberlond, and of Est Angle al so;
Of Kent, and of West Sex, and of þe March þer to.
þe kyng of þe March þilke tyme hadde wel þe beste,
Muche del of Engolond, þe on half al bi Weste.
Wircestre schire, and Warwik, and also of Gloucestre,
þat ys nez al þe bischop riche of Wircestre.
He hadde eke þer to Chesturschire, and Derbyschire also,
And Stafford schire, þat beþ alle in on bischopriche y do,
In þe bischop riche of Chestre; and ȝet he hadde þer to
Schropschire som, and half Warwik schire al so.
þis kyng hadde eke Herfortschire, þat on bischopriche is;
Ac Schropschire naþ haluendel to þilke bischopriche i wis.
And som of Gloucestre schire, and of Warwik schire al so.
ȝet hadde þe kyng of þe March wel more lond þer to,
Northamptschire, & Bokyngham, and þe schire of Oxenfort;
Leycetre, and Lyncolne, and þe schire of Hertfort;
þat is al on bischopriche, þat of Lyncolne ys,
þat wule was at Dorchestre bi syde Oxenfort iwis.
ȝet hadde þe kyng of þe March Notyngham schire þer to,
In þe bischop riche of Euerwik, ac þo nas hit noȝt so.
And al Walis ȝet þer to, þat a gret lond ys:
Al þis was þenne y cleped the March of Walis.
For þat lond þat bi twene Homber & the water of Temese y wis
Ich wene in þe bischop riche of Lyncolne ys.
And þe bischop riche of Lyncolne, and bi West al þat lond,
þe kyng som tyme of þe March hadde al in hys hond.
þe kyng of West sex hadde þo al Wilt schire y wys,
And Dorsete and Barkschire, þat o bischopriche is.
þe bischopriche of Salesbury, & al Souþsex, he hadde also,
þe welde & al þe bischopriche of Chichestre þer to.
And Souþampschire & Soþereẏ, þat on bischop riche ys.
þe bischopriche of Wynchestre, þat ȝet ys þere y wys.
And Somersete, þat to Welles þike tyme drow,
And now ys þe bischop riche of Baþe, ȝe wyteþ wel y now.
Seþþe hadde þe kyng of West sex al Denene schire ẏ wys,
And Cornewayle, þat in þe bischopriche of Exetre ys.
þe kyng of Kent was þo kyng of al þo lond of Kent,
þer were two bischopes, & ȝet nys it noȝt y went.
þe bischopriche of Canterbury, þat of Engelond ys hext,
And þe bischopriche of Roucestre, þat in the West syde is next,
þe kyng of Est Angle kyng was of Northfolc,
þe bischopriche of Northwych, and al so of Soþfolc.
And of þe bischopriche of Ely, þat þe yle of Ely ys,
And of al Cambrugge schire, þat þerto falleþ y wys.
þe kyng of Northumburlonde kyng was ich vnderstonde
Of al þo lond bi ȝonde Homber anon in to Scotlonde.
þese fyue kynges were þo, ac bute on now þer nẏs.
For þe kyng of West sex al þe oþer wan y wys,
And was seþþe al one kyng, as oure kyng now ys.
Here afturward in þis bok me schal here al þis.
In Vide Camden's Remaines, p. 8. þe contre of Canterbury mest plente of fysche ys.
And mest Chalke at Saresbu∣ry, & wild bestes y wys Ar. chase a boute Salesburi of wylde bestes y wys.
At London schippes mest, & wyn at Wyncestre.
At Herford schep & orf, & fruyt at Wircestre.
Sope a boute Couyntre, yrn at Gloucestre.
Metel, And pro as in Ar. as led & tyn, in þe contre of Excestre.
Euerwik of fairest wode, Lyncolne of fayrest men,
Grantebrugge and Hontyndone mest plente of dup fen.
Elẏ of fairest Plate Ar. place, of fairest siȝte Roucestre.
Euene aȝeyn Fraunce stonde þe contre of Chichestre,
Norwiche aȝeyn Denemarc, Chestre aȝeyn Yrlond,
Duram aȝeyn Norwei, as ich vnderstonde.
þre wondres þer beþ in Engolond, none more y not.
þat water of Baþe ys þat on, þat euer ys yliche hot.
Desunt in Ar. And fersch & euere springe, ne be chele no so gret.
Suche baþes þer beþ fele in þe clos & in þe stret.″
Upon þe pleyn of Salesbury þat oþer wonder ys,
þat Stonhenge Ar. Stonhyngel ys y clepud, no more wonder nys.
þe stones stondeþ þer so grete, no more ne mowe be,
Euene vp ryȝt & swyþe hye, þat wonder it is to se:
And oþer liggeþ hye aboue, þat a mon may be of a ferd,
þat vche mon wondre maẏ how heo were first a rered.
For noþer gyn, ny monne's strengþe, yt þynkeþ, ne myȝte yt do.
Telle me schal here afturward of þis wondres boþe two,
And how heo were first y mad. þe þridde wonder ys
Up þe hul of þe pek. Norþ wynd þere y wys
Out of the erþe ofte comeþ, of holes as yt were,
And bloweþ vp of þilke holes, so þat yt wolde a rere
And bere vp grete cloþes, ȝef heo were þer ney,
And blowe hem here and þere vpon þe lofte on heẏ.

Ac foure mest of alle þer beþ ich vnderstonde,
þat þe olde kynges mad, wer þoru me may wende
From þe on ende of Engelond uorþ to þe oþer ende.

From þe Souþ tilleþ in to þe Norþ Erming∣street vulgo. At in Ar. lyne pro Eningestret habemus. Sic enim illic: Lẏne me clepeth eke thulke wey, he goth thorgh Glou∣ceter, And thorgh Circetre euene also, and thorgh Wynchestre. Verum his de viis videsis trac∣tatum egregium, (ab Amico doctissimo Rogero Galeo scri∣ptum, & à nobis in VI. Volu∣mine Itinerarii Lelandi edi∣tum,) cui titulus, "An Essay towards the Recovery of the Courses of the four great Roman ways," ubi (p. 106.) frag∣mentum Roberti nostri de iis∣dem, ad fidem Codicis Digbei∣ani, exstat. Eningestret;
And from þe Est in to þe West Ikenildestrete.
From Douere in to Chestre tilleþ Watlingestrete,
From Souþ Est in to Norþ West, and þat ys som del grete.
þe ferþe is mest of alle, þat tilleþ from Tottenais,
From þe on ende Cornewayle anon to Catenays,
Fro þe Norþ Est in to Souþ West in to Engelonde's ende:
Fosse me clepuþ þike wey, þat by mony god toun doþ wende,
So clene A lond Ar. lond ys Engolond, and so pur with outen ore,
þat þe fairest men of þe world þer inne beþ y bore.
So clene, so whyte, so fayr of hew, among Ar. So clene, and fiar, & purwyt, among oþer men heo beþ,
þat me knoweþ hem in eche lond bi syȝte, where me hem seþ.
So clene al so is þat lond, & monne's blod so pur,
þat þe gret vnel comeþ not þer, þat me clepuþ þo Wilde fuyr Ar. holy fur,
þat Deest Ar. for″ freteþ monnes lymes, ryȝt as heo were For brende Ar. brende.
Ac men of France in þilke vnel Ofte me sykþ amende Ar. me syþ sone a mende,
ȝef heo ben brouȝt in to Engolond: war þorw me may wyte,
þat Engelond ys lond best, as yt is y write.
FRO þe by gynnyng of þe world, to þe tyme þat now is,
Sene ages þer habbeþ y be, as sene tyme y wys.
þe firste age & tyme was from oure firste fader Adam
To Noe, & seþþe þo oþer from Noe to Abraham.
þe þridde was from Habraham forte Moyses com,
þe ferthe fro Moyses to Dauid kyndom.
þe fyfþe was from Dauid to þe transmigracion
Of Babilonye, & þe sixþe to þe incarnacion,
þat is, forte God was y bore. þe sene was & ys
From oure Lorde's burþe time to þe worlde's ende y wys.
After þat Adam maked was his ofspryng wax wyde, At on eynde of þe worlde hit gan in þe Est syde Ar. þo Adam was first y mad, & hys of spryng wex wyde,
Heo by gonne at þe on ende of þe world, al in þe Est syde.
Seþþe it wex wyde a boute, fro lond to londe,
So þat in þe þridde age it wes er it come to Engelonde.
For in þe tyme bi twene Abraham & Moyses it was,
þat men come to Engolond. ich wol telle ȝou þat cas.
A Batayle þer was while in þe contre of Rome,
þe meste þat euer was, as me haþ herd y lome:
þe bataile of Troie, þat laste fele ȝer.
Mony was þe gode body, þat y slawe was þer.
For þer nas knyȝt in monylonde, ny stalewarde man,
þat in þe o syde þer was; & al for a Womman Ar. wommon,
þat Elyne was y clepud, þis bataile first bi gan.
An hey mon þer was by fore, þat me clepude Dardan.
Of hym com þe gode Bruyt, þat was þe firste man
þat lord was in Engelond, as y ȝou telle can.
Dardan bi get Troye, þat god mon was & wys.
Troie bi get Priamus, & al so Anchis.
þese were in þis batail of mest myȝt and mayn.
Anchis bi get Eneas, and Eneas Ascayn.
Ascayn bi get Silui, of whom þe Brut com.
For Eneas aftur þe bataile Ascayn ys sone nom,
And Silui Ascaine's sone, & oþer þat þer were,
In to þe lond of Lumbardy wende, & wonede forþ þere.
þo Silui hadde bi gete a child, fayn he wolde y wyte,
What mon þat child schulde be, þat he hadde y gete.
A clerk þoru enchantement hym bi gan to telle,
þat þat childe sholde furst Ar. þat þe schulde first fader and moder quelle:
And seþþe he schulde monẏ lond ouer passe and wende,
And mony bataile ouer come, and seþþe, at þe ende,
To a noble lond he scholde come, & þere al lord be,
And kynges come of hys blod, & þat me schulde se.

þre þousend yer and foure skor fram þe worlde's gẏnnynge Was, byfore þat Eneas hys tem to Itaille þus gan brynge. þo þis clerk hadde y sed al hys enchaun∣terye, Siluius let hym sle. litel was þat maistrye. Ar. þat Eneas bi gan hys of spryng of Lumbardie first brynge
þre þousant & sixe & tuenti ȝer fro þo worlde's bi gynnynge.
þo þe clerk hadde y seid hys enchaunterye,
þer fore Silui hym let sle. ac þat was lytel maistrie.
For hit com ner þe later, as he hadde y seyd.
For In trauail as he was bore, his moder was þo deed Ar. è regione vero (in margine) manu recentiori, his mother dyed in childe bede. in trauayl of hys beryng hys moder was first ded.
þo þis child was y bore, me lette hym clepe Brut Ar. Bruyt.
First lord he was in Engolond, of wham me spekeþ ȝet.
þe child wex & wel þrof, as þe clerk seyde er.
Seþþe þo yt hadde þe elde of fyftene ȝer,
As he wolde schete an hert, al a ȝeyn hys wille
To deþe he schet ys owne fader, þat he lay þer stille.
Hit hym for pouȝte sore y now, ac noþeles ȝet he was
Out of þat lond ydriue for þat deolful cas.
In to þe lond of Grece he wende, And þenne fond he þere Ar. & þo wonede he þere
Of þe kynde of Priamus mony men, þat þor were,
þat wer þer of hys nexte blode, þat were þer in seruage.
Here elderne þer by fore were y nome in ostage
Fram þe bataile of Troie, in wreche as it were,
For þe grete slauȝt and wo, þat here kynde dude þere.
þo þat Brut Ar. þe Bruyt among hem com, to such prowes he drow,
þat Al his kyn, þat wisten hit, þer of had ioye y now Ar. al þe kyn, þat hym say, hadde of him joye ynow.
So þat at þe laste, þo he Manne's stat Ar. in stat was,
And þem þouȝte, þat ys pere in þe world nas,
þe folc of þat ilke blode aboutein hym drowe faste,
þat he scholde ys owne kynde of þat seruage caste.

Hy come al a bouten hym, & whanne hem alle he sey, Hẏm þoughte he hadde power ynow of noble folk & hey. He gaderede hem alle to gedere faste, a fayr oste þer was Ar. Heo comen alle a bouten hym, so þat þe Brut y sey,
þat heo were of gret power, & noble folc & hey, 3 Yut Ar.
Heo ȝarkeden hem to gedere, þat a fair ost yt was.
To þe kyng of Grece he sende, þat hatte Pandras,
þat heo scholde so noble folc, þat of so gret blod come,
Out of seruage lete, and out of þraldome,
Oþer hym ne sholde nought wondry, þough hy, for hure ryht, Wiþ hure bodies make hem fre dude þer to hure myght Ar. Or hym ne schulde not wondrẏ, þaẏ heo dude here myȝt
With here bodies, þat aȝte be so free, for to wynne her ryȝt.
þo kynge hadde in hys þoȝt gret Skorne Ar. bysmar of þis kyng.
He Or∣deyned Ar. ȝarkede is ost anon, to grounde hem to bryng. Bellum.
þis Brut a ȝeyn hym with ys ost wel wyssyche drowe.
Hy Ar. Heo smyton þer a batayle hard and strong ynow.
þe prowes þat þe Brute dude no tonge no telle ne maẏ,
Mony was þe gode body þat hym self slou þat daẏ.
What halt yt longe to telle? Hys fon he ouercom,
And Pandras, þe stronge kyng, as Pri∣soner Ar. pryson he nom. Capcio regis.
þis kyng þo he was y nome, here wille dude anon.
þo he non oþer bote y sey, he yaff hem hure fredom Ar. And broȝte hem out of þraldom, þo he say non oþer won.
He by gan to loue Brut so muche, for ys faire cheiance,
þat he wyllede, mest of alle þynge, to hym enlyance.
"Brut," he seyde, "þou art now þe beste body þat ys.
"For þe noble kyn, of wom þou art, & for þi prowes y wis,
"Ych obligi me to þe, and my kyndom al so.
"A doȝter ich haue of gret prys, & noble & god al so,
"Y ȝeue here þe to þi wyf, &, ȝef þou wolt by leue here,
"þe þridde del Of my Ar. my kyndom y ȝeue þe to be my fere.
"And ȝef þou nylt not here be, ac wolt ȝet fonde more,
"Gold & seluer ich wol þe ȝeue, & y now of eche store:

Kymbelyn, kyng of Bru∣taẏne, sones hadde tweẏe Ar. Kynbel, oure kyng of þis lond, sones hadde twei,
Guyder and Aruirag, noblemen beye.
Guyder aftur ys fader kyng was of þis lond,
And Claudius emperour aftur Gay ich vnderstonde.
Y mad he was emperour sixti ȝer, ich wene,
Aftur þat God was y bore, and a bouten an eiȝtetene
Aftur oure lorde's deþ. a sene hundred ȝer.
And euene eiȝte and nyenti Rome was y mad er.
GWIDER, our kyng of þis lond, ys truage at huld sone,
That his auncetres to Rome were woned to done Ar. To Rome þat ys eldore were y wond to done.
Claudius þe emperour þer of hym gan bi se. Claudius venit An∣gliam.
þe ferþe ȝer þat he hadde emperour y be
Mid gret ost he wende here to þis londe,
In the contreie of Southamtone Ar. A boute Souþhamto he a ryuede ich vnderstonde.
þo kyng Guyder vnder ȝet, þat heo a riuede þere,
Hym þouȝte lonȝ mid ys Power pro ost in Ar. ost er he at hem were.
Hii Ar. Heo mette hem to gedere With gret power ynough Ar. mid power ynoȝ.
Muche folk On aither side to grounde me faste slough Ar. in eyþe half to gronde me slog. Bellum.
þe kyng Guyder more folk Slough with his honde Ar. slowe ys owne honde,
þan muche del of ys Folk pro ost in Ar. ost, as ich vnderstonde.
The Romaynes, Ar. þis Romaynes were for noȝt ouercome atte laste,
So that themperour Ar. þat þe emperour with ys ost bi gan to fle faste.
A cheuenteyn þer was with hym, Lellius Haym Ar. & Lellius Hamon∣dus in marg. Haym was ys name.
He sey, þat His partye was neygh y brought to shame Ar. heore partye wroȝt was ney to schame.
He by þouȝte hym of felonye, and lette hym arme þere
Mid armes of Brytones, as he of þis lond were.
He sywede myd þe Brytones vp þe Romaynes so faste,

þat vr Kyng Hym louede wel, & his herte to hym caste. He spake Brutone, for he was with osta∣ges at Rome byfore Of this londe a queynted, and hadde hit nought y lore. He was euere oure kyng nexte Ar. hym louede, & ys herte al vp hym caste. Haym in∣terfecit re∣gem per fraudem.
He spek Englisch, for he was at Rome ynorisched bi fore
Myd ostage of þis lond, me louede hym þe bet þer fore.
He was euer ur kyng nex, and atte last he drow
Hys swerd, Er me were y war, and oure kyng a slough Ar. ar he were y war, & oure kyng so slow.
þer was tricheri y now. for nomon ne may bet do
Gyle To a nothur, than he that a man trusteth most to Ar. an oþer, þan þilke þat he trusteþ mest to.
To hys felawes he Yede anon, Ar. wende anon, & bad hem hardi be;
So þat þe Brytones were In poynt forto Ar. vp þe poynt to″ fle.
Aruirag, oure kynge's broþer, wende forþ anon þere,
And dude on þe kynge's armes, hym self as yt were.
And lepte on ys stede, and siwede and sloȝ fast ys fon,
The Brutones wende hit were hure kyng, & siwede hym echon Ar. And þe Brutones with hym, for heo wende, þat it were þe kyng echon.
Heo were alle þo so Wel y hardied, Ar. harde, and þat folk slowe so faste,
þat þe emperour bi gan to fle mid ys folk at the laste
To his shipes in to the see with wrechede ynough. The luther Haym with othur folk to ward a wode hem drough Ar. To schippes, & into þe see with wrechede hed y now.
Ac þe luþur Haym with ys folk toward þe wode hym drowe.
Aruirag hym sywede, and Euere to grounde slough. And atte laste Ar. to grounde euer slowȝ.
Atte laste ys tricherie wel lutel he By lough Ar. by lowȝ.
He ouer tok hym at an hauene & sloȝ hym ryȝt þere. Hamptone.
Lutel harm thei tricherus Alle so y serued Ar. so alle y serued were.
þe hauene þer he was y slawe, aftur Haym ywis, Haymtone was Ar. Haym ys name y wẏs,
Hamptone was y clepud, as he ȝet y clepud ys.
Southamtone hit is eke y clu∣ped, Ar. For Souþhamptone he ys y clepud, and worþ euermo.
In þis maner þe Britones þis lond Kepte tho Ar. wiste þo.
Claudius þe emperour nolde not ȝet bi leue.
Eft sone he Com with his ost in to the lond weue Ar. gan with ys ost into þis lond weue.
Aruirag at Wynchestre with ys men was echon.
With ys power þe emperour Bysette hem echon [l. anon.] Aruiragus araiede hẏm, and ordeynede his route, Wende forth to yeue hem bataille that were with oute. He com outward Ar. bisegede hym anon.
Aruirag greyþede hym and ys folk a boute,
And wendeþ forþ to ȝeue hym batail with oute.
þo he com out ward with ys folk, þe emperour with stod,
And dredde of hys hardynesse, & þouȝte yt was not god,
To do hys lyf In auenture, and his men∣nes also Ar. an auntre, and ys men al so.
He þougte te speke of a cord, ȝef it myȝte be y do.
To þke kyng he sende word, þat he schulde hym By se Ar. be se
And make a forme of a cord, as yt myȝte best be.
For wen heo hadde al y foȝte, & here lyf In auenture Ar. an auntre y do,
And here folk slawe on eyþer syde, & perauntre hem self also,
Al for a lutel couetyse The by ẏete were thanne lẏte Ar. þe bi ȝete war þanne lute,
Beter yt were To acordy Ar. a cordy, and bi leue heore Pruyte Ar. prude.
For he was so god A knyght Ar. knyȝt, and also so noble kyng,
He Praide hym for to Ar. At beod rectè se habet. idem nempe est atque offered. beod for to ȝeue hym ys doȝter in spousyng,
þe nobleste damesel þat was in eny londe,
And to spouse þe emperoure's Douȝhtur nere to hẏm no shonde, For thy that he bere Ar. doȝter yt ner hym no schonde,

Ea conditione (ait) ut imperio Romano subditus es∣set. Sic enim Galfridus Mon. Mandabat igitur ei [Arvi∣rago] concordiam, daturum∣que promittebat sese filiam suam, si tantummodo reg∣num Britanniae sub Roma∣na potestate recognosceret. For wat he bere ys truage, as ryȝt Was Ar. were, to Rome
As The pro alle in Ar. alle oþer kynges dude, and ys eldren y lome.
þe kyng for ys heye herte anon yt with seide:
Ac noþeles ys conseil hym gan þer to rede,
And saide, þat it was to hym gret prow and honour,
To be in such mariage alied to þe emperour,
þo Heighest Ar. hexte prince of þe world, and þo maide so noble al so,
And þat it Were Ar. nere hym no schame, ys truage to do
To þe noble stude of Rome, wan oþer kynges echone
Hit dude þorȝ al þe world, Ac pro & in Ar. & in so noble forme none.
þe kyng, þei he hawteyn were, ches þe best won,
And dude after his consail, Ar. And vnder stod ys conseil, so þat heo were at on, Sponsacio filiae Clau∣dii.
þat he bere ys truage, as oþer dude, to Rome,
And þat he þe emperoure's doȝter in spoushed þus nome.
þat maide was to lond y broȝt of so noble gentrise,
Fairor womman nas þo non, y hote heo was Gewise.
At a lute toun, þat was þo bi Est Walis,
þat vp Seuerne stod, y spoused Hii Ar. heo were y wys.
þe kyng louede ys wyf a non so purliche & so faste,

þat al His herte toward hure al outrẏght he caste Ar. ys herte Ontliche forsitan malint nonnulli, ut only denotet. At outliche lectio verissima, idem scilicet quod utterly valens. Id quod etiam è Galfr. Mon. liquet. Sic enim ille: Erat autem nomen puellae Genui∣sa, er atque tantae pulcritu∣dinis, ut aspicientes in ad∣mirationem deduceret. Et ut maritali lege copulata fuit, tanto fervore amoris succendit regem, ita ut ipsam solam cunctis rebus praeferret. Et tamen ont∣liche ferri potest, ea, qua dixi, significatione, pro more An∣glo-Saxonum, qui vocum ad unam eandem{que} rem signifi∣candam repetitionem amant. outliche on hire one he caste.
For honour of þe mariage, þe emperour and he Vocacio Glouce∣striae.
Thar (omisso rerde, quod tamen praefigi debet) that he ẏ spoused was, a noble cite, Ar. Rerde, as heo y spoused was, a swyþe fair cite,
And aftur þe emperoure's name, þat Claudius was,
Heo lette þe cite clepe Claucestre for þis cas.
And þe emperour bi ȝet seþþe in þilke toun bi cas
A sone, þat me clepede Glow, þat gret mon seþþe was,
That duk was aftur of the toun, and clepede hit y wis Aftur his name Glowcestre, as hit nough cleped is Ar. An hey duk of al þat stude, he clepede þat toun y wys
Aftur ys name Gloucestre, as he ȝut y clepud ys.
A boute four & twenti ȝer, as þis clerkes vnderstode,
Aftur þat oure Lord Crist do was on the roode Ar. lord was y do on þe rode.
Gloucestre þorȝ þe emperour first þus a rerd was,
And Souþhampton þer bi fore, ȝe habbeþ y herd þat cas.
Sente Peter þer bi fore so muche Erasit quispiam in Ar. so″ it were
Pope was Of Rome, Cristendom Ar. omisso first. at Rome first, Cristendom to lere,
And sende Sent Mark þe euangelist in to Egypt for to preche
þe gospel þat he hadde y mad, and Cristendom to teche.
Sent Poul eke þilke tyme to Cristendom wende,
Sent Denys, & monẏ oþer, as vr Lord a boute hem L. sende cum Ar. semde.
Sent Peter fyue and twenti ȝer Pope bi leuede so
Fort hit Ar. Forto yt was þe laste ȝer of þe emperour Nero.
þo þe emperour in þis lond hadde is wille i do y nowȝ,

He lette þe kyng Totam Britanniae potestatem, sua ab∣sentia, Arvirago concessisse Claudium, hîc indicat auctor, illis verbis fultus, quae Gal∣fridus protulit, viz. Aedi∣ficata igitur urbe, ac paci∣ficata insula, rediit Claudius Romam, regnumque pro∣vincialium insularum Arvi∣rago permisit. al y worþe, & to Rome a ȝeyn drowȝ,
þe kyng dyȝte þo þis lond nobliche with alle:
And pro he in Ar. He lette bulde vp grete townes, þat were ney a doun falle.
þo Claudius þe emperour to ys ende was y do,
Aftur hym was emperour þe luþur mon Nero, Nero.
Trittene Ar. þrottene ȝer and an half, and þat was longe y now,

And Seynt Peter & Seynt Poule in hys Repone laste ex Ar. Nec est cur pu∣tes, lafte recte posse retineri, ut sententia sit, eo anno, quo fuerit mortuus relictus. SS. Petrum atque Paulum occi∣disse. lafte ȝer he slowȝ.
He bi com Sone afterward puẏr Ar. sone þer aftur pur gydi and wod: Passio Pe∣tri & Pau∣li.
And hough he was in his moder wombe he thoughte & vnderstood Ar. For he was in ys moder wembe, as he vnderstod.
He þoȝte he wolde wyte, & se how Mury Ar. fair þe chaumbre were,
What that he was ynne y kenned, er Ar. War inne he was & kenede, ar ys moder hym bere.
Ys moder he let quelle a non, forto se with inne
How fair þe inneward was, þat he kenede inne.
þo ys moder y slaw was, me blamede hym þer fore,
And seyde, þat heo boȝte hym dere, er he were y bore.
"Ye, quath he, is hit strong, with childe to be bystonde? Bẏ the feẏ ich owe to my Godes, the sothe Ar. ȝe is hyt," quoþ he, "so strong, myd childe to be stonde?
"Bi þe fey, þat ich owe Mahone, þe soþe ich wol fonde.
Hys ficicianes he Clepede tho, and Ar. clepede, and swor ys oþ anon,
Bute heo maden hym with childe, he wolde hem sle echon.
Heo bi speke hem Bitwyne than, deth Ar. bi twene, and, þe deþ forto fle,
þei ȝeuen hym a koynte drench, with childe for to be.
Hys wombe bi gan to Grety, Ar. grete, & euer þe lenger þe more,
So Deest Ar. longe,″ þat hym þoȝte strong, hys wombe ok wel sore.
He clepede ys fiscicianes, And swor his oth anon, Bute hii delyuerede hym anon, hii sholde deye echon. Hii yef Ar. and swor grete a non,
Bute heo made hym bere child, he wolde hem honge echon.
Hii Ar. þe ȝeue hym an oþer drenche, to habbe child þer,
So þat atte laste a sory child he ber. Rana.
For tho hit al forth com, hit was a wel foul frogge. His fisiciens hadde y holde hym wel in the gogge. Yut this gidy wreche Ar. For it alles com forþ, yt was a foul frogge.
For gode me þinkeþ litel harm, þei yt hadde i be a dogge.
ȝet þis ȝredi wreche louede þis foule best,
As A woman doth Ar. wommon deþ hire child Alther thẏnge Ar. alle þing mest,
And Let arere (omis∣so hym) in Ar. let hym rere a noble court, with gret quoyntyse and gynne,
At þe on ende of Rome, to norische þe schrewe inne;
And clepude þe court Laterane, aftur þe frogge y wys,
For in þe langage of Rome, rane a frogge ys.
So ys þat stude y clepud now, & euer worþ for þat cas.
Feble was þe Godfader, aftur wam þe name was.
The ferste cherche me rerede there of al Cristendom. And of Seẏnt Johanes de Laterane thus the name com. Suthe the luthure Emperour Ar. þe firste chirche þat me lette in þo lond rere,
Seyn Jone's þe Lateran me rerede seþþe þere,
þat stond ȝet, & heued chirche þat of al Cristendom ys,
Ac a beter chef þer ys now, þan þe frogge was y wys.
Seþþe þe luþer emperour hadde in his herte joie,

To þenche On fair fuer, that brend the toun of Troẏe, When the grete toures brende & courtes day and nyght, Hym thoughte hit was a mury game to se such a syght. The wood wretche Ar. on fuyr, þat was in þe bataile of Troie, Combustio Romae.
þo me barnde grete townes & courtes day & nyȝt,
And þoȝte yt was mury joie, to se so fair alyȝt.
þe gydye wretche lette sette þe Cite Ar. toun of Rome on fuyre,
To habbe game of þe lyȝt, þe while yt myȝte dure.
þo wende forþ þe toun folk, as heo moste nede,
And nolde no more suffre þe schrewe among hem wede,
He sleigh for fere out of toun, and hym self slough, And for he Petur & Powel slough he hadde ven∣geance y nough Ar. And slowe þe schrewe in fyl deþ ynow,
And þus hym fel wreche of God for he þe apostle slowȝ.
VASPASIAN þe emperour aftur Nero com,
þat beter man was þan he, & Deest Ar. ne″ worrede noȝt Cristendom.
þe Giwes he worrede Stronge ynough Ar. y now, & broȝt hem Al to Ar. first to noȝt,
For as muche as þe luþer men oure Lord to deþ broȝt.
For he and Tytus ys sone of oure Lord vnderstode,
Fourti ȝer aftur þat he deide on þe rode,
Wonne the toun of Jerusalem, and fulde hit doun to grounde, Ar. And wende to Jerusalem, and þat toun felde to grounde, Occisio Ju∣daeorum.
And slowe There the Ar. þe luþer Gywes al þat heo founde,
Som yut of hem a skapede, & that was harm y wis, Ar. Bute a schipful þer of a scapede, þat were to fele y wẏs,
War of com þe luþer brod, þat a mong men ȝet ys.
Ten Yer afterward Vas∣pasian Ar. ȝer Vaspasian emperour was þo,
And Tytus ys sone aftur hym Two Ar. recte. Adeo ut teu reponerem. ten ȝer, and no mo.
Domician, Tytus broþer, emperour þo was,
Fiftene ȝer aftur hym. no more schrewe þer nas.
For he Werrede Ar. worrede Cristendom, as þe luþer Nero,
And let Martire Seẏnt Ar. martri Seyn Denys, & monẏ oþer al so.
Litteram hanc majusculam A rectissime omit∣tit Ar. A NERUA was þo emperour a ȝer, & somdel more.
Trajan Com tho after hym, a man Ar. com aftur hym, mon of gret lore. Trajanus.
Nyentene ȝer & an half emperour he was,
Noble man for soth he was, but he Ar. þe noblest þat myȝte, bote þat he Cristene nas.
So ryȝtful he was, þat Theigh pro þan in Ar. þan he hadde a dede hym self ydo,
þat a ȝeyn The lawe were, or his sone Ar. ys lawes was, and ys sone al so,
For which dede a man sholde, for that he hadde y wrought, Lese eny of hys lymes, hym self ne sparede he nought, Ac let Ar. For such dede a man schulde, þat þis hadde y wroȝt,
Lese ys on eye, & he hym self ne sparede hym self noȝt,
Bute let pulte out ys own eye, & ys sone's al so.
Deest Ar. Wel″ fewe kynges Me nough sikth Ar. me syþ, þat yt wolde do.
þer fore Seyn Gregori, þo he o londe was,
More þan fyf hundred ȝer aftur þis ryȝtful cas,
þat such a mon schulde in helle be, he carede in hys þoȝt,
þe soule Thurgh Ar. þorþ Gode's grace out of helle he broȝte,
And to ys body Hym Ar. ys joyned, & gef hym Cristendom,
Whar thurgh, as Ar. War with, as he worþi was, to blisse of Heuene He com Ar. com.
ADRIAN com þo next, and twenti ȝer and on
Aftur hym emperour he was, of Giwes ne louede he non.
þe Burgh Ar. boru of Jerusalem he let somdel a Deest Ar. ȝeyn″ rere,
þat Vaspasian felde adoun, þo he slow þe Giwes þere.
Ac he nolde The Jewes loue for no thyng, that hii myghte, That hii moste of the burghe ones haue Ar. þe Giwes leue ȝeue for noþing, þat heo myȝte,
þat þe moste of þe boru enes habbe a syȝte.
He dude hem schame y now, & temprede hem fulwel,
And made Hem meok and mylde ynough, that erst were rebel Ar. hem sone milde y now, þo heo were rebel.
ANTONIN was þo emperour twenti ȝer and two,
And aftur hym twei breþeren in þe emperie were y do,
Marcus & Aurelius, nyentene ȝer heo were,
Cristendam bi here day Me gan faste to lere Ar. me by gan faste lere.
For Eleu∣therie the good man Ar. Eleuthere a god mon was þo pope of Rome,
þorw wam first Cris∣tendom Ar. Christenemen in to Engolond come,
Ych wol sone telle how, as ich vnderstonde,
And telle aftur þis emperoures of kynges of þis londe:
AFTUR kyng Aruirag, of wam we habbeþ y told, Reges.
Marius, ys sone, was kyng, quoynte mon & bold.
And ys sone was aftur hym, Kyng Coel was his name, A noble man & queẏnte, and of good fame, Ar. Coil was ys name,
Boþe it were quoynte men, & of noble fame,
And here truage dude to Rome, as hem aȝte to do.
For þer nas None Ar. nower so noble prince, þat ne dude Also Ar. so.
Lucye, Coile's sone, aftur hym kyng was.
To fore hym in Engelonde Cris∣tendom none nas Ar. For, as me may þe soþe segge, by fore hym no beter nas.
For he herde Ofte telle Ar. of telle of miracles, þat come
þorw Cristenemen al a boute, as wel as at Rome.
He willede anon in hys herte to fonge Cristendom.
þer fore ys messageres mid gode lettres he nom,
þat to þe pope, Eleutherie Ar. Eleuchere hastiliche heo wende,
And that Ar. þat he quik in to ys lond Cristendom hym sende, Prima Christiani∣tas Angliae.
þat He Ar. heo myȝte serue God, for he wilnede muche þer to,
And he ne schulde not be glad, er þe dede were y do.
The Ar. þo pope here of was glad, & twei holy men hym sende,
Fagan and Damian Ar. Dimian, hys soule for to amende
The ryght bileue to teche, & yaf hym Cristendom. That folk faste a boute wide ther to com Ar. þat ryȝt bi leue hym taȝte, and ȝef hym Cristendom.
þo folk þo faste a boute wyde þer to com.
þis was an hundred ȝer, and sixti ȝer and two,
Aftur þat God was ybore, þat þis dede was y do.

Thus com lo Cristen∣dom in to Brutaẏne londe, But ther were erst some preueliche Cristendom hadde fonge. As at the place of Glastyngbury Joseph of Arimathie Lyuede ther in Criste's laẏ, with hys companye. Ther were tho in Brutayne, false lawes to lere, Ar. þus com lo into þis lond first Cristendam,
Bute yt were any holi man, þat priueliche arst yt nom.
þer were arst in Engelond, hor false lawes to lere,
Eyȝte and twenti chef studes, bischopriches as it were,
And þre architemples, as it were Heẏghest Ar. hext of echon,

London, and Ebrack∣wik, and ther to Carlyon. The kyng and othur holy men de∣struẏde hem alle y fere, And eighte and twenty bisshopes in hure stede dude there, And thre Erchebisshopes ther the Erchetemples were, Ar. Euerwik, and in Glomorgan on.
þis gode kyng & his holi men lette felle hem alle þere, Episcopa∣tus.
And eiȝte & tuenti bischopriches in here studes lette rere.
And þe erchbischopriches as þe þre architemples were, Archiepi∣scopatus.
As yt were of alle chef Cristendom to lere.
Alle þo bischopriches vnder Euerwik were ydo
þat ben bi Norþ Homber, as heo deþ ȝet al so.
London Had∣de that othur del, that a this side Humber is, Fram Douere in to Cornewaille to the see ywis Ar. Adeo ut Souþ pro Norþ reponi debeat. hadde þo al þis lond, þat bi Norþ Homber ys,
From Douere to Seuerne, and al Cornewaile iwis.
þe þridde erchbischopriche was at Carleon in Walis
Vp Osk in Glomorgan, ac þe see a doune ys,
Ac endes of olde walles þer stondeþ ȝet Deest in Ar. euerne,″
Under hym Walis þilke hadde, & al bi West Seuerne.
Thus com in to this lond the lawe of Cristendom, Ar. þus com lo in to þis lond first Cristendom, Reditus incredulita∣tis.
Ac þoru a luþer emperour, þat þer aftur com,
þat het Dioclician, it was seþþe i broȝt to gronde,
And Hethenesse Ar. heþenes y brogt aȝeyn for to Seynt Austyn it vn bonde.
Lucie þis gode kyng, þat þus Cristene bi com,
Deide aboute four ȝer aftur ys Cristendom.
At Gloucetre he was y buried, ac heir hadde he non, Muchel sorwe to the lond, and to the men echon. Seuer was tho Em∣perour Ar. Gloucestre he deide, ac eir nadde he non,
þat a corede al þis lond, and ys men echon.
SOUER was emperour þilke tyme at Rome,
So þat þe tyþinges sone to hym come,
þat The Ar. þo kyng of Breteyne with oute eyr was ded.
Sone he þoru is court þer of nom ys red,
And wende hider hastiliche With gret power y nough. That folk Ar. with power y now,
And folk, þat stode a ȝeyn hym, faste to ȝronde he slow.
A duk þer was of þis lond, Fulgence was ys name,
He stod aȝeyn hym mid ys ost, & dude hym gret schame;
And, forto be þe sikerore, he wende In to Ar. to Scotlond,
And made hym þere A gret ost of landfolk of the londe, And wende out vpon hym Ar. gret ost of folk of þat lond,
And wende oft vp hym, and slow and barnde faste.
Ac euer hadde þe emperour þe maystre atte laste.
Themperour here in this lond tho weddede a wife, Ar. þe emperour in þis lond weddede þo a wyf, Imperator sponsat so∣rorem Ful∣gencii.
þat was Fulgence's Suster in this ilke strife Ar. sostre, þo in al þis strif.
Bi hire he hadde a god sone, y clepud Basian;
An oþer he hadde, y hote Get, þat he at Rome wan Ar. Rome biwan.
þo Fulgence seiþ, þat he ne myȝte aȝeyn hym stonde,
To þe Contreie of Sithie Ar. lond of Scicie he wende out of þis londe,

And of Pictes gedered an ost, and hure cheuenteyn was, Staleworthe men and hardy, to helpe hym in this cas. Tho this ost y gadered was of yonge bachelrie, Ar. And a gret ost of Picars, whas cheuenteyn he was,
Of stronge men he gederede, to helpe hym in þis cas.
þo he y mad hym a fayr ost of þis bachelerie,
He com a ȝeyn in to þis lond out of Sithie. He byseged Euerwyk vpon them∣perour faste Ar. Scicie.
He by lay first Euerwik op þe emperour faste.
So þat þe emperour hym ȝef batail at þe laste. Bellum.
For pro ac in Ar. Ac muche del of þis lond to Fulgence toke,
For He of hare kynde was, Ar. he more of kynde was, & þe emperour for soke.
Bataile þei smyte strong ynow, & mony slowe to gronde,
So þat Fulgence þere hadde deþeiswonde.
Ac þe emperour Was er y slawe, Ar. was y slawe, & y buried at Euerwyk.
And Fulgence deẏde afterward, tho he hadde longe be sik. Tho these men Ar. Ac Fulgence deide seþþe, þo he hadde y ley sik.
þo þis men were boþe ded, me moste habbe a kyng. Contencio.
Bi twene þo Romaynes & þis lond þer bi gan þo stryuyng.
Geth, themperoure's Ar. Get, þe emperoure's sone, þe Romaynes to kyng nome.
For he was Of the fader blod, & of the kynde of Rome Ar. of fader and moder of þe kynde of Rome.
Ac þe Brutones of þis lond nome Basian þer to.
For ys moder was of þis lond, & ys vncle al so.
Theigh they were bretheren beẏe, ther was nought gret loue, Ne theẏ myghte reste haue, forte on was a boue Ar. þo þer were twei kynges þus, þer nas not wel gret loue,
Ne myȝte, þei heo breþren were, er þo on were a boue.
So þat eiþer Upon Ar. vp oþer werrede Swithe faste, Ar. faste, Bellum.
And a batail strong y now smyten at þe laste.
So Bassian Ar. And Basian and ys power slow Geth Ar. Get ys broþer,
And so he was al one kyng, for ther was non other Ar. And Basian bi leuede kyng, for þer nas þo non oþer.
A STALEWORÞE ȝong bachiler in þis lond was þo,
Karant cluped he was, & couthe on muchel wo Ar. Caraus was yclepud, þat couþe of muche wo.
For þo he hadde in werre y be, Y do Ar. & do gret maistrie,
And a sayd muche hym self, he thoughte in trecherie Ar. And hym self muche yfonded, he þouȝte do tricherie.
He wente and bed leue þo of þe emperour of Rome,
To kepe the Bruttẏsshe see fro strange men that come Ar. To wyte þe se a boute þis lond fram stronge men þat come,
And bi het hym, þat, ȝef þer of wel auaunsed he were,
To ȝelde more god to Rome, þan al Breteyne þider bere.
þo þe conseil of Rome y leuede ys faire bi hest,
And þat he was strong mon, & of gret power with þe meste,
þe emperour with god cartre, & mid ys owne Sele, Ar. cel,
Hym yaf the power of this lond to hym euery dele Ar. Hym ȝef of þe se a boute þe warde euer y del.
þis false mon wende Forth tho with his chartre Ar. þo mid ys cartre a boute,
And of Euel doynge men ga∣derede Ar. willesful men hym ȝederede a gret route,
And bi het hem Good Ar. god y now of purchas, þat God hem sende,
And purueide Hym Ar. hem gode schippes, & in to þe se wende,
And won hem sone muche god mid strengþe & quoyntise,
And seþþe mid robbery, bute þei myȝte Omittit Ar. in″ oþer wyse.
So large he was to hys men of thynges that hii founde, Ar. Of hys purchas so large he was to men þat he fonde,
þat he hadde a gret ost in a lutel stonde.
þe yles he robbede in þe see, & þe hauenes Deest in Ar. seþþe″ a boute.

Sic igitur ipso a∣gente confluebant ad illum quicunque in aliena anhela∣bant; ita ut in brevi tantum haberet exercitum, quanto nullus vicinus princeps resis∣tere quivisset Galfr. Mon. So þat men of purchas come to hym so gret route,
þat þer nas Prince non that Ar. prince vn neþe þat hym myȝte at route.
Hys power wex euer so, þat eche lond hym gan doute.
So þat he spek mid hey men here of þis lond,
And bi het hem faire y now, & dude hem to vnderstonde,
þat ȝef heo abowe to hym, and to here kyng hym nome,
þat he Wolde hem brynge al out of Ar. wole al out hem brynge of þe daunger of Rome,
And De∣lyuere out of this lond the Romeynes echon: So freo a lond as this in the worlde sholde be non. That folk hym made tho hure kyng, Ar. deliuere þis lond of Romaynes, & of stronge men echon,
þat so fre lond as þis ne schulde nower non.
þe lond hym made þo here kyng, for he was so quoynte man,
And he bi gan to werre anon vp þe kyng Basian,
And eyþer aȝeyn oþer gederede ys ost faste,
So þat þei comen and smyton a batail atte laste. Bellum.

Quod cum impetrasset, dimi∣cavit confestim cum Bassiano & interfecit eum, & guberna∣culum regni suscepit. Prodi∣derant enim Bassianum Picti, quos dux Fulgentius, ma∣tris suae frater, in Britanniam conduxerat. Nam dum sibi auxiliari debuissent, promis∣sis & donariis Carausii cor∣rupti, in ipso proelio diverte∣runt se à Bassiano, & in com∣militones suos irruerunt. Unde stupefacti ceteri, cum ignorarent quis socius esset, quis hostis, ocius dilabuntur, & victoria cessit Carausio. Qui ut triumphum habuit, dedit Pictis locum mansionis in Albania, ubi cum Britoni∣bus mixti per subsequens aevum permanserunt Galfr. Mon. Ac Carant of his felonye gan hym Ar. Caraus of felonye hym gan vnderstonde,
And þoȝte, þat The Pictes Ar. Picars were of Strange Ar. strong londe,
þat Hii were Ar. were with Basian þe kyng, þat Fulgence His Uncle broughte, Ar. hider broȝte,
þat Hii Ar. heo wolde liȝtliche to hym turne Hure thoughte. To hem he spak Ar. he þoȝte.
Mid hem he spek so quoyntoliche, & mede Bygan hem beode, Ar. bi gan bede,
So þat þe kyng Basian heo by traide in hys nede.
For þo heo come to batail, heo turnede a ȝeyn hym echon:
He Ar. Heo nuste wich were His Ar. here frend, ne wych were His Ar. here fon.
And Ar. Ac Basian and al ys folk eode a non to gronde,
And he hym self, and mony oþer y slawe were in astonde.
þo was þis false Carant Ar. Caraus kyng of þis lond here,
Unele bẏ cam hym of kynde to haue such power Ar. Unel it bi com hym of kynde to ben of such power.
þo tyþing com þo to Rome, þat he dude hem such schame,
Hii Ar. Heo nome a gret lordyng, Allect was ys name,
And sende hym in to þis lond, & men mid hym ynowe,
So þat in batail þis Carant hii Ar. Caraus heo slowe.
þo þis batail was y do, heo bi gonne arere
Werre vp men of þis lond, for Hii with Carant Ar. heo with Caraus were.
þe Brytones þo of þis lond, to schilde Hem self fram Ar. hem fro schame,
Chese Ar. Cheson hem anew kyng, Asclepedot Ar. Asclepiod was ys name,
þat was erl of Cornewail. he Ga∣derede Ar. gedere ys ost anon
To werre, & to stonde a ȝeyn þe Romeynes, that were his fon Ar. Romaynes ys fon.
He Wende thuder sone anon, ther as Allect was, Ar. wende hym to Londone, as kyng Allect þo was,
To honoure His Ar. here false Godes, as it fel þo bi cas.
Tho Allect this vnder yat Ar. þo þis kyng þis vnder ȝet, þat þis folk þus come,
He by lefte Ar. He bi leuede ys sacrifise, & ys folk with hym nom,
And wende out aȝeyn hem, & strong bataile heo smyte.
So muche folk þer was y slawe, þat deol yt was to wyte. Bellum.
These Ar. þis Britones were so egre, and wox euer so faste,
þat The Ar. þo Romaynes and here kyng gonne fle atte laste.
The Ar. þo Britones siwede aftur, as heo aȝt do,
And slowe mony þousant, and Allect þe kyng al so.
A Lordlyng Ar. lordyng of þe Romaynes, þat y hote was Galle,
Com & ẏeld Ar. ȝold hym to oure kyng, & ys men ney wat alle.
þe kyng hym nom to prison, to London he was y broȝt.
þe kyng hym wolde ȝeue lyf, ac ys men nolde noȝt,
Ne suffre, þat þer were Alyue Ar. o liue eny of here fon,
Ac ladde hym in to London, & ys men echon,
To a rennyng water, þat ȝet ys þer y wene,
And smyten of alle here hedes, to bryng hem out of tene.
þe water þer heo were y slawe me clepude Galle brok,
Aftur Galle þilke prince, þat þer ys deþ tok.
þo was Breteyn þis lond of Romaynes almest lere,
Unnethe was hit ten yer, that hii her a yen nere. As∣cleopedot hym let tho crouny kyng a non Ar. Ac albysi were yt ten ȝer, ar heo here aȝeyn were.
Asclepiod let hym þo crowne to kyng a non,
And kept a boute ten ȝer þis lond Pro wel mid legend. potius cum Ar. fram his fon. Id quod carminis ratio postulat. wel mid.
Ac þoru Romaynes, þat Hider Ar. here come, þat heþene were echon,
And þoru Othur mysbeleuede, Cristen∣dom was al gon Ar. oþer, Cristendom was nei wat al agon.
TWEI Vide Editionem nostram vitae Ael∣fredi Magni Spelmannianae, p. 4. emperoures At Rome were, on Dioclician, Ar. of Rome, Dyoclician,
And an oþer, ys felaw, þat het Maximian,
And were bothe Ar. Were boþe at on tyme, þe on in þe Est ende,
The othur in the West of the worlde, as Cristen∣dom to shende Ar. And þe oþer in þe West, Cristendom to schende.
For þe luþer Maximian Westward hider soȝte,
And Cristenemen, þat he fond, to strong deþ he broȝte.
Chirches he fel al a doun, þer ne moste non stonde.
And al þe bokes, þat he myȝte fynde in eny londe,
He wolde lete hem berne echon amid þe heye strete,
And The Ar. þo Cristenemen A sle Ar. alle sle, and none A lyue Ar. o liue lete.
Seþþe God was Y bore, vpon Cristendom Such persecucion as tho was hadde ther be non Ar. y bore, þer nas for Cristendom
In so lute stonde y do so gret martirdom.
For þer were in a moneþ seuentene þousant and mo
Y martired for oure Lorde's loue, (Nas there a gret wo? Ar. nas not here gret wo?)
With oute Othure grete halwen, Ar. grete halwe, þat heo hulde longe in torment,
As Seynt Cristyne & Seynt Fey, & al so Seynt Vincent;

Fabian and Sebastian, and othur, as men rede, that helde faste in the fey, and hadde non drede. And, among men of these londe, ther were ma∣nyon I martred at thulke tyme, Ar. As Sebastian, & mony oþer, as me may in Chirche rede,
And monyon turnede a ȝeyn to heþene for drede.
Among alle þese in þis lond, þat were monion
Y martred as þilke tyme, Seynt Albon was on,
He was the furste martir of Brutayne that com. Muche was the shame me dude tho to Cristendom. Under Ar. þat was þe firste martir, þat to Engolond come,
Dere haþ, Lord! mony a mon y boȝt Cristendom.
Under þis luþer Emperour Ar. emperoures þer was a noble mon,
As of Hure luthur lawe, and vnder hym muche wan Ar. heore luþer lawes, þat vnder hem muche won.
Constance was ys name, he conquerede of Spayne Constan∣cius.
þe truage, and of Fraunce, & seþþe here of Bretayne.
COLE was a noble mon, & Muche Ar. gret power hadde on honde,
Erl he was of Colchestre here in þis londe,
And Colchestre aftur ys name y clepud ys ich vnderstonde.
Oure lord, among oþer þinges, hym sende a fair sonde,
þat He gat a fair doughter at Coel∣chestre Ar. he hadde an holy doȝter al Colchestre in þis londe,
þat Seynt Helene was y clepud, þat The Ar. þo holy croys fonde.
Bi twene oure kyng Astleopedot Ar. Asclepiod & þis erl with oute faile
Gan ther were a contek, so that hii smyte ane bataille Ar. þer wox gret worre, so þat heo smyte bataile. Bellum.
And þis erl Cole slow þe kyng, & þo he hadde The heygher Ar. þo ouer hond,
Kyng he let hym crowne þo of Al the Bru∣tayne lond Ar. al þis lond.
þat folk was þo of þis lond y payed wel ynow,
þat he hadde y wonne þe kyndom, & þat he þe oþer slow.
þe tyþing to Rome com, The kyng a slawe was, Ar. þat he y slawe was,
þat hem hadde y do schame, heo were glad of þat cas.
þe noble prince Hii Ar. heo sende hyder þe gode knyȝt Constance,
þat wan hem al þe power of Spayne & eke of France,
And that Ar. þat he scholde eke þis lond wynne a ȝeyn to Rome.
So þat þis noble prince, and ys men hyder come.
Tho Coel Ar. þe kyng Cole yt vnder ȝet, he dradde in ys mod,
For he was so noble Prince Ar. knyȝt, þat no mon hym with stod.
To hym he sende of acord, ȝef it were is wille, Concordia.
þat he wolde to Rome abowe, & lete alle strif be stille,
And þider bere ys truage, as oþer dude bi fore,
And to kepe the kynedom, that hit nere forlore. Constancius grauntede this, & Ar. For wat he huld þe kindam, wen þe truage were ybore.
Constance it grantede, and nom ys truage,
And to be the sikerour, of hym toke good ostage, Ar. And nom also to be siker of hym god ostage,
And grantede hym þe kyndom and þe pes of Rome,
And bi leuede in þis lond To ge∣dere botho y come. Sone by fel afterward, That Coel kyng sik lay, And deide sone afterward with ynne a short day, Ar. to godere y some.
A moneþ it was þer aftur, þat Cole syk lay,
And deide, as God wolde, with inne þe eiȝteþe day,
And oþer eir nadde he non, bute Seynt Helene þe gode,
Ys doȝter, þat seþþe fond þe swete holy rode.
Constance, for hire eritage, þis maide to wyne nom, Sponsacio Helenae.
And nom with Hure al this lond, Ar. hire so þis lond, and þis kyndom,
And let hym Crouny to kyng, that good knyght was & fyn, Ar. crowne kyng, & god kyng was and fyn.
By hire he hadde a god sone, y clepu Constantyn.
þo Constance hadde y be ellene ȝer kyng y wys,
He deide at E∣bracwyk, and ther y buried ys. Constantyn Ar. Euerwyk, and y buried was þer and ys.
CONSTANTYN, is ȝonge sone, ycrowned was þo kyng.
Noble mon he bicom & Wys thurgh Ar. wytty þorþ alle þing.
Kyng he was þritti Yer of this kyngdom, And gouernede hit swythe wel with queyntise & wysdom. The luthur Ar. ȝer. he ladde þis kyndom
Ryȝt nobliche and swiþe wel with quoyntyse and wysdom.
A LUTHER emperour bi fore, þat het Maximian,
þat was Upon Cristendom a swithe luthur man, Ar. vp Cristenemen (as we seide) so luþer a man,
A sone he hadde Sherewed ek, Maxent was his name, Hym he made Ar. schrewe y now, Maxencius to name,
Hym me made emperour, mony mon to schame.
He wes, as wel as ys fader, gret schrewe y now.

For Kateryne, and other mo, in stronge deth he slough. Much folk he dude shame, and the folk of Rome also He fondede to disherite, and brynge hem to wo. The disheritez of Rome to this londe come To Constantyn, and bysoughte hym of hem to take gome. And he hem Ar. For in strong martirdom Seynt Kateryn he slow,
And mony oþer martir, and þat folk of Rome al so
He fondede to deserie, and mony schames do.
So þat þe deserites in to þis lond come
To Constantyn, þe gode kyng, for de faute from Rome.
And he hem faire vnder fong, so þat mo and mo
þer come for enlegeance to habbe of heore wo.
So þat The disherites gonne on hym to grede Ar. þese deserites bi gonne al on hym grede.
"Sire," heo seiden, "for Gode's loue bryng vs of þis wrechede.
"Of þe kynde blod of emperie þer nys bi leued non,
"That sholde be kynde emperour, non but though al on Ar. Ne þat bi kynde were emperour, non bute þou on.
"How longe wolt þou suffre þe schrewe's out rage?
"Go and wyn þi kynde lond and þyn eritage.
"þou schalt habbe þer help y now of þi kynde londe.
"Wel þou wost, þat Lytel while they shulleth the withstonde Ar. lute while þe schrewe þe at stonde.
Constantyn hym vnderstod of ys kynde londe,
And that hit were good to haue Ar. And god it were to habbe þis and þat on honde.
Muche power of þis lond mid hym forþ he nom,
And seþþe also of France, as he þer forþ com.
And wende toward Rome to wynne þe emperie,
To brynge þe schrewe adoun, þat dude þat robberye.
As he wende, he bi huld toward heuene an hey, Visio crucis.
And þo vp in þe firmament an angel he sey,
þat huld a croys, and þer on y write was lo! þis,
"Constantyn Ar. & sic in∣fra. Costantyne þorȝ þis signe þou schalt be maister iwis."
Constantyne þis vnderstod, heþene þai he were.
A crois, in stude of ys baner, Tofore hym he let rere Ar. ys men bi fore hym bere.
Maxencius þo he wiste him come, he hadde of hym gret doute.
He let at Rome a strong dich make al a boute
And dep aȝen Constantyne, and a ȝeyn al ys route,
Forto holde hem þer þoru wan heo come with oute.
As he was a boute þis dich, he ne ȝan not muche wynne.
For he fel al amidde, and dreynt hym þer inne.
þoru þe vertu of the crois he was sone ouercome,
And Costantyn hadde al so sone þe toun ynome,
Constantyn ther after∣ward com in bataille non Ar. Costantyn ne com nower in batail non,
þat he nadde þorȝ þe crois þe maistri of fon.
So þat he hym vnderstod What best was to don, Ar. of þe beste won,
And of Seynt Siluestre þe pope hym let baptize anon. Baptiza∣cio Con∣stantini.
And he was (as yt is ywrite) pur mesel þo,
And he bi com in hys baptizing hol of ys wo.
Seynt Siluestre was pope þo, and þe first þat þer com
Of alle popes þat deide with oute martirdom.
For þer nas non by fore him þat he martired nas
Of þe luther emperoures, for eche heþene was.
A chirche of Seynt Jon þe baptist Constantyn let rere, Levacio ecclesia∣rum.
And clepude yt Constantiniane, Ar. Costantiniane, for he was ybaptized þere.
To pro of in Ar. Of Seynt Petur & of Poule an oþer he rerede al so,
And in strong Mast∣lyng he let hure bones do Ar. mastlyng he haþ þer inne boþe heore bones y do.
Of seynt Laurence he rerde anoþer, of seynt Anneis eke on.
And of oþer Seyntes þat ȝet stondeþ he rerede eke monion.
þo sende he Seynt Elene ys moder, That wẏs womman was kud, Ar. þat wys was y kud,
To Jerusalem to seche þe croys, þat þere was y hud.
So þat it was þer y founde In the gynnynge of May, Ar. þe by gyng of þe Maẏ,
As ȝe habbeþ ofte yherd, þe holy rode daẏ.
Costantyn lette also in Jerusalem chirches rere,
And Wende a boute Ar. wyde aboute elles wer, Cristendom to lere.
So þat þoru Gode's grace so noble mon he was,
þat þer nas prince in al þe world, þat vnder ys power nas.
þre vnclen ys moder hadde, þat on hatte Honyn,
And Trahen þo oþer hette, and þe þridde Maryn.
Alle þre Costantyn nom with hym to Rome,
And grete lordes þoru hym alle þre þer bi come.
AN erl þer was in þis lond, Octaui was ys name:
Romaynes, þat Were byleued, Ar. here bileuede, he dude ofte schame,
And slow hem faste her & þer, That few me myghte y se Ar. þat me schulde uewe y se.
þe Brutones hym crownede þo heore kyng for to be.
Whan this word cam to Constantyn, he nuste what best to done: Ar. þis word com to Costantyn, he þouȝte was to done:
Trahen, ys moder vncle, hyder he sende sone.
With gret power ynow, to wynne þis kyndom.

And gederede þer A newe ost a yenst the kyng as blyue, Ar. al new ost aȝeyn þe kyng bi liue,

þo was Trahen As lord, Ar. al a lord, þe wyle yt wolde laste.
Ac as he out of Londen wente in a tyde,
A gret erl hym kepte þer in a wode syde,
With an hundred knyȝtes y armed wel ynow.
þis prince al vn ywar toward hem drow.
Heo comen aȝeyn Hem Ar. hym vn war, & slowe Hem for nought Ar. hym al for noȝt.
þis tyþing was ouer se to þe kyng sone y broȝt.
He com hyder sone a ȝeyn joyful y now,
And The Ar. þo Romaẏnes, þat he fond, to gronde faste he slow.
þo gederede he so gret Ost, and so gret Ar. tresour, and al so so gret route,
And so gret power, þat he nadde of no prince in þe world doute.
For þer nas prince non þat hym dorste arere strif.
So þat he huld þo þis lond in pes al is lyf.
He Axede Ar. ascode at ys conseileres, þo he to elde com,
How he myȝte best do mid His Ar. þis kyndom,

þat he schulde nyme ys neuew, þat Was hote Ar. hatte Conan,

þe beter pays þer scholde be for the riȝtful cas.
Conan, þe kynge's neuew, þo he herde þis,
Wex wroþ, Ar. Was wroþ, and destourbede al þe court y wys.
And naþeles Cradok hym held al euene and stille,
And þe kyng stilleliche broȝte al to hys wille.
To Rome he sende Morice, þat ys owne sone was,
Pryueliche to Maximian, to telle hym of þis cas.
þer was þo stryf at Rome bi twene þis Maximian,
And þo emperour, þat was þo, þat hatte Gracian.
þo Morice þider com, and faire was vnderfonge,
And herde þis contek, þat ilaste longe,
To þis senatour he seide, "Sire Maximian,
"Ut quid Gratianum ti∣mes, Maximiane, cum tibi pa∣teat via, qua ei imperium eri∣pere poteris? Galfridus Mon. Whi art þou so sore a drad of þis Gracian,
"Thugh myght of hym haue al thi wille, & thugh konne the by se. Com with me Ar. Wen þou miȝt of hym god wei alto þin wille y se?
"For com with me to Bretayne, & þou schalt þere kyng be.
"For þe kyng Nough is old, & ne hath non heir y wys, But a dough∣tur that is yong, that hym lef is, Ar. now in elde naþ non eyr y wys
"Kynde, bote ys doȝter one, þat hym fol lef ys,

"And he haþ god wille to þe, As he is vnderstonde, To wedde to the, by cause thugh ert of kynde of this londe. And such power whan hit is so though myght ther thurgh avonge, Ar. as me deþ hym to vnderstonde,
"þat þou hire spousedest. for þou art of þe kynde of the londe.
"And such myȝt, wan yt so ys, þou myȝt þer þoru a fonge,
"þat þou myȝt perauntre Be lord of Rome er longe Ar. Rome wynne ar come oȝt lonȝe.
"For þi gode cosyn Costantyn Rome wan al so,
"And mony oþer of our kynges in þis maner come þer to.
þo þis Maximian vnderstod al þis,
He dude hym sone hyderward mid ȝret power y wis.
He ariuede at Souþ hampton, as The Ar. þo wynd hym had y lad.
þo our kyng herde her of, he was somdel a drad,
Leste he hadde for vnel y come. And tho he wiste hough hit was, Ar. Ac þe he wiste wad he was,
He vnder feng hym fayr y now, & conseilede of This cas Ar. þe cas.
Some seyde, Betere hit were to take Ar. þat hym wer beter take ys neuew Conan
þe kyndom of þis lond, and some To Maximian, And some othur lordes of this londe that hys doughtur toke, And the kyng∣dom with hure, that hit couthe best loke Ar. Maximian,
And some, an hey mon of þis lond þat he ys doȝter toke,
And ys kyndom mid hire, for he yt wolde best loke.
Ac ys hext conseil naþeles, that he mest vnder stod,
Radde hym to Maximian, That was of heygh blod, And of the good Ar. for he was of so hey blod,
Of þe gode quene Elene, & of þe noble Costantyn,
(þat was kyng here of þis lond, & emperour atte fyn,)
And of kynge's blood Coel of this londe com, Ar. And of þe kynge's blod Cole kyng of þis lond he com,
þat god yt were to al þe lond to take hym þe kindom.
þe kyng and ys meste men hulde al þis wisdom.
So þat þe kynge's doȝter mid þis lond he nom.
Ac Conan, þe kynge's neuew, ne likede not þis game.
He ordeyned with his pow∣er to du hem alle shame Ar. He garkede power a ȝeyn hym to hym alle schame.
Ac ys power Litel Ar. lute was. for þe kyng was euer aboue,
So þat atte laste þei were y broȝt To loue Ar. in loue
Bi Graciane's dai þe emperour. þis was, as ich wene,
In the yer of oure Lord Crist thre hundred & seuen∣tene, (sine & LX.) Ar. minus recte. A boute þe ȝer of grace CCC. & LX. & seuentene.
Withinne fyf-ȝer aftur þis kyng so prout bi com,
For þe grete tresour nameliche þat he alday nom,
þat he Was nought onlich a paid to haue the kyngdom, Ar. nas not ene y paid to habbe þis kyndom,
Bute he hadde France al so with strengþe wyþ oute dom.
He nom with hym of This Ar. hys lond gret power y now,
And to þe lond, þat was yclepud Armorike, Ar. Armore, he drow,
þat Breteyn ys now yclepud, as he it Clupede Ar. nempde þo.
Fyftene þousant Hors y heled there were Ar. hors y wrye þer were aȝeyn hym, & mo,
Of þe lond of France, and of oþer londes bi syde. Bellum.
þer heo smyte a batail, þat cowþ was fulwyde.
þer was þe Kyng Ar. duk of France y slaw, and al is folk ney.
þo þe kyng Maximian þis grete slaȝt y sei,
He was glad, for he wiste wel to wynne þo al ys wille.
Conan, The quene's cosẏn, he let tho clepe hym tille, And thus he began to speke to hym. We haueth nough, he sede, Wonne that on ende Ar. þe quene cosyn, he clepude out þo stille.

He bi gan som del to Id est, to laugh. Sic enim Galfr. Mon. Vocavit er∣go Conanum ad se extra tur∣mas, & paulisper subridens ait: Ecce unum ex potioribus regnis Galliae subjugavimus, ecce spem ad cetera habere possumus. &c. lihe. "We habbeþ now," he seyde,
"Y wonne an ende of France, of þe oþer nys no drede.
"þei ich be kyng of Breteyne, þat was þin Uncle's Ar. vncle lond,
"Ne be þou not sori þer fore, for ich wol habbe more an hond.
"Ych wol make þe of þis lond kyng, þou schalt yse,

"And this, in mynde of that othur, the lasse Brutayne shal be. In honour of the more Brutayne, to what thugh haddest kende, The lasse Brutayne this shal be, to haue the more in mẏende Ar. And þis lond schal be þyn, and þe oþer Breteyn be.
"For honour of Breteyne, to wam þou haddest kynde,
"þe oþer Breteyne yt schal hote, as to habbe of þe mynde.
"Deliuere we schul yt of þis folk, þat Ther Ar. hire inne ys,
"And of folk fulle it fol of Thyne. kynde Ar. oure kynde y wis.
Conan bowede a doun to hym, & þonkede hym Ful faste, Ar. faste,
And bi het to serue hym trewliche, þe while ys lyf laste.
Heo wende a boute in al þe lond, & heye townes nome,
And al þe men, þat heo fonde, heo slow euer as heo come,
And let þe wimmen go aliue; & þo heo hadde al On Ar. an honde,
And hadde delyuered al a boute clene that folk of londe, Ar. And hadde y slawe al clene a boute þat folk of þe londe,
In eche stude heo sette þere strong warnesture and god
Of folk of þis lond Here of hure Ar. here, and of here owne blod.
þe kyng an hundred þousant Men of this londe let fette, Ar. men in þis lond fette,
Praeterea xxx. milia militum, qui ipsos infra patriam, qua mansuri erant, ab hostili ir∣ruptione tuerentur. Galfr. Mon. And þritti þousant knyȝtes Hure Ar. here wardeynes he sette.
And delde among hem al þe lond, & ȝef eche diuerse þing,
And made Conan of hem alle, & of al þe lond kyng.
Thus was litle Brutayne Ar. And þus was Breteyne y wonne þoru oure Princes Ar. prince here,
And aftur þis lond Bretayn iclepud in þis maner.
Maximian wende Tho forth Ar. forþ þorw ys grete maistrie,
And wan with strengþe al France, and seþþe Normondie.
He yaf ech man that to hym com of purchas of his londe. So muche people drough to hym, myghte hym no man with∣stonde Ar. For he ȝef ech mon, þat to hym com, his purchas in eche londe.
So muche power fel hym to, þat noþing myȝt hym at stonde.
And Gracian þe emperour at Rome Suth he dude to dethe, And his brothur Valentinian a scapede a lyue vnnethe. Ac thurgh an em∣perour Ar. seþþe he slowȝ,
þat for hys hardy dedes of hym me dradde ynowȝ.
Ac þoru þe emperour, þat seþþe com, y hote Theodose,
Maximian was seþþe y slaw, Maugre al his nose. But erst these sher∣rewe robboures hadde hure wille a stounde, And suth for hure roborie hii were y brought to grounde. þe Bru∣tones Ar. magrei ys nose.
And so þe schrewe robboures hadde here wille at stonde,
And cheui in here robberi, atte laste it goþ to gronde.
þe Britones, þat Maximian of þis lond broȝte þo,

Byleuede in Brutayne, that Conan com thus ther to, That Armorike erst cluped was, & to newe name thus com By conqueste, as who seith, more than thurgh Ar. In þe lasse Breteyne bi leueþ ȝet, and schul euer mo.
And so þilke Brutayne of þis lond com
More þoru strengþe, as ȝe yseþ, þan þoru ryȝt dom.

So þat þe meste del a dreynt were in þe se,
And to oþer londes some y driue, and ne come ner aȝe.
A kyng þer was of Hongri, Guayn was ys name,
And Melga, kyng of Picardye, þat couþe ynow of schame,
þe wateres for to loke a boute þe se heo were,
A companye of þis maydenes so þat heo mette þere.
To here foly he wolde hem nime and hor men al so,
Ac þe maydenes wolde raþer dye, þan a cente þer to.
þo wende forþ þe luþer men, & the maydenes slow echon,
So þat to þe lasse Breteyne þer ne com aliue non.
OF þe wo, þat þer haþ in Engelond y be,
þoru emperoures of Rome, here ȝe mowe y se.
In oþer manere þat Scottes & Pictes Ar. Picars, as ich seide,
Habbeþ y worred þis lond, ich wol telle þe dede.
Guain þe kyng of Hongri, and þe kyng of Picardie,
þo heo hadde, as ych haue y seit, mid so gret vilenie
Y slawe of þis maydenes þat swete companie,
Bi þouȝte to do þis lond more tricherie.
Heo vnderstode, þat þis lond ymad was al clene
Of people thurgh Ar. Of god folk þoru Maximian and Conan Deest Ar. as″ at ene,
And þat heo myȝte þis lond al for noȝt wynne,
Heo gederede folk faste, þe werre to bi gynne.
To þe se heo sende mid heore folk, þat heo hadde on honde,
And come, as hem leuest was, first in to Scotlonde.
Toward þis lond heo bi gonne forto robby faste,
þat folk to sle, and townes and castles adoun caste.
þe simple men, þat heore were, here red þer of nome,
And sende aftur more help to þe emperour of Rome.
A duk, þat Height Gracian, Maxi∣mian hider sende. With two legiones of men hiderward he wende. The landfolk Ar. het Gracian, from Rome me sende,
þat mid gret power to þis lond hyder wende.
þo lond folk, þo he hyder com, turnede to hym faste,
So þat þer was slawȝt gret, þe wyle it wolde laste.
And þis kyng of Picardyo, and al so hys felawe,
Wer of come atte laste, þat heo nuste wyder to drawe.
Viliche þei were & mid strengþe ydryue into Yrlonde.
þo hadde Gracian þis lond al clanliche on honde,
And let hym self crouny kyng, & tho he al lord was, Ar. He let hym þo crowne kyng, and þo he alord was,
No more schrewe, þan he bi com, ych wene non nas.
The landfolk so hii sey this, to gedre faste hem drough, Ar. þat lond folk eode forþ, and to gedere drowe,
And, ar he dude to muche wo, þo foule schrewe slowe.
þat þo kyng was y slawe, it was sone couþ
In eche half from lond to lond, boþe Norþ & Souþ,
So þat it to þe kynges come, þat wende in to Yrlond.
Hii purueyede hem, that hii hadde sone pow∣er an honde Ar. Heo porueide þat heo haddo folk y now on honde
Of Norwei, and of Denemark, and al so of Scotlonde,
And barnde and to gronde slowe faste in þis londe.
So þat þe folk of þis lond al clene was ouercome.
For Maximian hadde out byfore al clene the knyghtes y nome Ar. For þe kyng had arst of þis lond þe knyȝtes so clene y nome.
Eft sone heo sende ȝet to Rome, wepyng ful sore,
þat heo schulde in here wo ȝet hem helpe more,
And Hii hem oblege wolde, and Ar. hem wolde obligi, and sikernesse finde gode,
To bere hem clene here truage, wyle þe world stode.
Eft sone ȝet þo Romaynes power hyder sende,
Knyȝtes and oþer werrours, þat to þis lond wende,
And in þe Souþ half ariuede of þis lond her.
Heo gadered folk ynow, þat heo hadde gret power,
And wende faste vp here fon, þat ne myȝt hem noȝt at stonde.
For some were y slawe sone, and some flow out of londe.
þo These lordlynges Ar. þis lordes of Rome al here wille hadde,
Heo nomen here conseil, & þe folk of þis lond radde,
þat heo bi twene þis lond & Scotland schulde a wal rere,
Strong and heyȝ on eche syde, þer no water nere,
From þat on se to þat oþer, þat were hem bi twene,
To lette hem wen heo come, & to saue hem fro tene.
For Scotlond haueth for vs y be luther recet y lome, And euere enemys to this lond, & wolde neuere be some. Ar. For Scotlond haþ euer y be a luþer recet y lome,
Wan þer any werrours toward þis lond come.
þe Romaynes seide eke, þat heo nolde in nomaner so wende
Out of heore lond hiderward, ne heore power so sende;

Ne to rokke hem so in þe se, ne heore lyf In a venture do, Ac witye hure owene lond at hom, and hure good also. For hii no more in this lond wolde come ne myghte, And that hii sholde hure yong folk teche forto fyghte. That folk Ar. an auntre do,
Bote wite heore lond at home, and heore god al so:
Ac ȝe schulde of oure ȝonge folke teche for te fyȝte,
For heo ne more in þis lond nolde come, ne myȝte.
þat folk þo of þis lond, þo heo nuste non oþer red,
Bi gonne to rere þe stronge wal, as hem was y seyd.
A rerde he was strong ynow, as þe stude is ȝet sene.
Muche me moste swynke er, and ther aboute spene.
þo þe wal wes ȝare y mad, a conseil heo nome,
þat al þe Grete pro conseil in Ar. conseil of þis lond schulde to London come.
þo heo were alle Thuder y come wisliche to rede, Therchebisshop Gwi∣thelyn of London thus sede: Ar. ycome wisliche for to rede,
þe bischop of London in þis maner him seyde:
"Mi leue frende, to telle ȝou, as þis heye men me bede,
"Beter wille ich habbe to wepe, þan to do oþer dede.

"Aftur þat Maximian our Folk Ar. fol gan awei lede,
"Al our knyȝtes, and swaynes, and al oure ȝong hede,
"And Othur londes storede ther with, alas! the deolful Ar. astored þer with oþer lond, alas! þat deolful dede!
"For ȝe ben men beter y taȝt to schouele and to spade,
"To cartestaf and to plowstaf, and a fischyng to wade,
"To hamer and to nedle, and to marchandise al so,

"Oþer ligge a doun and be slawe, oþer fle and drenche.

"Help is ther non with yow, but clenlich al this londe, Al the helpyng and lokyng, ys in othur manne's honde. Ar. Wor þere Eritne ergo spes vestra sem∣per in alieno tutamine, & non, instructis manibus vestris, en∣sibus & hastis depelletis la∣trones, nequaquam vobis for∣tiores, nisi segnitia & torpor adesset? Jam taedet Romanos tam assidui itineris &c. Galfr. Mon. any hope of ow, bote clanliche al þat lond,
"Al þe help and lokyng, ys in oþer monne honde?
"Malim ac pro and. And þe Romaynes beþ anyed of here trauail so sore,
"Of perel on se, & eke on lond, þat heo nul come her no more.
"Heo wol raþer bi leue here truage, þat ȝe hem bereþ aȝer.
"Ne konne ȝe noȝt lerne þing, þat ȝe dude neuer er?
"Aplieth your hondes to the spere and to swerd also Ar. Change ȝoure hond, & to vse of swerd & lance ys ydo.
"For no men ne beþ strengor þen ȝe, ȝef ȝe turnede þer to.

"Nonne homines transverso ordine nascuntur, ita ut ex rustico generetur miles, & ex milite rusticus? Miles etiam de mangone venit, & de milite mango. Galfr. Mon. Me may se a bonde mone's sone Som tyme a knyght by come, And of a grom a squyer, and after knyghtes some Ar. oþer wyle knyȝt bi come,
"And some gromes and squiers, and seþþe knyȝtes some.
"Wen ȝe habbeþ The fourme Ar. forme of men, beþ men In Ar. on alle wise,
"And turneþ ȝour hond to manhede, & Kepeth youre Ar. wyteþ oure franchise.
The erchebisshop Gwithelyn, Ar. þis bischop, þat hatte Gocelyn,″ þoru heor Aldre [l. alre] Ar. alle rede,
To þe lasse Breteyne wende for þis dede.
King Conan he fond ded, And a nothur Ar. an oþer of gret fame
Kyng he fond in hys stude, An∣droge Ar. Androw was ys name.
"Sire kyng," quoþ þe bischop, "ȝef þou wolt vnderstonde,
"Deol þou myȝt habbe in þin herte of þi kynde londe,
"Of þe more Bretayn, Ther thyne el∣derne Ar. as þin eldre were y bore.
"For þou wost wel Maximian þe kyng, & Conan her bi fore
"þe bachelerie al þat Ought was Ar. aȝt wes out of þat lond nome,
"And a stored here þis Lond thurgh the power Ar. lond and þe power of Rome,
"And londes abouten vs habbeþ wel vnder ȝite,
"þat þer nis no folk bi leued, þat lond forto wyte.
"Heo sleþ & destruyeþ al, þat þer nys noþing bi leued,
"Warbi men Myght Ar. mow libbe, and al for defaut of heued.
"And þer nys no mor þat kynde haþ þerto bute þou Al on Ar. on.
"Help Nough thyn olde heritage, Ar. þi kynde eritage, & þou worst þer kyng anon.
þe kyng gan som del to Laughe, Ar. lyȝhe, þo he herde þis.

"Ych Olim tempus erat quo non negarem insulam Britanniae accipere, si quis eam mihi lar∣giretur. Non enim existimo alteram patriam fertiliorem fuisse, dum pace & tranquil∣litate frueretur. At nunc, quoniam infortunia accesse∣runt. &c. Galfr. Mon. habbe," he seyde, "sire bischop, such tyme y sey y wys,
"That ich hit wolde nought haue forsake, yf hit hadde ther to be brought Ar. þat y nolde noȝt habbe for sake þat lond ho me hadde y broȝt þer to.
"Ac so muche Wrecchede now ther is, that now is hit so nought Ar. wrecched hed þer ys, þat nys not now so.
"And nameliche for þe folk of Rome such seruice Ar. Rome þat so muche seruise habbeþ þere,
"Deest Ar. þat″ in such þraldam forto be Ech man ful loth were Ar. eche god mon loþ were.
"þis lond ich Holde as freo, y ne dar non othur a buye, But witie me fro the kyng of France, Ar. habbe here so fre, þat to non herre y schal abuye,
"Bute wite fram þe kyng of France, þat doþ me ofte anye.
"And for to wyte me from hym, y nyl not Hens Ar. henne wende.
"Ac for myn Elderne Ar. eldore hadde þat lond, Y seigh yow atten eynde, Ar. y segge þe atte ende,
"To brynge it aȝeyn To ryght, ich Ar. to oure kynde, ich wol þider sende
"Costantyn my broþer, þat god knyȝt ys and hende,
"And wel Y founded Ar. y fonded in armes, & two Thousend Ar. cum Galfrido Mon. hondred knyȝtes al so,
Wel A rayd in good a tire, dedes of armes to do With the folk Ar. y wrye with þe atyl, þat god dede mow do
"Mid þe folk of þe lond, ȝef Hii Ar. heo aȝtes beþ,
"And ȝe mow hym make ȝoure kyng, wen ȝe The tyme Ar. tyme seþ.
þis Costantyn was of send, and These Ar. þis knygtes also,
And Hure shipes redy mad, this dede for to do Ar. schippes and here a tyl prest, such prowes forto do.
Ac heo ne myȝte So sone come, that the luther kynges tweye Ar. so raþe come, þat þe kynges twei
Nere y come out Yrlond, With Ar. wyt gret power bey
Of Scottes and of Picars, of Denemarch, And of Ar. of Norwei,
þat euer Haueth hated this lond, but Ar. habbeþ þis lond y hated, bote it were for eye.
Fer bi Norþ Bigonne (simplici voce) in Ar. bi gonne, and hider faste drowe,
And caste a doun Pict Wall Ar. þis stronge wal, & townes grete y nowe.
þe Britones, þat myȝte of scapie, by gonne faste to fle,
Some in roches, some in wodes, þat Deol pro rewþe in Ar. rewþe yt was to se.
COSTANTYN And his power in al this Ar. myd ys power, among al þis wrechedom,
At þe hauene of Tottenais Stille a lond Ar. stilleliche o lond com.
Glad were þo þe Britones, & joyful & proute.
Heo comen out of þe wodes sone, and of þe roches aboute.
So þat Costantyn hadde sone Gret power y nough, Ar. power y now,
And toward þis luþer men Norþward sone drow.
Hii Ar. He cudde þat Hii Ar. heo were men, & slowe Faste to Ar. to gronde,
þe prude Of this luther men hii batide in a stounde Ar. of Scottes & Picars abouten in a stonde.
For heo flowe þat myȝte fle, and some fel to gronde.
Heo myȝte Truly seigh tho, hure peer hii hadde y founde Ar. segge, wen heo come home, þat heo hadde here pere y fonde.
To Yrlond heo flowe aȝeyn, & elles wyder heo myȝte.
Heo ne þouȝte not a god while with þe Brytones to fyȝte.
þe Brytones nome þo Costantyn, & glade þoru all þyng
In þe town of Rectius Silchestre cum Galfr. Mon. At Cirecestria in Aluredo Beverlacensi, quem de∣floravit Galfridus. Cicestre crowned hym Desunt Ar. to here″ kyng.
The lond was tho wel y kept in pais Ar. þis was so wel y wist in pes, with oute strif,
þat þer ne come ne Scottes þider, ne Picardes Ar. Pycars al ys lyf.

þre Sones hadde this Constan∣tyn, Constans [Constans quoque in Aluredo Bev. & Galfr. Mon.] het that on, Aurelie Ambrose the other, the thridde Uter Pendragon. Constans his el∣deste Ar. sones he hadde al so, Costantyn was on,
And Aurely and Uter, gode children echon.
Costanteyn, ys eldeste sone, in Gode's seruise
Monk he made at Wynchestre, & dude as þe wyse.
God mon he was y now, and gode lawes forþ caste,
And god pais Was in his tyme, while his lyf y laste Ar. wes al ys lyf, F. ac. & to lute wyle þat laste.
For þer com a Picte Ar. Pycard, þat ys maners wel Wuste, Ar. wiste,
And þat he louede wel y now, & muche to hym truste.

He ladde hym into an Postremo, cum x. anni praeterissent, venit quidam Pi∣ctus, qui in obsequium suum fuerat, & quasi secretum collo∣quium habiturus, in virgulto quodam semotis cunctis eum cultro interfecit Galfridus Mon. orchard, For consail as hit were, And to speke Ar. as yt gret ned were
To speke wyþ hym priueliche, þat noman ywar nere.
Ac þo heo were al bi hem selue, & no mon hem neyȝ,
He drow ys knyf, & slow þe kyng, þat no man Hit ne seigh Ar. yt y seyȝ.
He was Anon Ar. sone forþ y went, er any mon were war.
And þo me hadde al y sought, þe kyng lay ded þar.
þo was þis lond kyngles, wat halt yt to telle longe?
Gret word was among þat folk, ho myȝte þe crowne fonge.
For þe eldoste sone monk was, & The othur two Ar. þe twei ȝonge were,
And to nyme For∣ther of his kyn no ryght men thoughte hit nere Ar. ferrore of ys kynde no ryȝt nere.

VORTIGER, The luther swike, Ar. þe quoynte swike, þat was erl of Cronica Latina vocat eum ducem Gewiseorum Ar. in margine. Et quidem Consul Gewissorum in Aluredo Bev. At in Galfr. Mon. consul Gewiseorum, i. Orientalium Anglorum. Corne∣wail,
Forto do A swykeldom he caste hym sanz faille. To the monek at Wynchestre sone he wende y wis Ar. a swykedom no conseil schulde hym fail.
To þe sone þat was monk to Wynchestre he wende y wis.
"Lo," (he seide) "now þou Sukst Ar. syst, þat þi fader ded ys,
"And þi breþeren to ȝonge beþ to a fonge þe crowne,
"And þei þou be in oþer cloþes, þi ryȝte Is nought ther Ar. nys not þer downe,
"Wel Thugh wost Ar. me Nec alium video in progenie tua, quem populus in regem promoveret Galfr. Mon. wot eldest þou art, & myd best ryȝt kyng al so.
"ȝef þou wolt Wel Ar. wol be my frend, & bi my red al do,
"Ich wole brynge The people in wille, Ar. þat folk in wille, to crowne þe to kyng.
"And þei þin ordre be þer aȝeyn, þer to ich wole it brynge.
"þo monk was joyful y now, þo he hurde þis,
"And bi het hym, ȝef it were so, euer more to be al hys.
Out of ys abyt anon Vortiger hym drow,
And cloþes As a kyng Ar. as to kyng bi come, dude on him faire ynowȝ.
And bi fore al þe Parlement to London he gan hym brynge,
And seide he was purest eyr, to be crowned Deest Ar. to″ kynge.
No mon ne myȝt wel it wyþ segge. Me may the ryght y se, That he ne is ver∣rei heir, Ar. me may ryȝt y se,
Wan he was þer, & was pur eyr, þei he hadde Adde y be cum Ar. monk.
Upon hym self a peril hit were, but he hit wolde do. The heigh Ar. Up hym self þe perel were, bote yt myȝte wel do.
þo hey men þoru Vortiger Assentede alle ther to Ar. a fong hym alle þer to.
þe erchbischop of London Gwẏthe∣lyn Ar. Gocelyn was þo ded,
And non oþer Hym crouny wolde, theigh Vortiger hem bed Ar. nolde hym crowne, for al þat þe erl bed.
For he hadde so longe in ordre be, & so was out y broȝt.
For al þat Yut Vortiger wolde by leue nought, that hym self ne croune hym, and made hym kyng ryght tho, And were hit ryght othur wough, yut hit was y do Ar. Vortiger nolde bi leue yt noȝt,
Ac hym self hym crownede, & made hym kyng so.
þe sacryng was lute worþ, and naþeles yt was y do.
þo he was kyng ymad, ys hest he made a non,
þat clanliche to Vortiger ys men Aboughwed Ar. abuyde echon.
Deest Ar. For″ hymself he Wolde thenke on nought, Ar. nolde þenche noȝt, bute take hym al on honde.
For he cowþe wel bet þan he gouerne such a londe.
þo bi þouȝte Vortiger mest þoru alle þyng,
How he myȝte do quoynteliche, þat he hym selue were kyng.
For that E∣uere was his thought, Ar. euer ys þoȝt, and þer fore þe monk he nom
To Be kyng. for Ar. kyng be. for he was nyce and kowþe no wisdom,
And ys twei breþren were broȝt out of cradel vnneþe.
And þe heye men mest of þe lond were y broȝt to deþe
Myd batailes & myd oþer wo, þer fore he was so prowt,

The kyng hym self was but a shade, & let him al one al out. And to the kyng Ar. And þe kyng Totum nam{que} dispositioni ejus regnum commissum fuerat, & Constans rex dicebatur, qui nisi pro umbra principis asta∣bat Galfr. Mon. nas bute a schade, & let hym worþe al out.
To þe kyng he seide, þat he moste ys castles astore,
þenne wolde ys fon aboute Douty Ar. doute hym þe more.
And for þe Pictes Ar. Picars were ys fon, some he wolde take
To be pryue with þe kyng, for þilke schulde make
Here felawes, þat were leued at home, to loue þat lond þe bet.

Ac Ecce occulta occulti amici proditio. Non enim id laudabat, ut salus inde proveniret Constantis, sed quia sciebat, Pictos gentem esse instabilem, & ad omne scelus paratam Galfr. Mon. naþeles þer fore Was hit nought what hit was al by set, Ar. nas yt noȝt þo yt wes al bi set,
Ac for þei louede not þe kyng, & in trayson were quoynte,
And that Ar. þat heo schulde þe kyng sle, wen heo come To the Ar. vp þe poynte.
þe kyng grantede al ys wil, and for ys gode He wende Ar. wende.
Aftur an hundred Pictes to Ar. Picars into Scotlond he sende
By certeyn messageres, so þat heo gonne brynge
