An hundred Pictes soudeours to by leue with oure kynge, And to be most preue with hym thurgh this Vortiger. Of the kynge's tresour he delt fer and ner, Ac most to the Pictes Ar. An hundred knyȝtes of Picars, þat bi leuede mid oure kynge,
Of mest priue men, þoru þis luþer Vortiger.
And þe kynge's tresour he delde eke a boute fer & ner,
And mest to þe Picars, for to hem mest loue he drow.
Myd alle þat he wolde hym self he made hym bi loued ynow.
Alle The seruantes of the kyng Ar. þat seruede þe kyng, þoru hym Were made echone Ar. were echone,

Ita ut eum pro rege haberent. Adulantes igitur ei per plateas psallebant, di∣gnus est Vortigernus impe∣rio, dignus est sceptro Bri∣tanniae, Constans vero indig∣nus Galfr. Mon. So þat ech mon was a boute for to paye hym one,
And Synge Ar. songe al day bi þe strete As for Ar. al for hys honour,
"Worþi were Vortiger To be kyng or emperour Ar. to kyng oþer emperour.
þo þis Vortiger hadde This Ar. þat folk al On Ar. in ys hond,
He seyde, he moste wende awyle out of þis lond,
To purchace more tresour þe kyng for to spene,
For he nadde noȝt y nowȝ, ys knyȝtes to sustene.
And Of the Pictes tok his leue, and of othur there, Ar. atte Picars nom ys leue, and at oþer þere,
And wende hom Ad hospitium suum Galfr. Mon. to His contre in sorwe as hit were Ar. hys fir, sori as he were.
þer was sorwe and deol ynow among al þe mayne,

For he schulde from hem Wende, (that was so large and fre) And among the Pictes most, that were of luther thought, That he hadde do so muchel honour, and louede the kyng nought Ar. wend, (for þer was no kyng bote he)
And nameliche among Picars, þat were of so luþer þouȝt,
þat he hadde do such honour, & þat ne louede þe kyng noȝt.
"Wat," heo seyden, "wat is This pro vs in Ar. vs to lete þis badde kyng
"Go þus o liue as a Shadewe, Ar. schade, þat nẏs worþ noþing?
Warto tarie we so longe, to quelle hym atten ende
þat Vortiger Myght be kyng, that to vs is so heynde? Ar. were kyng, þat a ȝen vs ys so hende?
In gret Wrath Ar. wayþe & hastinesse to þe kynge's chaumber heo wende,
And smyten of hys hed, and to Vortiger yt sende.
Vortiger made deol y now, And wep fol sore ther fore Ar. and sori was þer fore:
Ac naþeles so glad he nas seþþe he was y bore.
For He hit hadde by compaced atte Ar. y compaced he hadde þat atte bi gynnyng,
First Tho he made the monek, þat nyce was, to kynge Ar. wen he broȝte on so nyce a mon to kyng.
And seþþe þo he lette ys fon & Pictes Ar. Picars to court brynge,
þat hatede muche þe kyng, And muche was for these thynge. And that he was Ar. & al was for þis þinge.
And þo he was so large & hende of hys ȝiftes al so.
Tho he hadde al his wille, when this was Ar. þo hadde he al ys wille, for when yt was al ydo,
Omittit Ar. And″ to suc ende yt was y come, As he cast in his thought. And euere he made hit so queynte, that me wiste hit nought Ar. as he hadde y compaced in ys þoȝt.
And naþeles he feynede hym, þat me vnder ȝet yt noȝt.
At London þis kyng was y slaw. he let þo nyme anon Decolla∣tio Picto∣rum.
Alle the Pictes thurgh juggement, and hefdede hem echon Ar. þe Picars, & þoru jugement let smyt of þe hedes echon.
þer he kudde That he Ar. wat he was, vn kynde schrewe & quoynte.
And al was, that me ne sholde aspie his falshede in no poynte. Ac natheles some hit vnderyede, & ne leuede Ar. Ac al he dude, þat me ne vnder ȝet in swykdom in no poynte.
And naþeles men yt trowede, and leuede not ys glose.
þe kynge's Yonge bretheren, Uter and Aurelie Ambrose, Ar. re∣ctius. breþren, Aurele and Ambrose,
Dradde, for here eritage, ymorþred for to be.
And Hii, Ar. heo, that hem hadde In warde, ther fore hem goune bẏ se. To the lasse Brutayne hii wende to Budic the kyng, Ar. to ward, þer fore gonne by se,
And to þe lasse Breteyne wende to þe kyng,
And he Hem let wardy wel, Ar. susteynede hem wel, for drede of þis þinge.
þo Vortiger al one was, and no pere Hadde in londe, Ar. nad a londe.
Sone he lette hym Crouny Ar. crowne kyng, & þe power nom on honde.
Princes ouer al aboute of Euery Ar. eche kyndom
Speke hym vnel, & hatede hym for hys Swikeldom Ar. swikedom.
þe Pictes Ar. Picars were wroþ eke, and Hatede Ar. þratten hym ynow,
That he with so vile deth hure fe∣lawes he slough Ar. For he myd such vnkyn dede heore felawes slow.
From þe lasse Bretayne eke hym com word ylome,
þat The two Ar. þo twei children gret power to hem nome,
And That hii stale∣worthe were, as of hure age, Ar. þat hit stronge childre were of here age,
And þat þei wolde hyder come, to wynne here heritage.
Such strong tyþinges in sorwe and in sore
Broȝt þis false kyng, and er þe lenger þe more.
Horn Ar. HORS and Hengist bothe, þat twei breþre were,
Come to Kent þilke tyme, and a riuede þere,
Myd þre schip ful of Men pro knygtes in Ar. At militibus in Galfr. Mon. knyȝtes y armed wel ynow.
The tydẏnges hough they come, were in contreie a brod drough. The kyng Ar. þo þis folk was on lond, forþ into Kent hit drow.
þo kyng was þo at Canterbury, and herde her of anon:
Bi fore hym he lette brynge These men Ar. þis knyȝtes″ echon.
The Ar. þo kyng bi huld hem faste ynow, (for it muchel men were)
And nameliche þe twei breþren, (Nam ipsi prae ceteris & nobilitate & decore praenitebant Galfr. Mon. for so muchel non þer nere.)
He Ax∣ede hem, whans hii were, & ho Ar. ascode hem, of wanne þei, and ho″ hem þider broȝte,
And for wat encheson heo come & wat þing þei soȝte?
"Sire kyng," (quoþ Hengist, þat for al oþer spek y wys) Hengistus.
"Saxonia tellus edi∣dit nos, una ex regionibus Germaniae Galfr. Mon. Of Saxonie we beþ y bore, Of Germanye that is Ar. þat of Germanie ys.
"þe maner ys of þilke lond, þat wen þer ys forþ ybroȝt
"So muche folk De∣sunt Ar. of men,″ þat The Ar. þo lond may Hem susteyne Ar. susteyne noȝt.
"Deest Ar. þo″ heye men of The Ar. þo lond schulle come bi fore þe kyng,

"And Alle the yonge bachelrie me shal to fore hym bryng. The stalewortheste me shal by loth and by chois also Chese, & sende hem out of londe, Ar. alle þo ȝonge men of þe lond lete bi fore hym brynge.
"þe strengeste me schal bi choys and bi lot al so
"Chese out, and sende in to oþer lond,″ here beste forto do.
"And Hii shulleth Ar. heo schulle be such, þat no prince Ne der Ar. dorre hem for sake,
"But Ar. Ac for heore prowesse gladliche in to here seruise take.
"þis cas ys to vs y come, y chose we beþ þer to,
"And for ther was to muche folk, oure beste we mote do. And to be Ar. For so muche ys in the lond, oure beste forto do.
"And forto be maistres of þis folk we beþ y chose & ynome
"Mi broþer & ich, (for wo beþ of dukes kyn y come.)
"For þoru our Godes in to þe se we wende ich vnderstonde,
"And Mercurius haþ vs y lad into This Ar. þi londe. Mercurius.
þo þe kyng herde nempne Mercurius in þis cas,
He askede, wat God and wat þing Mercurius was?
"Oure bi leue (quoþ That Ar. þis oþer) in þe hye God Ar. Godes ys y do,
"Saturnus and Jupiter, and al þe oþer al so,
"þat vp holdeþ þe world, & in Mercurius mest y wys,
"Omittit Galfridus Mon. þe heye God,″ þat in oure tonge Woden y clepud ys.

"Lege, þer uer vr eldore, i. e. therefore our elders &c. Nam in Galfr. Mon. huic veteres nostri dicaverunt quartam feriam septimanae, quae usque in hodiernum diem nomen Wodnesdei de nomine ipsius sortita est. þer ner vrel dore him bi toke of þe woke þe ferþe day,
"In honour of hym y clepud in oure tonge Wednesday.
"Aftur hym we honoureþ Venus mest, þat Frie y clepud ys Venus.
"In oure tonge, & in þe wyke Friday for hym y wys.
"Her of ȝe schul vnderstonde, þat in þe firmament beþ
"Planetes, y liche cler sterres, seuene, as ȝe seþ:
"Saturnus and Jubiter, Mars and þe Sonne y wys,
"Venus and Mercurius, and þe Mone lowest ys.
"Aftur ech of hem in þe wike y clepud ys a day:
"First Of the Sonne, & so forth the senethe Ar. os Sonne, & so of oþere and þe seneþe Saturday.
"And for weder, & oþer Thynges Ar. þing on erþe, aftur hem muche is,
"These mysbyleuede Ar. þis mẏs bi leuede men hem clepede Godes while y wis.
"Sori ich am" (quoþ Vortiger) "þo he herde þis.
"For ȝoure bi leue, þat Ye bileueth, no bileue is. But of youre come ich Ar. ȝe segget, for no bileue yt nys.
Ac for ȝoure coming ich am glad, ho so ow hider ladde,
Were hit God, or eny othur, for al nede ych hadde Ar. Were yt God, were yt oþer, for nede ich hadde.
For ich am myd my fon In euery half Ar. on ech half by set,
Andȝef ich hem may ouer come þoru ȝou þe bet,

Ich yough wole with me witholde, & gret honour yut do, And yiftes yiue ynough of londes, & othur catelles also. Hii made a certayn couenant, so that hii were at on; Ar. Ich ȝou myd me at holde, & in grete richesse ȝou do
Of ȝiftes, and of chatews, and of londes al so.

Heo Paruerunt illico barbari, & foedere confirmato in curia ipsius remanserunt. Nec mora emergentes ex Albania Picti, exercitum valde grandem mit∣tunt, aquilonaresque partes insulae vastare coeperunt Galfr. Mon. maden certeyne couenaunt þat heo were al at on;
So þat þei bi leuede forþ with Our pro þe in Ar. þe kyng echon.
Hit was not longe Afterward that the Pictes ne come Ar. þer aftur þat þis Picars ne come
Out of Scotlond Souþward, and townes faste nome. Bellum.
Tho the tydyng of this thyng to Vortiger come. Ar. þe tyþing her of to oure kyng com,
þe wey mid al ys power aȝen hem faste he nom.
Strong bataile heo smyte þer, ac þe Saxones anon
So god were, þat þe oþere bi gonne to fle echone.
þo Vortiger þoru hem hadde þe maistrie,
He ȝef hem ȝiftes grete ynow, and dude ys corteyse.
Hengist, þat here maistre was, he ȝaf in Lyndeseẏe
Londes faire, and rentes and Tounes, & gret nobleye Ar. townes grete and heye,″
Quibus sese & commili∣tones suos sustentaret Galfr. Mon. War þoru hym & ys men In to rẏchesse Ar. in fair wareson he broȝte.
And yut tho he hadde al this, forthermore he thoughte Ar. þo Hengist hadde þis, forþer more he þoȝte.
þo he hadde þe kyng in priuete al clene at ys wille,
"Sire," he seide, "of derne Thyng pro cas in Ar. cas ich wol þe warne stille. Petieio Hengisti.
"þine fon beþ in ech half, & þis ys þe meste doute,
"þat þin owne men ne loueþ þe noȝt, þat þe beth aboute.
"Heo þretneþ þe stille, & seggeþ heo wolleþ Vocu∣lam hanc erasit in Ar. eadem, ut videtur, manus quae & scrip∣sit. þe″ brynge
"þe twei breþre from Breteyne, & Crouny on to kynge Ar. crowne þat on kynge:
"Si placet tibi, mittamus in patriam nostram, & invitemus milites ex ea, &c. Galfr. Mon. þer fore ich The rede, that we sende to my Ar. rede, þat me sende into my contrei ywys
"To Sic in Cod. Har∣leyano. At Saxonie in Ar. Saxoine aftur more help, for help y now þer ys.
For If thugh hast power y nough, thugh maist be Ar. habbe þou power ynow, þou myȝt be glad & bliþe.

Ac oþing ich Wole bidde the, & thugh wolt me lithe. Bidde what thugh wolt, quath the kyng, ich wole the graunte ywis, Elles forsothe ich were to blame, ẏf hit to graunty is. And fetthe [l. fetche] help al that thugh maist, that be of good araye, And ich wole hure while yelde, and hure huyre paye. Hengis faire hym thonked tho, and his heed bowed a doun Ar. wolde bidde þe, þat þou me woldest tyþe.

"Send Ad haec Vortigernus, "Mitte ergo legatos tuos ad Germaniam, & invita quos vo∣lueris, & pete à me quod de∣sideras, & nullam repulsam patieris Galfr. Mon. aftur help," quoþ þe kyng, "þat þou me noȝt bi traie,
"And wole heore while ȝelde, so þat scholle holde hem wel paie.
"And bidde of me wat þou wolt, & ich wol þe grante ywis,
"For elles ich were vnkynde, ȝef it to grante ys.
Hengist faire hym þonkede, and hys hed lowtede a doun.
"þou hast," he seide, "ȝeue me mony a fayr town.
"And naþeles such þing Haue ich nought, as a duk Ar. nabbe y noȝt, as it to duk bi come.
"For wan ich am A duke's sone, me thinketh hit were to done Ar. duke's sone, yt bi comeþ to me″
"For to Haue Ar. habbe som Deest Ar. gret″ cite or castel me to Where Ar. ware,
"And, yf that ich nede hadde, kepe me fro dere. Therfore, Ar. War inne y myȝte to þyn nede habbe my folk ȝare.
þer fore,″ as ich am þi knyȝt, & Redy to the also, Ar. prest to þi nede al so,
Grante me Cite or castel my nede inne to do Ar. castel oþer cite þi nede in to do.
"Hengist," quoþ þe Kyng, hit were me nought to done Ar. kyng þo, "ner me not to done
"Such þyng, as þou me biddest to graunte þe, so sone.
"For þou art mon off strange lond, & Cristene mon non.
"And eke, þei ich wolde, my barones wolde yt with segge echon.
"Sire, grante me þonne," quoþ Hengist, "ȝef yt ys þi wille,
"As much as with a bole huyde ich may ouer tille, Ar. As muche place, as myd a þong ich may a boute tille,
"Quo me, si opus fuerit, re∣cipiam Galfr. Mon. þat ich þer Vppon maẏ a siker place Ar. vppe mowe a siker bold″ a rere,
"þat ich Myghte in thyne seruise me wytie and nede were Ar. mowe in þi seruise wytie, ȝef yt nede were.
þe kyng ne hulde þat bute a Lite, & grauntede al his bone Ar. lutel, he grantede hẏs bone.
Hengist sende in to hys contre aftur more power sone.
þo carf he a bole hyde smale al To one thonge Thurgh out, while hit wolde y laste, and that was somdel longe Ar. to a þong þongca∣ster.
þoru out, wil he wolde laste, & þo was he somdel long.
In an hard Roche's stode Ar. Saxorum locum habet Galfr. Mon. roche stude ys þong aboute he drow,
And þer wyþ inne al to ys wille markede place ynow,
And rerde þer an castel god y now and strong,

And Thwong castel, or Tancastel, cleped is for the thwong. Thenne come ther out of Germanye vnder that, ich wene, Charged with or∣pede men, shipes eightetene Ar. þat þangcaster, oþer Tangcaster, yclepud was for þe þong.
þer come out of Germanie vnder þat, ych wene,
Y charged mid gode knyȝtes, schippes eiȝtetene.
And Rowen, Hengiste's doȝter, among hem y broȝt was,
þat fairor wommon nower a boute in no lond nas.
þo þis castel A redy was Ar. ȝare was, Hengist þe king bi soȝte
To come and se his castel, and men he hadde y broughte. The kyng Ar. To come to hys castol, & se þe knyȝtes þat he broȝte.
þo kyng com þider priueliche, & These Ar. þis knyȝtes y sey,
And þis castel, Deest Ar. so″ sone a rerd, so Noble pro strong in Ar. strong and so hey.

With al Ar. Mid al Ut vero regiis epulis refectus fuit, egressa est puella de thalamo, aureum ciphum, plenum vino, ferens. Accedens deinde pro∣pius, flexis genibus dixit, louerd ching woschail Galfr. Mon. he was wel a payed and bi leuede atte mete.
þis mayde out of chambre com, þo Hii hadde y yete Ar. þei hadden y ȝete,
With a coppe of gold, fol of wyn, syde drow hire tail

A kne sheo sette hure byfore the kyng, & seide, "sire wassail Ar. A kne to þe kyng heo seyde, Vide Seldeni Notas in Dray∣toni Poly-olbion, pag. 153. ubi locum quendam è Roberto nostro (alio tamen usus MS.) adduxit, innuit{que} Louerd kyng was-heil idem esse quod Lord kyng a health; Drinc-heile vero idem quod Drinke the health. Verum his de rebus scripserunt plures, in quibus & ipse numerandus est Somnerus. Atqui tot auctorum verba non est cur exscribam. Sat est si ea tantummodo in medium profe∣ram, quae observavit in Itine∣rario Cantiano (p. 20.) doctis∣simus Lambardus. idque ea potissimum de caussa, quod & illum hac occasione plane con∣sulendum esse monuerit erudi∣tissimus Spelmannus in Glos∣sario. [Hengist] espying there∣fore, that king Vortiger was much delighted in womens companie, and knowing wel, that sine Cerere & Libero, fri∣get Venus, he bad him to a solempne banquet, and after that he had (according to the maner of Germanie yet conti∣nuing) well plied him with pots, hee let slip before him a faire gentlewoman, his owne daughter, called Roxena, or Rowen, which being instructed before hande how to behaue hir selfe, most amiablie pre∣sented him with a goblet of wine, saying in hir own lan∣guage, wessail Lorde king, The first wasseling cup. that is to say, bee merie Lord king: with which hir daliance, the King was so delighted, that he not onely vouchsafed to pledge hir, but desired also to performe it in the right maner of hir owne countrey. And there∣fore he answered (as he was taught) vnto hir againe, drinke merily. Which when shee had done, himselfe tooke the cup, and pledged hir so hartely, that from thencefoorth hee could neuer be in rest, vntill he had obtained hir to wife, The issue of an ungodly marriage. little weighing, either how deepely he had endaungered his conscience in matching himselfe with a heathen wo∣man, or how greatly he had hazarded his Croune by joyn∣ing handes with so mightie a forein Nation. "lord kyng wasseyl.Wasseyl.

þe kyng bi huld hire Faste ynough Ar. swiþe ynow, & wondrede hire Fair∣hede Ar. unica voce. Nec ta∣men idem quod forehead esse judicarim. Non aliud enim plane est quam facies pulchra. id quod è Galfrido Monumetensi constat, qui sic ait: At ille, visa facie puellae, admiratus est tan∣tum ejus decorem, & incaluit. fair hede.

And of men of hure langage couthe he axede what sheo sede? A non men tolde the kyng fore what was to seye wassail, And that he sholde to hure that tyme answere ther to drynk hail. Drynk hail, seide the kyng a ye, Ar. For so fair wommon nuste he non. He askede wat heo seide?
Men, þat knew þe langage, seide, wat was wassayl,
And þat he scholde þat broȝte onswere, "drynkhayl.
"Drinkhayl, quoþ þis kyng aȝen, & bed hire drinke anon.

þe coupe He toke of hure anon, and a mong echon Kussed hure & a doun hure sette, & gladly dronk hure hail. And thus was here in this londe furst y knowe wassail Ar. he nom seþþe of hire among hem echon,
And custe hire, & sette hire a doun, & glad dronk hire hail.
And þat was lo! in þis lond þe firste vassayl,
As in langage of Saxonie, þat me myȝte euer y wyte,
And so Wel yut hit paieth the folk, that hit is nought for yite Ar. wel he paiþ þat folk aboute, þat he nys not ȝet for gete.

No sire, ne be þe day so Long, and sitteth murye a benche, And of the nyght yut nymeth ther to, drynke ther by to shenche, On an holy prechoure's word hii wol nought so wel theuche, As hii doth of that mury word of that sely wenche. The kyng on hure gan madde so, that anon Ar. long, þe while heo sitteþ o benche,
And som of þe nyȝt nimeþ þer to, þe drynke forto sthenche,
Of an holi prechoure's word heo nolde not so ofte þenche,
As of the muri word, þat hem þinkeþ of þe sely wenche.
So foul lechour was þe kyng, that anon″ in þe howse
He willede, for foul lecheri, þis mayde Pro, forto. forte spouse.
Hengist wiste wel ys wille, And knew his nycete, And grauntede al for felonye his doughtur his wif to be, By so the kyng hym wolde yiue the Ar. & þat he wes hastyf.

He grantede Sed omnibus unum consilium fuit, ut puella daretur regi, & ut peteret pro ea provinciam Cantiae ab illo. Nec mora, data fuit puella regi Wortigerno, & provincia Cantiae Hengisto, &c. Galfridus Mon. in hys felonye ys doȝter to be ys wyf,
For wat þe kyng ȝeue hym þe″ contre of Kent y wis.
þe kyng in ys foule wille grantede al þis,
And weddede þis mayde This was a sory cas Ar. in a wel luþer cas,
For þat he was Cristene, and heo a paynen was.
The people was Ar. þat lond wes vnel y paied þer wyþ, & ys þre sones also,
Vortimer, and Katigern Ar. Catigen, and Passen þer to.
Four hundred ȝer and fourti and Sic plane in Cod. nostro Har∣leyano. At fyue in Ar. nyene, ich vnderstonde,
Yt wes of grace, þat þe Saxones þus come to þis londe.
þo were among Cristenemen The hethene thus Ar. þis paynes þus y menged,
þat mys bileue In al Ar. into al þis lond a mong men was y sprenged.
Hengist seide to þe kyng, "Sire, þou myȝte y se,
"þat ich am in stude of þi fader, & þi conseiler schal be. Consilius. Hengisti.
"Do al aftur my conseil, and þou schalt þoru me
"Ouer come al þi fon, to soþe ich segge þe.
"Sende we ȝet aftur my sones Octa & Ose, Ar. Octe and Ebise, Duo filii Hengesti.
"þat quaynte werroures heþ, and stalworþe and wyse.
"In þe Norþ half ȝef hem lond, wher þou wolt by se,
"þat heo mowe bi tuene þe and þe Scottes be.
"þenne þou Maist Ar. myȝt siker be by Souþ Homber ywys.
þe kyng he sende aftur hem, and grauntede al þis.
So þat mid þre hundred schipes heo ariuede here,
Ful of trauaillyng men, this was gret power Ar. Ful of armes and of men, here was gret power.
þe kyng wel Fawe Ar. fayn ȝaf hem lond, as Hengist hym bi soȝte,
And Hengist euer mo and mo schippes hyder broȝte.
þo þe Brytones þis ẏ seye, of treson heo were in drede.
For þo lond was al mid hem y fuld, þer fore þe kyng Hii Ar. heo bede,
þat he schulde hym vnder stonde, & out of This londe Ar. lond hem do.
For yt ne bi com noȝt to payns among Cristen men be so.
For yt was Cristendam, & in mony studes me nuste
Wuch was on, ne wuch was oþer, ne to wam me myȝte truste.
Some faderes were Cristene, & þo moderes heþene were.
Me nuste to weþer heo bi come þe children þat heo bere.
þe kyng louede þe Saxones, for loue of ys wyue,
And nolde, for al þe Britones, out of This Ar. hys londe hem dryue.

SEYNT Germayn bysshop of Au∣ferne, as ich vnderstonde, And of Treueros seynt Lup, come to this londe, For mysbileue a mong men, and othur here∣sye, That me clepede Arriane and also Pelagye, And prech∣ede the people, as nede was, and faire miracles wroughte, So that thurgh hem Cri∣stendom to betere stat was broughte. And hii a forcede hem Ar. Germayn þe bischop to þis londe com,
For mysbileue þat tyme, & to amende Cristendom,
And prechede, as yt nede was, & faire miracles wroȝte,
So þat þe Cristene men in beter stat he broȝte.
And heo a forcede hom″ þe more, þe heþene a wey to dryue.
And wold nought leue for the kyng, Ar. He nolde bileue here porpos for þe kyng, ne for ys wyue.
Heo for soke þe kyng al out, and binome Hym his Ar. ys power,
And hys eldest sone made kyng, þat hatte Vortimer.
þis Vortimer with gret power and god ernest ynow,
þoru conseil of Seynt Germayn, aȝen The pro þis in Ar. þis heþene drow.
The senethe yer ther af∣ter hit was, that hii Ar. þo sene ȝer yt was aftur, þat heo to londe come,
þe kyng was, God i þonk, a boue in four batailes, þat heo nome.
Alle heo were in one ȝer. atte firste, withoute one,
Catigen, þe kynge's broþer, myd hys men echone,
Asailede Hors and hys ost, so þat heo fouȝte faste,Bellum Hors.
So þat þis Catigen yslawe was atte laste.
þo kyng for ys broþer deþ sori was y now.
To þis Hors he smot anon, & among al ys folk hym slow.
þo þis strong mon was slawe, þat so strong was in fyȝt,
Ys men bi gonne to fle Deest Ar. and″ fayn þat heo mygt.
þe þridde batail, þat heo smyte, was ryȝt Upon Ar. vp the se,
þer com þe kyng myd ys ost, and Hengist hym a ȝe.
þer was batail strong y now, and mest yt was vp tweye,
Up þe kyng and Hengist, þat were so stronge beye.
þo stronge dyntes, þat heo smyten, grisliche yt was to se. Fuga Hengisti.
So þat Hengist bi gan atte laste to fle.
He, þat neuer er ne fley, fond þer ys pere.
He fley in to þe yle of Tenet, he no dorste a bide no ner.
ȝet eft heo fouȝten in þe se, and by side þere;
Ac þe Britones at eche tyme þe maistrye a wey bere.
The Sax∣ones sey, that they ne myghte a yenst the Brutones stonde, Ar. þo Saxones heo seye, þat heo myȝte no leng at stonde,
To þe kyng þei sende, þat þei Myghte Ar. most wende hom to here londe.
þo heo were alle henne y went, here was joye y now,
þe kyng ȝef ys men grete ȝiftes, & gret loue to hem drow,
And let arere chirches vp, þat þe schrewes a doun caste,
And bi gan to make a muri lond, ac to lute wyle yt laste.
þe Deuel hadde enuẏ þer to, þat he susteynede Cristendam,
And in ys Step∣modere's herte sone his In he nom Ar. stepmoder herte ys woniyng he nom.
So þat The Ar. þo luþer wommon of poyson hire bi þouȝte,
And apoysnede þe godeman, and to Deest Ar. þe″ deþe hym broȝte.
The kyng, tho he sholde be ded, his knyghtes let of sende, And shewede hem of his stat, and of his lyf is ende, And yaf hem goold Ar. þis kyng, þo he sey þen deþ, ys knyȝtes he let of sende,
And schewede hem al þe wey wyder he schulde wende,
And ȝef hem gold and″ soluer, and ȝiftes riche and gode,

And Audaces autem & bellicosos juvenes, qui ei in debellationi∣bus suis astare solebant, horta∣batur, ut pro patria pugnan∣tes, eam ab hostium irruptione tueri niterentur Galfr. Mon. bad hem for þe loue of God, þat heo hem vnderstode,
And Stabelliche helde hem to hepe, forto sauy that lond, Ar. stabliche holde to gedere, to saue þat lond,
þat neuer þe luþer payns yt hadde eft an hond.
And if he langor myght haue leued, he wolde haue drad ryght nought. But whan hit ther to come were, he were to deth y brought, Ar. And ȝef he myȝte libbe lenger, he nolde drede noȝt.
And wan it alles so was, þat he wes to deþe y broȝt,
He bed, wan he were ded, þat me schulde ys bodi nome,
And burie yt At an hauene, þer the he∣thene men vp come, In a tumbe swithe an heigh, þat me myghte hit fer y se, Ar. þe hauene, wer þe payns come,
In a temple swiþe heye, þat heo myȝt yt fer yse,
þat heo, for drede of þe syȝte, myȝte sone fle.
Hard Ar. Hardi was is herte to hem, wen he wolde þat þei hadde
Drede of ys bodi ded, As they a lyue hadde Ar. wan heo o liue hym dradde.
þer was deol & sorwe y now, þo þis gode mon was ded.
Ac noþeles heo ne buriede hym noȝt, as he hym self bed.
For hem þoȝte yt nas bute a wille, ac, as hee hem by þoȝte,
In London myd honour þis bedi an erþe broȝte.
VORTIGER, þe luþer mon, þo hys sone ded was,
Underfong aȝeyn to hym þe kyndam, alas!
For sone, þoru ys wyue's red, aftur Hengist he sende,
þat he þider to hym with Ut iterum in Bri∣taniam rediret; attamen priva∣tim & cum paucis Galfr. Mon. simple folk wende.
For he dradde, ȝef he hadde to gret power an honde,
þat þer schulde a rise strif by twene hym and þe londe.
þo Hengist herde telle, þat Vortimer was ded, Reditus Hengisti.
He gaderede power y now, and sone now ys red.
And þre hundred þousond Men yarmyd with hym he nom, And with al hure atyr to this londe he com. Whan the kyng Ar. men mid y armod he nom,
And mid al þe atyl þer to in to þis lond he com.
þo þe kyng & ys consel wiste of This comp. Ar. ys grete companye,
Heo bi þouȝte & dradde sore, Deest Ar. þat″ it were for tricherie.
And naþeles he sende hem word a ȝen in ys felonye,
þat in gret loue hider he com, and no þoȝte no vilanye,
Bute for drede of Vortimer, Lest he a lyue Ar. last he o liue were,
Such folk myd hym he brouȝte, for he hadde of hym fere.
Ac wen he nas o liue noȝt, he bad þe kyng be hende,
þat he myȝte myd ys folk Upon his Ar. vp ys lond wende,
Bi fore hym and ys conseil, In certeyn Ar. a certeyn tyme and place,
With oute eny manere armes to fondy of his grace Ar. With any maner arme to fonde ys grace,
And þat The Ar. þo kyng of hys men at huld wuche he wolde,
And dryue aȝeyn ouer þe se þilke þat he nolde.
þe kyng was her wyþ wel ypayd, & sette hem þo day,
And al ys owe folk, þat heo come þe firste day of May
At Ambresburi, For to speke of this Ar. rectius. Et tamen Auc∣tori magis commodum, for to do (i. e. to make.) for to of þis þing som ende,
To at holde wuche he wolde of hem, & þe oþer aȝen sende.
þo þis folk in eyþer syde y war was of þe day,
In a newe maner Hengist þouȝt þe kyng & ys To by traye Ar. bi tray.
He hette al ys knyȝtes, þat myd hym þer were,
þat in ys hose stilleliche ych of hem a knyf bere,
And, wan heo to The assemble among the Brutones Ar. þis semble among þis Britones come,
þat ech of hem an hey mon in conseil to hym nome,
And swyþe faire speke with hym, & wan he þanne seyde,
"Nymeþ ȝoure saxes," Thanne a∣non with that ilke rede, Ech drough his knyf, & slough his felawe an vnywar, Ar. þat he a non mid þe dede Nymeþ owre sexes.
Drow ys knyf, and slow a non al an on ywar,
þat heo myȝt of þe hexte men þat lond make bar.
þis word was wel vnderstonde, And to hure day they come To Ambresbury on aithur side, as they the day nome. Sym∣pleliche the Brutones come for pees they vnderstode, Ar. so þat þo heo come
In eyþer syde to Ambrisbury, þo day þat heo nome,
And þe Brutones al simpliche in god pay, as heo vnderstode,
And Hengist spek with þe kyng, as yt were for gode,
And þo he say ys time wel, he gan to grede anon,
"Nymeþ ȝoure saxes," and ys men Tho anon echon Kaughte out hure longe knyues, and slough ther with to grounde, Ar. þer with echon
Kypte heore longe knyues, and slowe faste to gronde,
So þat heo slow Ita & Galfr. Mon. Sed thre Ar. cum Aluredo Bev. four hundred & sixti in astonde
Of erles and of barons þe Heighest Ar. hexte þat þer were.
Alas! þe deol to þis lond, Such Ar. wuch treson was þere?
Now ne kouþe þe Britones non Englisch y wys,
Ac þe Saxones speche it was, & þorw hem y come yt ys.
Hengist anon With that word the kyng to hym caughte Ar. mid þe word Et ilico Vortigernum accepit, & per pallium detinuit Galfr. Mon. þe kyng hente faste
Bi þe mantel, and anon to his fet hym Raughte Ar. caste.
So þat þis gode men were y broȝt myd treson to gronde,
Ac some, þat of scapede, mid stones, þat heo fonde,
And mid staues of hegges, defondede hem a boute,
And slow of þis luþer men mony on in þe route. Pugna.
ELDOL, erl of Gloucestre, That staleworthe man was, Hente a tronchon on his hond that hym com by cas, Ar. þat a strong knyȝt was,
Hente a strong leuour, þat hym a com at honde bi cas.
þo he say ys felawes ymorþred so viliche,
God ernest he nom to hym, and sturde hym harde liche.
He smot to gronde, & lyȝtliche he ne ȝef strok non,
þat he ne brak hed oþer arm, or som oþer bon.
He ne ȝef of hys lyf noȝt, ys felawes for to awreke,
So þat he slow in þe place, er ys staf gonne breke,
Sixti mon and tene, and wondede mony on,
And ȝet he of scapede o liue for hem euer ech on
And þe luþer folk, þat slowe þus þat folk myd tricherie.
The Ar. þo kyng þei bonde faste Anon pro y now in Ar. y now, þat rewliche he gan crie,
And so they gonne fare with hym, forte he swor his oth, Al hure wille for to do, were hym neuere so loth Ar. And defoulede hym myd bendes, forto he swor ys oþ,
Alle here wille euer eft to do, ner hym ner so loþ.
þo wende forþ þis luþer folk, and nome Town adjicit Ar. London,
And Euerwyk, and Lincolne, al With tresoun Ar. þoru þis treson.
And Deest Ar. seþþe″ Wynchestre bi Souþe, & oþer Omittit Ar. grete″ townes mo,
And robbede euer as heo wende, & slow, & dude gret wo.

þese were Oure olde fadres lo! of wham we buth y come, And with such trechourie this lond thus hii haueth ynome. Vor∣tiger this luthur kyng, that litel worth was tho, As he hadde of serued wel, hadde muche wo, And was let go a lyue. To Walis he wende sone, And axede tho of his consaillers, what best hym was to done? Ar. lo! our faderes, of wam we beþ of y come,
þat mid such traison habbeþ þis lond þus y nome.

VORTIGER, Cum igitur tandem tantam cladem inspexisset Vortigernus, se∣cessit in partes Cambriae, in∣scius quid contra nefandam gentem ageret. Vocatis de∣nique magis suis, consuluit illos, jussitque dicere quid faceret? &c. Galfr. Mon. oure feble kyng, þat lute was worþ þo,
As he it hadde of serued wel to lutel hadde of wo,
He flow in to Walis, þider he com sone,
He ascode of hys conselers wat was best to done?
Me radde hym, for ys casteles al hym bi nome were,
þat he in som siker stude a castel Sholde rere, Ar. bulde þere,
þat he myȝte sikerliche wyte hym from hys fon.
þe kyng A good place ther fore let Ar. a god stude þer to let seche out a non,
And let bygẏnne a castel of strong lym and ston, Ar. And bigan a strong castel of lym and off ston,
And of quoynte werkmen let hym brynge mony on.
In He∣refordshire vp the mont of Eirik [Eir Galfr. Mon.] ful high Was this castel by gon∣ne, vpon the water of Wigh. Tho hii bygonne the castel Ar. þo heo bi gonne þis castel,″ al þat heo made a day,
O morwe, wen þei come þer to, al clene þer downe it lay.
Euere more hit ferde thus, nere that werk so strong Ar. No beter sped heo, nere þat werk ner so strong.
þe kyng ascode at enchanteres, war on yt was ylong?

The kynge's enchaun∣tours seide hym tho, ther most a child be sought, That hadde neuere fader, and thuder hit moste be brought, And sle that child, and with the blood me sholde bysprenge the ston Ar. þe enchanteres seide, þat me a childe soȝte,
þat were y gete with oute fader, & þat me yt þider broȝte,
And slow yt, and mid þe blode bisprenge wel here ston″
And here morter, & yt scholde stonde þenne anon.
This thoughte hem won∣der for to do, & yut they left hit nought, Ar. Hem þoȝte yt was euel y do, ac heo bi leuede yt noȝt,
þat in mony a contrey such a child nas y soȝt. Invencio Merlini.
So þat some Of the Ar. þe messingeres to Kermerdyn come,
And Of children in the strete that playde they toke gome Ar. how children bi fore þe ȝate pleyede he toke gome.
þo seide on to That other, what myschaunce is the, Ar. an oþer, "Merlyn, wat ys þe,
"Quid mecum contendis fatue? Galfr. Mon. þou faderles schrewe wy Mysdoist thugh me? Ar. misdostow me?
"For ich am of Good men pro kynges in Ar. kynges ycome, & þou nart not worþ a fille.
"For þou Haddest neuere fader, Ar. naddest ner no fader, þer fore hold þe stille.
þo þe messageres herde þis, heo astynte þere,
And askede Of the men Ar. at men aboute, wat þat child were?

Men seyde, he hadde fader non, as hii couthe vnderstonde. His moder kynge's doughter was of i. Southwales
Demecie londe, And duelleth and [l. at] Seynt Petre's church, as a nonne there Ar. Adeo ut hod, sive had, pro bod reponerem. He ne bod neuer fader, heo seyde, þat me myȝte vnder∣stonde,
And ys moder a kynge's doȝter was of þilke londe,
And wonede at Seynt Petre's in a nonnery þere.
þo þe messageres herde þis, joyful y now þei were.
To þe baylys of þe toun hastiliche heo wende,
þat he þe moder and þe sone to þe kyng sende.
þo me wiste wat They Ar. heo were, me ne durste with segge it noȝt,
So þat þe moder & þe sone to þe kyng were y broȝt.

þe kyng Het Ar. bad þe wommon segge soþ, For no thyng shold heo lete, That heo ne told openlich, who þat child was by yete Ar. per∣inde ac si who idem quod how valeret. Illud tamen noto, in margine (ab eadem autem manu) voculam was adjectam esse, hac nota (viz. ⁁) in textu posita. þat heo noþing lete,
þat he ne seide in soþnesse, ho þat child bi gete.
"My lord Kyng, seide heo tho, the sothe ych sey the, Ar. kyng," quoþ þis oþer, "to þe soþe i segge it þe,
"þat neuer mon ney me Cam, þat hit by gat in me. And of on thyng ich wote, whan ich al one was In priue chaumbres with oute felawes, Ar. com, þat yt bi get on me.
"Ac of o þing ich wot, wan ich ofte was
"In chambre mid my felawes,″ þer com to me bi cas

"Folia octo in Ar. ex∣cisa esse deprehendo, in quo proinde de sequentibus, usque ad hanc notam ☞ (quam in margine apposuimus, utpote ad quam iterum occurrit Ar.) longe fusius quam in Codice Harleyano tractatum est. And swyþe fair mon with alle, & bi clupte wel softe,
"And semblant made fair ynow, & custe me wel ofte.
"þenne wende he forþ, as in schade, y nuste how ny ware.
"þo he hadde y siwed me longe in þis fare,
"Atte laste in forme of mon ofte he lay bi me,
"Ac oþer mon neuer non, to soþe y segge it þe.
þo þe kyng herde þis, gret wonder he þouȝte þere.
He asched at is clerkes, I. e. whether he might bi∣lieve it? Nam, si id, quod mulier dixerat, fieri potuisset, in Galfr. Mon. wer yt to leue were?
þe clerkes seide, þat yt is in philosophie y fonde,
þat þer beþ in þe eir an hey, fer fro þe gronde,
As a maner gostes, wyȝtes as it be,
And me may hem ofte on erþe in wylde studes y se,
And ofte in monne's fourme wymmen heo comeþ to,
And ofte in wymmen forme þei comeþ to men al so,
þat men clepuþ eluene, and perantre in þis maner
On of hem in þis wommon bi get þis child her.
þo Merlyn hadde al þis y herd, to þe kyng he sede:
"Sire kyng, wy dudest þou my moder & me bi fore þe lede!
"My enchantoures," quoþ þe kyng, "me habbeþ þer to yrad,
"þat a child, þat nadde no fader, bi fore me were y lad,
"And þat þe werk myd ys blod, þat we habbeþ on honde,
"Be sprenged þat falleþ adoun, & þenne yt schulde stonde.
"Lat þin enchantors," quoþ Merlyn, "sone bi fore me brynge,
"And ich wol preue bi fore þe, þat heo telleþ al lesynge.
þis enchantors were ybroȝt sone bi fore þe kyng.
"Wad segge ȝe," quoþ Merlyn, "of þis newe þinge?

"Radde ȝe, þat me by sprengede þat morter mid my Potest & interrogandi nota distingui, nisi quod ple∣nam sane distinctionem in Co∣dice eximio (utcunque ad finem manco) Galfridi Monumethensis, mihi donato ab amico illo eru∣ditissimo Richardo Gravesio de Mickleton in agro Gloucestri∣ensi, reperiam. Sic enim ibi: Laudavistis, ut sanguis meus diffunderetur in caementum, & quasi illico opus constaret. Set dicite michi quid sub funda∣mento latet? blod.
"Here me schal sone y se, þat ne konne no god.
"Seggeth me, ȝef þat ȝe konne, wat ys bi neþe þe gronde,
"þat makeþ þat þo fundement no stond none stonde.
þei ne kouþe onswere noȝt, as it ys y wryte.
"Lord kyng," quoþ Merlyn, "ȝef þou wolt þe soþe wyte,
"Lat delue vnder þe fundement, & þou schalt bi neþe fynde
"A water pol, þat haþ y mad, þat þis werk ys bi hynde.
Me dalf bi neþe, and fond þe water, as Merlyn hadde y seid.
"Wat segge ȝe maistres," quod Merlyn, "þat ȝeue þat cole red,
"To bi nyme blod & my lyf, was ys bi neþe now þere?
þe maistres sete stille y now, ryȝt as heo doumbe were.
"Doþ out þis water," quoþ Merlyn, "& wen it is a weye,
"ȝe schul bi neþe ȝet y fynde holwe stones tweye,
"And in eyþer a dragon þer inne slepe faste.
Me let sone out of þis pol þe water clene caste,
And fonde, as he hadde y seid. Men wondred ynow,
And þoȝte, þat ys monhede to Godhed drow.
As þis Vortiger and þis folk token gome,
Twei grete dragones out of þis stones come,
þat on was red, þe oþer wyte. þo gonne to fyȝte faste Pugna draconum.
Strong batail, and þe fuyr out of þe mouþ caste.
So þat þe white was aboue, as þe folk y seye,
And drof þe rede al abak out of þe put ney.
þe rede, as for sorinesse, by turnede hym atten ende,
And asailede þe wyte, & made hym abac wende.
As þis dragones foȝte þus, þe kynge hette Merlyn þere,
Forte segge, ȝef he couþe, wat þe tokonyng were.
Merlyn gan to wepe þo, and bi gan ys prophecie: Prophecia Merlini.
"Awey!" he seide, "þe rede dragon! for ys ende gynneþ to hye,
"And þe white dragon schal in to ys holes wende,
"þat bi tokeneþ þe Saxones, þat þou let aftur sende.
"þe rede bi tokeneþ þe Britones, and ȝoure kynde þat is,
"þat þe Saxones schulleþ ȝet ouer come, and here londe wynne ywis.
"Grote watres worþeþ ȝet rede of monne's blode,
"Cristendom worþ y cast a doun, & chirchon þat er stode.
"Ac ȝet schul þe Britones som tyme aȝeyn stonde,
"For þe bor of Cornewail schal helpe þis londe,
"And þo Saxnes hedes vnder fet trede.
"Mony yles wynne he schal, lond and oþer stude
"Lord we worþ of France, & Rome schal hys sturnhede
"Doute, & quake þerfore, ac ys endyng worþ in drede.
"In ore populorum celebra∣bitur, & actus ejus cibus erit narrantibus Galfr. Mon. þat folk schal euer speke of hym, and ys noble dede
"Worþ to hym a swete mete, þat it con a rede.
"Sex posteri ejus sequentur scep∣trum, sed post ipsos exsurget Germanicus vermis, Galfr. Mon. Siþe, þat comeþ aftur hym, schulleþ holde þe seynorie.
Ac aftur hem schal aryse a worm of Germanye,
And þe Aequoreus lupus Galfr. Mon. se wolf hym schal brynge vp, Delebitur item religio, & transmutatio pri∣marum sedium fiet. Dignitas Londoniae adornabit Doro∣berniam. Galfr. Mon. & þanne religion
And holychirche eftsone worþ y broȝt al a don.
Change worþ of bischopriches, & þe digne sege y wys
Worþ y broȝt to Canterbury, þat at London now ys.
Much of this Ar. Al þis bi fel afturward, as ȝe schul Hure, as of the Cornyssh boor, that Ar. y hure, ☜
F. þro. þo Cornewaile's bor, of wam he spek, þat″ was kyng Arthure,
þat so wel huld vp þis lond, and ys fon ouer com,
And thurgh his grete nobleye Ar. þat þoru ys nobley wan mony a kyndom.
Of prophecie of Merlyn we ne mow telle no more,
For it so derk to symple men, bute me were þe bet in lore.
Gret wonder hadde þat folk of þe wisdam, þat he seyde,
Of þing, þat to come was, and of his ȝong hede.
þe kyng bed þo Merlyn, þat he hym tolde an dede,
In wat deþ he scholde deye, & Merlyn þis hym seyde.
"Con∣stantyne's sones fuir Ar. Costantyne's sones Ig∣nem filiorum Constantini dif∣fuge, si diffugere valueris Galfr. Mon. fur fle, ȝef þou myȝt.
"For hure naueye hii arayth hiderward nough ryght. They leueth the londe of Armoryk. Ar. For heo ȝarkeþ here schipes toward þi lond ryȝt.
"Heo bileueþ þat lond of Armore,″ þat þo lasse Breteyn ys.
"Heore seyles heo spredeþ in þe se, & hyder comeþ y wis.
"þe Saxones heo wolleþ a saile, & to gronde brynge,
"And the sle in thyn owen tour Ar. Ac heo wolle þe in þin owne tour sle″ atte bigynnynge.
"Hure fader and hure bro∣ther eke þurgh thi treson men slowe Ar. þoru þi traison luþer mon heor fader þou slowe.
"Deest Ar. And″ þoru þi trayson Saxones Ferst in to this lond drowe Ar. into þis lond þou drowe.
"þou bede hem forto helpe þe, ac to þin wo heo beþ y come.
"Twei sorwes The cometh an honde, & neither the ne worth by nome. The Sax∣ones nough destroyeth thy lond in the on ende. The two Ar. þe beþ vp on, & þe ne worþ nowþ bi nome.
"For Hinc enim regnum tuum devastant Saxones, &c. Galfr. Mon. þe Saxoues destruyeþ þi lond in to þo on ende.
"þo twei″ breþren in þe oþer half Up the wolleþ wende, To a wreke hure fader deth, the ne tideth no pays Ar. vp þi lond wol wende,
"To awreke on þe here heor fader deþ, þe ne tyd no pays.
"For heo wolleþ to morwe aryue atte haue of Tottenays.
"And wen Hengist ys yslawe, Aurely worþ kyng.
"Pays he wole brynge aȝeyn, & Chirches Ar. chirchon þoru alle þing.
"Apoysned he worþ atte ende, and aftur hym an haste
"Hys broþer schal haue þe kyndam, þat apoysned worþ atte laste.
"So gret treson worþ among hem, þat aftur þe schul come,
But thurgh the boor of Cornewaille shal wrech of hym be nome Ar. Ac þe Cornewaile's bor hem schal chaste some.
AURELI & Uter, þe twei breþren corteys,
With gret power a morwe ariuede at Totteneis.
þo þe tyþing sprong, þat heo comen attelaste,
þe Brutones, þat were helples, come aboute hem faste,
þat were to sprad here & þere, heo were þo glad ynowȝ,
The folk eke of holy Ar. þat folk al so of holy chirche aboute hem faste drowȝ.
þer heo made Aureli kyng, & homage hym dude echon,
And Consailed hym on the Sax∣ones, forto weynde anon Ar. bede, þat heo moste vp þe Saxones wende anon.
Ac þe kyng Aurely þer aȝeyn gan To speke, And wylned vpon Vortager his fader Ar. speke.
For he þoȝte on Vortiger ys fader first awreke.
Adeo enim propter prodi∣tionem patri illatam doluerat, quod nil agere videretur, nisi ipsum prius vindicaret Galfr. Mon. For ys herte was so gret for ys fader deþ þere,
þat he ne myȝt glad be, ar he awreke were.
Vortiger Was Ar. ys y flowe, for drede of hym ywis,

To Ge∣nor castel in Yrchne, in the on ende of Walis, Vp an hille, that Dirty hight, þis castel stode ful hie, In the shire of Hergyn [Heryng∣fordeshire, i. Herfordshire, in margine] vp the water of Wye. The kyng tho he thu∣der com, spake in this ma∣ner to Eldoph, Erl of Glou∣cetre, sure se this castel here, Wher may hit this Vortiger wity fram his deth, And hit ich myghte in his bodẏ make my bodẏ a sheth. He is to me man worst to loken on with eẏe, His deth ne myghte to luther be þan he sholde deye Ar. To an castel in Yrchenfeld, in þe Est ende of Walis,
A boue þe water of Wye, vp an hul on heyȝ.
þe kyng Aureli þider com, & þat castel y seyȝ.
To Eldolf, erl of Gloucestre, he spek in þis manere:

"Respice, dux nobilis, hujus urbis moenia, utrum po∣terint Vortegirnum protegere, quin gladii mei mucronem ipse infra viscera ipsius recondam. &c. Galfr. Mon. Sire noble erl nym god ȝeme of þis castel here,
"Were he mowe þe luþer Vortiger wytye fro þe deþe,
"þat ich in ys inneward my swerd ne make a scheþe,
"þat ys aller mon worst, þat me euer sey with ye.
"þe deþ ne myȝte be to luþer, that he schulde in dye.
"For my fader Costantyn first he bi trayde amys,
"þat sauede hym & al þat lond from þe Pictes Ar. Picars y wys.
"Seþþe my broþer Constans he made to be kyng: Ar. Constance he broȝte hym to kynge:
"For he wolde hym bi traie, and to deþe brynge.
"And seþþe, þoru ys tricherie þo he hadde þis lond on honde,
"He mengede þe luþer payns among The Cristenmen pro ȝou in Ar. ȝou in þis londe,
"To pro forte in Ar. Forte holde me & myn broþer out of oure eritage.
"But God on his owene hede hath tournd his outrage. The Saxones whan hii vn∣derstode of his luther dede, Ar. Ac oure Lord haþ vp ys heued ybroȝt ys owne outrage.
"For þe luþer Saxones vnder ȝete ys luþer dede,

"Heo by nome hym ys kyndom, Thurgh gile & fals∣hede. Ac of one thyng Ar. Sed Galfr. Mon. plane ut Codex Harleyanus. Sic enim ille: Nam ut nequitiam ipsius com∣pererunt Saxones, ejecerunt illum ex regno, quod nemi∣nem pigere debeat. & þat was a ryȝtful dede.
"Ac of o þing ich habbe deol, þat þis payns, þat luþer beþ,
"þat he broȝte first to londe, as ȝe alle y seþ,
"þe noble men of þis lond þus to schame broȝte,
"And þis lond, þat was riche, wastede al to noȝte,
"And al holy chirche & Cristendom habbeþ y broȝt to gronde
"Fram þat On see Ar. o se to þat oþer, Alas! the harde stounde! Ar. a las! þilke stonde!
"Now ȝe kynde men of þis lond Kyeth your manhede Ar. cuþeþ ȝoure monhede.
"And awrekeþ ȝou of þis luþer men, þoru wam com þis wrechedhede;
"Deinde vertamus arma in ho∣stes imminentes, &c. Galfr. Mon. And seþþe turne we oure hond vp oure oþer fon,
"And Delyuere we this lond of luther Ar. delyuere þis lond of þe luþer men echon.

The folk with good herte tho this castel gonne asaile. And for the ca∣stel was so strong, whan will dude hem faile, With queyn∣tise hii caste fure, and brende hit with gynne, And Vorti∣ger alto douste brende ther with ynne Ar. þis folk myd god herte þis castel a sailede.
Ac for þe castel wes strong, here wille þo hem faylede.
Myd quoyntise heo casten fuyr, & barnde þat castel withinne,
Aud þe kyng Vortiger was to doust y barnd þer inne.
And þo myȝte he fynde soþ, þat Merlyn hym er seide,
þat Constantyne's sones fuyr he sholde fle Ar. heo Costantyne's sones fuyr schulde fle & drede.
þo was Hengist sore adrad of kyng Aurely þer,
And nomeliche for þe noble los, That men of hym bere Ar. þat he herde of hym er.
For þer nas in non ende of France, ny in no lond þer a boute,
þat in joustes & Tour∣nementz me ne hadde of hym ȝret doute Ar. tornemens echo mon gan hym doute.
For þer nas so god knyȝt non nower a boute France,
þat in joustes scholde at sitte þe dynt of ys lance,
þat he Nam si con∣gressum fecisset, vel hostem ab equo prosterneret, vel has∣tam in frusta confringeret Galfr. Mon. ne schulde a doun oþer ys hors oþer boþe anon,
Oþer þe lance schulde breke in peses mony on.
þer fore Hengist was a drad to mete with ys launce,
Ouer Homber he fley a non, to wyte hym from meschance;
And casteles and cytees a storede faste þere,
Al toward Scotlond, ther his recettes were. For ther a luthere recett hath be euer to Engelonde. All that hiderward wolde harme, ther hii mowe astonde Ar. And in Scotlond al so; for þilke londes were
A luþer recet euer a geyn Engelonde.
For eche þat wolde hider harm, þer myȝte at stonde.

Cumque id Aurelio nuntiatum fuisset, audacior effectus, spem victoriae recepit Galfr. Mon. At in Cod. Ar. Tho kyng Aure∣lie hadde word, the Saxones were yflowe, Wel the more was his joye, the lasse was his howe. þo Aureli wiste, þat heo were y flowe to hurne,
He was glad, þat heo were a ferd, & þoȝte be hom sturne.″
He ȝarkede ys ost, & siwede aftur hem faste Norþ,
And þo he sey þe contreis, as he passede forþ,
Destruyde & bare in eche half, gret deol he made þere,
And nameliche for chirches, þat y cast to gronde were.
He made to God his a∣vow, to haue the heigher honde, Ar. He bi het God almyȝty, ȝef he sende hym þo ouer hond,
To rere vp aȝen þe chirches a boute into al þat lond.
þo Hengist wiste, þat He Ar. heo come toward Scotlond,

He gan faste to greithi his oste, ayen hym forto stonde. El∣dolf, erl of Gloucetre, that wende in companye Wiþ the kyng thuderward, gan to hym speke an hie: "Sire kyng, he seide, alle deies þat y haue go Ar. He ȝarkede ys ost faste, aȝeyn hem for to stonde.
ELDOL, erl of Gloucestre, as he wende in þis ferhede
Toward þe batail, to þe kyng þese wordes he seyde:
"Sire kyng, for al þe dayes, þat ich haue on erþe y go,
"O day me wolde þinke ynow to Lyue Ar. libbe with oute mo,
"þat ich þe luþer Hengist in Batail myȝte mete,
"For on of vs schulde deye er we To pro þat in Ar. þat batail lete.

"So Reminiscor namque diei, qua convenimus quasi pacem habituri. Cum∣que & de concordia ageretur, prodidit omnes qui aderant, & cum cultris interfecit, prae∣ter me solum, qui reperto palo evasi. Succubuerunt eadem die CCCC. LXXX. barones ac consu∣les, qui omnes inermes advene∣rant Galfr. Mon. muche for ich habbe in myn herte, wan y þer on þenche,
"Whan we come to make pees, of his lither wrenche, That of Erles and Barons, that Ar. þon come to make pays, of ys luþer wrenche,
"þat of oure erles and barnes, þat so noblemen were,
"Four hundred & four score With Ar. mid treson he slow þere,
"Of hem þat Were an vnywar, and vnarmed also. God leue that hit mote be wreke by twixte vs two. The kyng Aurelie Ar. were al on war, & with oute armour were also.
"Now God leue, þat þe wreche þer of by twene vs mow be do.
þe kyng Aurely ys felawes comforted wel to fyȝte,
And al ys hope in Gode's sone Ar. Godesone dude & al ys myȝte.
As þe ost in eiþer syde to The pro this in Ar. þis batail drow,
Heo come & metten baldeliche mid god ernest y now.
Heo smyten harde & made mony a strong wonde.
Heo schedde blod and slowe in eyþer syde to gronde.
Aureli comfortede þe Cristenemen a boute,
And Hengist in his Half also the hethene of his route Ar. half þe heþene menne's route.
Ac þe Cristene, þoru Gode's grace, hadde þe beter ende,
So þat toward Cones∣burgh Ar. Corneborw þe heþene gonne wende,
The Cristene siwede after faste, broughte to grounde y now Ar. And þo Cristene aftur, & to gronde broȝte y nowe.
For al þat heo myȝte of take, heo nome oþer slowe.
þo Hengist y sey þe Cristene men hym siwe so faste,
And þat he moste nede turne aȝeyn, oþer deye atte laste,
He bi gan to ordeyne ys folk, & to batail aȝen drow,
Yn aither syde, as hii dude er, muche folk me slough. The cry of folk þat was a slawe, the other Ar. And in eyþer syde, as heo dude er, to gronde me slow,
þat þe cry of þe folk, þat me slow, þe oþere″ broȝte in drede.
Atte laste þe heþene men bi gonne hem to sprede.
þe Cristene were þe boldere, And the heþene faste of sette, And faste comfortide his men to sle alle that hii mette Ar. þe kyng faste sette
Forto comforte ys men, and slow al þat he mette.
Eldol, erl of Gloucester, al so in hys syde
Rood, & kept her and ther all a boute wide Ar. Arnde, and kepte her and þer, and slow a boute wyde.
And muche hys entente was With Hengis Ar. Hengist forto mete.
So at last to gedere hii mette, and other batailles lete. Wonder stronge were the strokes, that Ar. Heo mette hem atte laste, er heo þe batail lete.
Ow! Lord! þe dyntes stronge, þat″ were bi twene hem þere,
The fuir smot out of the ire, Ar. þat fuyr smot out of þat yre, lyȝtyng as yt were.
So strong knyȝtes boþe þei were, And the herte so gret was Ar. & here herte gret was.
Gorlois, erl of Cornewail, By side hem com by cas Ar. þer forþ com bicas.
As sone as Eldol hym seye, ys herte vpward drow:
Hengist by þe helme by neþe he hente faste ynowȝ,
And myd strengþe hym drow a doun, & lowde bi gan to grede,
"Cristenemen fiȝteþ now, of noþing ȝe ne drede.
"God me haþ my wille y ȝeue; for ich hym habbe nowþe,
"Hym þat made al þis wo bi Norþ & eke by Souþe.
"Cuþeþ now, þat ȝe ben men; for þe maistry al oure ys.
The Cri∣stene to grounde Ar. þo Cristene men to grounde slow, þo Hii Ar. heo herde þis.
And neuer wolde fyne, er the other were to grounde Ar. Heo ne fynede neuer mo, ar þo oþer ware at gronde.
Some flowe to hulles and to wodes, þat heo fonde.
Ac Octa, Hengiste's sone, and ys power atte laste
Askapide in to Ebracwike, Ar. Of scapede to Euerwik, & strengþede þe toun faste.
Hengist was o liue y nome, and y holde faste.
þo þis batail was y do, These Ar. þis Britones attelaste
Nome þe town of Cones∣burgh Ar. Cornboru, and þer inne hadde reste
þre dayes and þre Nyght, as hem thought beste Ar. nyȝt, forto bi þenche hore beste.
þe kyng lette Thulke while the deed bury there, And dude tho to lechecraft, that y wounded were Ar. þe wyle burye þe dede men þere,
And do vnder lechecraft hem, þat y wonded were.
þe kyng The kyng let Hengist af∣terward be brought to fore hym sone, And axede of his Barones, best what was of hym to done? Ar. lette bryng þer aftur Hengist bi fore hym sone,
And aschede at erles & barnes, wat were mid hym to done?

Eldad, Ar. Eldal, þat bischop of Gloucestre Tho was, And the ferthe brother Eldolf, ther was eke by cas. Eldad seide the verdit for alle that ther were, When he seygh Hengis stonde byfore the kyng there. "Theigh alle," he seide, "that here beth him wolde dely∣uere echon, To smale pecis alto hacky ich hym wolde a∣lone. For of prophete Samu∣el ich wolde vnderstonde, That Agag the luthur kyng hadde vnder hond, Ar. was,
And þe erl ys broþer Eldol, was þer bi cas.
þo he sey Hengist stonde bi fore þe kyng þere,
He stod vp & seide þe verdyt by fore alle oþere þat þer were.
"ȝef oþer" he seide, "þat þer beþ hym wol deliuere echone,
"To smale peces ich hym wolde to hakke al one.

"In∣sequerer namque prophetam Samuelem, qui cum Agag re∣gem Amalech in potestatem retinuisset, concidit illum in frusta dicens, Sicut fecisti matres sine liberis, sic fa∣ciam hodie matrem tuam sine liberis inter mulieres. Galfr. Mon. For ich wolde þo prophete wyle Samuel vnderstonde,
"þat þo he hadde þe luþer kyng Agag vnderhonde,″
"He lette hym hewe to peses, and also he seide,
"As þou hast y mad mony A wif Ar. wyf deolful lyf to lede,
"And mony child with oute fader, & mony wif lordles,
"So wole y make to day thi sone fader∣les Ar. Al so ich wole make to day þine sones faderles.
"Al so Do Ar. doþ bi þis mon, þat so muche wo haþ y do,
"So mony child mad faderles, dyȝteþ hym al so.
þis word was for dom yholde, þe erl Eldol hym drow,
And ladde hym with oute þe town With gret filte y now, Ar. mid god herte y now;
And smot of hys hed, þat so muche wo hadde y do.
þo was mony mon a wreke, and mony mon glad al so.
þis was euene fourty ȝer, þat he hadde þis dom,
Aftur þat He ferst with his Ar. he mid his folc to þis lond com.
þo wende þe kyng myd god ost to Euerwik anon,
For to sle Hen∣giste's sone, Ar. Hengistesone, and ys men echon.
þo Octa hit onderstod, þat heo comyng were,
He sei wel, þat His pow∣er was nought a yen so many there. A gret cheyne of iren Ar. power nas noȝt aȝeyn hem þere.

An Communicato itaque consilio, egressus est cum no∣bilioribus qui secum aderant, gestans catenam in manu, & sabulonem in capite, & sese regi in haec verba praesentavit Galfr. Mon. raketyne of yre in hys hond he nom,
And myd þe hexte of ys men A ye the kyng com Ar. to þe kyng he com.
"Sire," he seide, "myne Godes al ouer come beþ,
"And þi God is Lord al one, as we alle y seth, Ar. Lord ys God al one, as we to soþe seþ,
"þat þus noble men to þyn wille bryngeþ in þis manere.

"Accipe ergo nos & catenam istam, &, nisi misericordiam habueris, habe nos ligatos, & ad quodlibet supplicium vo∣luntarie paratos Galfr. Mon. þer fore vs with Thes feteres Ar. veteres vnderfong now here.
"To (omisso þat) which torment though wlt vs do, we beth redy in this place, But though wlt vs pyte do, or eny other grace Ar. þat to eche torment, þat ȝe wole vs, ȝare we beþ in þis place,
"Bute þou wole of vs here pyte habbe and grace.
þe kyng hadde rewþe Of hym, as his con∣sail yaf hym tho, And siker∣nysse nam of hym, to serue hym euere mo Ar. of hem, & ys conseil hym gef þo,
Nom of hem sikernesse to ys þral euer mo″
And of eche þat with hym was, and in gret destresse,
Bi syde Scotlond hem ȝef a place, al in wildernesse,
To wone inne in þraldam vnder þe kyng euer mo.
þese, and mony oþere, þat y flowe were þo,
Y sei, þat þe kyng hadde such mercy hem do,
To hym heo wende as prisones, and Mercy bede also Ar. bedom mercy also.
þe kyng al inon maner hem ȝef Mylce Ar. mercy and grace,
To wone al in Thraldom Ar. þralhede in þike wylde place,
To wro∣therhele to al this lond, that he mylde was tho. For they dude to al this lond suthe muche wo Ar. To wroþe hele al þis lond was he so mylde þo.
For þe schrewes dude to þis lond seþþe wel muche wo.
þo al þis was y do, þe kyng, ar he wende,
Let ordeyne in Euerwik þis lond for to amende,
And lette rere vp chirches in al þe lond a bowte,
And bischopes dude in heore power, þat Erst Ar. er were al withoute.
Aftur fyftene dawes, þat Hii Ar. he hadde y ordeyned Al this Ar. þis,
To London Hii Ar. he wende, for to amende Thyngs that were amys. And let amendy al the toun Ar. þat þer was amys.
He let amende al þo town of howses þat were a downe,
Churchen he rerde in contreye fram toun to toune. Olde lawes, Ar. And in þe contrey chirches let rere, and in þe towne.
Gode lawes,″ þat were aleyd, newe he lette make.
And londes, Ar. Londes, þat were Er Ar. arst by nome, To the ryght heires take. His wille was al clen∣ly this lond for to amende Ar. þe ryȝt eyr he lette take.
Bute ys wille al clene was ys lond forto amende.
And aftur al þis to Wynchestre from Londone he wende,
For to amende þilke Cite, and so to Sales∣bury Ar. syde, & so & so to Salusbury.
And so, for to amende more, to þe Toune Ar. downe of Ambresbury.
þo he com to þat place, þat þe heye men inne laye,
þat Hengist myd ys sexes let sle and by traye,
Of þe morþre he hadde deol, & bi gan to wepe sore,
He þoȝte in hys herte, how he myȝte þe place Worshipe more. For ther Ar. worþi.
For þer lay so gode men, Hym thought hit wel to do, By cause, in sense of the lond, they were amorthered so Ar. yt was wel ydo,
þat, for to defende þat lond, y morþred were so.
Hys conseil he tok þo, how he myȝt make þere
Some werk, That hii euere more after in mynde were Ar. in honowr of hem, þat euer in mynde were.
þe erchbischop of Walis seide ys auys,
"Sire," he seide, "ȝef þer ys any mon so wys,
"That best red can ther of rede, Merlyn hit is Ar. þat beste red þe can rede, Merlyn þat ys.
For Quippe non existimo, alterum in regno tuo esse, cui sit clarius ingenium, sive in futuris dicen∣dis, sive in operationibus ma∣chinandis Galfr. Mon. þer nys in þi kyndam so wys mon y wys,
To segge soþ of þinges, þat to comene beþ.
Ne of queynte thynges for to rede, Ar. Ne of quoyntes for to rede, as we al day y seþ.
Merlyn was þo in Walis. he was sone of soȝt
Myd messingeres, & y fonde, & to þe kyng y broȝte.
The kyng made hym joye ynow, & Among Ar. amon hem alle
Bed hym telle of som Thinges, Ar. þing, þat hym schulde bi falle.
"Sire kyng," quoþ Merlyn þo, "suche þinges y wys
"Ne beþ for to schewe noȝt, but wen gret nede ys.
"For Nam si ea in derisionem sive vanitatem proferrem, ta∣ceret spiritus, qui me docet, &, cum opus superveniret, recede∣ret Galfr. Mon. ȝef ich seide in bismare, oþer bute yt ned were,
"Sone from me Deest Ar. he″ wolde wende þe Gost, þat doþ me lere.
The kyng, tho other [f. tho non other] myghte be, bad hym Ar. þe kyng, þo non oþer nas, bod hym som quoyntyse
Bi þenke aboute Thulke bodies, Ar. þilke cors, þat so noble were and wyse.
"Sire kyng," quoþ Merlyn þo, "ȝef þou wolt here caste,
"In Deest Ar. þe″ honour of hem, a werk that euer schal y laste,
"To þe Hille of Kildar Ar. hul of Kylar send in to Yrlond Kylar.
"After stones noble and goode, that longe han ther stonde, That was carole of Geantz, for queynte werk hit is Ar. Aftur þe noble stones, þat þer habbet lenge y stonde,
"þat was þe treche of geandes, for a quoynte werk þer ys
"Of stones al wyþ art y mad, in þe world such non ys.

"Ne ther is nothing, that hem sholde with strength a doun caste Ar. Ne þer nys noþing, þat me scholde Grandes sunt lapides, nec est aliquis cujus virtuti cedant. Qui si eo modo, quo ibi positi sunt, circa plateam locabuntur, sta∣bunt in aeternum Galfr. Mon. myd strengþe a doun caste.
"Stode heo here, as heo doþ þere, Euere hii wolde y laste Ar. euer a wolde laste.
þe kyng By gan somdel to laugh Ar. somdel to lyȝhe, þo he herde þis tale.
"Who Ar. How myȝte," he seyde, "suche stones, so grete & so fale,
"Bryng fro so ferre lond? And the meste were, that men wolde wene in þis Ar. Be y broȝt of so fer lond? & ȝet mest of were,
"Me wolde wene, þat in þis lond no ston to worche nere.

"Sire, quath Merlyn, ne taketh nought an ydel such lyghẏnge. For hitt is an ydel nought, that y telle of this thynge Ar. Ad haec Mer∣linus: Ne moveas rex va∣num risum, quia haec absque vanitate profero Galfr. Mon. Sire kyng," quoþ Merlyn, "ne make noȝt an ydel such lyȝhyng.
"For yt nys an ydel noȝt, þat ich telle þis tyþing.
"For in þe farreste stude of Affric geandes while fette
"þike stones for medycine, & in Yrlond hem sette,
"The while hii wonede in Ir∣londe, to make hem bathes there, Ar. While heo woneden in Yrlond, to make here baþes þere,
"þer vnder forto baþi, wen þei syk were.

"For Lavabant nam∣que lapides, & infra balnea diffundebant, unde egroti curabantur. Miscebant etiam cum herbarum confectionibus, unde vulnerati sanabantur. Non est ibi lapis, qui medi∣camento careat Galfr. Mon. heo wolde þe stones wasch, & þer inne baþe y wis.
"For ther is Ar. For ys no ston þer among, þat of gret vertu nẏs.
þe kyng and ys conseil Radde tho the stones Ar. radde þo stones forte fette,
And that with gret power of men, yf eny wolde lette Ar. And with gret power of batail, ȝef any mon hem lette.
Uter, (þe kynge's broþer,) þat Ambrose hette al so,
In anoþer maner name, y chose was þer to,
And fiftene þousant men, þis dede forto do,
And Merlyn, for his Queynte witt, Ar. quoyntise,″ þider wente al so.
Gwy∣neman, that was thulke tyme kyng Ar. Gynemon was þilke kyng of Irlonde.
þo me tolde hym, þat þis Britones y come were to ys londe,
Aȝen hem he wente anon myd Gret pro god in Ar. god power ynowȝ.
þo me told him here ernde, he astynte and lowȝ.
"No wonder," he seyd, Theigh Brutons Ar. þaw Breteyne al day go to gronde,
"The moste foles of the worlde ofte hii beth y founde. Who saw such a folye in to the worlde's eynde, Stones out of Irlond to Brutaẏn seynde? Ar. Wan heo, þat þer inne beþ, suche foles beþ yfonde.
"Wo haþ y herd such folye, wer þer be in non ende
"Stones, þer þat aȝtes be heo hyder sende?
"Armeþ ȝow Sone y now Ar. faste now, and wyteþ ȝowre lond.
"For Hii ne shul haue the leste ston, the while ic welde myn hond Ar. heo schul not habbe here no ston, wyle ich may wolde myn hond.
Uter and ys companye redi aȝeyn hem were,

So that the Irissh men hii ouercome there, And wente forth with strengthe, that noman hem ne lette, To the hulle of Kildar the stones forto fette Ar. And a strong batail smyte, & þe Yrische to driue þere,
And wende forþ myd strengþe, þo nomon hem no lette,
And come to Kylar, þo stones forto fette.
þo heo sey þis pro þo in Ar. þo stones, heo wondred y now
Of þe werk, þat was so gret, & Who Ar. ho yt þider drow.
"ȝe ȝonge men," quoþ Merlyn, "cuþeþ now ȝoure myȝte,
"How ȝe mow Thes Ar. þis stones best to þe Shippys Ar. schip dyȝte.
Heo stode, & bi þoȝte hem best, & cables fette ynowe,
And laddres, and leueres, & faste schoue & drowe.
Ac heo ne myȝte come for noþyng to ende Of hure wille Ar. myd here wille.
Merlyn Sey al this, Ar. say þis, and low, and bad hem stonde stille.

He sette hys gynnes, as he wolde, & His queyntise caste. The folke of the stones tho hadde hure wille an haste, And hem to shippe gonne bryng, and so in to this londe, Ac nought with out enchauntemente, as y vnderstonde Ar. ys quoyntise dude stille,
And þe folk myd þo stones þo dude al here wille,
And lette hem to schippes brynge, & so in to þis londe,
Ac þer was som enchantery þer to, ich vnderstonde.
To þe Dounes Ar. downe of Ambres bury Thes stones Ar. þe stones y broȝt were,
A ȝeyn þe fest of Wittsonday, as Merlyn gan hem lere Ar. Wytson tyde, as Merlyn gan lere.
Four hondred ȝer & four score & aboute þe tenþe ȝer,
Aftur Lege, cum Ar. that God on erthe come &c. þat gon on erþe com, y set þei were þere.
Alle þe hey men of The Ar. þo lond þe kyng lette of sende,
Erles and barones and knyȝtes By euery ende Ar. in eche ende,
Bischopes and abbotes and Othur soth y say, That sholde come to the kyngus fest a Witt∣soneday Ar. oþere þat þere were,
þat þe fest of Wytsontyde myd hem were þere.″
þe kyng at Wytsonday, þo heo come alle to ys heste,
Sette þe crowne on ys heued, and huld A noble Ar. noble feste.
And fully alle Ar. And alle þe foure dayes þe fest Held he there. Bysshopryches, that he held, delyuered there were Ar. he huld there.
Interea honores, qui posses∣soribus carebant, domesticis suis largitur, ut eis obsequii sui laborem remuneraret Galfr. Mon. Bischopes also, þat delyuered were,
In honour of þilke stude, þere he Yaf hem tho, ȝef ys þo,
As of Walis, & Ebracwick, and othur many mo Ar. Euerwyk, & of Walis, & also of oþere mo.
Merlyn with ys chauntement, & myd ys quoyntyse, þer
Sette vp þe stones ryȝt so, as heo stode in Yrlond er.
þus was Stonehenge þus Furst y made, that we al day seith, Ar. y mad, þat men al day seþ,
In honour of þe noble men, þat þer y buried beþ.
Passent, Vortigeris sone, tho his fader forbrend was, Ar. PASCENCE, Vortigere's sone, ys fader for barnd was,
Fley into Germanye With full hasty Ar. myd wel hasty pas.
þere he gaderede folc of Saxones y nowe,
For to a wreke hym of hem, þat ys fader slowe.
In þe Norþ ende of þis lond heo by gonne ariue,
And faste slowe and Brende, and robbede swythe blyue Ar. barnde, and robbode bi lyue.
þat word To kyng Aurelye come, Ar. to owre kyng com, so þat he wende
Myd ys power among hem, & heore prude schende.
Pascence and ys men, That Ar. þo ascapede o lyue,
To schippes flowe faste A ye, hying swyth blyue Ar. aȝen, ech whyle hem þoȝte fyue.″
A boute heo wende by þe se, so þat to Yrlond heo come.
Gyneman kyng of Yrlond and heo gret conseil nome.
And þis lond forte schende alle heo swere an oþ.
For Gyneman was for þe Stonhenge hiderward ȝet wroþ.
So þat þe Yrische and heo myd gret power y wys
Come toward þis lond, and aryuede in Walis.
In þe town of Sent Dauid heo by leuede and aboute,
And forto asaile þis lond greyþed here route.
Kyng Aureli at Wynchestre to gret siknesse drow,
Gyneman and Pascente wer glad þer of y now.
A quoynte maistre of þe Saxones (Coppa Ar. Eope was ys name)
To Pascence wende A non, God yif hym moch shame Ar. anon, þat God ȝeue hym schame.
"What wolt thou, he sayne, yiue the to his mede fawe, that wolde kyng Aurelie brynge of lyff dawe? Ar. Wat woldest," he seyde, "þilke mon to ys mede ȝeue fawe,
"þat þe kyng Aurely broȝte of lyf dawe?
"ȝef ich myȝte," quoþ Pascence, "such mon fynde on,
"A þousant pownd of seluer ich wolde hym ȝeue anon,
"And make hym euer vnder me mayster of al my londe,
"And þat ich hym wolde myd trewþe siker faste on honde.
þis forward was faste y mad, now couþe þis luþer man
The langage of Brutones, as Ar. Langage of þis lond, as″ he were Cristeneman,
And all the ma∣nere of hem, Ar. And þe maner of Bruytones, as he hadde among Hem go, Ar. hem y go,
And þe art of lechecraft, al to muche þo.
His berd he lette schere first, And made hym a croune also, Ar. and a brod crowne al so,
And seþþe a monke's abyt on hym he lette do.
And nom with hym spicery, And pro that in Ar. þat to fysik drow,
And wende hym to Wynchestre quoyntoliche y now,

And seyde The kyng (that longe hadde be sike) he wolde to hele brẏnge Ar. Urbem po∣stremo ingressus, obtulit obse∣quium suum clientibus regis, & gratiam in oculis eorum in∣venit. Nihil enim desiderabi∣lius expectabant, quam medi∣cum Galfr. Mon. þe kynge's, þat he wolde hym to hele brynge.
The folk Ar. þat folk was sone glad y now for þe Tydynge Ar. tyþinge.
So wysliche he made yt & so wel, þat me leuede hym faste.
þe kyng in hys Side al∣so, his herte Ar. syde ys herte al vp hym caste.
He ȝef hym a luþer drench, & þo he hadde dronke yt so,
He bed hym lygge & slepe wel, þat yt myȝte do bet hym do.
þe kyng hopede wel On hẏm, Ar. to hym, and lette hym helie faste,
And stille was with oute noyse, & lay & slepte ys laste.
For þe poyson in ys slep þe veynes so Thurgh Ar. þorþ souȝte,
That all the body hit ouerẏede, & sone to deth hym broughte Ar. þat it of eode al þat body, & to deþe sone hym broȝte.

þe Interea nefandus proditor ille, inter unum & alium ela∣psus, in curia nusquam compa∣ruit Galfr. Mon. wyle he slep, This tray∣tour his wey a weyward nome Al by halues stillelych, me nuste Ar. þe traytour þo wey aweyward nom
Stilleliche bi halues, þat me nuste wher he bi com.
Riȝt aboute þe kynge's deþ, in þe firmament an hey
A sterre, gret and fayr ynow, and swyþe cler, me sey.
A cler leome fro hure com, bryght so gold pure, Ar. O cler leom, with oute mo, þer stod fram hym wel pur,
Y formed as a dragon, as red as þe fuyr.
Out of þe dragone's mouþ twei leomes þer stode þere;
The gryttere Ar. Grettor tylde euene Est ouer Fraunce, as yt were,
þe oþer hadde sene branches, alle cler ynowe,
And toward þe Yrische see Westward euene Deest Ar. þei″ drowe.
þo þis sterre was y sey, men Wondrede ther on y nowe Ar. wondrede y now.
Uter, þe kynge's broþer, myd ys ost þo drow
To Walis to þis strange men, to a sayle hem & fyȝte.
A drad he was Swythe sore of Ar. sore y now of þis wonder syȝte.
Of Merlyn he axede anon, hough hitt myght be Ar. Merlyn he clepude & aschede anon, how he myȝte þer of be?
Merlyn wep a non so faste, þat deol yt was to se.
"Alas!" he seyde, "þe deolful harm, þat ys endeles!
"Alas! The folk Ar. þat folk of Breyteyne, þat now ys helples!
"Ded Deest Ar. he″ ys þe noble kyng Aureli þi broþer.
"Ac þe sterre, þat me yseyþ, bi toþoneþ a noþer.
"Hye now þou noble duc, þat þe batail were y smyte.
"For kyng þou worst of Breteyne, & þe Maistry biyite. The bryght sterre bytokneth the, and the fury Ar. maistry þou schalt gete.
"For þe sterre bi tokoneþ þe, and þe fur dragon al so.
"þe leom, That cometh out of his mouth, Ar. þat out of ys mouþ ouer France ys y do,
"þat by tokeneþ a chyld, þat þou schalt bi gete ywys,
"þat schal wynne France & oþer londes, in þe world such mon nys.
"þe leome, þat tylde Westward, a doȝter þat ys,

"Thugh shalt biẏite of thy body, that shal haue sones y wis, That kynges of Bru∣taẏne shul here aftur be, Of sorwe and of contak thenne me shal y se Ar. þat þou schalt bi gete, and schal habbe sones ywys.
"þat scal, eche aftur oþer, kyng of Breteyne be,
"Of some oþer al in contek, and þis me schal y se.
þe noble mon, of wam he spek, þat he Sholde biẏite, Ar. wolde be gete,
þat was þe kyng Arthure, as ȝe schul ywyte.

U∣ther, when he hadde hurd al this, forth he wende anon Toward Seynt Dauidis, to mete with his fon Ar. At U∣ther (in dubio tamen existens, an verum protulisset Merli∣nus) in hostes, ut coeperat, progreditur. Advenerat nam∣que prope Meneviam, &c. Galfr. Mon. Uter let al þis be (for he ne leuede yt not anon)
And wende toward Sent Dauid, to mete with ys fon.
þe oþer were of hem y war, & Greithede hem Ar. ȝarkede hem in here syde,
And Lete hem army swithe well, the bataille to a byde Ar. lette arme here ost wel, batail forto abyde. Bellum.
Heo come & smyte þis bataile, & faste slowe to gronde,
In eyþer syde muche folk in a lute stonde,
Knyȝtes and oþer folk, atte laste oure Lord þoȝte
On ys Cristene folk, and þe Victory Ar. maystry hem broȝte.
For þer was Gynemon y slawe, (þe kyng of Yrlonde)
And Pascence (Vortigere's sone) þat so gret power hade in honde,
And muche of here folk with hem, so þat fowe Atten ende Ar. atte nende
Alyue þer of scapede, þat to schip myȝte wende.
And so Hy myghte lerny, Ar. heo schulde lerne, with Cristenemen to fyȝte.
For our lord wole among hys men euer cuþe ys myȝte.
To Uter of ys broþer deþ þer com werd atte laste.
Aftur þis batayl he wende to Wynchestre faste.
Ac er was the kyng Ar. Arst was þe kyng y buryed, er he Deest Ar. myȝte″ come þere,
Withinne þe place of þe Stonheng, þat he Let furst rere. He hadde lete halwy the place, for coorses that ther were, By therchebisshopp Seynt Dobrice, and other that were there Ar. lette rere.
For he lette þe stude halwe, for þe gode cors þat þer were,
And bischopes and worthi men ys body þider bere.″
UTER, aftur ys Bro∣ther is deth, Ar. broþer deþ, þe crowne to hym nom,
And þoru þe heye men Of the lond a veng the kẏngdom Ar. of þis lond fong þis kyndom.
Of þe dragon He gan by thenche, that was y seye an hegh Ar. he vnderstod, þat y seye was on heye.
And of þat Merlyn hadde Y seid, thurȝh sight that he segh. Two ryche Ar. y seid, of þe siȝte þat me seye.
To riche dragones of gold he lette Makie Ar. make anon,
Atte hegh mynstre Ar. And at þe mynstre of Wynchestre he offerede þat on.
The othur Ar. þat oþer he lette bi fore hym bere in batail wan he was.
Me clepede hym Uterpendragon þer aftur for þis cas,
þat Is, Ar. was, Uter dragone's heued, Deest Ar. & ″ þat was to signifie,
þat Merlyn hym clepude dragon in hys prophecie.
Octa (Hen∣giste's sone) the luthere Ar. Otte, (Hengiste sone) þat luþer Saxone,
And Osa his brother also by∣thoughte hem on treson Ar. Eose ys cosyn, heo þoȝte of treson.
þe oþ, þat to kyng Auryli heo swere by fore,
Hem þoȝte, þo he was ded, þat yt was al for lore.
Heo þoȝte, to do þis lond schame, to Germanye heo sende Sone, Ar. y lome,″
(þat ys lond in Alymaine, Of wham hii furst come) Ar. from wam heo alle come)
Aftur more folk of here kynde, so þat þer come ynowe.
At Scotlond heo by gonne, and faste barnde and slowe,
And so Euer to ward Ar. forþ toward Euerwyk þe contre Doun caste, And whan hii come to Ebrac∣wyk by segede the toun faste. Whan kyng Uther hurde Ar. a doun þei caste,
And bi segede Euerwik, þo heo þider come, faste.
þe kyng Uter herde″ here of, þiderward faste he drowþ.
To gedere heo come, and smyte a batail strong y now. Bellum.
Heo Foughte and Ar. smyten & slowe in eyther syde, þat rewþe yt was to se.
Atte laste The Saxones Ar. þis Saxones by gonne forto fle,
And The Bru∣tones Ar. þis Britones aftur, and slowe to gronde faste;
So þat some of scapode vp monteynes atte laste,
And some in to townes, and yt drow to nyȝt,
So þat Hii ne myght y se no lengor forto fight Ar. heo ne myȝt noþer longor y se to fyȝte.
And þe Britones hem wyþ drow, & þe Saxones hem reste.
Kyng Uter nom ys conseil, What hym were do beste Ar. wat red were beste.
Gorloys, erl of Cornewayl, (þat wysest was y holde,
And old, and mest hadde y seye) ys red first he tolde.
"We mote," he seyde, "be hardy, & stalworþe, & wyse,
"ȝef we wol habbe oure lyf, and holde oure franchise.
"Wexing euer beþ oure fon bi water and by londe,
"þat, ȝef we abydeth longe, we schal hem not at stonde.
"Now Hii beth an vnywar, hii wole y swyke Ar. he beþ al on ywar, heo wolleþ y swike by daye,
"þer fore Y rede in no wise this thẏng lengour Ar. y ne rede in no maner þis nede lengor delaye.
"We schul hem habbe now for noȝt, y ne rede no lengor abyde,
"For he beþ naked & on ywar, And y sprad a wyde Ar. & to sprad wyde.
þis consel was wel yherd, heo hulde þer to echon:
Al by nyȝte he wende forþ, and soȝte out here fon.
Some heo fonde ligge A slepe, Ar. slepe, heo demayde hem anon.
And some wolde haue armede hem, but tyme hadde the non Ar. Some hem wolde arme, ac wyle nadde he non. Capcio Octae.
So þat þeo slow þere a þousant and mo,
And nome Octa and Osa, Ar. Octe and Eose, þat wroȝte al This wo, Ar. þe wo,
And dude hem at London in pryson, & þat was rewþe sore
þat heo nadde hem y slawe, for sorw þei dude ȝet more.
At Ester the kyng made a feste, & sende a boute his sonde, That to London sholde come alle the hegh men of the londe, Ar. AT þe fest of Estre þo kyng sende ys sonde,
þat heo comen alle to London þe hey men of þis londe,
And þe Ladyes Ar. leuedys al so Deest Ar. god,″ to ys noble fest wyde,
For he Wolde Ar. schulde crowne bere, for þe hye tyde.
Alle þe noble men of þis lond to þe noble fest come,
And heore wyues & heore doȝtren with hem mony nome.
þis fest was noble ynow, and Nobelly Ar. nobliche y do;
For mony was þe faire ledy, þat y come was þerto.
Ygerne, Gorloys wyf, was fairest of echon,
þat was contasse of Cornewail, Deest Ar. for″ so fair nas þer non.
þe kyng by huld hire faste y now, & ys herte on hire caste,
And þoȝte, þay heo were A wif, Ar. wyf, to do folye atte laste.
He made To hure semblant fair, to non Ar. hire semblant fair y now, to non oþer so gret.
þe erl Was nought a paid ther with, tho he Ar. nas not þer with y payed, þo he yt vnder ȝet.
Aftur mete he nom ys wyf myd Stourdy mod Ar. stordy med y now,
And, with oute leue of þe kyng, to ys contrei drow.
þe kyng sende to hym þo, to by leue al nyȝt,
For he moste of gret consel habbe som insyȝt.
But al was nought. The kyng eftsone sende a yen his sonde Ar. þat was for noȝt. Nolde he noȝt þe kyng sende ȝet ys sonde.
þat he by leuede at Deest Ar. ys″ parlemente, for nede of þe londe.
The kyng was, tho he wolde nought, Ar. þo kyng was, þo he nolde noȝt, anguyssous & wroþ.

For That despit Ar. despyte he wolde Be a wreke, & that he swor his oth. And but he wolde do his wille, he wolde hym a gaste. So that in to Corne∣waille he greithed his ost faste. In a castel of that cost, me cluped Tyntagel, The erl let putte his wif that stored was ful wel. And in anothur hym self he was, for he wolde nought, Yf cas come hit were wonne, bothe to dethe be brought Ar. a wreke be he swor ys oþ,
Bute he come to amendement. Ys power atte laste
He ȝarkede, and wende forþ to Cornewail faste.
Gorloys ys casteles a store al a boute.
In a strong castel he dude ys wyf, for of hire was al ys doute.
In anoþer hym self he was, for he nolde noȝt,
ȝef cas come, þat heo were boþe to deþe y broȝt.″
þe castel, þat þe erl inne was, þe kyng by segede faste,
For F. he ne myghte. Et tamen particula negativa deest etiam in Ar. he myȝte ys gynnes for schame to þe oþer caste.
Tho Ar. þe he was þer sene nyȝt, and Deest Ar. he″ spedde noȝt,
Igerne þe contesse so muche was in ys þoȝt,
That almost he loste his witt, ac yut he ne dorste for shame Telle hyt but to a pryue Ar. þat he nuste non oþer wyt, ne he ne myȝte for schame
Telle yt bute a pryue knyȝt, Ulfyn was ys name,
þat he truste mest to. And þo þe knyȝt herde þis,
"Syre," he seide, "Y can no red, what vs to don is Ar. y ne can wyte, wat red here of ys.
"For þe castel ys so strong, þat þe lady ys inne,
"That y wene al this lond hym ne sholde a wynne Ar. For ich wene al þe lond ne schulde yt myd strengþe wynne.
"For þe se geþ al aboute, But on entre ther is, Ar. bute entre on þer nys,
"And þat ys vp An harde roche, & so narw ywis, Ar. on harde roches, & so narw wei it ys,
"þat þer may go bote on & on, þat þre men with inne
"Myȝte sle al þe lond, er heo come þer inne.
"And noȝt for þan, ȝef Merlyn at þi conseil were,
"ȝef Eny man couth or myghte, he wolde the best lere Ar. any myȝte, he couþe þe best red þe lere.
Merlyn was Fulsone Ar. sone of send, yseid yt was hym Fulsone, Ar. sone,
þat he schulde þe beste red segge, wat were to done.
Merlyn was sory ynow for þe kynge's folye,
And naþeles, "Sire kyng," he seide, "Her to by houeth maistrie Ar. here mot to maistrie.
"þe erl haþ twey men hym next, Bryghtol Ar. Britahel Galfr. Mon. Bryȝthoel & Jordan.
"Ich wol The make, if thuw wolt, Ar. make þi self, ȝef þou wolt, þoru art þat y can,
"Haue the fourme Ar. Habbe al þo fourme of þe erl, as þou were ryȝt he,
"And Olfyn as Jordan, and as Brithoel me.
þis art was al Sone Ar. clene y do, þat al Changed hii Ar. changet he were.
Heo þre in þe oþeres forme, Hem self as hit were Ar. þe selue at yt were.
Aȝeyn euen Hii Ar. he wende forþ, Ne wiste no man this cas Ar. nuste nomon þat cas.
To þe castel heo come ryȝt as yt euene was.
þe porter y se ys lord come, & His moste priuees beye, Als hym thought, and let hem yn, & his seriauntz tweye Ar. ys meste priuey twei,
With god herte he lette ys lord in, & ys men beye.″
þe contas was glad y now, þo hire lord to hire com,
And eyþer oþer in here armes myd gret joye nom.
þo heo to bedde com, þat so longe a two were,
With hem was so gret delyt, þat bitwene hem þere
Bi gete was þe beste body, þat euer was in þis londe,
Kyng Arthure þe noble mon, þat euer worþ vnderstonde.
þo þe kynge's men nuste amorwe, wer he was bi come,
Heo ferde as wodemen, and wende he were ynome.
They assail∣ede the castel egrely, as he shold doun anon Ar. Heo a saileden þe castel, as yt schulde adoun a non.
Heo, þat with inne were, Grei∣thed Ar. ȝarkede hem echon, Occisio Gorlois.
And smyte out With a full Ar. in a fole wille, & foȝte myd here fon:
So þat þe erl was y slawe, & of ys men mony on,
And þe castel was y nome, & þe folk to sprad þere,
ȝet, þo þei hadde al ydo, heo ne fonde not þe kyng þere.
