þe Tydyng Ar. tyþing to þe L. contas. Nam countesse in Ar. compas sone was Re∣ctius, y come, cum Ar. y nome,
þat hire lord was y slawe, and þe castel y nome.

Ac Sed cum regem in specie consulis juxta eam residere inspexis∣sent [nuncii,] erubescentes admirabantur ipsum, quem in obsidione interfectum deseru∣erant, ita incolumem praeve∣nisse Galfr. Mon. þo þe messinger Y seigh the Erl right, as hym thought, Ar. hym sey þe erl, as hym þoȝte,
þat he hadde so foule Y lowe, sore hit hẏm of thought, Ar. ylow, ful sore hym of þoȝte.
þe contasse made some del deol, But yut forsothe heo nuste Ar. for no soþnesse heo nuste.
þe kyng, Thenne, to glady hure, clupte hure ofte & kuste Ar. for to glade here, bi clupte hire and custe.

"Dame," he seide, "Ne seist though well, that fals hit is al this? Ne seist though well y am a lyue? Y woll telle hough hit is Ar. Potest tamen ne idem quod now hîc significare, quo sensu plena distinctione, non interrogandi nota, est utendum, id quod di∣cendum etiam est de no in tex∣tu, quod idem atque now va∣lere queat. no sixt þou wel, þat les yt ys al þis?
"Ne wost þou wel ich am olyue? Ich wole þe segge how it ys.
"Out of þe castel Priuely Ar. stilleliche ych wende al in priuete,
"þat none of myne men yt Wiste, to speke a word with the. And whanne hii faillede of me to daẏ. Ar. nuste, for to speke with þe.
"And þo heo myste me to day, and nuste wer ich was,
"Hii ferde y wot as gidy men, with wham no red nas, Ar. Heo ferden riȝt as gydie men, myd wam no red nas,
"And foȝte with þe folk Ther oute, and haueth Ar. with oute, & habbeþ in þis manere
"I lost the castel & hem self, but y am with the here Ar. Y lore þe castel & hem selue, ac wel þou wost y am here.
"Ac for my castel, þat ys ylore, sory ich am y now,
"And for myn men, þat þe kyng and ys power sloȝ.
"Ac Oure power ys now lyte, Ar. my power is now to lute, þer fore y drede sore,
"Leste þe kyng Her ynne vs nyme, that were sorwe more Ar. vs nyme here, & sorwe þat we were more.
"þer fore ich wole, how so yt be, wende aȝen þe kynge,
"And make Ferst my pees with hym, Ar. my pays with hym, ar he vs to schame Recte omittit Ar. vs″ brynge.
Forþ he wende, & het ys men, Yf that the Ar. þat ȝef þe kyng come,
þat þei schulde hym þe castel ȝelde, ar he with strengþe it nome.
þo he come toward ys men, ys owne forme he nom,
And leuede þe erle's fourme, And kyng a ye by cam Ar. & þe kyng Uter by com.
Sore hym of þoȝte þe erle's deþ, ac in oþer half he fonde
Joye in hys herte, for þe contasse of spoushed was vnbonde.
þo he hadde þat he wolde, and paysed with ys fon,
To þe contasse he wende aȝen, me let hym in a non.
Wat halt it to telle longe? bute heo were seþþe at on,
In gret loue longe y now, wan yt nolde oþer gon;
And hadde to gedere þis noble sone, þat in þo world ys pere nas,
þe kyng Arture, and a doȝter, Anne hire name was.
Octa and Osa, the luthere Saxones tweẏe, Ar. OCTE and Eose, þis luþer Saxones twey,
In prison were at London, as ich ȝou tolde, beye.
Myd here wardeynes þei spekon, so þat þei boþ y wys
Flowe into Ger∣manie Ar. Germaine, þat in Alimayne ys,
And grete power gaderede of Saxones þer.
ȝet it hadde beter Y be, they hadde be queld ere Ar. y bo, þat me hadde y slawe hem er.
In Scotlond heo ariuede, and Werrede swithe faste, Ar. werreden faste,
And barnde & slow to gronde, & townes a doun caste.
þe kyng lay þo sore syk, heo were glad for þat cas.
An erl þer was of Leycetre, Lot ys name was,
þat Stale∣worth man was & good, the kyng toke hym his myght, Ar. strong knyȝt was & god, þe kyng hym by tok ys myȝt,
And þe power of þis lond, With hethene men Ar. with þe heþe men to fyȝte.
Also ys doȝter Anne he ȝif hym to Deest Ar. hys″ wyue.
þis noble Erl a yenst the Saxones wende forth as blyue, Ar. erl with þe Britones aȝeyn ys fon wente biliue,
And faȝt, and slow Staleworthly, and Ar. faste, and þe heþene Also good. For the hethene men strengore euer with stood. The Brutones eke for pruyte nought for the Erl do Ar. al so god.
Ac naþeles þe heþene folk fastor a ȝen stod.
For þe Brutones nolde for prude aftur þe erl do.
For he nas not kyng, & þer fore þe worse hem Cam to Ar. com to.
þo þe tiþing com to þe kyng, þat Hii Ar. heo so febliche spedde,
He was so sori and so wroþ, þat he ney awedde.
Bi fore hym he lette brynge ys men, & bi gan hem faste blame,
þat heo for heore prude broȝte þis lond to schame.
þider he seide he wolde hym self, þaȝ he ne myȝte on fote, go,
ȝef any horsbere wolde hym bere, to wreke hym of ys fo.
Myd god wille he wende forþ in an horse bere,
The folk, that wende forth with hym, the bolder for hym were Ar. And ys folc forþ with hym, þat þe balder for hym were.
þe Saxones were so prowde, þat þe kyng com so,
þat Unnethe for hure prute hii wolde Ar. vnneþe heo wolde″ armes on hem do.
For heo seide, it were schame, þat we y armed were.
He is more than Ar. Nys he more þan half ded y lad in a bere?
þe kyng His herte sett an hygh, & ordenyd his folk faste Ar. sette vp ẏs herte hye, & ordeyned ys men faste.
þe Saxones Hii asail∣lede, and slough to gronde faste Ar. he asailede, and to gronde caste.
So þat sone dayes hem of Thought al hure gret pruyte, That hii of the noble man Ar. þoȝte here prute,
þat heo of þe noble mon þe kyng tolde so Luyte Ar. lute.
For þer was Octa y slawe, and Osa also, Ar. Otte y slawe, and ys cosyn Oese al so, Occisio Octae.
And so yt hadde be beter, þat me hadde er y do.
þe Saxones, þat myȝte fle, bi gonne to fle faste.
þus The half dede Ar. Se∣mimortuus Galfr. Mon. þe same dede kyng couþe hem agaste.
"Lo half dede kyng, he sede, ye clupeth me somme, Yut haue y leuer half dede hem ouercome, Ar. Lo," he seide, "þei clepude me sam ded kyng some,
"And ȝet ich habbe leuer sam ded hem ouercome,
"þan hol and sond be ouercome; and leuer al so me ys
"For to dye myd honour, þan Lyue, Ar. libbe in schame y wys.

The Saxones tho were ouercome, that hii by left hit nought. Hure sherewed herte hem wrother hele to deth for∣soth brought. Afterwar eft the Saxones ost wax euer mo and mo Ar. þe Saxones Devicti autem Saxones, non idcirco à mali∣tia sua destiterunt, sed aqui∣lonares provincias ingressi, populos incessanter infesta∣bant Galfr. Mon. were þo ouercome, ac heo ne leuede ȝet noȝt
Heore schrewede dede, ac to wroþe hele wer heo to deþe y broȝt.
For heore ost euer wax hem com euer mo and mo.
Boþe bi Est and bi Norþ þei dude Gret Ar. muchel wo.
þe kyng wolde aȝen hem wende, ac he no moste for ys conseil.
For þe Feblor he was tho for his erst travayll Ar. feblor wel he was for þe oþer trauail.
þe Saxones hem hadde ymad in þis lond ywys
Kynges in þre Stedes, that come to on now is Ar. studes, þat al to on y comen ys. Primi re∣ges Saxo∣num.
Hengist Furst was kyng in Kent, and Elle Ar. was first kyng of Sic. Keng, & Elle in Souþsex,
And seþþe last was Certyk kyng of Westsex.
For he and Kenryk ys sone come vp at ȝarnemouþe,
And seþþe a duk, þat hatte Port, com vp at Portesmowþe.
Yt was as In the ẏer Ar. in ȝere of grace þat God was bore, ich wene,
þat Certik com first, four hundred ȝer & four score & tene.
Kyng he was of West sex, and ys ofspryng al so,
And atte laste þilke kynde al þe oþer wan þer to.
For Port, þike grete duk, com vp here by Souþe,
Me clepuþ Deest Ar. yt,″ þer he first com vp, aftur hym Portes∣mowþe.
þus were Deest Ar. heo″ in werre and In wo men∣ged Ar. wo ymenged þe Saxones,
Som tyme aboue Deest Ar. & ″ some tyme by neþe, A∣mong the Ar. here myd þe Britones.
Ac al aboue Where hii neuere er after Ar. neuere hii nere ar aftur þe kyng Arture.
But after hym hii wonne al clene, as ye shul after hure Ar. Ac suþþe hii wonne al clene out, as ȝe solle here aftur hure.
Uter, þe gode kynȝe, (of Wham Ar. wan we speke bẏ vore,)
Gan faste for to feble an horse beere y bore, So that he moste for feblesse nedes Ar. Was feble after þat he was in þe hors bere ẏ bore,
þat he moste vor feblesse nede″ holde hẏm stẏlle,
Ther fore Ar. þer vore þe luþer Saxons To muche Ar. so muche adde her wẏlle.

ẏut (omisso and) tho they ne Ar. And ȝute þo hẏẏ ne myȝte hym se, Hii thoughte in treson For to brẏnge hẏm to deth with som maner poyson. Hii sende fele messageres in poure men∣nes wede, Ar. hẏẏ þoȝte wyt traẏson
In some manere hẏm brynge of lẏue, oþer wyþ poyson.
Hiẏ sende her feble messagers in pouere monne wede,
þat at doles in þe court her mete mẏd oþere bede.
Hii aspẏed in þe court ouer al of þynges alle,

So þat hyi vnder ȝete A well, negh the kynge's halle, Of which the kyng ofte dronk. For in this ilke cas Litel othur thẏng he dronk, but water that cold was. Whanne he dronk also anẏ wyne, ther on hit was y do, And mete me made in the court of thulk welle also Ar. an welle, neẏ þe halle,
Of wat þe kẏng ofte dronc. vor he ne dronc in such cas
Lutẏl oþer þyng bote þere of, vor þe wadyr so cold was.
Wanne he dronc ekyn wyn, þeramong yt was ẏdo.
And me made metes in þe court mẏd þulke water al so.
þo þe traytors ẏt vnder ȝete, hii Fontem namque aggressi sunt nephandi proditores, ip∣sumque affecerunt veneno, ita ut manans aqua tota corrum∣peretur Galfr. Mon. en venymede wẏþ ẏnne
þe welle aboute in eche sẏde With hure enuenymouse gynne Ar. mẏd her luþer gẏnne.
þat þe water, þat þerof com, poẏson was Full Ar. wel strong.
þe kyng was sone apoẏsond, Whan he Ar. þo he þerof dronc,
An mo þan an hondred of hys men, ar me wyste were of ẏt com.
Muche ssame were hii wurþe, þat doþ such Swikeldom. So hẏm seyde Merlyn er he sholde thurgh poẏson deye. The hegh men of the lond, tho hii his deth y seye, Ar. suẏke dom.
Soþ hym sede Merlyn er, þat he solde þoru puẏson deye.
þe chere men of lond, þo hii ded hym yseẏe,
Deol & sorwe hii made ynou, ac þo þer nas oþer red,
Hii let hym beburye by ys broþer, as he hẏm sulf bede,
By side the toun of Ambresbury, at Stonehenge y wis Ar. Atte mynẏstre of Ambẏsbure, at Stoneheng ẏwys.
Wel aȝte That be a worthi stede, ther such sepulture is Ar. þat he be wurþe stude, þat such sepulture ys.
ARTURE, Uthere's sone, (of wham) Ar. Uter sone, (of wan we tolde bẏ uore,)
Ye abbyth ẏ hurd hou he was bygete & ẏbore.
þo þẏs kyng was þus ded, þe heye men alle come
Of þe lond to Cilchestre Ar. Cẏlẏcestre, and conseyl þerof nome

Vor to make hem a kyng. Urgebat enim eos necessitas. quia, audito praedicti regis obitu, Saxones concives suos ex Germania invitaverunt, & duce Colgrino ipsos extermi∣nare nitebantur Galfr. Mon. Vor nede hom drof þerto.
Vor the Saxons wuste, þat þe kẏng was ded so,
Hii sende uorthe to Alymayne after more poer blyue,
And þoȝte þẏs Brutons al clene of londe dryue.
So þat hii adde ẏwonne al clene þat Norþ londe,
Fram Homber to Cataneys, & adde al in her honde.
Artur was þo ȝong mon of vyftene þere vnneþe,
And ȝut al þat londe made Subintellige, kyng. hym, after ys fader's deþe,
And Thenne bygan such a man to be, That me myghte in non londe no whar his per se Ar. began suon eke er such man vorto be,
þat menessolde in none londe ys per nour ẏse.
So large he was & so hende, & Deest Ar. al″ so de bonere;
So hardy and so gentyl, and of so vayr manere.
And so Ar. þo so muche folc to hẏm come, Of yonge and of olde, Ar. of kynȝtys ȝong & olde,
þat he Hadde vnnethe whar∣with such a meyne holde Ar. nadde noȝt wel ware wyth such meyne up to holde.

Ac Arthurus ergo, quia in illo probitas largitatem comitaba∣tur, statuit Saxones inquietare, ut eorum opibus, quae ei fa∣mulabatur, ditaret familiam Galfr. Mon. ys herte was euere god, ȝong þey he were,
And euere he thoghte of the Saxones his dis∣penses rere Ar. Vor he þoȝte of þe Saxons ys spence vp arere.
He bẏgan þo wel sone to arere ẏs baner.
Vor ys prowesse he adde sone gret folc and poer.
He wende toward Euerwyk With gret power y nogh Ar. myd vayr Sic. copanye ẏ nou.
þo þe Saxons hyt vnder ȝete, þat he þuderward drou,
Of Scottes, and of Pẏcars, and of hym sulue hii nome,
Gret poer ẏ nou and strong, and aȝen hym come.
Ther was slaughter gret y nogh, and mercy lite ther was Ar. þer was slaȝt in eẏþer half, none mercy þer nas.
Ac kyng Arture atte laste (as God wolde) aboue was,
And sywede into Euerwẏk Colgrẏn Ar. Colgrym her cheuenteẏn,
And hym, þo he was wyþẏnne, byseged With his myght and mayn. Bathulf Colgryne's brother, Ar. myd al ẏs manẏ.
Baldulf, Colgryme's broþer, syx þousend men myd him nom,
And, ẏs broþer vorto help, toward Euerwẏk com.
And tho he was Ar. So he was fram Euerwyk aboute A Ar. an ten myle,
He Astynte, Ar. at stunte, & þoȝte, þat he wolde myd gyle
Up þe kyng Arture come anonẏwar by nẏȝte,
And so him and al ẏs folc ssende, ȝyf he mẏtte.
þe kyng was Her of y war, and thoghte her of do bote. With six Ar. þerof ẏwar, he þoȝte to do bote.
Myd sẏx hondred kynȝtes, & Foure Ar. þre þousend men Sed ut Codex noster Har∣leyanus in Galfr. Mon. A fote, Ar. auote,
Cadour, erl of Cornwayle, aȝen hym he sende,
An vn ywar to falle on hym, by weye as hii wende. The Erl brak vp his bussh∣ment, & broghte manyon to dethe Ar. þat aȝen hẏm come anonẏware, by aweẏ þat he wende,
And slou and vere woundede, and monye broȝte to deþe,
So þat þẏs Ilke Bathulf ascapede a lyue vnnethe Ar. Baldulf of scapede alẏue vnneþe.
þe wẏle Deest Ar. þat″ þe kyng Arture biseged Euerwyk,
Me tolde hym of a gret duc, Me clupede Cheldyrk, Ar. þat het Theldryk,
þat out of Alemaẏne com To Scot∣londe tho Ar. in to Scotlonde so

With VI. hundred shupfull of men, and hure atyr ther to. That was power wonder gret to on londe y ladde. Tho the kyng hurde this, he was somdel a dradde. The kynge's counsail radde hym a non, to London forto wende, To counsaille hogh he mẏght best his ene∣myes a shende Ar. Myd syx hondred syppuol kynȝtys, & al þe atyl þer to.
þere was so gret poyr in to an londe y lad.
þo þe kẏngy's conseyl wuste þẏs, hyt was som dele adrad.
þe kyng Arture hii radde anon, to London vorte wende,
To nyme þer ẏs conseyl, wuch were best ȝende,
Leste such poer come vp hẏm, and him ssende.
þe kyng dude aftur her rede, and to Londone wende.
þere he hulde ẏs Parlement, wat were best to done.

So that Ar. þo Communi tan∣dem assensu illato, mittuntur Armoricam nuncii ad regem Hoëlum, qui ei calamitatem Britanniae notificarent. Erat autem Hoëlus filius sororis Arthuri, ex Budicio, rege Ar∣moricorum Britonum, gene∣ratus Galfr. Mon. þat he and ys conseyl at one red were sone.
To the lasse Brutayne forto sende sone Ar. þo þat to þe lasse Brutayne þe kyng sone sende
To Howwel, kyng of þe lond, þat he to hym wende
To helpe hẏm in such nede, and that hym vnderstode
þat kunde yt wolde þat he dude, vor hii were of one blode.
þe kyng Arture's sẏster's sone þys kyng Howwel was,
The kynredene of hem no ferther nas Ar. And þe kyngys sone of lasse Brytaẏne, & none nerer kunde þer nas.
þo þe messager wyþ þe tydẏng to kyng Howwel com,
Hẏs conseyl wel hastelyche in such nede he nome,
Vor to helpe ys Kynnes∣man, Ar. neueu, and ys kynedom.
With XV. thou∣send of men to this Ar. Mẏd vẏftene þousend kynȝtes into þẏs londe he com.
At Souþhamtone This kynges tweẏne furst to gedre come. Aither othur clippe gan, and kuste to gedre y lome Ar. he com vp, & þo hyi to gadere come
þys tueye kyngys hii custe hem, & hii clupte hem ẏlome.
þo hii adde her folc ẏ set, As hit fel in such Ar. as ryȝt was in such cas,

Vorþward toward Lyncolne hii wende A ful good pas. The Brutones and the Saxones smẏte a gret ba∣taille there, So that sixty thousand [sed, sex milia in Galfr. Mon.] Saxones ther y slawe were, And fele ther of were a dreẏnt, so Ar. myd god pas.
þere hii come & mette hym, & strong bataẏle smyte þere,
So þat moo þan sẏx þousend of þe Saxon aslawe were,
Wat aslawe wat adrent, so þat atte laste,
þo Hii seygh non othur won, Ar. hii ne seye oþer won, hii gonne to fle vaste
In to a wode þer bẏ syde: and Whenne Ar. þo hii þer in come,
Hem þoȝte hii were sẏkere ynou, & toke þe lasse gome.
þe kyng sẏwede After faste, and Ar. after, and bẏseged hem aboute.
Deest Ar. Ac″ among þe Trees hii kepte hem longe, for al Ar∣thure's route Ar. tren hii wuste hem, þat hii nadde nodoute.″
þo þe kyng Arture ẏseẏ, þat hii nolde out come,
A boute þe wode he let fulle þe grete tren sone,
And leẏde ech vpe oþer aboute in ech ende,
þat ẏt was, as yt were, awal þat hii ne solde oute wende.
þre Dayes & thre nyght hii were y kepte so, That hii nuste for hunȝre What hii myghte do. Of kyng Ar. dawes & þre nyȝt mete les hii wuste hem so,
þat hii nuste hou on take, ne wat vor hunger do.
þe kyng″ Arture hii bẏsoȝte mercẏ Atten ende, Ar. atte ende,
þat he granted hem in pes out of ẏs londe wende,
An hii granted hym al her god, þat hii hyder ladde,
Gold and seluer and tresour, al clene þat hii adde.
Hii Promiserunt quoque, se daturos ei tributum ex Ger∣mania, obsidesque inde man∣suros Galfr. Mon. bẏhete hym eke ech ȝer, to bere hẏm truage
Out of her londe, and þerto Make hym good Ar. take hym god ostage.
þe kyng þoru ys conseyl Assentede ther to, And ostage of hem nam truage to do. At helde hem & al hure ȝood, & let hem bar wende Ar. encented wel her to,
An god ostage of nom, þe truage vor to do;
And atel al her god, and let him al bar wende.
And ȝut hym of þoȝte sone, þat he was hem so hende.
Mẏd her gold & seluer & myd her tresour he mẏȝte
Susteẏnẏ gode wẏle hys ost vorto fyȝte.
Ac ȝut þys luþere false men, in þe see þo hii come,
Turnede aȝen to suẏkedome, and anoþer red nome.
Atte hauene of Tottenas hii gonne Up arẏue, And come a londe, & robbede in Deuenesshire as blyue Ar. eft arẏue,
And dude hym alond, & rewede in Deuenyssyre blẏue.
And so uorþ in Somersete, Deest Ar. and″ muche wo gonne do
Al anone to Seuerne, and to Baþe Also, Ar. so,

And bysegede þe Toun, but out hii holde were. The kyng fer by Northe was forto werry there. Of Scottes & of Picardz a wreke hym he thoghte, That euermore to his lond muche shame wroghte. The tydynge to hym com of thes Saxones tho, He wiste neuere hoder turne so wo was hym tho. Of Scottes Ar. thoun, ac wyt þoute hii were.
Vor þe kyng byuore was hii bygonne her werre þere.
Vor þe kyng was toward Scotlond, & awreke hym þoȝte
Of Scottes and of Pigars, þat euer vnele hẏm wroȝte.
þo þe tydẏng to hẏm come of þe Saxons We idem est quod Anglo-Sax. þa sive þae, i. e. wo vel sorrow. Sed þo (ut reor) est reponendum è Cod. Ar. ut prius þo, when, posterius then signet. we,
He nuste in weþer ende turne, so vol he was of wo.
Of þe Scottes″ he wolde awreke be, ȝẏf tẏme hym þerto ȝoue,
Ac he Wolde for no thyng Ar. nolde vor non þyng þe Saxons byleue.

But for Howel, his suster sone, kyng of lasse Brutayne, At Alclud sore sik lay, he was in gret payne, And that he moste nedely byleue hym tho there, Leste the Scottes dude hym shame, or elles that he dede were. He bileft a power with hẏm, and toward So∣mersete He wende a yen the Saxones, he wolde hit noght for lete Ar. Howwel, ys scẏster sone, kẏng of þe oþer Brutaẏne,
Mest in ẏs herte was, vor anguẏsse to plaẏne,
(Vor he laẏ byuore sẏk) þat he solde bẏ leue hym þere,
Laste þe Scottes hym dude ssame, oþer þat he ded were.
He byleuẏd hẏm poer ẏnou, and toward Somersete
Wende toward þe Saxons, vor þat nolde he noȝt lete.″
þo he come to Somersete, and þe Saxons seẏ,
He houede, & spec to ys men þes wordes al an heẏ:

"Vor These Ar. þẏs luþer Saxons Haueth of vs dedeyne, And haueth thus y broke hure oth, yf y haue mẏght and mayne, I make a vogh to Jhesu Christ, (to holde, ẏf y may,) The blood, that they haueth shad, to venge yut to day Ar. abbyt gret dedeẏn
"Vorto holde me treuþe, ȝẏf ẏch abbe enẏ maẏn,
"Ich chẏlle treuþe holde to Jhesu Crist treulẏ (ȝẏf ẏch maẏ)
"And þat blod of ẏs kunde floc awreke ȝut to daẏ.″

Eche ȝer, and holde of hym and of hẏs in seruage.

þat me ne mẏȝte Of such a los no man vnderstonde Ar. of so noble los man neuere vnderstonde.

Hẏm þoȝte he adde ẏrest ynou, He wolde no lengor abide. He let of sende his power, that spar∣puled was ful wide. And greẏþede ẏs noble ost, and dude hẏm in þe weẏe,
And dude hẏm so in to see, and vorst to Norþweẏe.

Mẏd ẏs poer, and smyte an batayle strong ynou,

Nogh hadde Fraunce thulke tyme a lord, het Frollon, (That vndertok the gouer∣naunce thurgh emperour Leon) That hardy man was & strong, and hadde power y nogh Ar. Nou adde France þulke tẏme þe emperour Leon;
And he bẏtoc ẏt in warde an duc, þat het Follon,
þat hardẏ bodẏ was and god, and poer adde ẏ nou.

Alle maner of men, of his power that were, He toke, and with the Brutones mette, & smyten a bataille there Ar. Alle þe kynȝtes and þe folc, þat in ys poer were,
He nom, & mette þe Brutons, & smẏte batayle þere.

And ẏs poer hii mẏȝte lute wule dure.

Vor Nam Arthurum juventus in∣sularum omnium, quas sub∣jugaverat, comitabatur. unde tantum perhibebatur habere exercitum, quantus erat diffi∣cile ab ullo posse superari Galfr. Mon. euere, wanne he Wan a lond Ar. nom alond, al þe bachelerẏe,
þat aȝt was in þe lond, he Toke Ar. nom in ẏs companẏe
And of mayne at his cost. and for he was so hende, Euery noble man was glad with hym forto wende. And the best part of Fraunce Ar. And of ẏs maẏnage vp ẏs coust, & vor he was so hende,
Ech noble man vawe was mẏd hẏm vorto wende.
Famulabatur quoque ei melior pars Gal∣licanae provinciae, quam sua largitate sibi obnoxiam fece∣rat Galfr. Mon. And beste partẏe of Fraunce to hẏm al so drou.
For his largeste & hendeneste, that hym com folk y nogh Ar. Vor he was so large & hende, þat to hẏm com poer ẏnou.
Vor me ne tolde welneẏ of no mon, noþer here ne þere,
Bote he mẏd þe kyng Arture in som manere were.
Whan that Frolle vnder∣stod, that he sconfited was, He flegh in to Parys with a quyke paas, Ar. þo þe duc Follon ẏseẏ, þat ẏs poer noþẏng nas,
He flen in to Parẏs mẏd wel quẏc pas,
And astorede The toun, and strengthed hym a boute Ar. þen toun, and strengþe hẏm aboute.
Kẏng Arture and ys poer aseged hẏm wẏþoute.
So þat wẏþẏnne A monthe day duk Flolle y seigh, That his men in defaute for honger deide negh, Ar. a monþe þe duc Follon ẏseẏ,
þat ẏs men, vor defaute and vor hunger, deẏde nẏ,
And þat ẏs poer nas noþẏng, aȝen kẏng Arture
He thoghte with his owene bodẏ, while he myght endure Ar. He þoȝte do ẏs owe body, wẏle he mẏȝte dure.
Vor he was strong man & hardẏ, þe strengoste of ẏs londe.
To þe kẏng Arture he sende, þat he ssolde Deest Ar. hẏm″ vnder stonde
And do the bataille, yf he wolde, with his owen honde, And whether myghte a boue be were maister of othere's londe Ar. To do an bataẏle hem sulue tuo mẏd her owe honde,
And weþer so myȝte aboute be were louerd of oþere's londe.
þo kyng Arture hurde This, gladder neuere he nas Ar. þẏs, no gladdere man nas.
He sende word, þat al prest to such bataẏle he was.

Sẏkernesse Dato igitur in amba parte foedere, conveniunt uterque in insulam, quae erat extra civi∣tatem, populo expectante quid de eis erat futurum Galfr. Mon. & trouþe Hii plight, and hure forward nome. So that at a day sett to bataille hii come Ar. ẏplẏȝt, of þys vorewarde hii nome.
So þat, at certeẏn daẏ ẏset, to þẏs batayle hii come
A lute wẏþoute Parẏs, Arayed wel y nogh Ar. atẏled wel ẏ nou.
Muche was The folk Ar. þat folc aboute, þat to þẏs bataẏle drou.
Hii a saide hure stedes furst, hure lances Ar. Hii fondede her steden vorst, & her lancen suþþe hii nome,
And wẏþ hard dunt & gret ẏre to gadere suþþe hii come.
And kyng Ar∣thur on the brest Frolle so hitte, That he fel doun to grounde, he myghte no lengor sitte Ar. þe kẏng Arture aȝen þe brest ẏs felawe uorst anhẏtte
Aȝen þe breste, þat he vel, & ne myȝte noleng sẏtte.
As sone as he myȝte turne ẏs hors, ẏs suerd he drou þer,
Vor to asaẏly hẏm þerwyþ, ac þe oþer was vppe er,
And Smot his stede in the breste, & yaf hym dethe's wonde Ar. ȝef þe sted mẏd ẏs sper aȝen brest deþe's wounde,
So þat boþe stede and kyng leẏe sone at grounde.

Desunt ali∣quammulta in Ar. utpote in quo folium unum integrum (fol. sc. LXIX. quatuor duntaxat versibus exceptis) hîc loci exci∣sum esse, particulamque unius paginae (sive faciei secundae folii LXVIII.) plane vacuam, video, in cujus tamen particulae vacuae margine The rounde table of Ar∣thur scriptum legitur. þo þe Brit∣tones ut regem prostratum vide∣runt, timentes eum peremptum esse, vix potuerunt retineri, quin rupto foedere in Gallos unanimiter irruerent Galfr. Mon. Brutons seye þẏs, hii vor bere vnneþe,
þat hii ne breke þe couenant, & broȝte þen oþer to deþe.
Ac kyng Arture keuerede vp, & asaẏlede Follon vaste,
And smyte eyþer oþer her & þer, & harde duntes caste,
So þat Follon mẏd a stroc þe Brutons sore aȝaste,
Vor þe kyng Arture aȝen þe frount he smot atte laste,
þat, ȝẏf he nadde wẏþ þe selde somdel þe dunt ẏhent,
Sẏker he hym adde aslawe, oþer al out ẏssent.

þo kyng Manante igitur san∣guine, cum Arthurus lori∣cam & clipeum rubere vi∣disset, ardentiori ira accensus est, atque erecto totis vi∣ribus culiburno, impressit eum per galeam in caput Follo∣nis, quod in duas partes disse∣cuit. Quo vulnere cecidit Follo, tellurem calcaneis pulsans, & spiritum in auras emisit Galfr. Mon. Arture ẏt ẏuelde, and ẏseẏ al so ẏs blod
Vp ẏs haubert & ẏs sselde, he was neẏ vor wraþþe wod.
He drou syre Calẏbourne ys suerd, þat was so gode,
And anowarde þe helm wyþ wel stourdẏ mod
þen oþer he smot, and to clef þat heued myd þe wounde.
He vel and ssoc þe helm, and deẏde in astounde.
þo þẏs dede was ẏdo, and þere oþer was ded,
þut conseẏl of France sone nom ys red,
And to þe kẏng Arture hẏm ȝolde ech man þat was wẏs,
And ȝolde hẏm vp al þat lond, & þe keẏen of Parẏs.
þys was lo þe Cornwellẏssebor, of wan Merlẏn spec ynou,
And clere leme of þe sterre, þat ouer France drou.
Som was ẏcome, as he sede, of þe noble kyng Arture,
Wel me ssal her after of hẏm ȝut ẏhure.
þo he adde ẏwonne France þus, & al þẏs was ẏdo,
þẏs noble kẏng Arture delde ẏs men atuo.

Et unam partem Haelo duci commisit, praecepitque illi, ut, ad expugnandum Guitardum, Pictaviensium ducem, iret; ipse vero cum reliqua parte ceteras provincias sibi subjugare vaca∣vit Galfr. Mon. þe kẏng Howwel he bẏtoc, and þe oþer princes al so,
þat odel of ẏs ost to wende to Peẏto
Vor to wẏnne þat lond, and hẏm sulf he wolde wende
Vor to wẏnne seẏnorẏe aboute in oþer ende.
Kyng Howwel wyþ ẏs poer wan sone Peẏto
Al to kẏng Arture's wẏlle, and Gascoẏne al so.
þe kẏng won Normandẏe, and also god Aungeo,
And wẏþẏnne anye ȝer al þẏs was ẏdo.
þe kyng wende þo to Parẏs, þo he adde ẏdo al þys,
And al heẏ men of lond þuder come ẏwẏs.
Her homages of hem, and her seruyse, he nom,
And þe lawes, as he wolde hẏm sulf, sette on þe kẏnedom.
He ȝef þat lond of Normandẏe Bedwer ẏs boteler,
And þat lond of Aungeo F. Kaẏe. Nam Gaioque Dapifero in Galfr. Mon. Kaxe ẏs panter,
And oþer þẏng oþer heẏe men, & sẏker ẏt made ẏnou,
And suþþe aboute Leẏnte toward þẏs lond drou.
ÞO þe kẏng Arture com here in þẏs londe,
And so muche lond adde ẏwonne, & adde al so an honde,
In yoe & blẏsse he was ẏnou, & alle þat wyþ hẏm were,
And aȝen Wẏttesonetyd yt was in þe ȝere.
He þoȝte þe heẏe feste of Wytesontyd do
Wẏþ honour among ẏs men, and þat alle come þer to,
Boþe kẏnges and dukes, and erles echon,
Barons and kynȝtes, squeers monẏon,
Laẏdẏes and maydens, and ech mon þat aȝt were
In enẏ lond, þat ẏs was, þat hii were alle þere.
Of ẏs rounde table ẏs ban aboute he sende,
þat eche a Wẏtesonetẏd to Carleon wende,
A toun þat ẏs in Glammorgan vp þe water of Osc ẏdo,
A lute bysyde Seuerne, in murye stede al so.
Vor me maẏ þere in þe Souþhalf al by the see lede
Fram oþer londes god ẏnou, to endy such a dede.
Hîc denuo pergit Cod. Ar. In oþer alf beþ grete wodes, lese and mede al so,
So þat þer vas no defaute such noble þyng to do.
þer come to þẏs rounde table, as he sende ẏs ban,
Anguissel Ar. Aunsel kẏng of Scotlond, and al so Vrẏan,
þat was kẏng of Murẏfẏcens, & also of Norþ Walẏs
Cadwal, and also Estan∣ter Ar. Scater kẏng of Souþ Walys,
Cador kẏng of Cornwaẏle, and erchebẏssopes al so
Of Londone, and of Euerwẏk, and of Carlyon Ar. Carlen þer to.
Erles þer come ek monẏon, as þe erl of Gloucestrye
Morwid Ar. in quo & Dude ywan pro Ingomer. Morond, and Ingomer erl of Leycestre,

Mau∣ran of Wircetre, [Maren Gwi∣gornensis, quae nunc Warguic dicitur, Galfr. Mon.] Cursal erl of Chestre, Aleth of Sa∣lesbury, Jonathas of Dorche∣stre, Kynmar Ar. Maron erl of Warewẏk, and Cursal of Cẏcestre,
Galluc erl of Salesburẏ, Jonatal of Dorcestre,
Kẏmmar erl of Kent, Ar. Canterburẏ, of Baþe syre Vrbygen, Boso Ar. Vrgen,
Bose″ erl of Oxenford, þat were alle noble men.
þe barons & the kẏnȝtẏs, þat of hẏs londe adaẏ
At hẏs rounde table were, noman telle ne maẏ.
Kẏnges þer were eke of ẏlẏs, As Ar. ar þe kẏng of ẏrlonde
Gwillamour, & Maunsel kyng of Islonde, Ar. Gẏllam, and also Malueẏs kẏng of ẏslonde,
Lot kẏng of Norþeweẏe, and Doldan Ar. Doldam of Godlond,
And þe kẏng of Orcadas, & of Denemarch ẏch vnderstonde.
Kẏnges eke of bẏȝende see, as Kay of Aungeo,
Bedwer of Normandẏe, Guẏder of Peẏto,
Lygger of Colonẏe, and al so the Dusze Ar. dosse pers
Of France were þere echon, þat so noble were and fers.
Hẏs neueu kẏng Howwel of þe lasse Brutenẏe al so
With muche poeple thuder com, and gret nobleie ther to Ar. Mẏd so vaẏr folc þuder com, & mẏd so gret charge þerto
Of mules, of cartes and of hors mẏdde alle gode,
þat þer nas non so wẏttẏ man, þat ẏt al vnderstode.

Ther was no prynce by twixte Spayne & Alemayne of pris, Ar. þer nas Praeter hos non remansit princeps alicujus pretii citra Hispaniam, quin ad istud edictum veniret. Nec mi∣rum. Largitas namque Arthu∣ri, per totum mundum divul∣gata, cunctos in amorem il∣lius illexerat Galfr. Mon. bẏtuene þys & Spanẏe no prince wiþoute al þẏs,
þat nas at þẏs rounde table, & at þẏs feste ẏwẏs.
And no wonder. Vor þe kynge's los so wyde sprong ẏnou
Of godenesse & of cortesye, That euery man to hym drogh Ar. þat her herte to hẏm drou.
ÞO þẏs heẏe men were alẏcome, & þe heẏe tẏme also
Of Wẏtsontyd, þe feste vor to do,

Thre Erchebisshopes were come, to sette on the kynge's croune. But Seynt Dubrice, that Erchebisshop was of the selue toune, (As hit was his costume that offys te do) Dude the seruise of holi churche, that byfel ther to. Tho the croune þe herchebyssopẏs were ẏbroȝt, to sette þe kẏnge's croune
On ẏs heued. Ac Dubricius ergo, quoniam in sua diocesi curia tenebatur, paratus ad cele∣brandum obsequium, hujus rei curam suscepit Galf. Mon. Seẏn Dubrẏc of sulue tẏme
Was erchebẏssop. hẏm byuel þe croune on hẏm do,
And þe seruẏse of holy chẏrche ek, þat byuel þer to.
þo croune was on ẏs heued, and ẏdo was ech oþer þẏng,
Tueẏe erchẏbẏssopys ladde þys noble kẏng
To þe chẏrche of heẏe munstre. And þer ȝeode bẏuore hẏm þere
Four kyngs, and four suerdes of golde bẏuore hẏm bere;
Vorst þe kyng of Scotlond, and þe kẏng of Norþwalys,
And þe kyng of Cornwale, and þe kẏng of Souþwalẏs.
And bysshopes, and other prelates, to fore the kyng Ar∣thure Songe with hure cler∣gie, that joye it was to hure Ar. Oþer bẏssopys and prelats by uore þẏs kyng Arture
And clerkes songe as rẏȝt was, þat joẏe yt was to hure.
In The othur Ar. oþer alf þe quene was Of therchbisshop also Ar. of erchebyssopys al so
ẏlad, and ẏcrouned eke, as ryȝt was vor to Do, To a nother munstre there, & iiii. quenes by fore wende Ar. do,
And to noþer munstre ẏlad, & four quenes bẏ uore hẏr wende,
þe four kẏnges wẏues, þat we bẏ uore nemde,
And euery of hem in hure hond a whit coluere bere. Ladies fele and faire y nogh also ther were Ar. And foure wyte colfren byuore hẏr also bere.
þe companye of laẏdẏes wel grete also were.

þo Postremo peracta processione, tot organa, tot cantus in utris∣que fiunt templis, ut prae nimia dulcedine milites, qui aderant, nescirent quod templorum prius adirent Galfr. Mon. hii were to chyrche ybroȝt eẏþer in ẏs sẏde,

So noble and mery was the song and melody that tyde, That men thoghte also murye as thegh hii hadde be nome, Ne hii ne wiste to whather churche meryer it was to come Ar. So gret & murẏe was þat song, þat me song þer inne wyde,
þat þe folc stod, þat þer were, as hii were y nome,
Ne hii nuste to weþer chẏrche murgorẏe yt was to come.
þe kyng was to ẏs paleẏs, þo þe seruyse was ẏ do,
Ylad wyþ His meyne, Ar. þẏs menẏe, and þe quene to hyre al so.

Vor Antiquam namque consue∣tudinem curiae servantes Brit∣tones, consueverant mares cum maribus, mulieres cum mulieri∣bus festivos dies celebrare se∣paratim Galfr. Mon. hii hulde þe olde vsages, þat men wyþ men were
Bẏ hem sulue, and wymmen bẏ hem sulue al so þere.
þo hii were echone ẏ set, as ẏt to her stat bycom,
Kaẏ, kẏng of Aungeo, a þousend kynȝtes nome
Of noble men, ẏ cloþed in ermẏne echone
Alle in on sewte, to serue the feste a non Ar. Of on sẏwete, and seruede Malim, at. as þẏs noble feste a non.
Bedwer þe botẏler, kẏng of Normandẏe,
Nom al so in ẏs half a uaẏr companye
Of a no∣ther siwte, to serue the butel∣rie Ar. Of on sywẏte, vorto seruy of þe botelerẏe.

Bẏ uore In palatio quoque reginae innumerabiles minis∣tri, diversis ornamentis induti, obsequium suum praestabant, morem suum exercentes. Quem si omnino describere pergerem, nimiam prolixitatem historiae generarem Galfr. Mon. þe Quene eke also ther was such cour∣taisye, Ar. quene ẏt was also of al suche corteẏsẏe,
Vorto telle al þe noblẏe þat þer was ẏ do,
þey mẏ tonge were of Stel, hit nolde suffice ther to. Wommen tolde of no knyght tho as in loue and druerye, But he were in armes preued atte leste thrye Ar. stel, me ssolde noȝt dure þerto.
Wẏmmen ne kepte of no kynȝt as in druerẏ,
Bote he were in armẏs wel ẏprowed, & atte leste þrẏe.
þat made, Tho the Ar. lo! þe wẏmmen þe Cha∣ster lyf to lede, Ar. chastore lẏf lede,
And þe kẏnȝtes þe stalwordore, & þe betere in her dede.
Sone after þys noble Mete, ech wende in his sẏde, Knyghtes and squyers eke, and buskede hem to ryde, In the feldes and in the medes Ar. mete, as rẏȝt was of such tẏde,
þe kẏnȝtes atẏled hem aboute in eche sẏde,
In feldes and in medẏs to preue her bachelerẏe.
Somme wyþ lance, some wẏþ suerd, wẏþ oute vylenẏe,
Wẏþ pley ẏnge at The tables, & the esche∣kere, Ar. tables, oþer atte chekere,
Wẏþ castynge oþer wẏþ ssetynge, Othur som othur manere. What man of any game hadde Ar. oþer in som oȝẏrt manere.
And Quicumque ergo ludi sui victoriam adeptus erat, ab Arturo largis muneri∣bus ditabatur Galfr. Mon. wuch so of eny game adde þe maẏstrẏe,

Sic Codex Harleyanus; at in Ar. plane, The kyng hem yaf ẏiftes grete, & dude hem cour∣taisye. And hegh vpon alures ladies gonne by holde, To waite ho so dude best, & most was of tolde. Alle fulle fower daies last thus hure pleye In valeis aboute, and faire feldes, & mete eke of nobleye. The v. day come thes men bifore the kyng there, Ar. þ kyng hem of ẏs ȝẏfteþ dude large corteẏsẏe.
V pe þe alurs of þe castles þe laẏdes þanne stode,
And byhulde þẏs noble game, & wẏche kynȝts were god.
Alle þe þre hexte dawes ẏlaste þẏs nobleye
In halles and in veldes, of mete and eke of pleye.
þẏs men come þe verþe daẏ bẏuore þe kynge þere,
And he ȝef hem larȝe ȝẏftẏs, euere as hii wurþe were.
Byssoprẏches and cherches To clerkes he yaf sone, Castelles to knyghtes eke, as best hym thoght to done. Ar. clerkes he ȝef somme,
And castles and tounes kynȝtes þat were ycome.″
Seyn Dauid was þe kẏnge's vncle, hẏm he Yaf that day Ar. ȝef adaẏ
þe herchebyssopryche of Carleon, as he wel bysaẏ.
Vor he was suẏþe holy mon, And let a munstre rere In the cite of Meneve, and lith nogh bu∣ryed there Ar. and munstre let rere,
þat me clepuþ in Walẏs Seẏn Dauid, & ȝut he lyþ þere.
þe bẏssoprẏche of Wẏnchestre a god mon he ȝef þo,
Of Chychestre anoþer, and ȝut oþer mo.
þe wule þe kẏng and ẏs men aboute þẏs nobleye were,
þer come in tuelf olde men mẏd Moderatis passibus Galfr. Mon. euene pas þere,
Men of wel vayr semblant, and branchẏs hii bere
Of olyue, as in sygne þat hii of pes were.
A letter Hii toke to the kyng, and he than let hit rede. Fro Lucẏe the senatour hit come, and thus hit sede: "Lucie senatour Ar. he toc þe kyng, þat þo he yt let rede.
Fram þe cenatour of Rome hii come, and þys seẏde:
"Lucie, þe cenatour of Rome, to Arture þe kyng,
"Sendeth, as he hath deseruyd, with oute gretyng. Muche wonder we haueth of thi reuerẏe, Ar. Send, þat he F. of deserued aþ. ofte serued aþ, wyþ oute gretẏnge.
"Muche Admi∣rans vehementer admiror su∣per tuae tirannidis protervia. Admiror, inquam, & injuriam, quam Romae intulisti, recolli∣gens indignor Galfr. Mon. me wondreþ and ouer muche of þy reuerẏe,
"Of þyn cruel luþer hede, and of þẏn robberẏ;
"And namelẏche of þẏn vn rygt ychabbe gret dedeẏn,
"þat þou to þe noble stede of Rome dest mẏd al þẏ mayn.
"And þat þou nelt Hure Ar. hẏm ẏknowe, ne do þyn seruage,
"Ne vnder stonde hou luþer yt ys, to Do hure eny Ar. do enẏ outrage
"Or greuy oght that noble stede, Ar. Oþer wernẏ out þe noble stude, þat al þe world Boweth Ar. abueþ to.
"Vor þyn auncetres dude al, þat we þe hoteþ do.
"And þou, as in gret despyt of so noble seẏnorẏe,
"Noght only at halst hure truage, but dost also roberie, By reuynst Fraunce and othur londes, Ar. Ne at halst noȝt one þy truage, ac myd þy reuerye
"Rauẏsest France & oþer londes, þat bẏ Weste beþ echon,

"þat bere Som tyme truage to Rome, & nogh bereth hii non. And for this ilke grete de∣spit the noble Court of Rome Ryght wole haue of, that thugh hast mysdo ofte y lome Ar. truage to Rome, & þoru þe ne doþ noȝt non.
"Vor þanne of þe gret despẏt þe noble court of Rome
"Ryȝt wole habbe of þe ẏwys, þat þou hym dest ẏlome.
"Amydde haruest we þe setteþ day of þẏs nexte ȝere,
"At Rome vorto ansuerẏe, and þat þou be þe sulf þere
"We þe hoteþ, vorto auonge þat þe court þe wole deme.

"And bote þou do Of that y seighe take ryght nogh good yeme, Elles my self y wole the seche, and thurgh my sweord restore Al that thugh vs hast bynome, and yut ther to wel more Ar. of one þyng nym wel ȝode ȝeme,
"þat ẏchylle my sulf þe seche out, & þoru suerd restore
"Al þat þẏ reuerẏe vs aþ by nome, and more.

þẏs was a prout mandement, And gret manassynge. The kyng hadde foul scorn of this ilke bostynge. For in stede of truage of siluer and of goolde He sende hem Lucie's body, burie hit ho so wolde Ar. and an heẏnol dede.
þe kyng adde þerof gret despyt, þo he hurde ẏt rede.
Vor þe vorste truage, þat he sende to Rome, of seluer oþer of golde,
þat was Lucẏe's bod aslawe, burẏe ȝyf hii ẏt wolde.
The kyng cluped ac noȝt vor þan ys conseyl wel sone,
To ansuerẏe to þẏs Ilke lettre, what Ar. mandement, wat were best to done.
Cadour, erle of Cornwayle, stod somdel and lou,
And verste seyde ys auẏs mẏde gode wylle ẏnou.

"Syre," he sede, "her Huc usque in timore fue∣ram, ne Britones, longa pace quietos, otium, quod ducunt, ignavos faceret, famamque mi∣litiae, qua ceteris gentibus cla∣riores censentur, in eis om∣nino deleret Galfr. Mon. bẏuore ychabbe ẏbe sore drad,
"Laste The ydel Ar. þat ẏdel lyf, þat þẏne men Longe haueth y lad, Nogh out of hure good loos in to slouth hem broghte Ar. abbẏþ ẏ lad,
"Nou monẏ day out of los and in sleuþe hem broȝte.
"Vor wanne men beþ al ydel, þat er bataẏles soȝte,
"Her ẏdelnesse hem ssal brẏnge to synne lecherye,
"To tauerne, and To drunkenesse, & othur hasardrie Ar. to sleuþe, and to hasarderẏe.
"Hyt ẏs neẏ vẏf ȝer, þat we abbẏþ ẏlyued in such vyce,
"Vor we Hadde noght to done, and haue had oure delice Ar. nadde noȝt to done, and in suche delẏce.
"And þer wẏþ Is noght God a payd, Ar. nẏs noȝt God ẏpaẏd, þer vore he aþ ybroȝt
"þe Romeẏns In to such a will, that we be ydel noght Ar. in suche wẏlle, þat we nere to ẏdel noȝt,
"Ac þat we come to vr stat aȝen of vre verste prowesse,
"Lest we felle in dedlych sunne vor vr ẏdelnẏsse.
þo he adde ysed ẏs auẏs, & oþere hẏm bere wẏtnysse,

Than seide kyng Arthur in murthe & in gladnesse. "Ye lor∣dynges, that y preued haue in consail and bataille, And as noble men founde, & wolde me neuere faille, Ar. þe kyng Arture sede ys al in gladnesse.
"ȝe louerdẏnges," he sede, "þat ychabbe in conseẏl & in batayle
"ẏ fonded as vor aȝte men, þat me nolde neuere faẏle,

"Doþ nou Facilius ergo inquietationem Lucii to∣lerare poterimus, si commu∣ni studio praemeditati fueri∣mus, quibus modis eam debili∣tare institerimus. Quam non multum timendam nobis exis∣timo, cum irrationabili causa exigat tributum, quod ex Bri∣tannia habere desiderat Galfr. Mon. al ȝoure wyt þerto, me wel to consayle,
"And casteth, hogh to make a knotte in the Romaynes taille Ar. And ych hopẏe we ssolle þe lasse recche of þe Romeyns tayle.
"Vor me þencheþ myd vn ryȝt hii Axeth Ar. esseþ vs truage.

"Vor Julius Ce∣sar alther furst tok hit with outrage, For a contek that bytwẏne oure eldrene was tho. He nom hit furst with vnright, & broght the lond in wo. That thyng, that with wrong is nome, hogh myght hit be with right? Ar. July Cesar yt nom vorst myd strengþe & mẏd out∣rage,
"þoru descord & contek, þat bytuene vr elderne vas þo.
"He nom verst myd vnryȝt, & broȝte þat lond in wo.
"And þẏng þat ys myd strengþe ẏnom, hou mẏȝte yt be myd ryȝt?
"Vor he Hath no reson to, but Ar. naþ reson non, bote robberye and mẏȝt.

"And with also good reson we mowe of hem y wis Abere thilke truage, that as thyng robbed is. For by Julie and other emperours hii thenk∣eth come ther to, And we in the same manere may seye also, That oure auncetres of this lond som tyme wonne Rome, As Belyn & Brenne, noble men that ye haue hurd of y lome Ar. And Quoniam ergo id, quod injustum est, à nobis praesump∣sit exigere, consimili ratione petamus ab illo tributum Ro∣mae, & qui fortior supervene∣rit ferat quod habere exop∣tavit. Nam si, quia Julius Caesar, ceterique Romani re∣ges Britanniam olim subjuga∣verunt, vectigal nunc debere sibi ex illa reddi decernit, si∣militer nunc ego censeo, quod Roma mihi tributum reddere debet, quia antecessores mei eam antiquitus obtinuerunt. Belinus etenim &c. Galfr. Mon. myd as reson we mowe of hem esse ywẏs.
"Bere he þanne þe oþer truage, þat byneþe ys.
"Vor July and oþer emperours, hii seggeþ, com þer to,
"þat emperors were of Rome. ẏch maẏ segge al so,
"þat myn auncetres of þẏs lond wyle wonne Rome,
"As Belẏ þe noble kyng, þat ȝe abbeþ ẏhurd ẏ lome,
"And Constantyn, Eleyne sone, Ye witeth Ar. hii wuteþ wel Rome nom,
"And suþþe Maxymẏan, and of F heyre. Nam hure in Ar. beyre blod ych com,
"Mẏn auncetres Hii were alle Ar. were alle þre, & kynges of þẏs londe,
"Hii wonne them∣perie of Rome, & tho hii hitte hadde an honde Ar. And wonne þe emperẏe of Rome, & boþe adde an honde.

"Of Cen∣setisne ergo vectigal ex Roma∣nis petendum? De Gallia au∣tem sive collateralibus insulis non est respondendum, cum illas diffugeretur defendere, quando easdem potestati eorum subtrahebamus Galfr. Mon. France & Of other londes, that we wonne with vnryght Ar. oþer londes, þat we wonne myd vr myȝte,

"We mowe segge, þat we Ne mogh answere ther to with ryght. When they forsoke and for sleuthede, and to non defence come, Tho we thurgh chiualrye out of hure hondes hit nome. For hii ne mogh seye with treson, ne with stalthe, hit was do, For thes ix. yer non of hem ones come ther to Ar. nabbeþ to ausuerẏe noȝt myd rẏȝte.
"Wanne hii for soke ẏs, & for slewþed, & to non defence ne come,
"þo we þoru chyualerẏe out of her poer ẏs nome.
"Vor hii ne mowe noȝt segge, þat with treson, oþer stalþe, ẏt were do.
"Vor wẏþinne nẏe ȝere non of hem ne com enes þer to.
Howwel, kyng of þe oþer Brẏtaẏne, þo he hurde þẏs he sede:
"þeẏ ech of vs sete aldaẏ, þe beste red to rede,
"Betere ansuere ne ssolde we fẏnde, Than that that ye han sede. Wel oughte the man honoured be, that is so noble of rede Ar. þan ge abbeþ nou ysed.
"þere vore we aȝte honoury wel of so noble wẏt þẏ red.

"Vor Nam si, juxta praedictam rationem, Romam adire volu∣eris, non dubito quin triumpho potiamur, dum libertatem no∣stram tueamur; dum juste ab inimicis nostris exigamus, quod à nobis injuste ipsi re∣petere inceperunt. Quicumque enim sua alteri eripere cona∣tur, merito, quae sua sunt, per eum, quem impetit, amittit Galfr. Mon. ȝẏfwe in þẏs manere wendeþ, we ne faẏleþ In non wise, To haue the maistre, in defence of oure owene franchise Ar. anone wẏse,
"þat we ne ssolde abbe þe maẏstre, wanne we defendeþ oure franchise.
"And wo so anoþer monne's Good taketh with vnright, Ar. god bẏnẏme wole mẏd vnryȝt,
"Mẏd ryȝt he maẏ ẏs Owene leose, & the de∣fendour haue myght Ar. owe lese, ȝẏf þe defendor aþ þe myȝte.
"And Sut∣the the Romeynes beth aboute to reue vs of oure right, Ar. wanne þe Romeyns aboute beþ, vs to bẏnẏme vr ryȝte,
"Wẏþ reson we Wolleth hem hure bynyme, & to gederes fight Ar. wolle hem bẏnẏme, ȝẏf we mowe to gadere fyȝt.
"Nou ẏt worþ Ful∣fuld, that Ar. ȝended, þat Sẏbyle þe sage sede bẏ uore,
"þat þer ssold of Brutaẏne þre men be ẏbore,
"þat ssold wẏnne þe emperẏe of Rome, Of the two do hit is, Ar. & þe tueye ẏdo ẏt ys,
"As of Belẏ and Constantẏn. & þou art þe þrydde ywẏs.
"Hye The faste for to Ar. nou vaste vorto auonge þẏs noble honour al,
"To brynge hem vnder þe, That wolde the make thral Ar. þat þe wolde make her þral.
"Hye Blyue to a vaunce vs alle, y wole noght be by hynde, Ar. nou to anhansẏ vs alle, & ẏnelle noȝt be byhẏnde,
"Ten þousend hors Heled ther to y wole the fynde Ar. ywrẏe, ẏch þe wolle fẏnde.
Aunsel, þat þe kẏng adde ẏmad kẏng of Scotlonde,
Glad ẏ nou was For that word Ar. myd þys word, & vor joẏe held vp ẏs honde.
"Vor þat," he sede, "ẏchabbe ẏhurd, so gret joẏe ẏchabbe and blys,
"That I haue no tonge, to telle hogh joyful my herte is Ar. þat ẏ nabbe non tonge, þat mowe al yt ssewe ẏwẏs.
"Vor al, þat we abbyþ of londes and of kynges byuore
"ẏ wonne mẏd chẏualerẏe, ẏt þyncþ me al vor lore,
"Bote we of Romeẏns be awreke & of Saxons al so,
"þat vre elderne er þẏs so muche ssame abbeþ ẏdo.
"And nou þe tẏme ẏs icome, þat we mowe ben awreke,
"So glad ẏcham, That I ne wot, what Ar. þat ẏ not, wat vor joye speke.
"Vor ẏ ne wẏlnede neuere þẏng so muche, as ych do her blod,

"Me thinketh, to haue to do o day with hem wold do me good. Softe wolde the woundes be to me, and no thyng stronge: Swete wolde also be my deth, yf y hym shal a fonge Ar. Ou! Jhesu! þat þulke daẏ worþ me suete and god.
"Suete wolleþ þe wounded be to me, & noþẏng stronge:
"Suete wole ek mẏ deþ be, ȝẏf ych ẏm auonge
"Vorto awreke Oure Ar. hor faderes, & to holde vp oure franchẏse,
"And vorto A vaunce Ar. anansẏ our kẏng, as we ssolde in al wyse.
"Seche Aggredia∣mur igitur semiviros illos, & aggrediendo perstemus, ut, devictis ipsis, eorum honori∣bus cum laeta potiamur vic∣toria Galfr. Mon. we out þulke halue men, ne abẏde we noȝt to longe,
"þat We mogh, when they beth dede, hure faire londes fonge Ar. we after her wrecche deþ her londes auonge.
"And ycholle our ost eche, and our bachelerẏe,
"Wẏþoute archers & vot men, wẏþ tuo þousend hors ẏ wrye.
Of men here of þẏs lond þe kẏng adde þer wyþoute
Sẏxtẏ þousend hors Y heled, and that Ar. y wrye, & þat was a uaẏr route.
þe kynges of sẏx ẏles ek, as Norþewey & Yrlonde,
Godlond and Orcadas, Denemarch and Yslonde.
Sene kynges ek aboute Fraunce, as Brutayne & Normandẏe,
Gascoẏne and Aungeo, and al so Pẏcardye,
Of Peyto, and of oþer tuo, and Dusze Ar. dozze pers of France.

Among hem alle Syker hii were, with oute variaunce. An hundred thusend hors he led, of fotmen was non ende. Ther was a faire companye thurgh al the wordle to wen∣de. Tho that al this was byspoke, and syker were alle at on, Euery man to his contre highede sone anon, I charged a Lammasse day with hure power hii come Euery man to Barbefleet, and this viage nome. Thanne to the messagers answerd Arthur the kyng, That to Rome he wolde come and no truage bryng, But forto wynne ther of hem thulke self seruage, Ar. hii were sẏker al, wẏþoute balance,
Of an hondred þousend hors, & four score þousend þerto,
And þre Sic. sousend wel ywrẏe, & tuo hondered also,
Wyþoute fot men, þat were so vale, þat þer nas of non ende,
þẏs was a uaẏr compaẏnẏe, þoru al þe world to wende.
þo þẏs was sẏker & byspeke, þe kyng hem het L. echon. echom,
þat hii wende ech in ẏs syde to her contreẏe anon,
And þat hii alammasse daẏ mẏd her poer come
Echone to Barbesflet, and þes veage nome.
þe kẏng bed þe messagers, þat hii þe senatour sede,
þat he wolde to Rome come, ac no truage hẏm to lede,
Ac vorto conquerẏ of hẏm þulke sulue seruage,
þat hii askẏeþ of hym Spitously, Ar. vyllẏche, and mẏd outrage,
And þat he wolde to Rome come þe daẏ þat hii hẏm sette
And ryght haue ho so myght, when hii to gederes mette Ar. þe rẏȝte abbe weþer so myȝte, wanne hii hem to gadere mette.

þus Digrediuntur ergo legati, digrediuntur reges, digredi∣untur proceres, &, quod eis praeceptum fuerat, perficere non differunt Galfr. Mon. departede Deest Ar. þo″ þe court, and Euery man wende on his syde, And euery man to holde his day a rayde hym thanne to ryde Ar. eche in ẏs sẏde
ȝarked hem aȝen þe daẏ, vor hii F. ne myȝte leng. mẏȝte leng abẏde.″
LUCE þe senatour, þo he wuste þys maundement,
Sone he adde wẏde aboute ẏs messagers Sent Ar. ysend,
Vorto gadery to ẏs help al The power Ar. þat poer of Rome,
So þat aȝen Lammasse alle þes kẏnges to hẏm come,
Of Affrẏc and of Grece, of Spaẏne and of Sẏrye,
Of Medes and of Perces, Of Tharce and of Libie Ar. of Ituraeorum Galfr. Mon. Ytours, of Lybye,
Of Egypt and of Babẏlonye, and of Frugye,
And al so of Mesopotanie Ar. Mesopot, of Bytẏnie, of Boecẏe.
Alle þes kynges, and al oþer þat were bẏ Este Rome
And al þat to Rome ssolde seruẏse, to hym come,
So þat fourty þousend hors & syxty hondred also
þer were, Tho hii were alle redy, this Ar. þo hii ȝare were, þẏs chyualerye to do.

Kẏng Compo∣sito igitur adventu ipsorum, Arturus, Modredo nepoti suo conservandam Britanniam atque Gannumarae [Sic Co∣dex MS. quem mihi perquam be∣nigne donavit amicissimus Gra∣vesius, licet alii Guennoveram & Guenheram, vel Gonnoram sive Gouernwauram appellent] reginae committens, cum exer∣citu suo portum Haẏmonis a∣divit, ubi tempestivo ventorum flatu mare ingressus est Galfr. Mon. Arture bytok Modred, ẏs sẏster sone, ẏch wene
Hẏs lond to kepe, tho he wende, & also Gonnore the quene Ar. þẏs lond to loke, þo he wende, & Gouernewaur þe quene.
Vor he truste to F. hem. hẏm mest, as me þẏngþ he wel aȝte,
Ac, as ye schulle her after hure, to most sorwe he hym broght Ar. And, as ȝe ssolde her after yhure, hii broȝte hym suþþe to naȝte.
Mẏd al ẏs ost of þys londe to Souþhamptone he wende,
And dude hẏm Forth in the see, Ar. in see, mẏd wẏnd þat God hẏm sende.
þo he come ver in þe see, and he aslepe was,
Euene a boute mydnyght, hym mette a wonder cas Ar. At tẏme of mydnyȝt of þe nyȝt, hẏm mette a greuous cas.
Hym þoȝte he seẏ a grẏslẏch beore Fle out of the Est an hegh, That alle men, that negh hym were, quaked, whan they hym segh. A grisly dragon fro by Weste Ar. fle in þe eẏr anheẏ,
Cujus murmure tota lit∣tora intremebant Galfr. Mon. þat alle þe þauenes quakede of þe flyȝt hẏm þoȝte he seẏ.
And an dreduol dragon fram þe West come myd hẏm to fyȝte,
þat Thurȝh the lightnesse of his eyen Ar. þe leom of ẏs eẏen al þe contreẏe A light Ar. lẏȝte.
An þe dragon Ouercome this bere, Ar. velde þulke bere, & to grounde hẏm caste.
Loco hujus versus haec habet Ar. And ded left hym in the feld, this Arthur sore a gaste Ar. An noþer dragon com fram Est, & mẏd þulke dragon faȝt vaste.″
þo þe kẏnge awok, he told ẏs meẏne of þẏs cas.
And some bẏþoȝte, and tolde wat þe Bitoknyng Ar. bẏtokne was,
þat þe dragon of bẏ Weste bytokned þe kẏng Arture,
And þe beore som foul geant, þat me ssolde of ẏhure.

Some seide also, that the kyng sholde with honour Fighte er longe were with the Cenatour, And seide, the Cena∣tour bi tokned the best of by Est, And Arthur to the dragon that com fro by West. Ther after hii come Ar. þat he ssolde ouercome þe geant; & þe dragon of bẏheste
Bẏtokned þe emperour of Rome, & þe bataẏle of the beste
Ouercome bẏtokned þat þe Romeẏns ssolde al so.
Ac þe kẏng ne jugede noȝt, þat ẏt ssolde be so ẏ do,
þer after hii come″ to Barbesflet, & pẏȝte þer by sẏde
Her tentes and pauẏlons, her compaẏnẏe to abẏde.
Under þat þer com word to þe kyng Arture,
þat þe meste geant, þat mon ssolde of ẏhure,
Out of þe lond of Spaẏne com, & adde Rauesshed Ar. ynome″ Eleẏne
þat was so vaẏr, þe kẏnge's nece Howwel of Brutayne,
And vpe þe mount of Seẏn Mẏchel ẏre lede atte laste,
And þe kynȝtes of þe lond sẏwed after vaste,

Ac hii ne myȝte nout aȝen hẏm do. Vor Nam sive mari, sive terra illum invadebant, aut naves eorum ingentibus saxis obruebat, aut diversorum ge∣nerum telis interimebat. Sed & plures capiebat, quos se∣mivivos devorabat Galfr. Mon. weþer so hii wende
Bẏ water, oþer bẏ londe, anon rẏȝt he hem ssende,
With speres & stones also, fewe a lyue he let Ar. Mẏd gleẏue oþer mẏd roches, and newe alẏue he let.
And some he mẏd strengþe nom, & al quyc hem fret.

Al stillely, whan hit was nyght, Arthur clepede a part Bed∣uer his boteler, and Kay his stiward, And two squyers with hem also, that he muche triste, And wende forth al pri∣uely, that his ost hit nyste. Whan thei negh the hulles come, a fure uppon they segh, And vppon the lasse hulle a nother that were somdel negh. Thau nuste hii Ar. Al styllelyche wẏþinne nẏȝt þe kẏnȝ nom ys boteler
Bedwer, þat nomon yt wste, and Gaẏ ys panyter,
(Vor he truste to hem meste) and wende vorþ as alone,

Vor Tanta namque virtute prae∣valendo negligebat contratalia monstra exercitum ducere, cum & suos hoc modo inanimaret, & solus ad illa destruenda suffi∣ceret Galfr. Mon. he volde to such geant verdes lede vone
Vor o bodẏ, as we seyþ, and so muche ek he truste
To hym sulue & to hardẏssẏ. Ys men wanne hii ẏt wuste,
þo he come toward þẏs hul, a gret fur þeruppe he seẏ,
And anoþer vppe a lasse hul, þat þer bẏsẏde was neẏ.
Nou Dubitantes illico super quem eorum habi∣tasset gigas, Beduerum diri∣gunt, ut certitudinem rei explo∣raret Galfr. Mon. nuste hii″ to soþe, vppe weþer þe geant were;
Bedwer he sende vorto aspẏe stẏlelẏche verst þere.
Verst to þe lasse hul In a bot, that he fond, Ar. mẏd Navicula Galfr. Mon. assẏp, þat he vond,
He wende al bẏ water, vor he ne Myght by lond Ar. mẏȝt noȝt alonde.

þo Cujus [montis] dum cacumen incepisset ascendere, audito desuper femineo ululato [Sic Codex ille, quem mihi dono de∣dit amicissimus Gravesius, non ululatu] primo inhorruit, quia dubitavit monstrum adesse Galfr. Mon. he com Up to the hulle an hegh, at the bygynnyng, Of a womman he hurde a cry pitously playnyng Ar. vp þe hul an heẏ, he hurde atte bẏgynnẏg
Of a womman a deoluol crẏ, and a pẏtos wepẏnge.″
Verst he was sore adrad, þat þe geant were þere neẏ,
And naþeles he Tok good herte, Ar. hente herte, & drou more an heẏ.

Tho he fond ther a fuyr, and a lytel Ar. þo vond he Sic qui∣dem Codex (quem sequimur) Harleyanus, pro quo alii (ut in Ar.) þer (sive þere) forsitan malint. Sed ȝere (quod para∣tum notat) retineo. ȝere þet fur, and a lute þer bẏsyde

A bu∣rieles newe made, & the wom∣man, that cride, Al for olded & for wope, and tho heo segh Bedewer, Lord haue mer∣cy, sheo sayde, on the man, what dost though nouth her? Alas! sheo seide, though wrecche man, what mys a venture Hath broght the to this stede, hogh shalt though longe endure? The pite, that y haue of the, thurgh my herte it geth. Sory I am, that though shalt suffre sone deth. For this foule Geant, haue he of the a∣syght, Thi body, that so gentil is, wole sone be to twyght. For hider he wole come right sone that ilke foule pece, That rauesshede faire Eleyne, kyng Howele's nece Ar. An Inspexit quo∣que tumulum recenter factum, & juxta eum quandam anum flentem & ejulantem. Quae ut eum aspexit, conspectum fletu impediente in hunc mo∣dum profata est: O infelix homo, quod infortunium te in hunc. locum subvectat? O! inenarrabiles mortis poenas passure! miseret me tui, miseret, quia tam detes∣tabile monstrum florem ju∣ventutis tuae in hac nocte consumet Galfr. Mon. burẏels al nywe ẏmad, & a womman, þat so crẏde,
Alner holded sytte þere, and anon, so heo ẏ seẏ
þe kẏng Bedwer, heo sẏȝte, and bẏgan to grede an heẏ,
"Alas! alas! þou wrecche mon, wuch mẏs auenture
"Haþ þe ẏbroȝt in to þẏs stede, alas! hou ssalt on dure?
"Alas! þe pẏnes, þat þou ssalt sone þolẏe, deþ!
"þe pẏte, þat ẏchabbe of þe, þoru out mẏn herte geþ.
"Vor þys verbroẏde geant, abbe he of the an sẏȝt,
"þy faẏre bodẏ so gentẏl vor suolwe he wole to nẏȝt.
"Vor he wole sone come þulke verbroẏde pece,
"þat nom Helene, noble maẏde, kẏng Howwel nece,″
"þat ẏchabbe nou rẏȝt her ẏbured, was norẏse ẏch was,
"þat was al mẏ soule, & al mẏ lyf, ẏch wene non such nas.

"And as this foule Geant wold haue leye hure by, This ilk faire mayde he slogh thurgh his lechery. Tho yede he to me, olde wrecche, his lechorye to fulfille, I take God to witnesse hit was a ye my wille, So that euere wole, whan hym lust with me haue a do. And thus I lyue in this penance, and dury moch wo. Wel sone he wole come her to me, and if though her be founde, Though shalt sey waillaway, & curse the harde stounde. Bedewer Ar. And Nam∣que, recepto infra tenerri∣mum pectus timore, dum eam nefandus ille amplecteretur, vitam, diuturniore luce dig∣nam, finivit. Ut igitur illam, quae erat mihi altera spes, al∣tera vita, altera dulcedo jo∣cunditatis, foedo coitu suo de∣turpare nequivit, detestanda venere succensus, mihi invitae (Deum & senectutem meam testor) violentiam ingessit. Fuge, dilecte mi, fuge, &c. Galfr. Mon. þe wule he wolde þẏs tendre þyng wemmẏ foule ẏ nou,
"And heo ne myȝte ẏt soffrẏ noȝt, mẏd lecherẏe he ẏr slou.
"þo eode he to me olde L. wrecche. werche, to endẏ ẏs L. foule. floule cas,
("To wytnesse God ẏch take, þat aȝen my wylle ẏt was)
"And dude bẏ me ẏs lecherye, alas! þulke stounde!
"þer uor fle þou hendy mon, vor sẏker be þou ẏ founde,
"Wanne he comþ bẏ me to lẏgge, he wole þe lẏme mele
"To drawe and vorsuolwe, perauntre at one mele.
Bedwer″ bẏgan to comfortẏ þe womman in þe place,
And bẏ het ẏre bote of hyre wo bẏtẏme, þoru Gode's grace,
And wende aȝen to þe kyng, and tolde al þys cas.
þe kẏng was sorẏ, þo he wuste, þat The Ar. þet maẏde aslawe was,
In a venture Ar. Ac anauntre he þoȝte hym do, & dude hẏm In his weye, Ar. in weẏe,
þẏs clene maẏde vorto A wreke, with his felawes tweye Ar. awreke, and ẏs felawes beẏe.
Ar hii come vpe To the hul, the Geant was come, And hadde broght a gret swyn, that he hadde nome, Ar. þẏs hul, arst he was ẏcome
þẏs grẏslyche geant, & hadde an vatte baru ẏnome,
And ẏspẏted hẏm þoru out mẏd an ẏrene spẏte,
And rostede in þẏs grete fure, to abbe þe folle bẏte.
Artur bed ẏs Felawes tho to lete hym al one, Ar. felawes, talate hẏm ẏworþe alone,
Ac ȝẏf hii seẏe hẏm in nede, þat hii ne made targynge none.
Kẏng Artur hẏm blessede, and baldelyche ẏnou
Toward þẏs ȝryslẏche Gest with good hert he drogh Ar. fourme myd gode herte hẏm drou.

þe Mox il∣los ut, nihil tale praemeditatus, aspexit, festinavit clavam su∣am sumere, quam duo juvenes vix à terra erigerent. Evagi∣navit ergo rex gladium suum, & praetenso clipeo, quantum velocitas sinebat, properabat eum praecedere, antequam cla∣vam cepisset. At ille, non ig∣narus meditationis, jam cepe∣rat eam, regemque interposito clipeo tanto conamine percus∣sit, quod sonitus ictus & tota littora replevit, & aures ejus∣dem ultra modum hebetavit Galfr. Mon. ȝeant, þo he seẏ hẏm come, bẏgan ys mace adrawe,
þat tueẏe stalwarde men ne ssolde noȝt Ones Ar. enes wawe.

Toward The kynge's hed he smot, he hept hym with his shelde. But yut he bowede hit al doun, and wel harde hit felde. For hit ferde of the strok al the hulle was stoned. Arthur was light a fote, as he was wo∣ned. And lept vp, tho he wra∣thed was, Ar. þe heued þe kẏng he smot, ac he hente mẏd ẏs sselde.
Ac ȝut he brẏde aladoun, and wel harde ẏt velde.
Vor yt F. þoȝte. þorte al þe hul mẏd þe stroc was astoned.
Artur was lyȝt ynou, as he was ẏwoned.
He hupe vp, þo he wroþþe was, and ys suerd adrou,
And smot The Ar. þen ssrewe in the frount, mẏd gode ernest ẏnouȝ
Ac þe vel & fless was so Togh, and the scolle so thicke, That hit greuede hym noȝt ful muche, thegh he harde hitte Ar. bard, & þe scolle hard & þẏcke,
þat, vor þeẏ ẏt ne come noȝt þoru, þe dunt nas noȝt wẏcke.
And ẏs mace he dude ek bẏtuene, And yut the blod out wende, And ran in his eyen so, that hit hym muche a blen∣de Ar. ac þet blod adoun wende
So vaste in eye, and in face, þat hym neẏ ablende.
þe kyng Lepte Ar. hupte her & þer, & leẏde on euere vaste,
So strong vas þe ssrewe, þat no dunt ne myȝte hym adoun caste.
He vemde, & grunte, & stod aȝen, as ẏt were a strong bor,
þat euere wole aȝen þe stroc, vorte he ne maẏ namor.
þe kẏng smot euere her and þer, so þat atte laste
Ernest of herte he nome to hẏm, and adrou so vaste
Calẏburne, ẏs god suerd, þat he scolle clef a tuo,
þat þe suerd was al þer inne ẏhud, The brayn orn out also. So grisly yul the sherrewe, and grisly was his bere, And fel doun as an oke, that for torne were Ar. þat braẏn ornout also.
þo Exclamavit ve∣ro invisus ille, & velut quer∣cus, ventorum viribus era∣dicata, cum maximo sonitu corruit Galfr. Mon. grẏslẏch ȝal þe ssrewe þo, þat grislẏch was ẏs bere.
He vel dounȝ as a gret ok, þat bẏneþe ẏcorue were,
þat ẏt þoȝte þat al hul mẏd þe vallẏnge ssok.
þo stod þe kẏng and lou, þeẏ ech lẏme hẏm ok,
Vor he was werẏ ẏfaȝt. Bedwer he het þere,
þat he Smyte of Ar. croune of þe grislẏch heued, & to castel bere.
So þat hii come to her felawes In the dawenynge Ar. in dawẏnge.
So noble A los was neuere Ar. los nas neuere yhurd, as me bar þo þe kẏnge.
Hẏs men truste þe bet to hẏm, and monẏ blessẏnge
He adde, vor he delẏuerede men of an so voule þẏnge.
þo kyng Arture's men ẏ come were echon,
Sone hii drowe hem toward France, vorto seche her fon.
Hem com tẏtẏnge, þat Themperour Ar. emperour to France ẏcome was
Mẏd so gret folc hẏm to seche, þat such neuere ẏseẏe was.
þer of nas noȝt þe kẏng adrad, Ac wende ther by side Ar. ac vorþore he wende bẏsẏde,
And bẏgan to Picche his pauelones, them∣perour to a bide Ar. puthe ẏs pauẏlons, hẏm vorto abẏde.
þe erl of Oxenford he nom, and anoþer erl al so,
And sẏre Waweẏn, ẏs sẏster sone, þo al þẏs was ẏdo,
And to Lucẏe þe senatour in þẏs manere hem sende,
To hote hẏm, þat hastelẏche out of France he wende,
Oþer þat he come On the morwe, Ar. amorwe, bataẏle vorto do,
Vorto cuþe, weþer adde beterre ryȝt þer to.
Thes Ar. þẏs noble kẏnȝtes wende vorþ, and hete Lucẏe so
Vorto wende out of France, Or elles the bataille do. The senatour's cosyn Quin∣cian answerede gayne atten∣ende, Ar. oþer bataẏle do.
Quẏntylẏan, ẏs neueu, ansuerede atten ende,
þat he nas noȝt þuder ycome, out þanne vorto wende,
Ac to gouernẏ France, That holden of Rome is, Ar. þat of rẏȝte of Rome ẏs,
And þat bote ȝulpẏnge and bost noþẏng mẏd Brutons nẏs.

Sire Wa∣wayn the good knyght was tho wroth y nogh, God wot, And sodeynly drough his sweord, & of his hed he smot, And with that hed to hors he lepte, ther folwede hym y nowe Of Romeyns, to haue wreke hure maistre, & made gret a vowe. Geryn Erl of Chartres, that messager also was, Byturnde hym, whan he sey the Romaynes folwe such a paas, And thurgh the body on he smot with his good launce Ar. Sẏre Ira∣tus illico Gwalguanus, ense, quo accinctus erat, irruit in eum, &, ejusdem capite ampu∣tato, ad equos cum sociis re∣greditur. Insequuntur ita∣que Romani, partim pede, partim equis, ut concivem suum in legatos omni nisu dif∣fugientes vindicent Galfr. Mon. Waweẏn, þe gode kẏngt, was þo wroþ ẏnou,
And among al þat folc hupte ner, and ys suerd adrou,
And smot of þat heued, & anon þat heued mẏd hẏm nom,
And wẏþ ẏs felawes to ẏs hors vor hem all ȝut he com.
Ac wat an horse, wat a vote, þe Romeẏns hẏm sẏwẏde ẏnouȝ,
Vorto awreke her gret maẏster, þat sẏre Waweẏn slou.
Gerẏn, erl of Carcoẏs, þat mẏd kyng Arture was,
He bẏturnede hẏm þo he seẏ þe Romeẏns luþer pas,
And on þoru out þat bodẏ he smot mẏd ẏs lance.
þe erl of Oxenford ek þoȝte of ys cheance,
And bẏturnde hẏm, & mẏd ẏs lance þoru þe þrote smot on.
And þus þẏs þre gode kẏnȝtẏs stured hem among her fon.
þo was þer on, þat het Marcel, þat fondede mẏd al ẏs maẏn,
Forto A venge Quincian, and quelle sire Ar. awreke Quintẏlyan, to sle syre Waweẏn.
Syre Waweẏn hẏm bẏturnde, & an stroc hẏm ȝef,
þat al The Ar. þat heued & þe brest Al clene he to claf Ar. clanlẏche hẏm to clef.
"Go," he seẏde, "to Quincian Ar. Quintẏlẏan in helle þer he ẏs,
"And seẏe hẏm, þat sẏre Waweẏn hẏm sende word þẏs,
"þat suche strokes þe Brutons conne ȝẏue ẏwys,
"For he seide, but ẏilpyng and bost with Brutons is Ar. þat he seẏde, þat myd hẏm bote ȝulpẏnge & bost nẏs.
"Vor Ywot Ar. ẏchot wel þuder þou ssalt, þẏn del þou myȝt hẏm ssewe.
Hẏs felawes he bed turne aȝen, Al thogh they Ar. al þeẏ hii were vewe.
Hii turnde aȝen, & ech of hem atte leste one slou.
Ac euere þe Romeẏns after sẏwede vaste ynouȝ.
So þat þer com out of an wode, as ẏt was bẏspeke,
An sẏx þousend of Brutons, her felawes vorto awreke.
Hii come out mẏd god eẏr, and asaẏlede vaste
The Romeẏns, & monẏe slowe, & somme adoun caste.
þo to Petreẏe, a gret Romeẏn, þẏs tẏdẏnge come,
Ten þousend of hors ẏ wrẏe mẏd hẏm sone he nome,
Vorto helpe ẏs felawes, and þo oþer ne mẏȝte be,
Toward þe wode, fram Whennes that hii come, Ar. wanne he come, þe Brutons gonne to fle.
Ac þo hii come among narwe heggẏs, hii stode aȝen anon,
And turnde Toward hure enemẏes, & faste leyde hem on Ar. þe breste aȝen, & vaste slowe her fon.
And þe Romeyns stod aȝen þo, þat þer was gret slaȝt.
So that the Erl of Oxenford seygh hure fare was noght, Ar. Adeo ut in Codice etiam Harleyano was pro nas forsitan sit repo∣nendum. þe erl of Oxenford ẏseẏ, þat þẏs fare nas noȝt,
þulke, þat he mest truste to, as a gret companẏe,
He bed hẏm sẏwẏ, trwelẏche to do chyualerẏe.
þo þẏs vorewarde was ẏmad, þoru out This ost Ar. ost he drou,
And percede þe ost þoru out, and vaste aboute slou.
So þat to her maẏster Petreye he come,
And vaste, as he adde ẏþoȝt, bẏ þe necke hẏm nome,

And Wrast Ar. quo modo etiam in Codice Harleyano potest legi, si litteram primam non pro þ sed pro þ (nam in hoc codice eodem modo hae litterae effinguntur) ha∣beas. þraste hẏm adoun of ẏs hors, & hẏm sulue al so
Fel doun euene vp hẏm, and ley ther bothe two Ar. Anowarde hẏm vel adoun, as he adde ẏþoȝt to do.″
þe Romeyns sturte Deest Ar. to″ anon, her prince vp to rere,
þe Brutons to helpe Hure lord, faste Ar. her alf, vaste aboute were.
þer was pultẏng and ssouẏng, and stroc mony one.
So þat þe Brutons atte laste, among alle her fon,
Mẏd strengþe ladde vorþ Petreẏe The Romeynes prince there Ar. her prince þere.
þo þe Romeẏns were wyþ out chef, dẏscomfortd hii were
And dis∣parpled her & ther, the Bru∣tones after hem faste, Ar. And to spradde hem her & þer, & þe oþere after vaste,
And slowe & despoẏlede, and to grounde hem caste,
And astored hem mẏd her armes, & þe hexte alẏue nome,
So þat mẏd gret prowesse to Deest Ar. þe″ kyng Arture hii come.
The kyng was tho glad y nogh, for he wiste ther of noght, Ar. Welle þat þe kẏng was þo glad, vor he nuste her of noȝt,
Vaẏre ȝẏftẏs he hym ȝef, and wel mo he adde yþoȝt.
þe prẏsons amorwe to Parẏs he sende,
To holde in prison, & wyþ Hem Ar. hẏm god condut þer wende.
þe Romeyns Thoght her on wel Ar. þoȝte þẏs wel, and, as þe maẏstres hete,
Vẏftene þousend þer wende, þẏs prisons vorto mete.
þo þe Brẏtons come mẏd þe prisons þar,
þe Romeyns come aȝen hem al anonẏwar,
And wende hem to ssende anon, ac þe Brutons aȝen stode,
And defended hem wẏle hii mẏȝte mẏd wel stourdy mode.
So þat, vor defaute of help, hii were al ney ẏssend.
Ac þo com þe duc of Peyto, as God adde þe grace ẏsend,
Mẏd þre þousend hors ywrẏe, & þer of was Id est, he was aware of the trap of the Romans. Nam, Guithardus etenim, dux Pictavensium, comperto dolo cum tribus milibus advenerat, in Galfr. Mon. y war.
þo were þe Brutons glad ẏnou, & þen feld made bar,
And þe kyng of Sirie, Ar. Sẏrge, and mony oþer hii slowe,
And louerdẏnges, þat hii nome, to prison vaste hii drowe.
þo hii to þe kẏng come, and ssewed her stalwardhede,
þe kẏng wos þo glad ẏnou, vor hym þoȝte he nadde no drede.
LUCE þe senatour in þoȝt was he sone,
In such ard cas as hẏm vel, wat were best to done.
So þat he þoȝte Priuely, Ar. stẏllelẏche, to a strong cẏte wende,
Vorte þe emperour hẏm mẏȝte more poer sende.
Kẏng Arture was her of ẏwar, and þoȝte, ar he slepe,
Mẏd al ẏs poer bẏ þe weẏ somwar hẏm To kepe Ar. kepe.
Vorþ he wende mẏd ẏs ost, and þo he was ẏ come
To þe stede, þer he wolde bee, cheueteyns he made somme;
As þe kyng of Cornwaẏle, and of Scotlond al so,
Of Norþweẏe, of Denemarch, of Bruteẏne, of Peẏto,
Of Gascoẏne, of Normandẏe, and erles ȝut þerto
Of Cartoẏs, of Oxenford, of Leẏcestre al so,
And sẏre Wawein ẏs neueu, flour of corteẏsẏe.
Hẏs ost he delde a seuene, and in ech companẏe
Vẏf þousend and vẏf hondred he dude of bachelerẏe
And vẏfty and vẏue, and þat was vaẏr seyngnerẏe.
þe eẏȝteþe ost to hẏm sulue he adde þer wyþoute,
Sẏx þousend and sẏx hondred þere were in þulke route
And syxtẏ and syxe, and ẏs dragon yrerd of golde,
As in stede of ẏs baner, and þanne, ȝẏf eny wolde
Come as to defense, þat ner wounded were,
Oþer werẏ, as in a castel recetted were þere.
þo he adde þẏs ost ẏset, he bẏgan hem rede,
And in þẏs bataẏle to conseẏly, and þes wordes seẏde:

"Myn Domestici mei, qui Brit∣tanniam terdenorum regnorum fecistis dominam, vestrae con∣gratulor probitati, quam nul∣latenus deficere, immo magis vigere, considero &c. Galfr. Mon. leue Preuede Ar. priue kẏnȝtes, þat gode abbẏþ euere y be,
("Vor non, as wẏde as ẏs þe worl, me ne ssal ȝoure per yseẏ)
"Ye haueth wonne to Brutayne, that is our kynde lond, Thritty grete kẏngdomes, and beth nogh in oure hond Ar. ȝe abbeþ ẏ mad leuedẏ, Brutaẏne ȝoure owe lond,
"Of þrettene kẏnedoms, þat we abbeþ in vr hond.
"Vor þeẏ ȝe abbẏþ nou vẏf ȝer Out of bataille be, Ar. of bataẏle vn vsed be,
"ȝut in ȝoure noble prowesse wel Duryng Ar. durẏnde ẏch ȝou se,
"þat so gret folc of Romeẏns ȝe vewe mad fle
"In to þẏs toun her bẏuore, þat sone wolleþ out te.
"And ȝe ssolle hem mete & quelle, as so monye ssepe, vor noȝt.

"Hii Sane orientalium gen∣tium segnitiam in vobis esse existimabant, dum patriam vestram facere tributariam, & vosmetipsos subjugare af∣fectarent Galfr. Mon. wende wel her owe sleuþe on ȝou abbe y caȝt,
"Wanne hii wolde of ȝoure lond so vẏllẏche abbe truage
"And noble men, as ȝe beþ, brẏnge in so vyle seruage.
"Nuteþ hii noȝt þe chẏualerẏe, þat ȝe abbeþ in France ẏdo,
"In Norþweẏe, & in Denemarch, & in oþer londes al so,
"Of her stẏnkẏnge seruẏse þat ȝe abbẏþ out ẏbroȝt?
"þẏs alue men ȝe ssolle wẏnne wel lyȝtloker & vor noȝt.
"Gret honour yogh wole byfalle, the Romeynes and ye ouercome, For we wole a non ther after wende to wynne Rome Ar. Wuch onouers wolde ȝou come, ȝẏf ȝe hem ouercome?
"Vor we wolde anon þer after vorþ and wynne Rome.
"Of þe tresour, þat ȝou þanne Shul haue, Ar. worþ,″ ne of tounes, ne of tours,
"Ne of londes, non ende ne worþ, ne of oþere honours.
þet folc bẏ hete hẏm þo echon, prest vor to be
To deẏe raþer in The feld, Ar. feld, þan þe bataẏle fle.
Lucye þe cenatour al so in ys dede
Ordeẏned and radde ẏs ost, and þes wordes seẏde:
"Mẏne noble kẏnȝtẏs, to was poer and heste
"Alle londẏs ssolle abouẏe Deest Ar. to″ by Weste and bẏ Este,
"þencheþ on ȝoure elderne, þat were of so noble mẏȝte,
"That dradde Ar. Ne dradde noȝt to ssede her blod, vorto wynne her rẏȝt,
"Ac euere foȝte, As thogh hem nere deth shape non, Ar. as hem nere deþ ẏssape none,
"An so hii wonne her seẏgnerye, & ouercome her fon,
"And adde seruage of al þe world, were ẏt nou wel bẏgonne,
"þat we lore þe nobleye, þat hii so noblẏche wonne?

Hys deþ broȝte to þẏs lond muche sorwe and wo.
The Saxones Ar. SAXONS & þe Englẏsse, & her compaẏnẏe,
Adde þo of þys londe al clene þe maẏstrẏe,

Ech kẏng ẏs kẏnedom, þat hii dude er in wo.

Of Estangle, of Norþhomber, of þe Marche, of Estsex.

Byssopes and monekes monẏ on in þe lond.

þat were vnder vii. celles, & ther of non ther nas, That ccc. monekes nere inne othur mo. And alle lyuede by hure swynch, loke whare they do now so. Dinoc het Ar. sene cellen, and þer of non nas
þat þre hondred monekes Malim, nere, ut in Ar. were inne, oþer mo.
And alle leuede by her suenche, loke ȝẏf hem nas wo.

Seynt Austẏn was wel ẏ paẏd, þat her bẏlyue was so god.
And naþeles he hem en yoẏnede Obedience to do Ar. bocsomnesse do
To þe herchebẏssop of Kanterburẏ, & to Englẏsse men also,

And go with hym to Englissh men, Cristendom to mende, And helpe hym preche a∣monges hem, as the pope hem sende. The bisshopes hym answerede, Ar. And among Englysse men vorþ mẏd hẏm Cristendom to amende,
And wende aboute and prechẏ, as þe pope hem sende.
þe bẏssop hẏm ansuerede, and þe abbod Dẏnok,
Al mẏd grete resons and wyt of her boc,
þat wan hii adde hem sulue erchebẏssop and kẏng,
Hii ne ssolde to Englẏsse men abue rẏȝt noþẏng.
For þe folc of Englẏss & Saxons Hure lond hem hadde bynome With gile, and hure heritage with falsnesse and tresone. Wher∣for hii wolde Ar. her lond hem bẏnome,
And her kunde erẏtage, mẏd trayson & suyke dome.
War vor hii nolde for non man nanmore to hem wende,
þan to so mony houndes, bote yt were hem to ssende.
"ȝẏf ȝe nolle," quaþ Seyn Austyn, "wyt ȝoure breþeren in peys be,
"þat beþ, as ȝe wẏteþ wel, Crẏstẏne as wel as ȝe;
"And ȝẏf ȝe nolle Englysse men Gode's lawe teche,
"And vorþ myd me among hem Cristendom preche,
"ȝoure fon ssolle her poer Among Ar. amorẏg ȝou wẏde reche,
"And brẏng ȝou to deþe monẏon, & þat ssal be ȝoure wreche.
After Seynt Austẏne's daẏe to soþe com al þẏs,
Ac þe wule he was alẏue noȝt, as ȝe nowe ẏhure ẏwẏs.
KNG Ethelbert Ar. Aẏlbryȝt gret despẏt adde in ẏs þoȝt,
þat þe Brutons nolde Seynt Austẏn abue noȝt.
Elfrid, Ar. Edelfred, þat was kẏng of Norþhomberlond,
He entẏced and oþer kẏnges here of þẏs lond,
þat hii wende to Walys, and þe Brutons ssende.
þe kẏnges, þo hii preste were, myd poer þuder wende.
At þe cẏtẏ of Cayrleon þe Brutons ost þer was.
þe Englẏsse anon þuderward drowe mẏd god pas.
A gret bataẏle hii smẏte þer in a lute stounde.
Ac Brocmayl, duc of Brutons, was þer ẏbroȝt to grounde.
Vor he flen and bẏleuede ys folc, þo he nuste oþer won,
Somme aslawe and somme ẏwounded, and bẏ neþe echon.
Nou were þer ẏ come fram Bangor monekes monẏon,
In vastyng and in orẏsons, to Praye Ar. bydde aȝen her fon.
And ermẏtes and monekes of oþer Houses bisyde. And prayed to God the Brutones Ar. studes bẏsyde
Bede God, þat þe Brutons þe maẏstrẏe moste bẏtẏde.
þo such folc of þys holymen kẏng Elfred ẏseẏ,
Sẏtte and Praye Ar. bẏdde vor her folc, and crẏe To Ar. on God an heẏ,
And me sede hẏm, þat hii Prayed for hure Brutones Ar. dede vor þe Brutons echon:
"ȝyf yt so ẏs," quaþ þe kẏng "þat hii Pray∣eth for oure fon Ar. byddẏþ vor vr fon,
"þanne vẏȝteþ hii aȝen vs, as muche as ẏs her mẏȝte,
"Mẏd her armes to God, þeẏ hii mẏd Armes Ar. sed alibi wepne in eod. Codice. arme ne fẏȝte.

þat folc was Redy Ar. prest þer to, & to grounde slowe anon.

And aboute an vẏftẏ of scapede alẏue vor fere.
þo was ẏt to hem ẏcome, þat Seynt Austyn hem seẏde,
And noȝt vor þan God dude wreche Of thulke lu∣ther dede. Forth went kyng Elfrid of Northhumberlonde tho To Bangor, to destruye Ar. of þe luþer dede.
Vor þe kẏng Edelfred wende toward Bangor þo,

Bẏtuene þe kyng El∣frid, Ar. Edelfred, and þe quene ẏs wẏf,

To þe kẏng Cadwan þe quene wende þo,

þe kẏng Cadwan was þo aboute, bẏtuene hẏre & The kynge Ar. kẏng
To make acord bẏ ẏs poer, and ne mẏȝte vor noþyng.
So þat he hulde vorþ þe quene in ẏs owe house,
Mẏd chẏlde helples as heo was, mẏd þe quene ys owe spouse,
þat mẏd chẏlde was as wel as heo, and of one tẏme neẏ.
