And slou of hem her hexte duc, & oþere men monẏ on.
Hii, þat mẏȝte of scaþẏe alẏue, of londe flowe echon.
El∣flede, Ar. Alfled, quene of þe March, strong Pro, womman sive woman. womwan was and L. queẏnte, cum Ar. uti etiam mox infra poẏnte. quenẏte

Ind in bataile as a kyng i holde in eche poẏnte. Al Wales sheo ouercome, and Yorke was hure also. Atte Camelworthe sheo deẏde sethe, and buried atte Gloucestre thoo Ar. Deinde desiderantur reli∣qua metra, ad Eadwardum hunc spectantia, multaque eo∣rundem loco oratione soluta in∣seruntur, in quibus & indicatur, eum Wigorniae, non Ferenduni (nunc Faringdon, in agro Ber∣cheriensi) obiisse. Nam sic au∣ctor: This Edwarde veil deẏde atte Worcetre, and bu∣ried was at Wẏnchestre, bẏ side his fader. (minus recte. Nam & alii Ferenduni hoc con∣tigisse asserunt.) qui & haec re∣tulit de morte atque sepultura Aelfledae, Elfledae, sive Ethel∣fledae: Ethelflede, lady of Mer∣cheneriche, a boue saide deide to fore hure brother Edwarde veil. v. ẏere, and was burẏed in Seynt Petre's churche atte Gloucestre, whiche heo, with hure husbonde [Ethelred] with grete diligence had i maked, be cause they hadde translated Seynt Oswalde's bonus fram Bardenaẏ thu∣der, but þat bẏ Danes de∣stroyed, a nother abbey now in . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . by Eldre erchbischop of York. In bataẏle, and ẏholde as quene in eche ponẏte.
Al Walẏs heo ouercom, and þe March þerto.
Stafford heo wan, and Leẏcestre, and Warewẏk þerto,
And Bruges & Euerwẏk, & þe contreye Abesse malim. & ″ al so
Of Euerwẏk to hẏre com, hẏre wẏlle vorto do.
At Tamewur þe heo deẏde suþþe, & ẏbured he was ẏ wẏs
In Seẏnt Petre's porche at Gloucestre, as þe abbeẏ ȝut ẏs.
þe kẏnedom þo of þe March kẏng Edward to hẏm nome,
As in þe sẏxe and tuentẏe ȝer of ẏs kẏnedom.
Kẏng Edward adde þre sones: þe eldoste Aþelston,
And Edmond and Eldred, þat kẏnges were echon.
And suþþe he deẏde at Farndone, as God ȝef þat cas,
And in mustre at Wẏnchestre bẏ ẏs fader ẏbured was.
AÞELSTON was þo kẏng, þat was Edwarde's sone,
And þoru þe heẏe men of þe lond ẏcrouned at Kẏngestone.
Nẏne hondred ȝer of grace & foure & tuentẏ ẏ crouned he was,
And but an xvi. yere after kyng he nas Ar. And aboute an fourtẏne ȝer kẏng þer after he was.
Holẏ chẏrche he louede wel, and rerde monẏ on.
þe vorste ȝer of ẏs kẏnedom ẏbore was Seẏn Dunstone.

Nẏwe abbeẏes he made Many ich vnder∣stande, Ne olde Abbey was ther none thourgh oute al his londe, That he ne amended with summe lond, other with summe buildẏng, Other with bokes other clothe, or summe riche thẏng Ar. vaste þẏs gode Aþelston,
And þer nas of olde house in þe lond non,
þat he ne amendede mẏd som lond, oþer mẏd bẏldynge,
Oþer mẏd boc, oþer rẏche cloþ, oþer oþer rẏche þẏnge.
Norþhomberlond he wan, and Walẏs and Scotlond,
And þe kẏnges & her lond held al in ẏs hond.
Hẏm þoȝte ẏt was more nobleẏe, þo he adde an hond al þẏs,
Vorto make kẏnges, þan to be kẏng ẏ wẏs.
Aȝen he made kẏnges, þat kẏnges er were,
Bote þat hii were vnder hẏm, and truage hẏm bere.
þo hii adde her lond aȝen, þe kẏng of Scotlond
Constantẏn, and Analaf kẏn of Homberlond,
Up þẏs kẏng Aþelston gaderede men ẏ nowe,
And here bẏsouþe Homber mẏd her ost drowe.
Analaf was gode Knẏght Ar. kẏnȝt, & stalward & queẏnte.
Menestral he was gode ẏnou, & harpare in eche poẏnte.
To Aþelston pauẏlon mẏd ẏs harpe he wende,
And so wel wẏþoute harpede, þat me after hẏm sende.
þer he harpede so wel, þat he paẏde al þe route,
Ac euere were ẏs eẏen in eche hurne aboute.
After mete, þo hii nolde nanmore of ys pleẏ,
Me ẏaf hẏm ẏiftes for Ar. Hii ȝeue hẏm seluer vor ẏs gle, & let hẏm go ẏs weẏ.
Of his ẏftes he tolde scorne, Ar. Of þe seluer he adde hoker, vor he ne com þuder vor non,
Ac ys wẏlle he adde þo he seẏ þe stat of ẏs fon.
On, þat adde ẏ be wẏþ hẏm, þe kẏng tolde þere.
þe kẏng hẏm blamede þo, þat he nadde ẏtold hẏm er.
"Sẏre, he seẏde, "ẏch was ẏsuore to hẏm ar to þe,
"And ȝẏf ẏch adde hẏm Be trayed, Ar. bysuẏke, þe wors þou wost Truste to me. Ac remewe to a nother stede thẏne tentes Ich the rede, Ar. leue me.
"Ac remewe in to anoþer stude þẏ pauylon bẏ myn rede,
"Oþer þou mẏȝt ȝut to nẏȝt of som treson drede.

Thenne to a nother stede the kyng remew gan. To that place the same nyght [a bischop] cam than, And wende to haue founde the kẏng ther, so that he logged ther, But the Enmẏs cam a nẏght, and wende the kẏng hit were, Ar. þe pauylon was remeued þo, and þe kẏng and alle ẏs,
Ac a bẏssop and ẏs men þer uorþ com ẏwẏs,
And pẏȝte þer her pauẏlon, & bẏleuede al nẏȝt þere.
And þẏs luþer men com anẏȝt, & wende þe kẏng ẏt were,
And slou þe bẏssop and alle ẏs men, þat gult nadde non.
And suþþe hii wende vorþore mo, and soȝte Aþelston.

Of hem nas he noȝt Tum ultra progre∣diens [Analaus] regem ipsum imparatum offendit, quippe qui nihil tale hostem ausu∣rum timens, largae quieti in∣dulserat Will. Malmesb. fol. 26. b. ẏwar Fort atte Ar. ar þo atte laste.
Ac sone he and ẏs men armede hem wel vaste,

And Edmond ẏs broþer mẏd hẏm, And dighte hem echechon Faste to the bataille, to mete with hure fone. The kyng trawe wolde his swerde, when he tẏme I seẏe, And thenne founde he there non. for hit was a waẏ Per aunter bẏ fallẏng a waẏ, or bẏ summe other cas. The kẏng was ther of sore abassh∣ed, as no wonder was. On God Ar. & þo hii preste were echon,
And wende to þẏs batayle, and mette mẏd her fon,
þe kẏng to ẏs suerde drou, and þo ne vond he non.
Hẏt was mẏd treson hẏm bẏnome, hard cas was þat on.
On God″ almẏȝtẏ & Seẏn Aldelm þe kẏng cride vaste þo,
And hii sende hẏm bẏ vayr mẏracle bote in ẏs wo.
To hẏs scaubert he pulte ẏs hond, al preste asuerd he vond
þer inne, þoru God ẏ sond, no betere in lond.
In þe kyng tresorẏe þat suerd ẏut i kepte is, Ar. ẏwust ẏs,
As vor A noble Ar. noble relẏke, ȝut to þẏs daẏe ẏwẏs.
Egged in the on half, Ar. I egged ẏt ẏs in on alf, and in þe oþer noȝt.
þere ne mẏȝte neuere gold ne seluer þeron be ẏbroȝt.
þẏs noble kẏng Aþelston, þo þẏs gode suerd hẏm com,
Nobẏlẏche & wel he faȝt, & so god ernest to hẏm nom,
þat fram þat þe sonne aros, vorte hẏt derc nyȝt was,
þe bataẏle ẏlaste, and neuere werẏ he nas.
Wat þoru ẏs stalwarhede, wat þoru Gode's grace,
Mony was The strong bodẏ, Ar. gode bodẏ, þat he slou in þe place.

þe bataẏle was at Brunnesbury Ar. Vide cl. Gibsoni nominum locorum Explicationem in Chronico Sax. uti etiam Additiones ad ejusd. Gibsoni Camdeni Bri∣tanniae Versionem Anglicam, p. 873. in comitatu Northumbr. Brẏmesburẏ, & þere were of Deneẏs
An of Scottes aslawe, and also of ẏreẏs,
Vẏf ȝonge Knẏghtes Ar. non adeo recte. kẏnges, prout þoru al þẏng,
And prout Constantẏn, þat of Scotlond was kẏng.
And of oþere, þat were aslawe, me ne mẏȝte non ende ẏse.
Hii, þat of scapede alẏue, bẏgonne vaste to fle.
þus This Ar. þe kẏng Aþelston agaste þo ẏs fon.
And for Ar. Vor hii ne ssolde in þẏs lond abbe Resceẏte Ar. recet non,

A castell Ar. Inde certe & in ad∣ditionibus oratione soluta in eodem codice scriptum le∣gimus, In the mene while Athelston lette throw downe, York an olde Castell at Ebraẏwik, that the Danes bẏ olde tẏme hadde i maked, and that hit shulde be no more refute to Enmys, and myche good, ther inne I founde, he parted a monge his men Ar. Sed vi∣desis Will. Malmesb. fol. 27. b. þe castel of Euerwyk to grounde he let caste.
(Vor ẏs fon were ofte þer inne, þe wule Hit dude i laste) Ar. he ẏlaste)
þat hii nadde non recet, vorto greuẏ ẏs lond.

Also of eche purchas, that he gat to his honde, Othur that anẏ of his men that any pur∣chas nome, He for bede that neuere mo a mong his purchas come, Ar. Al so of ech maner porchas, þat com in ẏs hond,
Oþer þat ȝẏf enẏ of ẏs as in porchas nome,
He verbed, þat neuere non among ẏs spence ne come,
Ac to hous of relẏgẏon þat me ẏt al clene bere,
And to poueremen aboute, That seke and mẏsaised were Ar. þat meseẏse were.
Alle þe kẏnges of Walẏs he bro.ȝte wel to lawe
To Hereford al vnder hẏm, to ẏs Wille wel fawe, Ar. wille vawe,
þat tuentẏ pound of golde ech of hem hym bere,
An Trecentas Will. Malmesbur. þrettẏ pound of seluer fram ȝere to ȝere,
And 25. millia Will. M. tuentẏ þousend Oxen a ẏere to this golde, Ar. oxen ek to þẏs golde,
An hauekes and hondes, as monẏ as he wolde.
To certeẏn wonẏnge he hem broȝte boþe lowe & heẏe,
So þat The Walesshmen he putte beẏonde Weigh, Ar. her wonẏnge were al bẏ weste Weye,
And nothẏng in þe Est alf. So þat Weẏe ẏ wẏs
ȝt to þẏs Daẏ deleth Ar. daẏe to delþ Engelond and Walys,
And þoru kẏng Aþelston þat was vorst ẏdo.

Men Inde di∣gressus in Occidentales Brit∣tones se convertit, qui Corne∣wallenses vocantur, quod in Occidente Brittanniae siti, cor∣nu Galliae ex obliquo respi∣ciunt. Illos quoque impigrè adorsus, ab Excestra, quam ad id temporis aequo cum An∣glis jure inhabitarant, cedere compulit, terminum provinciae suae citra Tàmbram fluvium statuens, sicut Aquilonaribus Brittannis amnem Waiam li∣mitem posuerat Will. Mal∣mesb. f. 27. b. of Cornwayle he broȝte to certeyn stude also.
Vor bẏȝonde þe water of Tamer he adde hem alle ẏbroȝt.
To wonẏe þer, as in her owe, and a þẏs alf noȝt.
Vor hii wonede þer bẏ uore anon to Excestre ryȝt,
And Welsse were in Engelond vorte Athelstone hit right Ar. he ẏt adde dẏȝt.
Kẏng Aþelston louede muche Malmesburẏ ẏ wẏs.
He ȝef hem of þe holẏ croẏs som, þat þere ȝut ẏs.
And he was at ẏs ende At Gloucestre he deyde Ar. in marg. daẏ vaẏre ẏbured þere.
Kẏng he adde arst ẏbe aboute an vẏftene ȝer.
EDMOND, Aþelstone's broþer, after hẏm was kẏng,
Gode man & doutede God þoru alle þẏng.
In þe ȝer of grace nẏne hondred ẏt was & Sic. forutẏ ȝer,
þat he was kẏng ẏ mad, and old he was er
Eẏȝtene ȝer, and he was kẏng sẏx ȝer And vii. monethes in Ar. and daẏ
Foure & tuentẏ ȝer he was old, þo he aslawe laẏ.
Saracens þer were, þe ȝut bẏleuede in Engelond,
In Lẏncolne & in Leycestre, & in Derby ẏch vnderstonde,
In Stafford & in Nothyngham. he drof hem al to noȝt,
And Cristẏnemen aboute in her stude broȝt.
þet hous of Glastẏnburẏ he louede wel ẏnou,
And made Seyn Dunston abbed þere, & to ẏs conseẏl hẏm drou,
And þoru ẏs conseẏl chyrchẏn wẏde he let rere,
And abbeẏs and priorẏes aboute here and þere.
In to hous of Glastẏnburẏ gret þẏng he ȝef þo,
And grete franchẏses hem granted, þat lasteþ euermo.

So that hii habbeth Fraunchise as hit were a kyng, As afterward me may I see, thourgh his conferm∣ẏng. Edwẏne his furste sone lithere was i nowe, But Ed∣gar the ẏonger to all gode∣nesse drowe Ar. þat hẏ adde her franchẏses as veruoþ as þe kẏng,
And mẏd gode chartre, þat ȝut ẏs þer, made confermẏng.
Edwẏne ẏs sone was þat luþer was ẏnou,
And Edgar þe ȝongore þat to alle godnesse drou.
Kẏng Edmond atte laste mẏd luþer deþe's wonde
þẏtoslyche was aslawe, alas! þulke stounde!
Vor a traẏtor of This londe, Leof Ar. in quo & Leof etiam infra. ẏs lond, Lof was ẏs name,
I flemed was oute of Engelond, where of cam ther grame Ar. ẏflou was out of Engelond mẏd wretchede & ssame.″
Suþþe adaẏ as þe kẏng sat at ẏs mete
At Pokelchyrche bẏsyde Brẏstowe, & somdel adde ẏȝete,
Lof, þẏs luþer traytor, mẏd ẏs cloþes ẏchanged þere,
Com in, & bẏuore hẏm et, anoþer man as ẏt were.
A Seẏn Austẏne's daẏ ẏt was, as ẏt valþ in Maẏ,
þe kẏng bẏhuld aboute, and þẏs traẏtor ẏ saẏ,
And auẏsed hẏm suẏþe wel, wat man yt were.
And þo he sey þat þẏs Lof, þẏs traẏtor sat þere,
He hupte hẏm vp fram þe bord, in gret wraþþe ẏnou,
And hente þẏs Lof bẏ þe top, And a doune hym drowe, Ar. fram þe borde hẏm drou,
An defouled hẏm vnder hẏm mẏd honde & myd fote.
þe þef, þat laẏ bẏneþe hẏm, þoȝte on luþer bote,
And smot þe kẏng wẏþ a knẏf in þe breste depe ynou,
And, to gret harm to al þẏs lond, þe gode kẏng he slou.
þet folc to drou þen traẏtor ech lẏme pecemele.

þe kẏng bẏgan All bẏ his lyf his gode a boute dele. At Pukelechurche was do this dede. for thẏ to Glastenburẏ He hit ẏaf, and bade me shulde at Glastenbu∣rẏ him burẏ Ar. bẏ al ẏs lyf ẏs gode wel wẏde dele,
And þe toun of Pokelchẏrche, and oþer þat ẏs were
He ȝef in to Glastẏnburẏ, & let hẏm burẏe þere.
And þere he lẏþ ȝut to þus daẏ, ac y not þoru What Ar. wuch dom
þe toun suþþe of Pokelchẏrche fram Glastẏnbury com.
Seẏn Dunston was at Glastynburẏ þo þe kẏng ẏwounded was,
And ẏut in the same stounde he wiste of this cas Ar. ȝut þoru joẏe of Deuel he wuste of þat cas.
Vor þe Deuel com by uore hẏm, Dauncyng and lowgh, And as hit were pleẏing made game i nogh Ar. & hoppede & lou,
And saẏlede and pleẏde, & made joẏe ẏ nou.
þẏs holẏ man wuste anon, wu ẏs joẏe was,
And þat vor som mescheance of þe kẏng he made Suche solas. Dunston toward Pu∣kelchurche dight him self bliue, So that me tolde him bẏ the waẏ, the kyng was out of lẏue Ar. so glad pas.
Toward Pokelchẏrche he wende hastelẏche and blẏue,
An me tolde hẏm bẏ þe weẏ, þat he was out of lẏue.
EDRED was þo kẏng anon after Edmond ẏs broþer,
Vor ẏs tueye sones so ȝonge were, þat me ne mẏȝte abbe non oþer.
God man Edred was y nou, & to godnesse drou anon,
And muche louede holẏ chẏrche, & þe godman Seyn Dunston.
Men of Norþhomberlond were aȝen hẏm vaste,
And of Scotlond also, ac her poer lute ẏlaste.
Vor wat wẏþ loue, wat wẏþ eẏe, he broȝte hem al to ẏs wylle,
And her olde seruage made hem holde al stẏlle.
The Latyn seiþ ix. yere and a half Ar. in margine. Vourtene ȝer he was kẏng, and at ẏs ende day,
Me tolde Seẏn Dunston Deest Ar. vore,″ þat he sẏk laẏ.
To hẏm he wende hastelẏche, and bẏ þe weẏ ẏwẏs

He hurde angles sẏnge an heẏ bẏ the Idem quod An∣gl. Sax. sive desiderium vel fervor. Sed hîc loci hila∣ritatem signabit. perinde ac si dicas, he heard angels sing on high with mirth this sive thus. Inde in Cod. Ar. And as he wende to him warde, he hurde bẏ the waẏ A mery song of angeles thus seggẏng heẏe &c. lẏste þẏs:
"þe kẏng Edred nou aslepe in oure Louerd ẏs.
þo wuste Seẏn Dunston, þat he was ẏwend to Heuene blẏs.

Suche dede kynges now fewe bene vs amonge, That angelus atte hure end∣ẏng maketh of eny songe Ar. Suche gode kẏnges me ssolde Potius, uou, i. e. few, ut ex Ar. constat, nisi cum eod. Cod. few adjicias, retento nou. nou vẏnde among,
þat angeles of her endẏnge mẏȝte made song.
EDWNE, Edmonde's sone, after Edred kẏng was
Fals & luþer, vor non worse in ẏs kunde nas.
As a nẏwe Herodes in such poer he com,
And with his vnell lẏuẏng apeyred Cristendom Ar. And vp ẏs poer destrude and apeẏrede Cristendom.
A fol womman in spousbreche he huld vnder ẏs wẏf.
Seẏn Dunston hẏm seẏde wel, þat ẏt was a luþer lẏf.
And, as Seyn. Jon Baptẏst, kalangede her mẏs dede.
Wroþ was þe kẏng and ẏs hore, þat he her folẏe F. wyþ sede. wyþ,
And þe womman fondede, hẏm to deþe brẏnge.
So þat Seẏn Dunston was, þoru hẏre and þe kẏng,
I flou out of Engelond, and to Flaundres wende.
The gode man was wel a paide of þat God hẏm sende Ar. þe gode man ne toc neuere gome, þat me hẏm so foule ssende.
Abbeẏs þẏs luþer man broȝte ek in alle wo.
And þat hous of Malmesburẏ, þat an old hous was þo,
Deest Ar. Of″ tuo hondred ȝer and seuentẏ ẏrerd þer byuore,
He made ẏt stable to ẏs hors, as ẏt were alle vorlore.
So luþer man was þe kẏng, þat þe heẏmen of þe londe
Bẏgonne, as hii nede moste, aȝen hẏm vaste at stonde,
And bẏnome hẏm muche of ẏs lond, And toke hit Edgar his brother Ar. & bẏtoke Edgar ẏs broþer.
Vor he drou to alle godenesse, and Heigher Ar. betere was þan oþer.
þẏs Edwẏne was þus kẏng þre ȝer, and somdel more,
And þat lond vor ẏs deþe ne wep noȝt ouersore.
And ȝut vor al ẏs ssrewede, as ẏt ẏwrẏte ẏs,
þoru bẏddẏnge of Seẏn Dunston, ẏs soule com to blẏs.
EDGAR Edwẏne's broþer, & Edmonde's sone þe kẏng,
Kẏng was after Edwẏne, gode man þoru alle þẏng.
Non lẏckore ẏs broþer hẏm nas, þan an wolf ẏs a lombe,
Of manere ne of dede, þeẏ hii were in one wombe.
Vor þulke tẏme þat Edgar of ẏs moder was ẏbore,
Seẏn Dunston was at Glastẏnburẏ, & þerafter & bẏuore,
þo hurde he þulke tẏme angles sẏnge ẏwẏs

"þe heẏe tre, þat þou ẏseẏe, bẏtokneþ þe ẏwẏs.
"þe tueẏe applen bẏtokneþ, ȝẏf þou yt wolt ẏwẏte,
"Tueye heẏe sones of þe, þat þou ssalt bẏȝẏte,
"þat þe one's bowe smẏte þen oþer to grounde,

"þe voẏs, þat seẏde, "wel ẏs þe," to toknẏ þat ẏs,
"þat hẏm worþ wel ẏnou, vor to heuene he wende ẏwẏs.

Seẏn Edward and Aeldred, þat kẏnges were beẏe,

He het, þat he hẏm sende eche ȝer bẏ maẏstrye

Of a so lute halue man, as kẏng Edgar was,
þat þer nas lond ne prince non, þat of hẏm adrad nas.
þẏs word com to þe kẏng Edgar, þeruor he þoȝte hẏm teche,
Wuch were þe halue man, ȝẏf he mẏȝte hẏm of reche.
He com and mette hẏm in a wode, and bed hẏm abẏde,
And he adde vor þe nones tueẏe suerdes bẏ ẏs sẏde.
He drou out boþe tuo, and bed hẏm nẏme an honde,

þe oþer vel adoun akne anon rẏȝt vor drede,

þe godenesse al of kẏng Edgar none tonge telle ne maẏ.

Sent Edward þe marter, as ẏch seẏde er, was ẏs sone

Bẏ ẏs raþere wẏf, and Seẏnt Atqui cave sis, ne pro filia legitima habeas. Spuria etenim erat, è Wlfritha sive Wlfrida ab Edgaro suscepta. Inde Will. Malmesb. (f. 33. b.) Nam de Egelfleda, cogno∣mento candida filia Ordmeri ducis potentissimi Edwardum genuit, & sanctam Editham de Wlfritha, [al. Wlfrida] quam certum est non tunc
sanctimonialem fuisse, sed ti∣more Regis puellam laicam se velavisse, moxque eandem ar∣repto velo lecto imperiali sub∣actam: Unde offensum bea∣tum Dunstanum, quòd illam concupisset, quae vel umbra∣ticè sanctimonialis fuisset, vigorem Pontificalem in eum egisse. Quae verba & ipsum etiam auctorem prosaicum in Codice Ar. ob oculos habuisse compertum habeo, quamvis Sanctam Editham non nomi∣net. Sic nempe ille: To this Ensample of cruwelte (jam an∣tea locutus fuerat de Ethel∣woldo, ab Edgaro occiso, eo quod minus honeste sese gessis∣set in negotio ad filiam ducis Devoniae, Venere quasi ipsa formosiorem, pertinente) er dude, his foos putteth a nother, that is to saye, that Wulfride monechẏn i sacred he toke out of hure abbey, & delt with her holdẏng his lemman. Which Poẏnt whenne Seẏnt Dunstone hurde, he blamed and vnder∣name the kyng hugeliche, so that he sette vii. ẏeres penaunce vpon him, the which he toke on hẏm, that is to say of, and that vii. yere he bare no crowne. But summe saith, that this Wulfride was nat vereliche a nonne, bote that for drede of the kẏng a Seculer woman i veẏled, and a none the veile so i doo a waẏ, & take to the kẏnge's bedde. but nat for than Dunstone dude the lawe a ẏenst the kyng as for a nonne, suth that the kyng wolde coueẏte anẏ, whether she were verreliche veiled or noo. But how so euer thes this [sic] thẏnges were, certeẏne hit is, that fro the xvi. ẏere of his age, whiche ẏer he was ordeyned kẏng, a non to the xxx. ẏere him lakked his coronẏng. And thenne was he crowned atte Bathe, and lẏued after but iii. ẏere. Neque hac in re magni aestimandam esse censeo aucto∣ritatem rotulae cujusdam mem∣braneae, sermone Gallico, penes Richardum Gravesium, ami∣cum illum eruditissimum, de Mickleton in agro Gloucestri∣ensi, in quarotula tanquam filia legitima commemoratur Editha, contra fidem scriptorum opti∣morum. Haec enim verba ro∣tulae: Iceti Edgar auoit. ii. femmes, le vne apres lautre. De la primer il engendra Edward, ke puis fu martẏr, e Seint Edith. de la secunde Eamun e Ethelred. Quam tamen rotu∣lam ideirco plurimi faciendam esse duco, quod plerisque, quas vidi, sit antiquior, picturasque regum ac principum exhibeat, minus equidem elegantes, sed quae antiquariis multis in rebus usui esse possint. Sed (quod dolendum) imperfecta est rotula, quippe quae incipit ab Athelstano rege, desinitque cum Edwardo post conquaes∣tum primo, priori parte, pa∣riter atque posteriori, abscis∣sa, & forsitan funditus deper∣dita. in cujus sane Athelstani regis pictura illud plane ob∣servatu dignissimum esse vi∣deo, quod sceptrum sive insig∣ne regium in manu teneat si∣nistra, veterum ad amussim re∣ferens . minime absur∣de, quum princeps esset belli∣cosissimus, clavaque Herculea usum fuisse censerent hostes. cujusmodi tamen neu∣tiquam, quod sciam, videas in nummis Athelstanianis. He deẏde & wende to heuene nẏn hondred ȝer ẏch wene
As in Adde, ȝer. þe of grace, and sẏxtẏ and fẏftene.
SENT Edward þe marter, ẏs eldore sone,
After hẏm was kẏng ẏmad, as lawe was & wone.
þe godnesse of þẏs ȝonge kẏng ne maẏ no tonge telle.
Vor he was mek & mẏlde ẏnou, & vaẏr of fless & felle,
Debonere to speke wyþ, & wẏþ pouere men mest.
Chast and wẏs of conseẏl, and prute he louede lest.
Wẏlde men ne louede he noȝt, þat rechẏles were of þoȝte,
Ac wẏse men he drou to hẏm, & after hem he wroȝte.
Ech gret dede þat he dude, þe messtedel ssolde go
After þe erchebẏssop Seẏn Dunston, þat was þo.
Gode pes þer was in Engelond, & loue & joẏe ẏnou,
And rẏchesse bẏ ẏs daẏe, vor elles ẏt were wẏþ wou.
To þe godnesse of þẏs holẏmon þe deuel adde enuẏe,
And þe luþer quene ẏs stepmoder, þat vol was of tricherẏe.
Vor heo þoȝte nẏȝt & daẏ, ȝẏf heo mẏȝte þoru enẏ þẏng
þat Seẏnt Edward were aslawe, & yre sone ẏmad kẏng.
þe ȝer þat he ẏmartred was þe hexte men of þe lond
In þe toun of Calne were, as ẏch vnderstonde.
As hii sete in an chambre an heẏ in conseẏl of speche
þe flor to brac vnder hem, as ẏt were vor wreche,
And hii velle and debrusede somme anon to deþe,
And somme ẏmaẏmed, & somme ẏhurt, so þat enẏ vnneþe,
Wẏþoute gret harm, of scapede, bote Seẏn Dunston by cas,
þat hente hẏm bẏ a bem, and ẏsaued was.
Wat bẏ toknede þẏs, þat þe heẏme men velle so,
Bote þat hii and al þat lond bẏneþe ssolde be ẏdo,
þoru folc of strange lond, and þat me ssolde ẏse,
Vor hii soffrede her kẏng so vẏllẏche ẏ morþred be?
Vor a daẏ as Seẏn Edward an hontey wende bẏ cas
In an wode in Dorsete, þat bẏsẏde Wharham Ar. Warham was,
þat vaẏr wode was þulke tẏme, a gret wẏlle hẏm com to,
Vor to ẏse ẏs ȝonge broþer, (vor anon he þoȝte ẏt do.)
Vor he was a lute þer bẏsyde, as ẏs stepmoder was,
In an toun, þat me cluped Corf, þat bote þre mẏle þanne nas.
A strong castel þer ẏs nou, ac þo nas non þere.
Longe þoȝte Seynt Edward at ẏs broþer ar he were.
An vewe men mẏd hẏm he nom, & þuder ward gan ryde.
Ilẏs men pleẏde bẏ þe weẏ, & spradde aboute wẏde.
So þat þẏs holẏ kẏng alone was sone,
And alone wende vorþ, as he þoȝte to done.
þo hys luþer stepmoder alone ẏseẏ hẏm come,
Heo þoȝte do ẏre wẏlle of hẏm, as heo adde ẏr red ẏ nome.
þo þẏs holẏ man was neẏ ẏcome, þe quene aȝen hẏm eode
Wyþ noble maẏne ẏnou, & gret loue hẏm gan bede.
þe feste þat heo wẏþ hym made non tongue telle ne maẏ.
Ileo suor, þat he ssolde alẏȝte, & bẏleue mẏd ẏre al day.
"Certes, madame," quaþ þẏs oþer, "so ne may ẏt noȝt be.
"Ac lat me speke mẏd mẏ broþer, vor me longeþ hym to se.
"Vor ar ẏch hẏm abbe ẏseẏe, ẏ ne worþe noȝt blẏþe ẏwẏs,
"Mẏn herte ẏs so muche on hẏm, & non wonder hẏt nẏs.
"A, syre," quaþ þẏs luþer quene, "wanne ẏt ne maẏ oþer be,
"Vorst ẏch wolle to þe drẏnke, & suþþe þou ssalt hẏm ẏse.
"As me hẏm drẏnke toc, on was prest ẏnou,
"And þoru ẏs wombe smot a knẏf, and ẏs gottes to droȝ.
A long knẏf ẏt was & smal ẏ nou, as me maẏ ȝut ẏse
Atte chẏrche of Kauersham, as he aþ ȝare ẏbe.
þẏs holẏman sat vp rẏȝt, & ẏseẏ ẏs deþe's wounde.
He ne rod bote lute weẏ, ar he vel to grounde,
An let þer ẏs suete lẏf, and to heuene wende.
Awey! lute wel þoȝte he, þo me ẏs wombe rende.
þo þẏs holẏ man ẏmartred was, hii, þat hẏm þer broȝte to,
Bẏþoȝte hou hii mẏȝte best mẏd þe holẏ bodẏ do.

þo þẏs dede was ẏdo, þe quene adde al hyre wẏlle,

For so orped knẏght me ne knewe wide Ar. minus quidem recte, & contra fidem eximii probique nostri historici Roberti, qui plane docuit, Edmundi matrem ux∣orem revera fuisse Ethelredi. id quod etiam fecerunt alii op∣timae notae scriptores, (inter quos jure optimo censendus eruditissimus Bradius) secus atque illi, qui, partibus addicti, nothum Edmundum (è concu∣bina nimirum genitum) fuisse produnt, in quibus & ipse erat Jacobus Tyrrellus, qui tamen, paullo antequam fatis conces∣sisset, me monente in Lelando nostro, (Coll. Vol. VI. p. 75.) sententiam mutavit, ut è nota quadam liquet in Bibliotheca Bodleiana ab ipso Jacobo pro∣pria manu in Historia sua An∣gliae generali scripta, quam si∣mul atque commodum fuerit consulas velim. Ceterum & il∣lud notandum est, per symple woman in Cod. Ar. non aliud quam ignobilem feminam esse intelligendum, de qua re nos etiam breviter egimus in Le∣lando. id quod etiam viderat auctor prosaicus in Cod. Ar. ubi de Edmundo sic scribit: This kynge's [Ethelred] sone was not of Emme quene, but of a nother woman unknow to the commune peple. Natheles he was a faire, jolyf ẏong man, a strong man and hardẏ, and for thi of Englẏsshmen was he cleped Edmunde Irenside. He muche a leide þe cowardẏse of his fader, and þe loughnesse of his moder in him self thorgh his vertue noblelich. At∣que haec chartis mandave∣ram priusquam rotulam (cujus supra, p. 286. mentionem feci) Gravesianam vidissem, quae tamen nec ipsa illis favet, qui Edmundum nothum fuisse ve∣lint. Contra, picturae tanquam primogenitum heredemque E∣thelredi exhibent, verbaque ip∣sa filium ex uxore non è con∣cubina fuisse innuunt. haec nempe, pro interpunctione rotulae. Icesti Ethelred engen∣dra Eamun ẏreneside de vne femme aliene ke fu la soer au duc de Normandie. si engen∣dra alured ke fu trai par Goud∣wẏn count de kent. E Edward le confessour ke gist a Westmo∣ster. E quibus verbis non est quod colligas, Edmundi ma∣trem fuisse ducis Normanniae sororem, quae tamen (utpole Ethelredi uxor secunda) Alu∣redi atque Edwardi mater re vera erat. Id quod satis erit manifestum, si hoc modo ver∣barotulae distinguantur. Icesti Ethelred engendra Eamun Yre∣neside. De une femme aliene, ke fu la soer au duc de Nor∣mandie, si engendra Alured, ke fu trai par Goudwyn count de Kent, e Edward le Confes∣sour, ke gist a Westmoster. Haec distinctio si probetur, id utique liquebit, rotulae aucto∣rem Edmundi matrem igno∣bilem itidem fuisse censuisse, nihilque proinde de eadem à seipso fuisse dicendum. Cete∣rum non diffiteor, alibi etiam de Irenside matre locutum fu∣isse scriptorem prosaicum in codice Ar. eamque pro concu∣bina habuisse. After the deth (inquit ille) of Knut, Harol∣de & Hardeknut, kynges of Engelonde, regned Seẏnt Ed∣warde Confessour, Edmunde Irenside's brother in his fader's half, that is to seye of Ethel∣red kyng, but nat in the mo∣der. for this Edmunde Iren∣side was gete of vnlawfulle bed∣de, thoughe he were noble and stronge in bataẏle. And vor wraþþe let bẏlẏme her ostages þat were.
Suþþe he wende into Westsex, and robbede þere,
And in Dorsete dude & Wẏltessẏre & Somerssete gret wo.
Kẏng Aẏldred laẏ sẏk in þe toun of Cosham þo,
In Westende of Wẏltessẏre, vor he was feble and old,
And wẏþ care and sorwe ouercome, as me aþ ẏtold.
An fram Cosham to Londone he of scapede vnneþe,
Vorto wẏte hẏm fram ẏs fon, þat hii ne broȝte hẏm to deþe.
þere he huld hẏm in þe toun mẏd muche sorwe and sore,
þat of al hẏs lond of Engelond he nadde an fot more.
þe ȝates he made vaste, and wuste hẏm wyþ inne.
His fon asaẏlede þen toun wẏþoute mẏd al here gẏnne.
Atte laste þẏs kẏng Aẏldred, as in al þẏs strẏue,
In an Seẏn Gregorẏe's daẏ, wende out of þẏs lẏue,
As in þe ȝer of grace a þousend & sẏxteþe.
Feblẏche he lẏuede al hẏs lẏue, & deẏde in feble deþe.
In suche sorwe he was kẏng seuene & þrẏttẏ ȝer.
He adde monẏ an sorẏ daẏ, & muchel anguẏsse er,
An, vor wreche of hẏs broþer deþ, al such sorwe to hẏm come,
þat lute joye he adde al ẏs lẏf of ẏs kenedom.
EDMOND ẏrenesyde, kẏng Aẏldrede's sone,
So gode knẏȝt of bodẏ was, þat longe worþ in mone.
Me nuste so gode in none londe, an atte bẏgẏnnynge,
After hẏs fader deþe, me ches hẏm to kẏnge,
þe heẏe men of þe lond, þat fals ne luþer nere.
Ac monẏe hulde mẏd kẏng Knout, þat false an trẏsthors were.
Edmond, vor ẏs strenge, was ẏcluped Yrenesẏde.
Dreduol he was to ẏs fon, þat hym durste vewe abyde.
Debonere and mylde he was to alle þat gode were.
Queynte & suẏþe hardẏ mon, as man wyþoute fere.
Vorst he wende to Westsex, and þere ech contreẏe
Aboute al to ẏs wille boþe vor loue and eẏe.
As leon hardẏ ẏnou he wende aboute wẏde,
An wan contreẏe and oþer aboute in eche sẏde.
þat Knout nadde poer non aȝen hẏm vor to stonde,
ȝẏf false traẏtors nadde ẏbe here of Engelonde,
þat hulde mẏd þe kẏng Knout, traẏtors as hii were.
So þat noþer of þẏs kẏnges abouẏnde to oþer nere,
Ac eẏþer gaderede gret ost, and of oþere's men slowe.
Atte laste mẏd her ost to gadere ward hii drowe,
And mete hem after mẏdsomer, þe feste of Seẏn Jon,
And a gret bataẏle smẏte bẏsẏde þe toun of Sserston,
And slowe to grounde muche folc, & þo al was ẏdo
þe kẏnges & muche of her folc alẏue partede atuo.
þo wende kẏng Edmond to Londone myd ẏs route,
And al þat folc of Denemarch destrude þer aboute,
And drof hem out of þẏs lond, & ȝut nolde he noȝt blẏnne,
Ac wende in to Westsex þulke contreẏe to wẏnne.
þo he was fram bẏ Este ẏwend, þe Deneẏs myd al here gẏnne
Bẏsegede Londone, ac hii ne mẏȝte noȝt come wẏþẏnne.
So wel he was wẏþynne ẏwust, þoru men þat þer were,
þe Deneẏs hem wẏþ drowe, þo hem ne spedde noȝt þere,
And wende Estward in to Kent, & robbede þere vaste,
And her preẏe at Medeweẏe in to ssẏppes caste.
Kẏng Edmond hem sẏwede, þo he hurde þẏs,
And passede Temese and Breẏnford ẏwẏs,
And slou aboute vaste ẏnou monẏe þat he vond,
And monẏe flowe her and þere aboute in þe lond.
Bataẏles hii smẏte monẏ one, as we bẏgonne to telle er.
Vor eẏȝte bataẏles hii dude neẏ wat wẏþinne half ȝer.
As at Sserston and ellesware, and þe sẏxte bataẏle was
Uppe þe hulle of Assesdonne, ẏchẏlle telle þat cas.
þẏs tueẏe noble kẏnges mẏd her poer hem mette,
And smẏte þere a bataẏle, and vaste to gadere sette.
ẏordeẏned hii adde her ost wel in eẏþer sẏde,
And Edmond ẏdẏȝt hẏs standard, were he ssolde hẏm sulf abẏde,
And hẏs dragon vp ẏset, and þẏs bataẏle ysmẏte.
Hii slowe to grounde in eẏþer alf, þat deol it was to wẏte.
In ys standard Edmond was, as rẏȝt was vor to abẏde.
He seẏ, þat me slou ẏs folc aboute in eche sẏde.
Hys herte hẏm nolde soffrẏ noȝt abẏde vorte tẏme were,
Ac to þe bataẏle smot anon, as man wyþoute fere,
And bẏleuede dragon & standard, & stured vaste ys honde,
And slou to grounde, as noþẏng hym ne ssolde at stonde.
Sone adde ẏs gode bodẏ ẏperced þe ost þoru out.
He made ẏs weẏ roume ẏnou, vorte he come to kyng Knout.
þere were duntes arẏȝt ẏsmẏte bẏtuene hem tueẏe
Of þe helmes, þat fur sprong out, vor hii were strong beẏe.
A duc, þat was mẏd kẏng Edmond, Edryc was ys name,
þat was traẏtor and louerd suẏke, our Louerd ȝẏue hẏm ssame.
Vor he fondede hẏm bẏtraẏe, vor kẏng Knoute's loue,
þo he dradde þat Edmond was, as he seẏ, al aboue,
And kẏng Knout neẏ ouercome, vp an hul an heẏ
He wende wẏþ ẏs suerde adrawe, þat þet folc hym al ẏseẏ.
He adrou ẏs blodẏ suerd, and loude bẏgan to grede:
"Englysse men, Englysse men, fleþ anon, ẏch rede.
"Vor Edmond, vre kẏng, to deþe he ẏs ẏdo.
Hym sulf he gan vorst to fle. vor oþere ssolde al so.
Englysse men hym leuede wel, & flowe after blẏue,
And al ẏt was to bẏtraẏe ẏs louerd, þat was alẏue.
þo kẏng Edmond þẏs yseẏ, þat ẏs folc vnder stod,
þat he was to deþe ẏbroȝt, and þeruor flowe vor wod,
He arnde vp a lute hul, and gradde in þe place
Hys folc, and dude of ẏs helm, and ssewede hẏs face,
And seẏde, "turneþ vaste aȝen, ẏcham alẏue ywys.
Hẏs folc turnede anon aȝen, þo hii hurde þẏs,
And smẏte vorþ þẏs bataẏle, gretter ne myȝte non be,
And foȝte vorte yt was nẏȝt, þat hii myȝte noleng ẏse.
Ac ẏe Englisse adde ybe aboue, ȝẏf ẏt nadde ẏbe vor nẏȝt.
Ac hii departede, as hii nede moste, vor defaute of sẏȝte.
Hii greẏþed hem þerafter, anoþer bataẏle to do,
And ef sone come to gadere vp Assesdoune al so,
And bataẏle smẏte strong ynou, ac Knoute's poer vaste
Wexẏnge was, þat he wan þe maẏstrie atte laste.
Sorẏ was Edmond þo, to Gloucestrye he wende,☜
To porueẏe hẏm more help, ȝẏf God hẏm grace sende.
Knut suẏd euer after hym euer atte taille Ar. Kẏng Knout sẏwed after mẏd an long taẏle.
So þat aboute Gloucestrẏe þe eẏȝteþe bataẏle

Upon Seuerne in a place they smyte stronge i now. Manẏ was the goode body in eyther half me slow. But yutte neyther partie the mastrẏe haue mẏght, By cause that theẏ were lette bẏ comẏng of the nẏght. Kyng Edmunde was of Seuerne in the West syde, And Knut in the Est half a ẏenst him ganne bide, So that the water was bẏ twene her bothes power, And the folke of Denemarch wax euer fer and ner Ar. Up Seuerne hii smẏte, & astede, & so vaste me slou
þe gode bodẏes in eyþer alf, þat ẏt was deol ẏnou.
Mẏd blod þe erþe was ẏheled, þat pyte ẏt was to wẏte.
Ac noþer partẏe ne mẏȝte þe maẏstrẏe.
Ne hii ne myȝte ẏse vor þe nẏȝte þe bataẏle to do non ende.
Hii departede mẏd sorw ẏnou amorwe aȝen to wende.
And kẏng Edmond ouer Seuerne was in West sẏde,
And kẏng Knout bẏgan mẏd ẏs ost in Estalf abẏde.
And Seuerne was bytuene hem, & Knoute's poer
Of volc of bẏȝonde see wax euere ver & ner.
As Edmond sat mẏd ẏs ost anyȝt in This cas, Wher manẏ a wound∣edman and werẏ i fouȝt was, Ar. such solas,
As folc mẏȝte, þat ver wounded & sor & werẏ was,
And speke of þẏs bataẏle, hou ẏt myȝte be god:
An old kẏnȝt þer ros vp, & bẏuore þys folc stode.
"Icham," he seyde, "mest fol. þeruore, as foles wolle,
"Mẏ fole red, ȝyf ȝe wolle ẏhure, vorst ssewe ichẏlle.
"Muche þẏng we abbeþ ẏseẏe, & vre elderne vs ek seẏde.
"Angusse & sorwe we abbeþ ẏnou, of wel more we mowe drede.
"We fyȝteþ & beþ ouercome, & non maystrie we ne ẏseþ.
"Hou mẏȝte we bote be ouercome, þat þus defoulede beþ?
"Dispoiled & foiled buth oure frendes, oure strenthes leseth we faste, And also of our awne lẏf we dredeth atte laste Ar. Despoẏled & verwounded, & vre strengþe le seþ vaste,
"Vre felawes & vre owe lẏf we dredeþ ek atte laste.
"Wanne ssal vre reste come, & endynge of vre wo,
"And among vus sẏkerness & paẏs? ẏch drede neuere mo.
"Edmond ne maẏ be ouercome vor hẏs strengþe ẏwẏs,
"Ne þe kẏng Knout oure fo, vor he so queẏnte ẏs.
"Wat maẏ þanne oure ende be, bote, wanne þẏs knẏȝtes echon
"In eẏþer sẏde beþ aslawe, & oure maystres byleued one,
"Oþer hii mote þanne acordẏ, oþer fẏȝte hem sulue tuo?

"What reson is hit, that hii ne mowe as∣well do now soo, While anẏ knẏghtes buth lefte a lẏue, that hem mowe serue & drede? Nere hem nought fairer so, where is hure Gidehede? Ar. Wat reson ẏs, þat hii ne mowe as wel nouþe so,
"þe wule hii abbeþ enẏ alẏue, þat hem mowe serue & drede?
"Nere hem noȝt boþe vayror so? wu wat ẏs gẏdy hede?
"þere were wule in Engelond at otẏme kẏnges fyue,
"And alle hii were rẏche ẏnou, & of noble lẏue.
"And nou to lute to hem tueẏe al Engelond ẏs.
"And ofte wo so coueẏteþ al, al leseþ ẏwẏs.
"ȝẏf eẏþer kẏng so muche wẏlneþ to be louerd her,
"þat her noþer nele abbe felawe, Ne non pere, Ar. ne pere,
"Fẏȝte hem sulue tueẏe, þat Woll be lordes all on. And so were hem fairer now, that whan hure knẏgtes echon, And al hure folke buth a slawe, and hii bẏ lafte all bare, Ar. louerd wolde be one.
"Wu nere hem noȝt betere nou so, þat wanne her knẏȝtes echone,
"And her folc were al aslawe, & hii bẏleued al bare,
"And ne founde who hem seruede in anguẏsse ne in care,
"Ne who myd hem in neode þat lond defend ẏmyȝte?
"Her of seggeth ẏoure avise, as bẏ ẏoure in∣sẏght Ar. Her of þat soþe seggeȝe, as bẏ ȝoure in sẏȝte.
Nadde þys knyȝt fulleche hẏs reson ẏsed,
þat ys felawes nadde sone ẏnome her red,
And seyde alle mẏd one mouþe, "we Assenteth Ar. ensenteþ þerto,
"þat þys tueye kynges acordẏ, oþer bataẏle hem sulue do.
Kyng Edmond, þo he hurde þẏs, vol was of joẏe & blẏs.
þe batayle, he seyde, he wolde Take Ar. nẏme myd god herte ẏwẏs.
þat worde he sende amorwe to Knout among ẏs fon,
And grantede ẏs owe bodẏ, þe batayle to do anon.
Theẏ armed hem self beithe, and dight hem with goude pas Into an Ile in Seuerne, that Ol∣neẏe cluped was Ar. Hii lete hem armẏ beye, in to an yle mẏd gode pas
Al mẏdde Seuerne hii wende, þat Olenege y cluped was.
þer inne hii were hem sulue tuo, & þe water al aboute.
Her ost was eẏþer in ẏs sẏde alonde bẏleued bẏ þoute.

The kẏnges thenne in ernest grete her swerdus drough bothe, And smẏte to gedre fast ẏ now a men that were wrothe. Kyng Edmunde assailled kẏng Knut so fast, that he was Negh ouer come, and sore he was a gast. He hadde lẏuer thanne enẏ thẏng accorded haue be there. But he nulde his feblenesse ẏut telle in no maner, Lest Edmunde hit vnderȝete that he were ouer∣come, And that he nolde fẏny til his lyf were bẏ nome Ar. Mẏd god ernest & god ynou her suerdes adrowe boþe,
þys kẏnges to gadere come, & made hem boþe wroþe.
To grounde hii smẏte & harde mẏd stalwarde honde,
þat wonder was, hou oþer mẏȝte oþere's dunt at stonde.
þo kyng Edmond ẏwraþþed was, & wẏþinne hot,
He ssoc ys suerde & grunte, & mẏd such ernest smot,
þat þe sprong out mẏd ech dunt of helme so þere,
þat ẏt þoȝte myd ech dunt, as þat heued afure were.
As þondre þat soun was, þe lyȝt as lẏȝtynge,
So þat ech dunt þoȝte leẏȝt as yt were & þondrẏnge.
Me specþ of monẏ stalward knẏȝt, ac me vond on þere.
ẏblessed be þe moder wombe þat hym to monne bere.
þe kẏng Knout was so debrused, þat he stod vnneþe.
He dradde wanne he lore þat lyf, & were ẏbroȝt to deþe.
He adde leuer þan enẏ þyng, þat hii acorded were.
Ac he ne dorste ẏs feblesse telle Edmond, vor fere
Laste, ȝẏf he vnder ȝete, þat he were so ouercome,
þat he nolde fẏne ar he adde ẏs lẏf hẏm bẏ nome.
þo he adde a wule ẏrest, ẏs armes he gan to caste,
And wẏþ gret ernest step ver, & asaẏled Edmond vaste,
Mẏd al þe strengþe þat he mẏȝte, & ssewe more þerto
Al vor he ne ssolde wene, þat he were ouercome so.
þys Knout bẏgan to reste, þo ẏs assaut was ẏdo,
And bet Edmond, as in pes, aword hure oþer tuo.
Kẏng Edmond hẏm grantede, & somdel hẏm wẏþ drou,
And lende vp hẏs sseld, & herkned hẏm ẏnou.
"Ich abbe, quaþ Knout, "ẏwẏlned þẏ kynedom ar þẏs,
"And nou, wel more þan þẏ lond, þẏ sulf ẏch wẏlnẏ ẏwẏs.
"Vor þou nart noȝt worþ one be of Engelond kẏng her,
"Ac To be kẏng of Ar. to prince of al þe world. vor in þe world nẏs þẏ per.
"Ich abbe al The Ar. þat lond of Norþweẏe & of Denemareh an honde.
"I ne wende noȝt þat enẏ man mẏ dunt ssolde atstonde.
"Ac þou ne at stonst ẏt noȝt one, ac art al clene aboue.
"War vore ẏch desẏrẏ mest þyn grace & þyn loue,
"And that thow of all mẏ londes mẏ felawe be and peer, And that ich of Engelond be thẏ partiner Ar. þat þou of alle myn londes me be felawe & per,
"An ẏch mot ek of Engelond be þẏ partẏner.
"Vor ȝẏf we to gadere beþ, & al clene of one rede,
"France & ech oþer lond, & ech prince vs wole drede.
"þer vor ẏch byseche þe, haue half mẏ lond myd me,
"An Ich wole, as Ar. ẏch, as þẏ partẏner, half Engelond mẏd þe.
Edmond, þo he hurde þẏs, ẏs grete herte wẏþ drou,
And Assented Ar. ensentede to ẏs rede, & bẏcom Meok Ar. mylde ynou,
An A bowede Ar. bẏude to ys mẏlde word, þat myd suerd was aboue.
Hii caste awey sseld & suerd, & turnde al to loue,
An bẏclupte hem & custe, & her folc in eẏþer sẏde,
þo hii seye hem acorded, vor joẏe loude hii crẏde,
An songe, te Deum laudamus, eẏþer in ẏs route,
An to gadere wende, & custe hem ech oþer aboute.
Bytuene þys tueye kynges was a certeyn fourme ẏdo,
An forewarde Bẏ twene Ar. among al her folc, ar hii Parted a two, That eẏther hadde his dele of lond and other thẏnges, And part∣ed with loue a two, and bẏ∣laste bothe kynges Ar. departed atuo,
Wat eẏþer adde to ẏs del of lond & oþer þẏnges,
And departede wẏþ loue atuo, & bẏleuede boþe kẏnges.
An ȝẏf hii adde in gode loue longe ẏlẏued beẏe,
Me adde þoru al Cristendom ẏspoke of hem tueẏe,
An eche prince & eche londe douted hem tuo.
Ac Edmond was al to raþe, alas! to deþe ẏ do.
Vor þe luþer duc Edrẏc þoȝte euere to bẏtraẏe
Kẏng Edmond, ẏs owe louerd, Knout vor to paẏe.
A luþer gadelẏng was ẏs sone, boþe at one rede.
Hii fondede mẏd alle gẏle to do þẏs luþer dede.
þo hii ne mẏȝte in oþer wẏse þẏs dede bringe to ende,
In to a chambre forene þe gadelẏng gan wende,
þat kyng Edmond com ofte to, & in þe dunge þar
Hudde hym þere longe, þat none man nas ẏ war.
An þo þe kẏng þerto com, ẏs nede vor to do,
þe luþer þef ȝare was mẏd ys arme þerto,
And smot Him into the founde∣ment into the guttes rẏght, There thourgh he deyde that hastelich, þat was so noble a knẏght Ar. im þoru þe foundement, & þoru þe gottes rẏȝt,
Edmond þe noble kẏng, þat was so noble knyȝt.
Wẏþ a long ẏponyted knẏf, yegged in eyþer sẏde,
þus Shenful∣lẏche Ar. ssenduollẏche he hẏm slou, aboute Seynt Andreu tyde.
Atte Oxenford Ar. An Oxenford he was aslawe, þoru þẏs luþer lore,
Mẏd treson & gẏle ẏnou, ẏnot hou mẏȝte be more.
þe beste bodẏ & noblest, þat in eny lond þo was,
ẏslawe was þoru a gadelẏng, so vẏllyche, alas!
Ar men mẏȝte aboute come, þen þef to seche þare,
Of scaped he was & ẏflowe, non man nuste ware.
Me greẏþede þẏs gode kẏng, Tho other bote nas, Ar. wanne non oþer nas,
An broȝte hẏm vayre anerþe, as he wel Worthẏ Ar. wurþe was,
In þe abbeye of Glastẏnburẏ, byuore The heigh auter. For he wilned to lẏgge neigh his graunt sire there Ar. þe heẏ wened anheẏ.
Vor he wyllnede vor to lẏgge ys gransyre neẏ
þe kyng Edgar þe gode kẏng, þat þere ẏbured ẏs.
þere hii lyggeþ vayre ynou boþe ȝut ẏwẏs.
Ac þys luþer gadelyng, þat þẏs gode kyng so slou,
To kẏng Knout wende anon glad ynou.
He grette hẏm anon," & seẏde, "hayl Be thow kyng al on. So is hit not, quod he a ȝe, hit is mẏne but in mone Ar. þou be kẏng one.
"So nẏs ẏt noȝt," quaþ þe kẏng, "vor mẏ kẏnedom ẏs ẏmone.
"Vor an felawe ẏch abbe þerto, þat ẏch loue ynou.
"For, Ar. Ver, gode syre kẏng," quaþ þys þef, "vor þy loue ych hẏm slou.
"Here ẏs þat knẏf al blodẏ, þat ych broȝte hẏm wyþ of dawe,
"An smot hẏm þoru þe foundement, & so vp to þe mawe.
"þy loue ych abbe wel dere aboȝt, & mẏ lyue anaunter ẏ do.
"þer nys non alyue nou, þat þe abbe yserued so.
"þeruore vnderstond þe wel, & ȝeld mẏ mede blẏue.
"Vor ych abbe ẏdo þe more gode, þan alle þe men alẏue.
"þou seẏst soþ," quaþ þe kyng, "þou ast muche ydo vor me,
"An ẏchylle wel þy mede ȝelde by þe treuþe ych on to þe.
"ẏchẏlle make þe heymon, Right sone ich haue I thought Ar. bẏ tẏme ẏchabbe ẏþoȝte,
"þat þou ne ssalt vor þẏ lẏflode neuere carẏe noȝt.
Edrẏc, þe luþer suẏke, ẏs fader, com al so:
"Syre," he seẏde, "ẏch abbe muche loue þe ẏdo,
"For sake ich haue mẏne awne lorde, and him by trayed for the. For thi, sir kyng, a benefeat ich aske in help to me Ar. Versake Edmond Pro, myn owe. mẏ nowe louerd, & bẏtraẏd vor þe,
"An let hẏm sle vor þẏ loue, hou wolton ẏt ȝelde me?
"þo seẏde kẏng Knout aȝe, traẏtor þou art ẏwẏs,
"An muche aȝe God & aȝen me þou ast ẏdo amẏs,
"Wanne þou ast L. þẏn owe. Nam thẏne awne in Ar. þẏ nowe louerd, as þou Me tellest fore Ar. tellest vore,
"To so vẏle deþe ẏbrot, þat was mẏ broþer ẏ suore.
"Hẏs blod, þat þou madest ssede, ssal arde com on þe.

"Vor L. þẏn owe. Sed thẏ nawne in Ar. þẏ nowe mouþ þe aþ ẏdemed bẏ þat þou seẏst To me. So that thesne tray∣tour he let take an hast, And prẏuẏliche with oute noẏse in to Themese him cast, And let him stilliche a drenche, that no noẏse were. And this was, loo! his good rewarde, thogh hit i nogh nere Ar. me.
He let caste þẏs traẏtor in þe euenẏnge late
At fenestre in Temese, nouse vor to abate.
And let hẏm stẏllelẏche adrenche, vor manne speche þere.
An þat was, lo! ẏs noble mede, to lute þeẏ ẏt were.
þe luþer traytor hẏs sone auanced was ȝut bet,
In robe of roiall dignite, that was well bẏ sette Ar. Vor hẏs robe & hẏs dẏgnẏte was al wel bẏset.
He ȝef hẏm such auancement, as he wolde, he suor ẏs oþ,
þat he ne dorste neueref carẏe For Ar. of mete ne Deest Ar. of″ cloþ.
An robe he let hym ssape verst of blod rede scarlet þere.
þe ssarpe stones In the Ar. bẏ þe strete hẏs taẏlors were.
Vor he let hym mẏd hors Deest Ar. to″ drawe fram strete to strete,
þat þe peces ffelle of ẏs fless aboute monye & grete.
His taillours corue him suche a robe, that none coueẏte wolde, Ne that he ne durst after neuer carie for the colde Ar. þe taẏlors corue so monge peces, vor ẏs robe ne ssolde powe.
He ne dorste þo carẏe noȝt of þe wẏnter couwe.
Suþþe he let smẏte of ẏs hede by þe ssoldren, as me seẏ,
And let ẏt sette vpon tour of Londone an heẏ.
And so he was heẏ man ẏmad, as he bẏhet hẏm to ẏs mede.
Alle traytors & Lord swykes Ar. louerd suẏken God late hem so spede.
KNOUT was þo alone kẏng, as wo seẏþ, of Engelond, Ar. Engelon,
Of Norþweẏe, And of Ar. of Denemarch, & gret poer adde anhon∣de,
Ac Edmond þe gode kyng, þat so vẏllẏche me slou þo,
Adde tueẏe ȝonge sones, ar he were to deþe ẏdo,
Edward & Edmunde, half bretherne tweẏ Ar. Edmond, & breþeren al so tueẏe
Seẏnt Edward & Alfred, þat in Normandẏe were beẏe.
Vor þes were kyng Edmond next, & ẏs eẏrs also.
Kẏng Knout þoȝte hou he mẏȝte best herof do,

To byneme hem her heritage how that he myght, As hit were bẏ coloure of summe maner ryght. For thogh manẏ maẏ do atte his lust some thyng, Of wrong he wolle make a ryght as by co∣louryng Ar. To bẏnẏme hem her erẏtage, & mẏd wuch wrong he mẏȝte,
And mẏd wuch treson, bote he adde som colour of rẏȝte.
Vor wanne man maẏ do wat he wole & vnrẏȝt ẏnou,
Ofte he brẏngþ vor coueẏtẏse to rẏȝte pur wou.
He made a gret parlement, & broȝte heẏe men þerto.
As wo seẏþ, ẏnele noþẏng wyþoute lokẏng do.
þo bed he þe court segge soþ, & rẏȝt vnderstonde,
Wat forewarde þer were ymad And fourme Ar. in fourme of Engelonde,
Bẏtuene hẏm & kẏng Edmond, þe wule he was alẏue,
And wam Edmond made His heire with oute any stryue, And to whom his ẏong sones in warde shulde be do, Ar. hẏs eẏr of ẏs londe wẏþoute striue,
And wam of ẏs ȝonges sones wardeẏn ek ẏdo,
And wat þyng he adde assẏgned ẏs tueye breþeren al so.
Herof he bed hem segge soþ, as ẏt were glosẏng.
Vor he ne kepte, he seẏde, mẏd vnrẏȝt of no monne's þẏnge.
þo stode þer somme vp, þat adde ẏnome her red,
Vorto paye kyng Knout, & noȝt Edmond þat was ded,
And seẏde bẏuore al court, þat kẏng Edmond bẏqueþ
Hys kynedom & al ẏs lond kẏng Knout byuore ẏs deþ,
And þe warde of ẏs tuo sones, vorte hii of elde were.
Alas! alas! þe trecherẏe, þat me myȝte ẏse þere!
Vor þe dede was verȝẏte anon, & þe quike vorto paẏe,
Hure soules by toke they to the fende, the rẏght heire to be traẏ Ar. Hii bẏtoke þe qued her soule, þe kunde eyrs to bẏtraye.
þẏs word was ẏholde stable, & ẏloked vor dome.
Kẏng Knout of Edmonde's londes anon seẏsyne nome,
And helde him self a lone kyng of all Engelond, And Norwey and Denemarch, and grete power hadde in hond Ar. And huld hẏm þo al clene kẏng of al Engelond,
Of Norþweye, of Denemarch, gret poer he adde an honde.
Ech þoȝte he was Gode next, þat mẏȝte abbe ẏs grace,
Of so gret poer þer bẏuore me ne kneu non in non place.
þo he was of al Engelond kẏng, wẏþoute Any mone, Ar. mone,
He bẏgan to cuþe anon, þat he was kẏng A lone Ar. one.
Alle þat were oȝt Sibbe sir Edmunde Ar. ẏsẏb Edmond þe kẏnge,
Or of Aliaunce in any wey, to dethe Ar. Oþer in alẏance of enẏ loue, to deþe he let bringe,
Oþer flemd hem out of Engelond, non byleued nere,
Bote ẏs tueye ȝonge sones, þat so feble & tendre were.
He ne mẏȝte, vor þe worlde's ssame, hem to deþe bringe.
But sente Ar. He sende hem out of Engelond, to An Ar. & heye kẏng
A lyte bẏ side Ar. Bẏsyde Denemarch, þat he hem to deþe broȝte,
So ver In couthe lande, wher no man of hem rought. Alas! the sely Ar. in onekeþelond, þer non man of hem ne roȝte.
Awey! sely ȝonge þẏnges, frendeles were hii þere,
þat so ver, as mẏlde lomb, to deþe ẏlad were.
þo hii to þe kynge come, To dethe that hem shulde haue brought, Ar. þat he hem to deþe broȝte,
Vor þe heẏe blod, They of come, he him sone by thought Ar. of wam hii come, þe kyng hym bẏþoȝte,
An adde reuþe of hem gret, & ẏs wille gan wyþ drawe,
An ne mẏȝte, vor reuþe, vor non þyng bring hẏm of lẏf dawe.

To the kẏng of Hungarẏ the selẏ children tweẏe. The kyng hem faire vnderfenge for hure heigh no∣bleẏ, So long fort Edmunde, that was the quene brothe [sic], Spoused his doughter, and seth made the other, That hiȝt Edwarde, spousy the emperoure's nevew Ar. To þe kẏng of Hongari þẏs selẏ chẏldren tueye
He sende hem vor to norẏsy, þat he warded hem wel beẏe.
þe kyng hem vaẏre vndervong, & honoured in ech wẏse,
An gret deuẏte tolde of hem, vor her gentrẏse,
So longe, þat he let Edmond, þat was þat on broþer,
Sspousy ys owe doȝter, & suþþe he let þe oþer,
þat het Edward, spousẏ þe emperoure's Non tantum cognata, sed filia re vera erat Henrici II. Imperatoris, nomenque ejus erat Agatha. mowe.
þo adde hii boþe ẏwẏued wel, & noȝt tolowe.
Deest Ar. Ac″ Edmond leuede lute wule, & no chẏld Hadde Ar. nadde alẏue.
Ac Edward þe oþer adde þre chẏldren by ẏs wẏue,
A sone, þat Height Ed∣gar, and also doughtren twey, Ar. Et quidem recte Edgar. het Edward, & doȝtren also tueẏe,
Margarete & Cristẏne, þat gode wommen were beẏe.
þẏs gode chẏldren aȝte be euermo in Mẏnde. For Engelond, ẏf theẏ nad i be, hadde be oute of kynde Ar. munde.
Vor Engelond, ȝẏf hii nere, were ȝut out of kunde,
As ȝe mowe Here after∣warde, in Harry the furste's lyf, I hure, how Ar. hure her afterward, in kẏng Henrẏe's lẏf,
Hou Engelond com to kunde aȝen þoru þe god Mold ẏs wẏf,

That doughter was of Mergarete, as ich vnderstande, By twene hure and Macolẏn kyng of Scotland. Knut of all Enge∣lond was thoo kyng thorough oute. Hit is no nede to esshe, ẏf he were kene and proute. Tho he was of Edmunde's sones, and all that with him were, Delyuered, he was proute i nough, and yet he was infere O kyng Ethel∣rede's ii. sones, that were in Normandẏe, Aluered and Seẏnt Edwarde, lest hii wolde a stẏȝe, Thorough Richard, duc of Normandẏe, Ar. þat þes Margarete doȝter was, Mold þe gode quene.
Vor þẏs lond were ȝut out of kunde, ȝẏf hii nadde ẏbe, ẏch wene.
Kẏng Knout of al Engelond was þo kẏng alout.
Me ne dar noȝt esse, were he kene þo & prout.
þo he was of Edmonde's sones, & of al, þat mẏd hym were,
Delẏuered, he was fers ẏnou, ac somdel he was in fere
Of Edmonde's tueye breþeren, þat wonede in Normandye,
Alfred & Seẏnt Edwarde, laste hii gonne astẏe
þoru þe duc of Normandye, þat her vncle was.
Hym þoȝte were he sẏker of hem, hẏm ne doutede of no cas.
Seẏnt Edwarde's moder þeruore he of sende,
Emme þe quene of Engelond, þat She Ar. he hẏder wende,
And the on of hure bretherne, that was duc Richarde, And thourgh assent of hure sones, Aluered and Edewarde, And spoused hẏm to wyue Ar. þoru conseẏl of her broþer, þat was þe duc Rẏchard,
An þoru ensent of hẏr tueye sones, Alfred & Seẏn Edward,
An were yspoused hẏm to wẏf, & oure quene were al so.
Wat halt ẏt to telle longe? þẏs dede was ẏdo.
Vor kẏng Edmond was aslawe a Seẏnt Androwe's tẏd, ẏch wene,
As in þe ẏer of grace a þousend and sẏxtene.

As in þe ȝer of grace of þousend and seuentene.
ȝut to be þe sẏkerore, after þẏs spousẏnge,
He let ẏs barons of Engelond to Oxenford bringe
A þousend as in þe ȝer of grace and eẏȝteþe ȝer,
An a parlement vor hẏs stat of hem made þere.
So þat ȝẏf þer enẏ was, þat aȝen hẏm herte bere,
Hym þ ȝte hẏs poer non þyng nas, ac All Ar. as vor noȝt yt were.
All were clene to hẏm i swore, ther was none be hẏnde Ar. As was to hẏm al clene ẏsuore, þer nas non bẏhẏnde.
þo was he al clene louered, to bẏnde and vnbynde.

A wẏf, þat her Helene Ar. quam Aelfgifam, sive Ael∣givam, appellant alii. Quin∣etiam & hoc notandum, pleros∣que scriptores eandem concubi∣nam, non uxorem, Canuti fuis∣se asserere. Unde sane doctis∣simus Bradius in textu histo∣riae suae (p. 129.) Cnute not long before he died, appointed his eldest son Swane, by his first Wife * Elgiva, to be king of Norway, and his second Son Harold, by the same Woman to be king of England, and Harde-Cnute his Son by Em∣me, king of Danemarke; ex Hovedeno nimirum 251. a. at in notis, * Bẏ most Writers reported to have been a Con∣cubine, she was Daughter to a Mercian Noble-man, who is said to have been Earl of Northampton. Aẏlẏne, he adde er of gret fame.
Bẏ hyre he adde an sone, Harald was hẏs name,
þat of þe kunde was of Denemarch, in eẏþer alf al out.
Bẏ Emme he adde anoþer sone, þat het Hardeknout,
þat beẏe were kynges after hẏm, as me ssal sone rede,
þẏs kẏng was þo þoruout al man of noble dede.
þo he was alone kẏng of grete londes þre,
Hẏm þoȝte al þe world ne mẏȝte aȝen ẏs poer be.
And naþeles he bẏgan ẏs herte in bocsumnesse amende,
An þoȝte on þe vaẏre grace, þat houre Louerd hym sende,
An louede Englysse men, and Engelond þerto,
An muche louede holẏ chẏrche & susteynde also,
An restorede abbeẏs, þat destrud were byuore,
An chyrchen let vp arere, þat were arst as verlore,
An let arere monye nẏwe, & in stedes mest þere
Where he Ar. As he adde men aslawe, & batayles ẏdo er,
As vpon Asshedoune and a boute there, As for the sowles of hem that slayne there were. Seẏnt Alphe Erchebẏsshop∣pe's body Ar. An vp Assesdone & þer aboute mest chẏrchen he let rere,
As vor her soulen, þat ẏslawe were þere.
Vor he & þe kẏng Edmond mest armes þere bere,
An mest man slaȝt þoru hem & bataẏles þer were.
Seẏnt Alfen's bodẏ,″ þat ẏ martred was
At Greneswuch þoru hẏs fader, as we tolde þat cas,
At Seyn Poule's of Londone, as ẏt was anerþe ẏdo,
Hẏs owe honde nome ẏt vp, &, as ẏt bẏuel þerto,
He let ẏt faẏre honourẏ, & sende ẏt atte fẏne
To þe munstre of Canterburẏ, And ther hit was in shrẏne Ar. as he lẏþ ȝut in ssrẏne.
þe þrẏdde ȝer ẏch vnderstonde, þat he was alone kẏng,
Fram hẏs lond of Denemarch me broȝte hym tẏthyng,
þat he was þere ẏworred vaste of hẏs fon.
He nome wẏþ hẏm of Engelond ȝod knẏȝt monẏon,
An mẏd gret poer & muche folc þuderward vende anon.
So þat he sone come bẏsyde hys fon echon,
An bẏleuede hẏm þer al nẏȝt, & al hẏs ost al so,
An þoȝte anon amorwe strong bataẏle do.
A gret erl of þẏs lond, Godwẏne was hẏs name,
Mẏd hẏs poer mẏd hẏm was, þat monẏon dude ssame.
Vor þẏs lond, as me ssal hure, ofte he dude bẏtraẏe.
He þoȝte þo hou he mẏȝte þe kẏng Knout best paẏe.
Bẏ nẏȝte Hẏm self and Ar. hẏm & hẏs poer he let armẏ þere,
And wende so anonẏwar, Wher the Ar. as þe kẏnge's fon were,

And founde hem muche del a slepe, so that in a stonde This En∣mẏs of Swethe londe hii brought all to grounde. Ulf and eke Ergall of Swethe lond kẏngus Fust [sic] to kyng Knutus host, at his comẏngus, Muche harme had i doo, but in this case wẏse Godewẏn with his men gate of hem the pryse. A morwe Ar. An fond hem, as wo seẏþ, aslepe. he leẏde on hem to grounde,
An slou and to drof hem alle in a lutel stunde.
Amorwe″ þo þe kyng wolde wende vp hẏs fon,
An mẏste Godwẏne & hẏs men, of gẏle he dradde anon,
þat þe Englysse hẏm bẏtraye wolde, he þoȝte of luþer won
Vor to sle þẏs Godwẏne, and þe Englysse echon.
An naþeles he wende toward hẏs fon mẏd al hẏs poer vaste,
Vor to smẏte an bataẏle, & þo ne wond he atte laste
Noȝt of hem bote caroẏne, & þe bodẏes dede al so,
þo he vond, þat Godwẏne such andede adde ẏ do,
An delyuered hẏm of hẏs fon, & ybroȝt hym so aboue,
Euereft he louede hẏm þe more, & al Englysse vor hys loue.
þo he seẏ, þat Englysse men so gode in nede were,
An hẏs fon were ouercome, noþẏng he nas in fere.
Tho hadde he al on the kẏngdomes of Ar. þo he adde one þe kẏnedom of grete londes þre,
Hym þoȝte That in all the worlde ne myght his pere be. Of all his proude dedis ne can iche telle nought, Bute of on tale ich wole, as hit cometh in thought Ar. al þe world ne mẏȝte aȝen hẏs poer be.
Of al hẏs proute dedes I ne maẏ verbere noȝt,
þat I ne mot ȝou telle of on, nou ẏt comþ in mẏ þoȝt.
A þousend as in þe ȝer of grace, & on & tuentẏ þerto,
An in þe vẏfte ȝer þat kẏng Knout in such poer was ẏdo,
He Wende a boute as Ar. wende, as noble sẏre, fram londe to londe,
þat He thought in all the worlde none shulde him with∣stonde Ar. hym þoȝte al world ne ssolde aȝen hẏm stonde.
As he wende aboute bẏ þe see, & such poer adde an honde,
Up achaere he sat adoun, al vp þe see sonde,
An Spak to his Ar. enresonede hẏs men, as hii bẏuore hẏm stode,
So þat þe tẏme com of þe see flode,
þat ẏt bẏgan to wexe vaste, as ẏt deþ atte tẏde.
þe kẏng bẏheld þe wexẏnge an hoker al asẏde,
So þat þe water vaste waxe Potius, upþard (idem quod Anglo-Sax. .) vppard heẏ & wẏde.
ẏut thought this grete lorde he wolde a bẏde ther Ar. þoȝte þẏs grete louerd, ȝut ychelle abẏde.
þo ẏt was neẏ to hẏm ẏcome, baldelẏche He spak Ar. spac
An sturnelẏche to þẏs water, þo ẏt alles out brac.
"Water," he seẏde, "What thenkest thow? I rede come no ner Ar. wat þencst on? ẏch rede ne com no ver.
"Under stond, þat þou art al clene in mẏ poer.
"Vor þat lond, vp wan þou vnrst, & vp wan ẏch sẏtte her,
"Is clene myn al aboute. vor þou wost ẏnabbe no per.
"þeruore ẏch Hote Ar. ote þe þẏne wexẏng anon lete,
"þat þou ne be so hardẏ noȝt, þẏn louerde's cloþes to wete,
"Ne hẏs lẏmes, ac vp Mẏ nawne Ar. mẏnowe let me in pes sẏtte,
"Or elles, by the feẏ that is me, ich wolle fyght mẏtte Ar. Oþer, bẏ þe feẏ þat ẏch ou to þe, ẏchelle rekenẏ mẏtte.
þe water dude vorþ hẏs kunde, & wax euere vaste,
