þe sẏxte ȝer, þat het Henry, þat suþþe was our kẏng.
In þe De∣sunt hîc tria metra in Ar. in cujus tamen margine ab ead. manu significatur, natum fu∣isse A. D. Ml. cxxxiido. enlene hondred ȝer þat our Loruerd anerþe com,
And þre & þrẏttyþe ȝer, þẏs chẏld ẏbore was,
þoru wan was suþþe ẏmartred þe gode man Seyn Thomas.
Glad was Deest Ar. þe″ kẏng Henry þo þe tyþynge hẏm com
Of þulke chẏld to ben hẏs eẏr of hẏs kynedom.
Noblẏche hẏs Ester feste he huld vor þẏs cas
In hẏs vaẏr halle Atte pro of in Ar. of Oxenford, þat þo nywe was.
A bẏsshop of Carlel, wher neuere none was er, He mak∣ed, and douwed him to serue God ther Ar. And byssoprẏche he made þo, & an bẏssop þere,
Bẏsẏde Scotlond at Cardoẏl, þat nas non neuere er.
þo wende he to Normandẏe. & Alle the furst ẏere, Ar. al nexe ȝer,
Vor joye of þe ȝonge child, he bẏleuede þere.
Suþþe þoru som heẏe herte þer Ros a litelle, Ar. wax a lute strẏf
Bẏtuene þe erl of Aungeo, & þe emperesse hys wẏf.
þe kẏng Wolde in Engelond glad∣lẏ haue I bene, But he bẏ∣lefte Ar. adde gode wẏlle, hẏder to wende, ych wene,
Ac he byleuede vor hẏs doȝter hẏre to sustene.
Heo was to prout A ẏenst Ar. agen hẏr Loruerd, vor hẏr heẏenesse,

Vor heo was eẏr, & kynge's doȝter, & eke Emperesse. Thelke tyme Henry kẏng, as Ich vnder∣stande, Made alle the lordes of Normandẏe, and of Enge∣lond, Swore helde & trewe be to themperisse and hure sone, And in hure state to meẏnteẏne hem after lawe & wone. Kyng Henry ganne to wexe in elde and into feblesse, Ar. emperesse.
þe kẏng hẏre fader was old man, & drou to feblesse,″
And þe anguẏsse of hẏs doȝter hym dude more destresse,
And Acoled Ar. akelde hẏm wel þe more, so þat feble he was.
So that in the forest of Lẏones he hunted to haue solas, Ar. So þat he wende an honteþ adaẏ, to abbe solas.
And þo he com hom he Wilned, a lamprey Ar. wẏllede, of an lampreẏe to ete.
Ac hẏs Leches seide, hit was for him vnholsom mete Ar. leches hẏm verbede, vor ẏt was a feble mete.
Ac he nolde ẏt noȝt bẏleue, vor he louede ẏt wel ẏnou,
And ete as in luþer cas, vor þulke lampreẏe hẏm slou.
Vor anon rẏȝt þerafter in to anguẏsse he drou,
And deẏde vor þẏs lampreẏe, þoru hẏs owe wou.
He sede ofte in hẏs deþ vnel, ar he were dede,
"Alas! alas! of Engelond ne con ẏch none rede.
"Vor ȝẏf ẏch ẏm bẏtake mẏ soster sone Steuene de Bleẏs,
"Vor he nẏs noȝt rẏȝt eẏr, he ne worþ neuere peẏs.
"And ȝẏf ẏch ẏm bẏtake þe rẏȝt eẏr Henrẏ, mẏ doȝter sone,
"þat nẏs noȝt ȝut þre ȝer old, ẏt worþ hẏm sone bẏ nom.
And naþeles al Engelond, & Steuene de Bleẏs also,
To emperesse & hẏr sone adde holde oþes ẏdo.

The. iiii. Nonas of De∣cember the ertliche deth he nom, In the xxxv. ẏere of his kyngdome, And in the. Ml. c. xxxvi. also Of oure Lorde's burthe tẏme, that his dethe cam him to Ar. þe vorste daẏ of Decembre kẏng Henrẏ þen deþ nome,
In þe syxe & þryttẏþe ȝer of hẏs kẏnedome.
And in enlene hondred ȝer, & sẏxe & þrytty þerto,
Of oure Louerde's burtẏme, deþ hẏm com þus to.
Ac Roberd Courtehose, hẏs broþer, as God wold, les þat lyf
Aboute þre ȝer bẏuore, in prison at Kerdẏf,
And bẏuore þe heẏe Auter Ar. wened in þe abbeẏe of Gloucestre y∣bured ys,
And Wẏllam, þe god knẏȝt hẏs sone, was al so ded ywẏs,
And aslawe byȝonde see, ar kyng Henrẏ ded were.
So þat of þulke kunne þer nas þo non fere.

In the ẏere of oure Lorde. Ml. c. xxxvie. Stephene Bleẏs, (the sone of Stephene, Erle of Bleẏs, of Ele, the conque∣rour's doghter & kyng Hen∣ry's suster) the xxii. daẏ after his vncle's dethe was croun∣ed kyng at of Wil∣liam Cuẏrboille, Archebis∣shop of Canterburẏ, as bẏ nethe in rẏme shalle be tolde. Stephene, the fader of this Stephene, hadde gete on Ele, kẏng Henry's suster. iiii. sones, and when this Ste∣phene was dede in the coun∣treẏ of the Est, the moder of hem, as a felle and a wẏse woman, ordeyned hem in this wẏse, hure furste sone bẏ cause he nas not wẏse, i putte a waẏ. Hur iide.The baud. Henry. Stephene. sone The baude she ordeẏned hure fader's heire. The iiide. Stephene withinne age sheo sente to kẏng Henry, hure broþer, Hure sone Stephene, [sic] to norẏshẏng an to au∣uance as his neuew. The. iiii. sone Henry sheo let make monek atte Clune, that me ne shulde nat segge, that heo hadde bore alle hure children to the worlde onliche bẏ pros∣ses of tyme Thenne after∣warde kyng let marye Ste∣phene forsaide to Molde, (the doughter and heire of Eu∣stace, Erle of Boloẏne,) i gete on Marie, Molde the goode quene's suster, kẏng Macolẏnus doghters of Scot∣londe. And with his nevew kẏng Henry ẏaf the Erle∣domes of Morteẏne and of Constance in Normandẏe. And Henry the monek a boue saide kẏng Henry let take oute of Clune, and made him abbot of Glastenburẏ, and af∣ter yaf him the bisshopriche of Wẏnchestre. So that by the Pope's dispensation he heolde bothe dignitees in his honde, thourgh whiche he gadered to muche tresoure, wherthourgh he was clepud bisshop Henry the Riche com∣menliche a mong the peple. Whiche lette make an heghe toure atte frounte of Seẏnt Swẏthene, that vnnethe suthe anẏ man mẏght part or throwe doune the walles, alle thow bẏshop William Edẏng∣don that the gable wẏndow atte churche ende let assaẏe, to haue hadde hem doune. In the ẏere of oure Lorde. Ml. cxxxvi. the churche of SeẏntBrennyng of Paule's churche. Paule's atte Lon∣done was brente. And thus, by as∣sent of Bisshop Henry the riche, and Roger Bisshop of Saresburẏ, was kyng Ste∣phene i crouned; and also the Erchebisshop William, and other, assented the mor ther to, for a grete man of þis londe, thulke tẏme the kynge's stywarde, Hughe Bigot bẏ name, affermed bẏ othes to for the lordes, that for cer∣teẏne countrouersies, that is, debates bẏ the kyng and his doughter late i spronge, he hadde disherited hur for e∣uere, and hadde ordeẏned Stephene his heire. ¶ The Emperice, and Robert Erle of Gloucetre hur bastarde brother, while thes thẏnges were doo in Engelonde, were in Normandie, and occupied certaẏne castels there, and bẏ cause Henry Curtmantelle, hure sone, was of to tendre age, suffred fort they seighe tyme.
Stephene the Bleẏs, þeRyme. gode knẏght & kẏnge's nevew also, Tho his vncle ded was, he cast what to do Ar. STEUENE þe Bleẏs, þat god knyȝt & stalward was also,
þo þe kyng was ded hẏs vncle, anoþer he þoȝte do.
He verȝet al þe strong oþ, þat he adde bẏuore
To Themperice Ar. emperesse & to Henrẏ hyr ȝonge sone ẏsuore.
And wende forthe hasteliche, and lete Ar. Ac he wende vorþ hastelẏche, to late hẏm crounẏ anon.
Deest Ar. þe″ heẏmen of þe lond As∣sented manẏ on, Both of bys∣shopes Ar. helde wyþ hẏm echon,
Boþe byssopes & oþer, þat þe oþ suor al so er.
A Seyn Steuene's daẏ Forsothe, ferst croune he bere. Therchebis∣shop Ar. anon, þe croune vorst he bere.
And þe erchebẏssop of Canterburẏ, Wẏllam þat þo was,
Sacrede hẏm, As right were, sẏnfullẏche, alas! Ar. as ẏt was rẏȝt, wel synuolyche, alas!
Vor he was þe vorst, as rẏȝt was & wone,
þat He∣olde to the Emperice Ar. holde oþes to þe emperesse suor, & to hyr sone.
þeruor þerafter sone wreche of God hem come.
Vor wẏþẏnne þe vorst ȝer hẏs lẏf God bẏnome.
And þe bẏssop Roger of Salesburẏ after hẏm suor anon,
And prechede vaste The folke ther on to holde echon. And thulke were the principalles, the Ar. þat folc, þen oþ to holde echon.
And þo was he princẏpal, þe sacrẏng vorto do,
And, vor ensample of hem, oþere Assented Ar. ensentede þerto.
Ac kẏng hẏmsulf ȝef suþþe hẏs mede, vor he nom hẏm vaste,
And in prison hẏm huld, & wrecchelẏche he deẏde atte laste.
And short∣liche also tho, Ar. Bote sstortlyche alle þo, þat þen oþ suore bẏuore
To þe emperesse, turnede þo to þe kẏng Steuene, & were ver∣suore.

And wonder yt was, þat Alle a londe at on tẏme echeon Tournede were so lightlich, and with seide non. Thenne bẏ fore twelf the day kẏng Stephene, as the hende, From his coroment fro Lon∣done to Redẏng warde gan wende, With therchebisshop, and manẏe men mo, And burẏed kẏng Henry's bodẏ, as righte was to do. Fro thenne wende forthe the kyng fro [sic pro for sive to] Oxen∣forde anon, And goode lawes Ar. alle þe lond in a stounde anon
Turnde to hẏm so verlẏche, & were versuore echon.
Kẏng Henry braẏn, & gottes, & eẏen ẏbured were
At Reẏnẏs in Normandẏe, & suþþe þe bones hii bere,
Wel ẏseld & ẏsode, to þe abbeye of Redẏnge,
And yburede ẏs þere vayre ynou, as vel to an kẏng.
ȝut byuore tuelf daẏ & kẏng Steuene, as þe hende,
Fram hẏs crounẏge of Londone aȝen hẏs vncle gan wende,
And þe erchebẏssop of Canterbure, & þe hext of þe lond also,
And þe bones burede vayre ynou, as ryȝt was to do.
þo wende þe kẏng þan ene to Oxenford anon,
And þe gode lawes, þat he behet, confermede echon.
And ȝẏf bẏssop, oþer abbed, in þẏs lond ded were,
He grantede, þat þoru kẏng non destourbance nere,
þat me ne chose in rẏȝte fourme anoþer anon,
And, whenne he were vn∣derfonge, his londes haue e∣chon Ar. And þat, wanne were vndervonge, hẏs londes adde echon.
And oþer monẏe luþer lawes, þat hys elderne adde ẏwroȝt,
He behet, þat he wolde abate, & naþeles he ne dude noȝt.
þe wule he was þus at Oxenford, tẏtynge hẏm com,
þat Dauẏt, kẏng of Scotlond, With treson hadde i nome Ar. mẏd treson nome
þe cẏte of Carloẏl, & þe nẏwe castel al so.
"Ye, quod the kyng, thenne a nother wole we doo Ar. Me ȝe," quaþ þe kẏng, "þo anoþer we ssolde do.
"þat he aþ Gete Ar. ẏ nome wẏþ treson, we ssolde wiþ maẏstrie.
Anon he wende þuderward wẏþ vaẏr compaẏnẏe.
þo þe kẏng of Scotlond yt wuste, aȝen hẏm he com,
And grantede al hẏs wẏlle, & Deest Ar. þe″ acord nome.
Ac hẏs man nolde he noȝt bẏcome, vor he was bẏuore
(As monẏe oþer in Engelond) to þe empresse ẏsuore.
So þat þe vorste tuo ȝer Goode grace and helpe i noughe To this kyng Stephne cam, ac suthe Ar. gode cas & hap ẏnou
In ech alf com to þe kẏng Steuene, ac suþþe ẏt wẏþdrou.
Vor in þe þrẏdde ȝer þe kẏng of Scotlond
Worrede bẏ Norþe, & orn up hẏs londe.
þe erl Roberd of Gloucestre, as man wyþoute fere,
þe strong castel of Brẏstow, þat he let hym sulf rere,
Astored wel ynou, & also þe slede,
And held hem boþe aȝe þe Kyng, (for his vn∣kẏndehede,) For themperice his suster, that he loued welle Ar. kẏng, to þenche on kunhede.5 Shulle Ar.
Vor emperesse was hẏs soster, & heo louede hẏm volwel.
And þe castel of Cary held Deest Ar. one″ Wẏllam Louel.
And þe castel of Lodelowe held Sẏre Paẏnel.
And Syre Roberd of Lẏncolne held of Waram þe castel,
And þe castel of Donstere Syre Wẏllam de Moẏon, That in the Prioury is bu∣ried of Bruton. Eustace filz John Ar. Moun,
þat þe priorẏe, as ych wene, rerde of Breutoun.
Eustas le fẏ & Jon″ held þe castel of Meltone,
And þe castel of Shirbourne Ar. Ssresbury held Wẏllam Aleẏne's sone.
Alle þes were aȝen þe kẏng, as Ferforth Ar. verþuorþ as hii couþe,
So þat he adde Foon i now bẏ Northe and eke by Ar. fon bẏ Norþe & bẏ Souþe.
He bẏgan to be luþer ẏnou. vor vorst holẏ chẏrche
He bẏgan to Werry, Ar. worrẏ, þat made hẏm þe worse wurche.
Vor he wende to Oxenford, & þo he þuder com,
þe byssop of Salesburẏ & of Lyncolne he nome.
þe bẏssop of Salesbury he ladde mẏd gret wo
To þe castel of Dẏuẏses, þat þe bẏssope's was þo.
An rop me dude aboute hẏs necke, he suor honge he ssolde

Bute his men with inne thane ca∣stelle uppe ẏolde. The men ẏolde up thane castelle, tho other bote nas. So that the kyng his tresoure hadde with∣oute nombre that was. For the bisshop was holde in prison forth, for his gret goodnesse, That he the kẏng dude, and was forswor to Molde thempe∣resse Ar. Anon, bote he þe castel anon hẏm vp ȝolde.
þe bẏssop hẏm toke þe castel, þo oþer bote nas.
He nom þere al hẏs tresour, þat wẏþout noumbre was,
And held hẏm vorþ in prison ȝut, & ȝeld hẏm hẏs godnesse
þat he dude hẏm, & was versuore aȝen þe emperesse.
Aȝen wende þe kẏng to Oxenford, & þe bẏssop vette
Alẏsandre of Lyncolne, þat he in prison sette.
And ladde hẏm to þe neweworc, to a uaẏr castel & god,
þat þe bẏssope's was, & vp Trent stod.
þer he suor, þat þe bẏssop neuere ete ne ssolde,
Ne drẏnke naþemo, ar þe castel hẏm were ẏȝolde.
þe bẏssop was wo ẏnou, vor he wuste wel, þeẏ he wolde
ȝelde hẏm vp þe castel, hẏs men wẏþẏnne nolde.
He bed hem, & cryde on hem, ac al ẏt was vor noȝt.
So þat þẏs byssop was ne to grounde ẏbroȝt
Mẏd And thurst addit Ar. honger, þat men adde reuþe þat hẏm knewe.
He wep & cryde on hẏs men, þat hii ssolde on hym rewe,
þat he nere to deþe ẏpẏned, þat hii seẏe wel he ssolde.
So þat to sauẏ hẏs lẏf þe castel vp hii ȝolde.
þe kẏng nom þerynne þe byssope's tresorẏe,
And in þẏs manere lo! bẏgan hẏs Werre Ar. worre myd robberẏe,
þat laste here in Engelond boþe gret & strong
A boute a xvii. Ar. Wel an seuentene ȝer, & þat was Sumdelle long Ar. al to long.
þe erchebẏssop of Canterburẏ, & oþer byssopes also,
So sorẏ wer vor þẏs dede, þat hii nuste wat to do.
At Wẏnchestre a parlement hii helde of These Ar. þys þẏng,
So þat wel pitoslyche hii wende alle to þe kẏng,
And velle adoun to hẏs fet, & pẏtoslyche bede,
þat he ssolde, vor Gode's loue, amendẏ such dede.
Ac al ẏt was þo vor noȝt, vor to worse euere he drou.
þe byssopes ne couþe oþer red, bote were wo ẏnou.

The ii. bisshopes a boue seide sone deide thoo For so∣rowe and mysayse, that to hem was i do.
¶ Kyng Stephne in his¶ Prose more plennere of the same ma∣ter. iiii. yer beẏng atte Oxenforde, lete take Roger bisshop of Sa∣lesbury, and Alisaundre bis∣shop of Lyncolne, &, as gul∣tẏe of manẏ wrongẏs, putte hem in Prisone, and bẏname hem hur Castels and hure tresoures. These. ii. bisshop∣pes to fore that tyme were the most a losed bisshoppes, among alle other. Roger, for∣sothe, bẏ Henry the ferst, themperice fader, was a∣uaunced, and was maked, in mẏnẏstrẏng of nedes of the regne, the secunde fro the kẏng. so that he gadered muche tresoure, thourghe whiche he made. ii. noble ca∣stels, that is to seẏe, of Shir∣bourne and the Vẏse, with huge costmous werke. And to his neuew Alisaundre he gat the byssoprich of Lẏncolne, whiche in castelle makyng was evene to his vncle. Na∣theles yut after wardes he bẏthẏnkẏng, that suche ca∣stellwerk was nat semẏng to Religion, in a mendement of that trespas, he maked so ma∣nẏ minstres of Religion, and endowed hem with londes and rentes. Roger bẏssop of Saresburẏ a bouesaide was the ferst, that dude his othe to the emperice, while hur fader lẏued, to be trewe & liege after to hure after his deþ, and noughte onliche swor ferst, but a betted alle other to sweer also, and spak the wordes of the kynge's wille, and after that, to haue the fauour of kẏng Stephene, he was nat shamed to be on of the ferst, that brake the fealte of the Emperice, and swoor newe to kynge Stephene, and so ẏaf to many other ensam∣ple of mẏdoẏng, as into whiche bisshop, as hit were bẏ Godde's ordenaunce, kyng Stephene was ordeẏned to do veniaunce, and ẏeue him penaunce, ferst by Prisone∣ment, and after by scarsenesse of mete and drẏnke. The bẏs∣shop Alexaundre of Lẏncolne in the same wẏse he destress∣ed, that he was faẏn to ẏelde him vp. ii. noble castells, in whiche his tresours were. For he was the kẏnge's Tre∣sourer. Rogger a boue saide, as me seide, in sorrow and mẏseise ended his lyf, and Alexandre also, a gret En∣sample to aftercomers. Gef∣freẏ, Erle of Angeo, them∣perice housbonde, entred in∣to Normandie, of whiche, for to haue trewes with hem. iii. yere, he toke bẏ ẏere Ml. marc.
Anno quinto. Ryme.
¶ The fifte ẏere of kyng Stephene Molde themperice com To Engelond, to cha∣lengi bẏ rẏght the kyngdom, And Robert Erle of Glouce∣tre with hure, hure half bro∣ther, also welle, Atte Mi∣chelle masse tẏde, as hit thoo bẏ felle. And furst the toke hure loggẏng in the castelle of Arundelle. Whenne kẏng Stephne hurde here of, sone he thedur come Ar. þe byssop of Salesburẏ deẏde sone þo,
Of wan we abbeþ er yspeke, in pur meseyse & wo.
Vndr þat þe emper esse to Engelond com,
To calangẏ, after hẏre fader, bẏ ryȝte þe kẏnedom.
In þe castel of Arundel vorst heo gan abẏde,
To loke wat were best to do, & to conseylẏ in eche sẏde.
þe kẏng Steuene ẏt wuste, þuder sone he com,″
Mẏd poer gret ynou, & þen castel nome,
And þẏs ladẏ þerinne, so þat vor franchẏse
He let hẏre go ware heo wolde, & ne dude noȝt as þe wyse.
And heo wende to Brẏstow, & bẏleuede þere
In hẏre broþer castel, strong ẏnou, vorte betere cas were.
Syre Randolf Ar. Rauf, erl of Chestre, hadde ẏspoused ẏwẏs
Erle Roberte's doughter of Glou∣cetre, of whham ich tolde er this Ar. þe Robertus douter of Gloucestre, of wan we tolde arþ ẏs.
So þat he huld wẏþ þe emperesse, (vor Elles Ar. el ẏt were amẏs)
And ladde ost gret ynou aȝe þe kẏng and hẏs.
He wende & nom Lẏncolne, & þe kynge's men out caste,
And sette þer inne folk ynou, & wende aboute vaste.
þe kẏng þo, þe sẏxte ȝer of hẏs kẏnedom,
Mẏd hẏs poer to Lẏncolne At Midsomer com, Ar. to Mydwynter com,
Vor to nyme þen toun vp hem, þat were þere inne,

Spek To the Erle of Gloucestre, and other knẏghtes echeon Ar. toward þe erl of Gloucestre, & þe knẏȝtes echon.

"Mẏd god wẏlle ic þanky ȝou, as ic wel aute To doo, Ar. do,

"And sẏweþ me in such pereẏl, & in deþe's drede.
"And wan ic ham enchesun of such pereyl ywẏs,

"After me, vor ẏch ẏse al hou ẏcholle do,

þe erl Roberd of Gloucestre spec þo þẏs ẏwẏs:
"Sẏre ȝong bacheler," he sede, "wel we wytẏþ þẏs,
"þat Thow Ar. þun art strong & corageus, & noȝt vnwurþe also,

"But that myght thow aske not, but for thẏnges twoo, As for noble∣nesse of heighe kynne, or for prowesse i do Ar. And naþeles þou ne mẏȝte ẏt esle noȝt, bote vor þẏnges tuo,
"Oþer vor nobleẏe of heẏe kẏnne, oþer vor prowesse ẏdo.

"Vor to fle, he ẏs so luþer, as ȝe alle ẏseẏe,

"Maẏster he ẏs to bẏtraẏe hẏs word, ẏs al falshede.

"Slou to fyȝte, & quic to fle, & þat nẏs non manhede.
"þe erl Hue comþ ek aȝen ȝou, þat fals ẏs & versuore,

"þat muche wul segge & bẏhote, & lute þer to do.

"Nou, ȝe Stal∣worthe knẏghtes, that Henry kyng vp brought, Helpeth his heires, that trewthe cleym∣eth, and falsede brẏngeth to noȝt. And a wreke ẏow on ẏoure foon, that in oure marches buth nouthe, That oure dedes be i kud bẏ Northe and eke bẏ Southe, Ar. stallewardes knẏȝtes, þat þe kyng Henrẏ vp broȝte,

"Opuþ, & eke in God, & eke in our rẏȝte,
"And nẏmeþ þe wreche of ȝour fon, þat our Lord ȝou bed nouþe.
"þat ȝoure dede mow be couþ, bẏ Norþe & ek by Souþe,

"And byhoteþ hym to be Stable, that ẏe ne shalle faylle noght Ar. stable, & þat ȝe ne ssolde fle noȝt.
Her honden hii hulde vp all þo, & bẏhete God to be

þe kẏng, after masse, vende toward þe bataẏle sone.
He ordeyned hẏs folc & hẏs ost, as he þoȝte to done.
þo bed he one sẏre Baldewẏne, þat folc arẏȝt rede.
Vor he spec wel, And wẏs was, and these wordes sede: Ar. & couþe also, & he þes wordes sede:
"Louerdẏnges, ȝe wẏte wel, þat wo so Wolle do suche thẏng, Ar. wolde such þẏng,

"Vorst þe rẏȝt of hẏs cause, & suþþe þe noumbre also
"Of hẏs men, & suþþe þenche her prowesse þerto.

"þe noumbre, þat vor defaute her fon aboue ne be.

"Vor pur mẏseẏse, & vor hope þat þer beþ mo.

"Ryȝt ẏs, aȝen hys Forsworne Ar. versuorẏe þat we wẏþ hẏm gon.

"þe prowesse Eke of oure men ho Ar. of þẏs noblemen wo mẏȝte telle mẏd mouþe,
"þat in armẏs ẏproued beþ bẏ Norþe And eke bẏ Ar. & bẏ Souþe?
"þe prowesse of our kẏng ẏs as wyþoute ende.
"For he alon may besette a ẏene Ar. Vor setteþ hẏm one baldelẏche aȝen an hondred to wende,

"And wanne our lẏge louerd, þat A noẏnted is With holẏ oẏle to Jhesu Christe, and so noble a bodẏ is, And her a mẏdde vs alle is to susteẏne the righte, Muche worship were to vs, for with him to fighte With trouthe & with soothe∣nesse Ar. ẏheled ẏs,

"Is here amẏdde vs alle, to susteynẏ hẏs rẏȝte,

"We trewe & in soþnesse″ aȝen hem þat false beþ.

"Of þe erl Roberd of Gloucestre ȝe ne dorre abbe non drede.

"Hẏs Wordes is as a lẏon, his hert arwe as an hare Ar. mouþ ẏs as a leon, hẏs herte arn as an hare.
"Al so of þe erl of Chestre ȝe ne dorre abbe non care.

"Hastẏf wyþoute porueance oþer wẏsdom in dede.

"Hẏs brayn & wẏs ẏs so feble, þat þer nys of hẏm non drede.
"Vor wat he aþ manlẏche bẏgonne, he ẏt aþ byleuede
"Wommanlẏche, as vor defaute of wẏt of hẏs heuede.

Of þe Welsse men, þat mẏd hẏm beþ, ne dorre ȝe noȝt drede.
"Vor folc hastẏf hii beþ ek ẏnou, & also wẏþout rede.
"Lepe hii conne, as naked Men, lowde crẏe and showte Ar. men, non dunt bẏlefþ wẏþout.
"We ssolle, as so monẏe ssep, to drẏue al þe route.
"Oþer knẏȝtes, þat þer beþ, lute beþ wurþ ẏwẏs.
"Vor euere mo þat þer beþ, Of hem, the better Ar. of þe betere to vs ẏt ẏs.
"Non ȝe noble knẏȝtes, of That ẏe Ar. wat ȝe abbeþ ẏdo,
"Of prowesse vnderstondeþ, & of ȝour elderne also.
"Kuthe Ar. Suþeþ to day ȝoure manhede, þat ẏt Maẏ Ar. mowe wende
"To ȝou & to ȝoure Children day with outen ende Ar. chyldren to honour wiþout en ende.
"þe Custume and the vs, Ar. wone & vse, þat ȝe abbeþ euer to be aboue,
"þat aȝte ȝou To make to fẏght with the better wille & loue Ar. make abbe to fẏȝte þe betere loue.
"And þat ȝoure fon abbeþ euere bẏneþe ẏbe,
"þat ssal hem brẏnge sone in wẏlle vor to fle.
"And welle Iche wote, hit hem of thenkethe sothely I wẏs Whelle sore, that hii huder come, and bithenkethe this, Ar. Ichot ẏnam noȝt bẏgabbed, þat ẏt ne of þencheþ hem bẏ þẏs
"Wel sore, þat hii here come. vor hii bẏþencheþ hem ywẏs,
"Hou hii myȝte best fle, ȝẏf hii wuste in wuche sẏde.
"And whanne hii ne witethe hoder to fleo, ne hii ne durre a bide Ar. Ac wanne hii L. ne vyte. vyte ware fle, ne hii ne dorre abẏde,
"Wat mẏȝte hii þanne more do, bote ȝelde hem alstẏlle,
"And her hors & her armes be & hem sulue at our wẏlle?
"þanne ȝe noblemen an hansẏeþ ȝoure þoȝt,
"And auongeþ nouþe Gode's grace, þat God ȝou aþ ẏbroȝt.
He ne mẏȝte of hẏs reson Vnnethe come to the laste, Ar. noȝt come to laste,
þat her fon toward Hem come pri∣kyng faste Ar. hem ne come prẏkẏe vaste.
þe erþe dunede vnder hem, vor stappes þat harde were.
þe hors neẏde & lepte, þat yt was gret fere.
þe bataẏle bẏgan strong ẏnou, vor þe deserytes gonne chese,
Raþer þan to lese her lond, her lẏf þere to lese.
Hii Putte Ar. pulte hem vorþ Bẏ fore other, as good men oughte. Ar. bẏuore þe oþere, as godemen & aȝte.
Hii asaẏlede þe vorst ost, & broȝte ẏt sone to naȝte,
þat þe erl Aleyn of Brutaẏne, as chef, was in do.
And Hue erl of Estangle, & þe erl of Meles al so,
And þe erl of Warenne ek, alle þes in a stounde,
And her folc þe deserẏtes broȝte ẏwẏs to grounde.

Of Aumarle and William of Ipers, Ar. Ammar & Wẏllam of ẏpre, ne lykede noȝt þẏs cas.

þat hẏs Welsse men eode adoun, he smot vorþ ywẏs,

Vor hii slowe monẏon, & þer flowe somme.
So that Ar. þo þat þe kẏng Steuene, Bẏ lafte Ar. byleue alone þere
Mẏd an vewe of hẏs men, That noble and stalworthe were, Ar. þat wel stalwarde were,

þe oþere wende al aboute vaste wyþout faẏle,
As ẏt were aboute a castel, þat me wolde asaẏle.

Of þe helmes al about, & somme velle among.

Myd al þe poer That he hadde, and Ar. þat was hẏs, & asaẏled hẏm ẏnou.

And þe Londreẏs mẏd her poer, & her ost greþed echon,
And smẏte þere an bataẏle, & manẏe broȝte to deþe.
þe emperesse bẏgan to fle, & of scapede vnneþe.
Manẏe of hẏre Worthẏ men fleyng i take were, Ar. gode men ffleẏnde ẏnome were,
And erl Roberd of Gloucestre was ek ẏnome þere.
Vor hẏre luþerhede þe emperesse al bẏneþe þo was.
Heo mẏȝte, wanne heo hom com, segge, Or cy haut cẏ bas Ar. "sẏ haust, sẏ base."
Of þe kẏnge's crounement as in þe syxte ȝere
Boþe, as ych abbe ẏtold, þẏs bataẏles ẏdo were.
þe erl delyuered þo þe kẏng, & þe kẏng hẏm Bẏ his othe, Ar. bẏ god oþ,
Bẏ such vorewarde ẏmad, þat hii were delyuered boþe.
þo kẏng Steuene was delyuered, He fonde by prowesse, Ar. he fondede hẏs proesse,

ȝẏf he mẏȝte enẏ tẏme hente Themperes∣se. Atte Wilton he cast a strengthe his Enmẏs to kepe, for which he was i chased a waẏ, and of his men an hepe I slayne sodeẏnliche, er theẏ wer i war. Sir William Mar∣telle, the kynge's asseore, take eke was ther, Whiche, quik for to goo fre wher he wolde, Resyngned vp Shir∣bourne castelle, that he had holde. Themperise atte Ox∣enforde was in the castelle. The kyng Stephne with his host thuder wende snelle. Atte Michelle masse to Oxen∣forde they come, as Ich gesse, And fort Ar. þe emperesse.
At Oxenforde þe emperesse was þo in þe castel.
þe kẏng hẏs poer & hys ost ȝarkede þo wol wel,
And wende, vorþ to Oxenford aboute Mẏhelmasse,
And vorto″ Mẏdewẏnter neẏ bẏseged þe emperesse.
So gret Frost Ar. forst þer com in Aduent, þat men mẏȝte agrẏse,
þat me mẏȝte boþe ryde & go in Temese Upon the Ise. A grete snow ther was also, therefore ane queyntyse Themperise hure bẏthought, Ar. vpe yse.
þe emperesse byþoȝte,″ & dude as þe wẏse.
Wẏte cloþes heo dude hẏre on, as, wo seẏþ, ẏlẏch þe snow,
þat me ne ssolde Hur perceẏue, ne for whitnesse know Ar. vor þe lyknesse ẏse hẏre, ne knowe;
And vpe þe ẏse of Temese Heo wende fro Oxenforde, Alle Suthe into the mede, Ar. wende vorþ, & so Rectius fro, ut in Ar. to Oxenford
Al Souþward in to þe med, & so to Walẏngford.
In þe seuene ȝer of hys kynedom þe kyng þe castel nom,
Ac þe emperesse ne vond he noȝt, þo he ẏn com.
Muche robberye me dude aboute in euerẏch toun,
And prysoned richemen, for they ẏeue raunsone Ar. And bounde men & enprisonede, vorte hii fynede raunson.
Hii ne sparede nanmore clerkes, þan lewed men ẏwẏs.
So þat þe byssopes, vorto amendẏ þẏs
In þe viii. Ar. eẏȝteþe ȝere of the kẏnge's kẏnedom

At Londone hii hulde a parlement, þatMuche folke to com, And the kẏng him self benyngliche ther was also. And ther was hit ordeyned, ho so honde sette to Upon Clerke, in vio∣lence, Religious or seculer, He shulde falle into the grete curs for his mẏster, And be nat assoyled, fort to the Pope he come, So that to Clerkes after ward me toke the more gome Ar. in quo & hîc loci haec habemus, inter alia, ab auctore prosaïco scripta de morte Galfridi Graundeville (vel, ut alii, Maundeville) & Roberti Marmyon: After that kyng Stephne, nat vn mẏnde∣fulle of the shame, that Gef∣freẏ Graundeville dude to him, while he was in warde, (as in holdyng the toure of Lon∣done, and in takyng the bis∣shop of Londone, and other doẏngges,) in a tyme, as this Geffraẏ cam to the kynge's Court atte Seynt Albone's, thenkyng not but good, by cause of the assuraunce, that was made in the deliuer∣aunce of kyng Stephene, the kyng, foryetyng his Roẏalle honeste, toke this Geffraẏ, and imprisoned him, fort he hadde yolde vp the toure of Londone, with other streng∣thes. And he, whanne he was delẏuered, gadered him a companẏe of luther doẏng men, toke with mastrey the Abbeẏ of Ramseẏ, and putte oute the monkes, and made castelle of the Abbeẏ, & made preẏs, & greued the coun∣tre with manẏ greuaunces, and manẏ assautes yaf to the king. This Geffrey after∣ward, in the seege of a ca∣stelle, i shot of a foteman with an arwe, deyde. ¶ A nother man, of the same doẏng as this Geffraẏ, was Robert Marmyon bẏ name, that hadde take te mynstre of Couentre, and put oute the monekes, as he wolde goo with an host a ẏenst Randolf Erle of Chestre, comyng with his host, he felle in a diche, brake his thẏe, and so he myght nat rise, but was of on of his Enmẏs bẏhefded. many man to com,
And þe kẏng hẏm sulf was þerate. hii amansede þo
Alle þulke, þat clerkes such despẏt dude & wo,
þat no man, bote þe pope one, hem asoẏly ne mẏȝte,
So þat me huld clerkes þerafter bet to rẏȝte.

A Continuation of Robert of Gloucester's History where Lord Harley's Copy ends.

LG.L: So that me huld clerkes ther after bet to rizte.
& king Stefne is Luthernesse Ar. suthernesse with drou an zeres vewe.
But er. v. yer wer goo, he ganne to wex a shrewe Ar. A car vif zer ther after he bicom he bicom eft a ssre we.
Vor he wende aboute, & robbede, & that lond to grounde brozte,
& the toun of Wircestre brende al to nozte.
In endleue hondred zer of grace, & vifti zer al so,
Wircestere was thus ibarnd, & other Harmes i doo Ar. harm ido.
Roberd erl of Gloucestere, of wan we speke er,
And alle halwe eue deide, thulke sulue zer,
& in the priorie of Seint Jame at Bristowe ibured was.
King Stefne was the Baldere for that ilke cas, Ar. boldore, & the prottore uor this cas.
Ac God sende an other cas, vor in the next zer anon,
In endleue hondred zer of grace and vifti and on,
Deide Geffre Plantaginet, erl of Aungeo.
Henri, is sone and is eyr, erl was imad tho
Of Aungeo, an duc of Normandie. Thenne cam hit in his mynde, Ar. tho was it muche is munde,
To come & winne Engelond, (uor he was next of kunde)
And to helpe is moder, that was her ofte in feble chaunce.
And he was A queẏnted Ar. a quointe muche to the quene of Fraunce,
And to muche, as me trowed, in some thẏng. The quene loued him somdelle more, thanne hure lorde the kyng Ar. And somdel to muche, as me wende, so that in som thing
The quene louede, as me wende, more him than the king.
So that it was uorþ I putte Ar. ipult, that the king & heo
So Neghe of kẏn Ar. sibbe″ were, that hii ne mizte leng to gadere beo.
The kunrede I proued Ar. improued was, so that king Lowis there
& Elianore is quene, vor kunrede, Parted Ar. departed were.
Some were tho glade inou, as it was isene,
Vor Henri, the emperesse sone, spousede tho the quene.
The quene richesse inou hadde vnder ire hond,
War thoru this Henri mizte the bet winne Engelond.
Endleue hondred zer and fifti and tuo,
After that God an erthe com, this spousinge was ido.
The nexte zer ther after Henry is poer nom,
& mid sixe & thritti sipes to Engelonde com,

Biuore Seint Hillarie's day, With joẏ and mẏrth i now Moche heighe folke of the londe sone to him drow. The erle of Waraẏne with his power sone a ẏenst him come, And to his castelle of Wa∣reẏne him faire vndernom. Also in his half araẏed him kyng Stephne, But for to wane power he bar him som∣delle evene. He ne hadde wer∣red but lite, er hii accorded were In fourme, that Steph∣ne alle his lẏf ther after the croune bere, And after his daẏ, Henri his heir and kyng shulde be. Henry after this accorde wente over see a ẏee Ar. in quo nihil praeterea de Stephano rhythmice habetur, aliquammulta tamen prosaice, è quibus haec paucula decer∣pam: And after in the yere of oure Lord Ml. cliii. [l. Ml. cliiii.] deyed kyng Stephene, and buryed is atte Feuersham in Kent, vii. mile fro Caunter∣burẏ, in a mẏnstre of Frensshe monkes, that Molde, kyng Stephne's quene, hadde founded newe in the worship of the croẏs, after that he had regned. xix. yere. In the whiche Abbey is a pece of the holẏ croẏs, that Godfray Boylon, for kynred, hadde sende to kyng Stephene. The Abbey of Feuershame was founded in the yere of oure Lorde Ml. cxlix. That ilke tẏme was Seynt Erkenwolde atte Poule's atte Londone Translacio Sancti Er∣kenwaldi. translated. Thebaud Erle of Bleys deide. In the yere of onre Lorde Ml. cxliiii. was founded the Priourẏe of cha∣nons of Brutone, where to fore honde were bretherne. But by Sir William Moẏon, the Erle of Somersete, ther were ordeyned chanons. and with joye inou
Azen him the erl of Wareine with gret power drou,
And in the castel of Wareine with gret joye him nom.
Muche heye folk of the lond sone to him com,
As to hor kunde louerd, so þat king Steuene,
Vor lute poer & fellesse, huld him al an euene.
Hii nadde iworred bote a lute, that hii acorded were
At Winchestre, & king Steuene in the nexte zere
Ther after deide sone. Endleue hondred zer it was
Of grace & foure & fifti, þat among hom vel this cas.
Ac the croune ne leuede he nozte, tho hii acorded were,
Bote that Henry the croune after is daie bere.
Vor the acord was so imad, & Henri the lasse strengthe
Made, uor that he isei is lif of lute lengthe.
Nintene zer king Steuene of this londe was king.
And this was al thulke time in worre & striuing.
Henri, the emperesse sone, tho king Stefne ded lay,
At Westmunstre let him crouny king, the nexte Soneday
Biuore Midewinter day, With grete nobleẏ Ar. with nobleye ynou,
& the heyemen of this lond vaste aboute him drou.
Tho wende he mid gret poer aboute here & there,
& nom castles & Toures, Ar. tounes, that his mid riȝte were.
Castles, that were nywe ymad, he broȝte Downe pro alle in Ar. alle to grounde,
& out of londe drof is fon, wan he eny founde.
& nameliche Them Ar. hom of Flaundres, vor hii were mest is fon.
Henri, is eldoste sone, ibore was tho anon.
The laste day of Feuerer, In the .xi.c. yere And .lv. that oure Lorde in Erthe a light here Ar. ac endleue hondred zer
& fiue & fifti vr Louerd an erthe alizte her.
At Londone he was ibore, ac an eldore brother ther was,
Willam, that deide sone, as God zef that cas.
Mold was after Henry, & suththe the gode knizt
King Richard, that ibore was in Septembre rizt.
Geffray tho, & suththe Jon, & Elianore last,
That to the Kyng of Ca∣stelle i spoused was fast. And to the duc of Saxone Ar. king de Chastles was suththe ispoused vast.
& to the king of Sesonie Mold ispoused was.
This Was a them fulle faire, but harde her chaunce was. The kyng Ar. was, lo! a uair tour, ac newe hadde god cas.
The king let Henri is sone, as God zef the cheaunce,
Spouse Merga∣rete, doughter of Lowes kyng of Fraunce Ar. Lowis dozter spousi, that was king of Fraunce.
King Henri wondede muche, to abbe men in offis
Mid him, that of conseil were god & wis.
Ercedekne of Kanterbury Sein Tomas tho was.
The king him made is chaunceler, And so his wille was Ar. at is wille it nout nas.
To him the king truste mest. ne ther nas non so heye
That so muche wuste is priuite, ne that him were so ney.
So muche he truste To Ar. on him, that in is warde he let do
Henri is eldoste sone, & is eir al so,
Hîc perplura omittuntur in Ar. That he werre his wardein, & al is ordeinour
To is wille to willi him, & to the kinge's honour.
The king wende to Normandie to soiorni there,
& mid Sein Tomas dude is sone, that he is wardein were.
Tho Tebaud the erchebissop suththe ded was,
The king & monekes ek chose Seint Tomas.
Tho he was erchebissop, he huld zut in is hond
That child, uort that the king come in to Engelond.
The child louede him inou, more nas neuere iseye.
Ne he nadde of no man more loue ne eye.
Tho the king to londe com, Sein Tomas nom is sone,
& wel vawe azen him wende to Southhamtone.
There was joye & blisse inou, tho hii to gadere come.
Hii custe hom & bi clupte, & herede God ilome.
It was endleue hundred zer, & sixti & tuo,
Of grace that Sein Tomas was erchebissop tho.
The next zer ther after, as it wolde be,
Endleue hundred zer of grace, & sixti & thre,
He halwede, as the king him bed, the churche of Redinge,
That verst ifounded was thoru Henri the other kinge.
He srinede thulke sulue zer Seint Edward iwis,
That was king of Engelond, at Westmunstre that is.
The king zef thulke sulue zer Henri is sone Aungeo,
Tours & al Normandie, & Richard is sone al so
He zef Gascoine & Aquitaine, so that hii dude homage
King Lowis of France theruore withoute outrage.
Geffray is sone he made erl of Brutaine al so.
The wule is children zonge were al this was ido.

No man Vide Seldeni Anglorum fa∣ciem alteram, p. 97, 100, 102, Lond. 1610. & ejusd. tract. ver∣sionem Angl. p. 74, 75, 77. Item Selden's England's Epino∣mis, p. 22, 23, 24. ne mizte thenche the loue that ther was
Bituene the king Henri, & the gode man Sein Tomas.
The deuel adde enuie ther to, & sed bituene Them feu Seld. hom seu.
Alas! alas! thulke stounde! vor al to wel it greu.
Vor ther adde er ibe kinges of luther dede,
As Willam bastard, & is sone Willam the rede,
That luther lawes made ynou, & helde In al Seld. in to al the lond.
The king nolde nouzt bileue the lawes that he fond,
Ne that is elderne hulde. Ne the gode man Sein Tomas
Thouzte, that thing aze riȝte neuere lawe nas,
Ne sothnesse, And Seld. ac custome mid strengthe vp iholde.
& he wuste, that Vre dere Lourd Seld. vr Louerd in the gospel tolde,
That he him sulf was sothnesse, & costume nout,
Ther uore luther costumes he nolde graunti nouȝt.
Ne the king nolde bileue that is elderne adde iholde.
So that contek sprong bituene Them Seld. hom mani volde.
The king drou to riȝte lawe mani luther costome.
Sein Tomas They withsed, Seld. hom withsede, & grantede some.
The lawes, that icholle nou telle, he grauntede vawe.
Zuf a Yuman Seld. thuman hath a sone to clergie idrawe,
He ne sal, withoute is Sub∣audi, wille. louerde's, icrouned nouzt be:
Vor Yuman, Seld. thuman ne may nouzt be imad azen is louerde's wille fre.
Another thing he grauntede ek, as ze mowe no u ise.
Zuf a man of holi chirche Hath Seld. halt eni lay fe,
Parson Seld. Person, other wat he be, he sal do theruore
Kinge's servise, that ther Valth, Seld. valp, that is rizte ne be uor lore;
In playdinge & in asise be, & in jugement also,
Bote war man sal be bilemed, other to dethe ido.
He grantede ek, zuf eni man the kinge's traytour were,
& eni man Deest Seld. of″ is Chateux Seld. chatens to holi churche bere,
That holi churche ne solde nouȝt the Chateux Seld. chateus there lette,
That the king there, other is, as is owene, is ne Wette Seld. vette.
Vor al that the felon hath, the kinge's it is.
& ech man mai in holi churche is owene take ywis.
He grantede ek, that a churche of the kinge's fe
In none stede ene & euere Ne Seld. no solde iziue be
As to hous of religion, withoute the kinge's leue,
& that he, other the patron, the zifte verst Gaue Seld. zeue.
Seint Tomas grantede wel thes & other mo.
Ac These Seld. this othere he withsede, that Did Seld. dude him wel wo.
Zuf bituene tueie lewede men were eni striuing,
Other betuene a lewede & a clerc, vor holi churche thing,
As vor voweson of churche, Whither Seld. wether solde the churche ziue,
The king wolde, that in is court the ple solde be driue.
Vor as muche as a lewed man, that the o partie was,
Chanliche Seld. Clanliche was vnder the king, & vnder no bissop nas.
Another was, that No clerc, ne bishop Seld. in Jani Angl. fac. altera, sed ut nos in England's Epinomis. no bissop, ne clerc nathemo,
Ne solde withoute kinge's leue out of The Seld. in J. Angl. f. a. sed this in E. Ep. this lond go.
& thanne hii solde suerie vpe the bok ywis,
That hii ne solde purchasy non uvel the king, ne non of his.
The thridde was, zuf eni man in Mausing Seld. mansinge were ibrouzt,
& suththe come to amendement, ne Age were nought, omisso riȝte, Seld. aze riȝte nere nozt,
That he ne suore Omittit Seld. nouzt″ upe the boc, ac Borowes Seld. borewes finde solde,
To stonde to that holi chirche ther of him Toky Seld. loky wolde.
The verthe was, that no man, that of the kinge hulde ouȝt
In chef, other in eni seruise, in mausinge nere ibrozt,
Bote the wardeins of holi chirche, that brozte him ther to,
The king sede, other is bailifs, wat he adde misdo,
& lokede verst, wer hii Deest Seld. wolde″ to amendement it bringe,
& bote hii wolde By their leue Seld. be hor leue do the Mausing Seld. mansinge.
The vifte was, that bissopriches, & abbeies al so,
That Va∣cans Seld. vacanns were of prelas, in the kinge's Hand Seld. hond were ido,
& that the king solde al the lond as is Owne Seld. owe take,
Vort atte laste that him luste eni prelat ther make,
& thanne thulke prelat solde in is chapele ichose be
Of is clerkes, Which he wuld Seld. wuche he wolde to such Sic etiam Seld. in Eng. Ep. sed prelace in Jani Ang. f. a. prelat bi se.
& thanne, wan he were ichose in is chapele riȝt there,
Homage he solde him do, ar he confermed were.
The sixte was, zuf eni play to chapitle were idrawe,
& eni man made is apel, zuf me dude him vnlawe,
That to the bissop fram ercedekne is apel solde make,
& fram bissop to erchebissop, & suththe non Other take, Seld. herre take;hier
& bote the erchebissope's court to riȝte him wolde bringe,
That he solde fram him Be cluthe Seld. bi clupe biuore the kinge.
& fram the king non Other mo Seld. herre mo. so that Attan Seld. atten ende
Plaininge of holi chirche to the king solde wende,
& the king Amend Seld. amendi solde the erchebissope's dede,
& be as in the pope's stude. And Seld. ac Sein Tomas it withsede.
The seuethe was, that plaidinge that of dette were,
To zelde wel thoru treuthe iplizte, & nouzt iholde nere
Al thei thoru treuthe it were, that ple solde be ibrozt
Biuore the king & is bailifs, & to holi churche nozt.
the eiȝtethe was, that in the londe citacion non nere
Thoru bulle of the pope of Rome, And Seld. ac clene bileued were.
The nithe was, that Petre's Pence Seld. panes, that me gadereth ma∣ni on,
The pope nere nouȝt on isend, ac the king ech on.
The tethe was, zuf eni clerc as felon were itake,
& vor felon iproued, & ne mizte it nozt uorsake,
That me solde him uerst desordeini, & suthth thoru There law, Seld. pur lawe,
& thoru jugement of the lond, honge him, other to drawe.
Vor thes, & vor other mo, the gode mon Seint Tomas
Fleu verst out of Engelond, & Eke imartred Seld. suththe ymartred was.
Vor he sei ther nas bote o wey, other he moste stif be,
Other holi churche was issent, That of right Seld. that mid rizte was so fre.
Endleue hundred zer of grace, & foure & sixti therto,
It was that Sein Tomas of londe wende so.
The nexte zer ther after the amperesse Mold
Wende out of this liue, as the boc ath itold.
The king let crouni to kinge, an vif zer after this,
Henri, is eldoste sone, at Westmunstre ywis.
As endleue hundred zer of grace, & sixti & tene,
& sixtene zer he was old, tho he was icrouned, ich wene.
The erchebissop of Euerwik, & the bissop of Londone,
& of Salesbury, him crounede, azen rizt & wone.
Vor the erchebissop of Canterburi mid rizte it solde do.
Tho Sein Tomas it wuste, gret deol he nom him to,
That the churche of Kanterbury in such vnriȝt was ibroȝt.
He nolde vor to tholie deth leng tholie it nozt.
He drou him towarde Engelond to is martirdom.
As Gode's knizt he bigan, tho he hider com.
He amansede alle thulke, that such vnrizt adde ido
To the churche of Canterbury, & the king icrouned so.
The thre bissopes worthe were, & nome hom to rede,
& wende vorth to Normandie, & the olde king it sede.
The king was nei vor wraththe wod, & sede, zuf that he
Amauseth alle thulke men, thanne amauseth he me.
He acorsede alle thulke men, that he hadde uorth ibrouȝt,
That of an false preste ne abbe eke him nouȝt.
That word he sede ofte in hastinesse ywis.
Foure of the deuele's limes, is kniȝtes hurde this.
Sire Reinaud Lefizours, sire Roger Brut al so,
Sir Hue de Moruile, Sir Willam Traci ther to.
Hii nome hom to rede, & uor to paye is wille,
Wende uorth to Engelond hasteliche & stille.
Tho the king com to is mete, & is kniȝtes mid him were,
He bihuld & miste thulke foure there.
Is herte him zef anon, wuderward hii wende.
In anguisse & sor ynou after hom he sende,
Toward the se hasteliche, that hii come aze.
Ar the messager come, hii were in the se.
Hii wende hom vorth to Kanterburi, & in the churche riȝt
Hii martreden Sein Tomas an Tiwesday at nizt.
This gode man sat adoun a kne, & is heued buyede adoun,
& wel softe, as some hurde, sede this orison:
"God & Seinte Marie, & Sein Denis al so,
"& alle the abowes of this churche, in was ore ich am ido,
"Ich bitake min soule, & holi churche rizte.
Zut he bed vor holi churche, tho he nadde other mizte.
Sir Reinaud Lefizours, mest srewe of ech on,
Vor to smite this holi man is suerd drou anon.
Ac Edward Grim, that was is clerc, of Grantebrugge ibore,
To helpe is louerd, zuf he mizte, pulte is arm biuore.
He wounde his arm suithe sore, thut blod orn adoun.
Mid thulke dunt ek he smot Sein Tomas upe the croun,
That thut blod orn bi is face, in the rizt half of the wounde.
Loude gradde the luther knizt, "smiteth alle to grounde."
In thulke sulue wounde, an other him smot tho,
That he abuyde is face adoun, vort ther com mo.
The thridde in thulke sulue stede ther after smot anon,
& made him a loute al adoun, is face vpe on the ston.
In thulke stede the verthe smot, that the othere adde er ydo,
& the point of is suerd brec in the marbreston a tuo.
Zut thulke point at Canterbury the monekes lateth wite,
Vor honour of the holi man, that ther with was ismite.
With thulke stroc he smot al of the scolle & ek the croune,
That the brain orn al abrod in the pauiment ther doune.
Tho this holi man imartred was, the kniȝtes gradde ech on,
"This traitour is to dethe ibrozt, wende we henne anon.
"Syweth vi the kinge's men, & alle that mid him beth,
"Of this traitor we beth awreke, as ze nou iseth.
"He thouzte be herre than the king, & binime him is croune,
"& to nouzte bringe al Engelond, & nou he lith ther doune.
In The. xi. c. yere Ar. endleue hundred zer of grace this gode man Sein Tomas,
& sixti & endleuene, thus imartred was.
Tho the king it wuste, he made deol ynou,
So that vor anguisse nei him sulue he slou.
In the castel of Argentein vourty dawes he was,
In a chaumbre al one, withoute eni solas.
In wop & sorwe & deol inou, & confort non him nas,
Ac euere on the holi man criede Sein Tomas.
So that tueie cardinals the pope him sende iwis,
& hii him asoilede of that was ido amis.
& he vndude the luther lawes, & grauntede alle the gode
That Sein Tomas esste, as hii vnderstode.
Of forest & of other thing, that is elderne nome amis,
He vndude, & ther to is chartre made iwis.
Ac after is daye iholde febliche it was
Of king Jon, & of othere, & natheles ther nas.
Non of hom, that some time, mid wille thei it nere,
Ne grauntede & confermede it, thei it lute wurth were.
Vor mani is the gode bodi, that aslawe is theruore.
To betere ende God it bringe, that vor vs was ibore.

The shap and the maners of kyng Henry a bouesaide Peres Bleẏs, archedekon of Bathe, descrẏueth in Epistelle, that he wrot to therchebishop Pan∣normitane thus. Of Dauid kyng, in preysẏng of him, hit is radde, that he was rede. but vnderstondeth, that mẏ lorde the kyng is subruphus, for a colour of worshipfulle age, whiche a litelle harenesse hathe chaunged sumwhat his colour. Of mene stature he is, so that a mong litle sem∣eth he nat muche, ne a mong long somethe he nat ouer lite. His heued is rounde, as tokne of a place of grete wẏt, and of specialle heighe con∣saille tresourie. The hefde is of suche quantite, that to the nekke, and to alle the bo∣dẏ, hit accordethe by euene proporcion. His eẏen pẏkeled and simple as coluer's while he is of plesede wẏlle, but thourgh stourbelẏng of hert as sperkelyng fuẏre, as light∣nẏng
with hastenesse. his shode shamed nat the harme of ballednesse, and whenne he is i clipped in squar the forhede, he sheweth as a lyo∣nus visage. the nostrelles euen and kyndelich, accord∣ẏng to the other membres. heghe vouted feet, legges able to ridẏng, large strecch∣ẏng oute breste, & long cham∣pione armes, which telleth him to be strong, lighte, and hardẏ. In a too of his foot the naile groweth ouer to the flesshe, and in harme to the foot hugeliche ouerwexethe. His hondes, thourgh hure gretnesse, shewethe sumwhat vn wẏt and necclẏgence. for he vtterliche leueth the kep∣ẏng of hem, and neuer, but whenne he bereth haukes, ne vseth he gloues. Eche daẏ atte masses and conseilles, and other open nedes of the regne, fro morwe to eve euere he stondeth a fote. And thogh that his legges in ridẏnges, thourgh ofte smẏtyng of hors, be gretliche i wounded, & be wanne ther of, but whanne he eteth or rideth, he ne ne∣uere sittethe. In on day, and nede be, he wolle rẏde. ii. or. iii. journeẏs, and so ofte hath be [f. he] disceẏued and de∣stroyed the castes and en∣gẏnes of his enmys. An huge louer of wodes is he. so that while he cesseth of werre, he hanteth huntẏng and hauk∣ynge botes withoute foldyng cappes. Homliche and shorte clothes vseth he. His flesshe wolde haue charged him with fatnesse, but that the wanto∣nesse of his wombe with tra∣uaile and fastẏng he a daunt∣eth, and in ridyng & goyng trauaẏleth mẏghteliche his ẏouthe. Nat as other kynges lieth he in his paleẏs, but trauaẏllẏng aboute by his prouẏnces aspẏe the doẏnges of alle men, and demed hem that were Jugges whenne theẏ dude wronge, & punẏssh∣ed hem by strengour Jugge∣ment than other men: No man more wẏs in conseilles, ne more dredfulle in prospe∣rite, ne stedfastour in adver∣sites. Wham ones he lou∣ethe, vnnethe wolde he euere after hatie. Wham ones he hatethe, vnnethe he resceẏu∣ethe into grace. Ofte holdeth he an honde swerdes, bowes, and huntẏngere, but he be atte counseils or atte boke. ¶ Whenne he maẏ rest fram worlde's busynesse, priuelich he occupieth him a boute lernẏng in redyng, and a mong his clerkes axeth que∣stiones. For thoghe youre kyng be welle i lettred, oure kyng bẏ feer is more i let∣tred. Iche for sothe in science
of lettres knowe the konnẏng of bothe, wetẏng ẏe, that mẏ lorde, the kẏng of Scisile, alle a yer was mẏ disciple. And thogh of ẏow he had the gẏn∣nẏng of lecture, bẏ me nathe∣les cam he to the benefice of more fulle science. And as non as Iche wente oute of the regne of Scicile, ẏoure kẏng cast a waẏ his bokes, and yaf him to Palatin ydel∣nesse. But for sothe atte oure lorde the kyng of Engelonde is eche daẏes scole. Among righte welle lettred men hau∣ẏng his conuersacion, he hathe busy discussyng of que∣stions. Non is more honest than oure kyng in spekẏng, in etẏng curtaysoure, ne in almesses largeoure. Therfor, as holẏ writte seith, me may seẏ of him thus: His name is a presious oẏnement oute helde, and the almesses of him alle the cherche of Seyntes shalle telle. Oure kyng is pesable, and ẏut in bataille glorious. Uppe alle the desires of the worlde he desireth pees, coueẏtẏng the welthe of his Pepelle. To the pees of his pepille bi∣longeth that he dothe in cle∣pyng counseills, and in tak∣yng trewes, in joẏning affi∣nites, and that he meketh prout men, and that he thret∣neth werre, & maketh prynces adrad. þe huge ẏftes of mo∣neẏ that he ẏeuethe, and eke rescẏuethe & gadereth, that he spendethe in was of Ci∣tees, or kernelles, strengthes and dẏches, in closyng of wilde bestes and fẏsshes, in paleẏs buldẏnges, alle he dothe to encresse to the Pe∣ple's pees, non was nobler thanne he. His fader in his tẏmes enlargissed his march∣es, as a noble and worthi Erle, but thes, passing his fader's Ricchesse, in wit and strenghte of his hondes en∣cressed his title and stile, by encresse of the duchie of Ac∣quitaẏne, the duchie of Bru∣taẏne, of the Reaumes of En∣gelond and Scotland, Erlond and Wales. None was more benẏng than he to men, that were in diseise, or in tour∣ment. Non fairer speched to poure men. Non more proute to proute. And thegh, after the custumes of his regne, in elecciones of dignitees of holẏ churche, he haue the moste voẏs and power to ẏeue hem, euere more he kepte his hondes gilteles of alle Sy∣monie. Whith these & other suche vertues of bodẏe and soule God clothed him. And whenne this Henrẏ, that is called the secunde, hadde gete the regne, he sewed the ma∣ners and dedes of Henry the ferst. ¶ In the iiide. yer [of his reign] in Septembre was bore to the kyng a sone, cle∣ped Richarde, atte Oxen∣forde, in his manoire, wher is now the White freres. ¶ In the vi. ẏer Matheu,¶ An ab∣besse i wedded. the Erle's sone of Flaundres, as ẏenst the vs of Christene Peple, wedded the abbesse of Romesey in Engelond, with whiche he hadde the Erle∣dom of Boloẏne. ¶ In the xe. ẏere of kyng Henrẏ he dude halwe the churche of Redẏng bẏ Thomas Erche∣bisshop. ¶ In the. xiii ẏere quene Alionore, passyng oute of Normandie into Engelond, childed a sone atte Oxenforde,¶ Kyng Johan's berthe Ml. c. lxvio. in the kynge's maner, that was cleped Johan, in the Cristesmasse ene. In whiche enetid appered in the West. ii. sterres of fuẏrẏ colour, on lite that other gret, and bẏ gonne to goo to geders, and sone after departed a twoo. And hit is to vnderstonde, that ther the kynge's maner was, hit is now the White Freours. ¶ The xvii. yere of the kyng Henry, Henry, bisshop of Wẏnchestre, and abbot of Glastenbury, kyng Stephne's brother, deide, whiche blynde to for his dethe lafte manẏ preciouse orna∣mentes to the Churche of Seẏnt Swẏthẏnne's. ¶ In þe ẏere of oure Lorde Ml. co. xx iiiivo. Sir John Courcẏ, that me seide was kyng Jone's sone bastard, and i norsshed atte the Prioury of Stogurcẏ in Somersetshire in ẏouthe, was made Erle of Ulnester in Irlond, the ferst of En∣glẏsshtong. and after him the kẏnrede of the Burghes, that bere the armes of goules with a white Croẏs. Of the sto∣rẏes of the lordes of this Ulster in the countre maẏ me rede manẏ dyuers thinges, ¶ In the xxxiii. ẏere Balde∣wẏne, Erehebishop of Caun∣terburẏ, was forbede bẏ the Pope's lettres to cesse of the buldẏng of a newe chaunte∣rẏe, atte Lambehithe, bẏgonne bẏ him. is dozter Elianore, as ze solle her after ihure.
Richard, king Henrie's sone, to Engelonde com,
And, after is fader dethe, aueng the kinedom.
The verthe day of Septembre, he let him crouny iwis
At Westmunstre hasteliche, as the rizte crouninge is,
Of the erchebissop of Kanterbury, Baldewine that was tho,
In a Sonen day as it vel, Gywes to muche wo.
Vor among alle the noble, that to suiche feste drowe,
Of erles & of barons, & of othere heye men inowe,
And of noble presauns, that ther come also,
The wrecche luther Giwes wende wel to do.
& a riche presant zarkede with gret prute,
& sende this noble kinge, ac hor thonc was lute.
Vor the king was somdel awlated, & to gret despit it nom,
That fram so vnclene thinges eni mete him com,
& het it do out of is court, & the wrecches ssame do.
Ther was mani a wilde hine, that prest was ther to,
& wende in to the Gywerie, & woundede & to drowe,
& robbede & barnde hous, & manie of hom slowe.
Ac sone in thulke sulue zer in to this kinedom
Hunger & deiinge of men, & muche wrechede com.
Richard tho he was king, & zef his brother Jon
The erldom of Gloucestre, & let him spousy anon
Isabel, that was eir, & grete londes ther to
Zef him here in Engelond, & bizonde se al so.
Ther was tho in the holi lond a strong bataile ido,
Bituene the luther Saladin & Cristine men al so,
A Sein Leonarde's eue. in the zer of grace y wis
Endleue hundred & ninty ydo was al this.
The maister of the temple was a slawe, & Sir Willa de Breus also,
& Sire Ingerard de Fenes, & other Cristine ther to.
Saladine's eldoste sone, than het Mirasalim,
Islawe was, & is neueu, that het Goekedin.
& Migenal is Mareschal, & no noumbre nas
Of Cristin folc & hethene, that there aslawe was.
Me prechede of the croyserye wide, ich vnderstonde,
& the bissop Willam of Ely here in Engelonde.
King Richard him zarkede to the holi lond to wende,
& bi tok the bissop of Ely this lond in ech ende
To wardi, vor he trewe was. & the erchebissop al so
Baldewine of Canterburi, & mani wende ther to.
As Roberd erl of Leicetre, the erl Willam de Ferers,
Sir Richard de Glanuille, & mani othere heye & fers:
The aumperour Frederic, & the king Philip of France,
Alle hii wende to Jerusalem, to do gode chaunce.
Endleue hundred zer of grace, & ninti & on,
Hii wende to the holi lond, this noblemen ech on.
Som of king Richarde's folc to the lond of Cypre com,
& the prince of the lond anon hom vaste nom,
& in strong prison hem caste, & king Richard, as man wod,
Tho he it wuste, wende thuder mid wel stourdi mod.
To the hauene al bi watere he com mid poer god.
The prince mid al is poer vaste azen him stod,
& nolde nozt deliuery the men that were inome.
The bataile was sone ido, and the prince ouer come.
The noble man king Richard sturede him ther so vaste,
& the mare of hor rugge with kene suerd agaste.
So that al out the lond he wan atte laste.
Some he slou, & some of hom in strong prison he caste.
So he dude thulke time, as ich vnderstonde,
The Cipre is euereft iholde of the king of Engelonde.
Gode wardeins he sette, vor to wite thut lond,
& adde at is owe wille al Cipre in his hond.
& the prince he nom with him, ibounde vet & honde
With veteres of siluer, toward the holi londe.
So that to Sir Philip, king of France, hii come,
&, as stalwarde noble men, the toun of Acres nome,
King Richard & king Philip, vpe the hethene men there.
Mani was the gode dunt that king Richard zaf er.
Endleue hundred zer of grace & ninti & to
King Richard this noble knizt Acres nom so,
& harlede so the Sarazins, in eche side aboute,
That the ssrewen ne dorste in non ende at route.
So that king Philip was annyd thor alle thing,
That ther nas of him word non, bote al of Richard the king.
Vaste he let trossi, to France uor to drawe.
Sori was the king Richard, to lese his felawe.
He bed him zerne vor to a bide, thoru him al to do.
Ac the other nolde vor no thing, ac to Fraunce wende so.
King Richard bileuede ther, & so nobliche he wrozte,
That al thut lond ther a boute in is poer he brozte.
Me nuste longe ther biuore, neuer eft in hethenesse,
Of so noble knizt ne prince, ne do so muche prowesse.
Me ne mai nozt al telle her, ac wo so it wole iwite,

Narratio autem dicta, rhythmica est (carminibus ta∣men brevioribus quam Ro∣berti nostri) curaque nostra impraesentiarum indigna. prae∣cipue quum & jam olim (quem∣admodum bene memini) ty∣pis excusa prodierit. of him imad me it may finde iwrite.
So that the Deuel adde ther to gret envie,
& in is brother herte Jon brozte an tricherie.
Vor he esste of heye men of this lond sikernesse ilome,
& homage to be king, bote is brother aze come.
The bissop of Eli, that this lond adde to loke,
& the triwe men of the lond vaste it vorsoke,
& sede, that Arthure of Brutaine, is eldore brother sone,
Kundere eir was than he bi pur lawe & wone.
The erl Jon worrede vpen hom, that azen hom were out,
He wuste, that the king of France ne louede is brother nozt.
Theruore he wende ouer se, & is man he bi com,
To helpe him azen is brother, to winne the kinedom.
So that the king & he king Richarde's lond
Destruede vaste in Normandie, & here in Engelond.
This word com to king Richard in Sirie as he was.
He suor he wolde awreke be of this vil trespas.
He beleuede is noble dede of the holi lond, alas!
& triwes nom of Saladin, vor this luther cas.

Romaynes the kyuge Henry's brother, the iiii: Nonas of Aprille atte castelle of Berkhamstede wente the waẏ of alle flesshe, whas hert was buried in the churche of Frere Menours atte Oxen∣forde, his bodẏ was buried in the abbeẏ of monekes of the ordre of Cisteaux atte Haẏles, whiche he hadde founded, and atte his awne cost i maked. The same ẏere the citezeynes of Norwiche rise a yenste the Priorie of monekes, so that they brent the churche cathedralle, vp whiche the kyng was a gre∣ued, and, in veniaunce of the mẏsdoers, he sente thedur a knẏghte Justice, i cleped Thomas Treuet, whiche was Justice of heire of the Croune. So that mẏche Peple, con∣uicte of that trespasses, were drawe at hors taille, and hanged. This Treuete's sone made Cronicles, -i cleped Triuete's Cronicles, of whiche manẏ thẏnges of thes Cronicles [i. e. of the prose Part, for Robert of Glouce∣ster himself was dead before Trivet flourished] beth i drawe oute of Henrẏ kyng of Engelond, corrupte with sekenesse, in the moneth of Nouember, a Seynt Edmunde the Erchebisshoppe's day, deẏde, and on the daẏ of Seynt Edmunde, kyng and martir, his body was buri∣ed atte Westmynster. This kyug as in worldeliche do∣ẏng was nat holde fulle wẏse, but more deuoute to spiri∣tualle thinges. Euery day commenliche he was woned to hure iii. masses bẏ note, and at other priuee masses never the later ẏut wolde he be busiliche. And so happed hit in a tyme, that Seẏnt Lowiz, kyng of Fraunce, spekyng with him of his do∣ẏng, a monge other thẏnges, seide, that nat alweẏ so to masses, but more busiliche to predicacions he shulde busie hẏm. And he curteẏsliche an∣swerẏng seyde, that him was lyuere ofte to see his frende, thenne ofte, theẏ hit were gode thynges, hue spekc of hẏm. This kyng was but of mene stature. his other eẏe lede hangyd so mẏche a doun, that hit heled half the blake of his eẏe. strong of strengthe, but fallẏng & vnwẏs in his doẏnges, in whiche, neuer∣theles, for hadde selby and faire endes, me troweth he was the lẏnx al þyng thurl∣yng, of which Merlyne me∣neth of.
